abstract: The Cartmen of this City have proposed to form themselves into a society to be called the United Cartmen's Protective Association. Its objects are to protect against hostile influences, and to elevate as a class, the Cartmen of the City of New-York.
lead_paragraph: The Cartmen of this City have proposed to form themselves into a society to be called the United Cartmen's Protective Association. Its objects are to protect against hostile influences, and to elevate as a class, the Cartmen of the City of New-York. A meeting of those friendly to the objects of the Association was held last evening in Convention Hall, Wooster-street, at which some two hundred persons were present. Mr. ABRAHAM E. DAYTON, the President, called the meeting to order. He said they, no doubt, had seen it stated in the newspapers that Hon. FERNANDO WOOD had consented to address them that evening. They had organized simply to promote the interests of the Cartmen, and they invited all that class of persons to join them in carrying out the objects of their Association. An Ode was then sung to the tune of the "Star Spangled Banner."

abstract: On the 31st January, a Contract of Transit from the Atlantic to the Pacific, over the territory of Nicaragua, was signed at Granada, between Capt. GEO. F. CAUTY, acting as agent for the British Navigation and Transit Company, and Senors FERNANDO GUZMAN and FULGENCIO VEGA, Commissioners appointed by the Government of Nicaragua. The contract is drawn for a period of forty years, with the privilege of renewal for fifty-nine years more, at the option of the Nicaraguan Government.

abstract: The seventh annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday P.M., in the Directors' room of the Metropolitan Bank. In the absence of the President, J.E. WILLIAMS, Esq., was called to the chair. The annual reports of the Secretary and Treasurer were presented, abstracts of which will be found below. A communication was received from ...
lead_paragraph: The seventh annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday P.M., in the Directors' room of the Metropolitan Bank. In the absence of the President, J.E. WILLIAMS, Esq., was called to the chair. The annual reports of the Secretary and Treasurer were presented, abstracts of which will be found below. A communication was received from ARCHIBALD RUSSELL, one of the Trustees, declining a reelection, on account of a press of other duties. The meeting then went into an election of Trustees for the ensuing year, with the following result: John L. Mason. James R. Spalding, Robert J. Livingston, WM. L. King, Charles L. Brace.

abstract: LECTURE BY MR. WH. CURTIS NOYES.--Mr. NOYES del vered his second lecture to the students of Columbia College Law School and a crowded audidience, upon "Criminal Jurisprudence in America before the Revolution," on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: LECTURE BY MR. WH. CURTIS NOYES.--Mr. NOYES del vered his second lecture to the students of Columbia College Law School and a crowded audidience, upon "Criminal Jurisprudence in America before the Revolution," on Tuesday evening. The lecture was mainly devoted to the State of the [???] law in England before our Revolution, and the principles of law which the Colonists brought with them. After giving a sketch of the early writ of habeas corpus and the act of CHARLES II., he proceeded to speak of the writ "de homino replegiando," or the writ for replevying a man. This was in the nature of a private writ, and was applicable when an individual was illegally imprisoned by a private person, while habeas corpus properly appertained to an unlawful imprisonment by public authority. The question whether a man was a slave, could be tried by a jury through the medium of this writ. A husband could also in this way claim the custody of his wife. The lecture spoke of a case in his own early practice, in which he had successfully used the writ for this purpose. The proceeding was very dilatory and technical. This remedy still exists in New-York, not having been abolished by the Code. This was originally the only mode of determining the question of Freedom and Slavery, and as such is to be held in grateful remembrance, as in some of the counties of England there were only three or four hundred free-men to forty or fifty thousand slaves. The Bill of Rights of 1688 was next noticed, and the fact that Massachusetts had secured a Bill of Rights forty years before, though not so full as the English Statute of William and Mary. The Colony bad the benefit of both. Trial by jury was spoken of, and the fines arbitrarily imposed by the judge upon jurymen for bringing in a verdict in accordance with their convictions. BUSHELL's case, reported in Vaughan's Reports and else where, established the rule that this practice was illegal and contrary to the fundamental law of England. The right to give a general verdict in criminal cases was established in 32d year of George III., chap. 60. Torture was unknown to the common or statute law of England, but existed in Scotland and other countries governed by the civil law till 150 years ago. The guillotine was in use in Scotland long before it was in France, under the seductive name of the Scottish maiden. It was fortunate for us that the law of Scotland was not brought to America. But something akin to torture prevailed in the common law, in order to extract a plea of guilty or not guilty when a prisoner was mute, (peine forte et dure.) This horrible punishment, which was graphically described, was inflicted in .Massachusetts, in the case of GILES COREY, a man of 80 years of age, tried for witchcraft. The Massachusetts Sheriff is said to have treated the prisoner most barbarously. This is believed to have been the only case in which this punishment was inflicted in America. New-York had the honor of establishing the humane rule, in 1788, that muteness was to be regarded as a plea of not guilty, while in England the rule was adopted in 1772, that muteness was equivalent to a plea of guilty. Peine forte et dure was not formally abolished in England till 1828. This lecture was evidently listened to by the audience with great gratification. The course is to be continued.

abstract: "One of the most interesting foreigners now residing in Tuscany is Walter Savage Landor. Although past eighty-six, he seems vigorous still, conversing in his own eloquent way of times past and gone, when he was young. To hear him describe the first Napoleon ...
lead_paragraph: "One of the most interesting foreigners now residing in Tuscany is Walter Savage Landor. Although past eighty-six, he seems vigorous still, conversing in his own eloquent way of times past and gone, when he was young. To hear him describe the first Napoleon as he has seen him in his youth, with a face 'round and olive, like that of a Greek girl,' and to see him stand before his exquisite portrait of Petrarch's Laura, discoursing all the while, as one would suppose the author of Imaginary Conversations ought to discourse, on such a subject, you will allow must hare been a great treat. The old man, with silver beard and hair, looks like one of the grand portraits he has always loved to see on his walls. I found him sitting at his writing table to-day before a splendid 'Salvator Rosa.' His collection of pictures was made with brains that knew how to choose from the world's treasury of art. Among his gems there hangs an Allori worthy to be set in gold. He is at present living in Florence, with comparatively few pictures about him, but at his villa near the city there are three or four hundred fine things, the collection of a long lifetime. You should hear him talk of Washington, whom, of all the sons of men that ever lived, he ranks first. Schlegel, whom he knew intimately, and of whom he tells capital stories, he places very high as a critic, giving him almost the highest niche as a commentator. He misses very much his dear old friend John kenyon, whom he loved and by whom he was beloved greatly. Mr. and Mrs. Browning are his constant correspondents from Rome, where they are spending the Winter. The world has not forgotten him, by any means, and one of the greatest privileges accorded to lovers of genius, as you may well suppose, is a visit to the sunny chambers of Walter Savage Landor."

abstract: We publish in a SUPPLEMENT to this morning's TIMES a full report of the speech made in the Senate yesterday by Mr. SEWARD. It will be eagerly read by men of all parties and in all sections of the Union. Mr. SEWARD is unquestionably ...
lead_paragraph: We publish in a SUPPLEMENT to this morning's TIMES a full report of the speech made in the Senate yesterday by Mr. SEWARD. It will be eagerly read by men of all parties and in all sections of the Union. Mr. SEWARD is unquestionably The most prominent and influential public man of the day: -- and in the present crisis of public affairs, anything he may say on topics of national concern is sure to be read with avidity, -- not only for the general principles it may embody, but on account of its bearing upon the political contests of the hour. Mr. SEWARD, it will be seen, has addressed himself directly to the point of most general interest, -- namely, the controversy carried on between the Democratic and Republican parties. His speech is a philosophical exposition of the real nature of that controversy, and aims mainly at dissipating the false impressions which misunderstanding on the one hand, and misrepresentation on the other, have created in regard to it. Its tone is eminently dispassionate and statesmanlike, and indicates a desire to allay agitation and remove unfounded prejudice from the public mind, rather than to stimulate the zeal or arouse the enthusiasm of partisan followers.

abstract: THE CASE OF DR. FARRAN. -- In the case of Dr.FARRAN, who has been on trial at Dover, N.H. charged with having kidnapped the child GILETT[???] FARRAN from her mother in October last, the jury on Saturday brought in a verdict of guilty without leaving their seats. This was done by consent of the parties interested, and the case will now go to the full bench of the Court on a question of law. If this rulings already made in the case be sustained, it only remains for FARRAN to be sentenced.

abstract: The galleries of the Senate chamber were yesterday thronged with eager-eyed expectants of the speech which Mr. SEWARD was to pronounce upon the great issues of the day. When the special order, the Kansas Admission Bill, came up, Mr. SEWARD arose and having presented a memorial of the Kansas Legislature demanding admission, proceeded to speak on the general subject of Slavery, and its place in politics.
lead_paragraph: The galleries of the Senate chamber were yesterday thronged with eager-eyed expectants of the speech which Mr. SEWARD was to pronounce upon the great issues of the day. When the special order, the Kansas Admission Bill, came up, Mr. SEWARD arose and having presented a memorial of the Kansas Legislature demanding admission, proceeded to speak on the general subject of Slavery, and its place in politics. Having reviewed the history of the question, as a conflict between Southern capital and Northern labor, he referred to the coming Presidential campaign and to the Republicans holding to the principle of preventing the, Territories, by constitutional means, from becoming houses for Slavery and Polygamy. He said the policy of the Republican Party was to stand by the freedom of speech and of the Press, the speedy improvement of the public domain by homestead laws, and to encourage mining, manufactures and internal commerce, with needful connections between the Atlantic and Pacific States. He alluded to the fact that many Southern men are not willing to see the inauguration of a Republican President because it is a sectional party, and passed on to prove that the Republican is not a sectional organization. He asked, is it easier for us to bear your sway than for you to bear ours? Is it unreasonable that for once we should alternate? He said the real principles of the Republican Party were national. He was no assailant of States. It was well and wisely arranged that the states were sovereign on the subject of Slavery within their own borders. He said JOHN BROWN and his associates acted on earnest, though fatally erroneous convictions. He pronounced the act an act of sedition and treason, and criminal to just the extent that it affected the public peace and was destructive of human life. He did not think anything serious would grow out of the oft-repeated threats to dissolve the Union. After Mr. SEWARD's speech had closed, there was a long debate, in which Messrs. DOUGLAS, DAVIS, TRUMBULL, DOOLITTLE and WIGFALL participated, when the subject was postponed till Monday. In the House, Mr. RUFFIN having succeeded in causing the journal of Monday to be amended, by the insertion of his vote for Mr. GLOSSBRENNER as Printer, the Speaker declared the election of Mr. FORD invalid; and an attempt of the Republicans to postpone action for the present failing, another vote was taken without result, and the subject laid aside. There was an immediate fight of members to the Senate Chamber, to hear the Senator from New-York. The remnant, twelve in number, was edified by a discourse from Mr. REAGAN, of Texas, in defence of Southern institutions.

abstract: Either in the Oyer and Terminer, or in the General Sessions, since the commencement of the year, criminals, for various offences and grades of offences, have been daily tried, and during most of this time these two Courts have been in joint session, Judge INGRAHAM presiding in the one, and Recorder BARNARD in the other; yet batch after batch of fresh indictments continue to pour in from the Grand Jury, and, although the Recorder is now holding an "extra session," there are over fifty prisoners waiting to be tried.

abstract: ARREST OF A BOSTON BROKER FOR VENDING BAD MONEY. -- The Boston Traveller, 27th, says: "Information having been received at the office of the Chief of Police leading to the belief that Mr. ALONZO P.BURRILL, at No. 16 State-street, was dealing largely in bad money, Officers HOMMES and WRIGHT of the detective force visited the place this morning, and found twenty counterfeit bills, amounting in all to $183, and 122 worthless bills, amounting to $l83. He will be taken before the Police Court this afternoon on charges of having this money in his possession; with intention to dispose of the same. It is believed that he has been in the habit of selling this money at 50 per cent, of the face of the bills, and the police have some evidence on this point, which they with introduce when the case comes before the Court. A few days since a young man was detected in passing counterfeit $20 bill, who stated that he obtained it of BURRILL, and since that time another party has obtained a counterfeit bill of him upon the terms stated above. BURRILL is about 26 or 27 years of age, and resides in Chelsea, and he has respectable connection in this city. He is not inclined to say much about the found in his possession, which are upon a very large number of banks."

abstract: The Pope is a two-fold debtor to the French Emperor. At Rome his throne is supported by French arms; in the Orient his spiritual dominion is being extended by French policy.
lead_paragraph: The Pope is a two-fold debtor to the French Emperor. At Rome his throne is supported by French arms; in the Orient his spiritual dominion is being extended by French policy. Before the Crimean war Russia was the Christian Power whose influence most preponderated in the Ottoman Empire, but her defeats and disasters in that war having destroyed her prestige, a way was prepared for the Third NAPOLEON to establish French influence in its stead, and how effectually he has succeeded in the accomplishment of this object, let passing events demonstrate.

abstract: Hiram Anderson vs. James Kearny and Robert G. Gregg, -- This was an application on behalf of the plaintiff for an order of injunction against the defendants -- he alleging that they had appropriated to their use and benefit his sign, the No. 99 Bowery. The affidavits of the plaintiff set forth that for eighteen years he had been selling carpets at this number on the Bowery, and that by a large expenditure of money he had established a reputation in his business at that place. It was then set forth that the defendants, in October last, began the sale of carpetings at No. 107 Bowery, and that they put up a sign with the figures "99" thereon, from twelve to fifteen inches in length, with the word "cents" under it in diminutive letters. This, the plaintiffs alleged, was an intended fraud upon him, and averred that he had already lost $5,000 by that means. The affidavits of a number of other persons set forth the same facts. Upon these affidavits Justice MONCRIEF, of the Superior Court, granted an injunction enjoining the defendants from a further use of this street number of the plaintiff.

abstract: It will be remembered that a quantity of valuable diamonds were several months since seized by U. S. Marshal Rynders and Surveyor Hart, which were found in the possession of two Spaniards, who had brought them from Europe in a Cunard steamer with the intention of evading the revenue laws.
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that a quantity of valuable diamonds were several months since seized by U. S. Marshal Rynders and Surveyor Hart, which were found in the possession of two Spaniards, who had brought them from Europe in a Cunard steamer with the intention of evading the revenue laws. These precious stones, pending legal proceedings in the matter, were placed in the public store No. 12 Broad-street, kept by McIntyre & Bixbie. Recently the diamonds were wanted, but a search for them resulted in showing that the entire package had been abstracted. Suspicion was at once cast upon Michael Murphy, foreman of the laborers employed at the store, who had not been seen for a day or two. A warrant was issued for his arrest, when a search resulted in discovering that he had disposed of his property, and fled from the City. The supposition is that Murphy has taken passage for England. The alleged delinquent has been long a resident in the Fifth Ward, where he took an active part in politics, and was well known. His position as foreman in the public store, it is said, was very lucrative, and much surprise is expressed that he should have committed the larceny. It is hardly possible that he will escape arrest.

abstract: We are requested to mention that the statement of our Washington correspondent "Q.," that the Seventh Regiment expressed its dissatisfaction with its treatment at the National Capital, by giving groans for Washington, in leaving there, was an error. Probably our correspondent mistook for groans a peculiar mode of salutation, in vogue with the members of the Regiment, called the "Richmond cheer." The correction, embodied in an account -- from another correspondent who left Washington with the Regiment -- of the journey homeward, has been crowded out from day to day, by the press of news arriving with the foreign mails.

abstract: It is indeed deplorable that Ex-Lieut.-Gov. FORD, so fairly elected printer to the House of Representatives, has been unseated and sent about his business by that merciless RUFFIN Of the Carolinas. Not that we have any special ...
lead_paragraph: It is indeed deplorable that Ex-Lieut.-Gov. FORD, so fairly elected printer to the House of Representatives, has been unseated and sent about his business by that merciless RUFFIN Of the Carolinas. Not that we have any special interest in the baffled man; but then his transient success terminated, as it seemed, a condition of affairs in the House which no rightly-judging man can desire to see renewed. The name of that audacious individual who so far forgot the loyal respect due to national legislators as to christen Congress a bear-garden, has escaped us. But whatever claims he may have had to greatness in other respects, that he well knew how to appreciate the propriety of epithets has often been demonstrated by the acts of Congressmen, and in a special manner by this growling fight over the printer. No political principles are at stake in the choice; it is solely a strife for spoils, and the eagerness of each party to secure the loaf for itself, has begotten a paltry squabble, in which various members, we grieve to say, forget that they are elected to forward the interests of the public, and seem bent only on securing the public plunder for their own party. So dominant were the selfish passions, that even when the contest was apparently ended, it was difficult for some time to proceed with important business, on account of personal bickerings and fretful complaints at newspaper paragraphs. If VAN AMBURGH's collection is noisy and full of fight, it is -- with the occasional exception of the elephant, ultra for the abolition of his own confinement -- properly restrained. In the national bear-garden, however, all restraints and checks of animal ferocity are scouted, and the proposition presented by a member from this State, to provide for the better protection of personal safety in the District of Columbia, is ignored without a hearing, though the necessity of its adoption was probably corroborated by the tell-tale revolvers peering from the numerous Representative pockets. The truth is, the real quadrupedal bears would doubtless enjoy the sympathy of the public in an attempt to imitate their biped types so far as to "rise to a question of privilege," and utter with ursine fervor their protest against a comparison which likens them to fellow-creatures which no muzzle can restrain from mischief save that of a Colt or Derringer. Let us unite in craving an early close to this pitiful but mischievous contest.

abstract: A CHURCH BLOWN DOWN IN TIME OF SERVICE. -- The Massillon, Ohio, Journal, says that during the gale of the 22d, the gable end of the Lutheran Church at West Brookfield, O., was forced in and the roof carried off. At the time a service was being held, the congregation numbering between three and four hundred. Fifteen persons were injured, four having fractured limbs. Great excitement and consternation prevailed, and the number of the wounded is considered very small in view of the circumstances under which the disaster occurred.
lead_paragraph: A CHURCH BLOWN DOWN IN TIME OF SERVICE. -- The Massillon, Ohio, Journal, says that during the gale of the 22d, the gable end of the Lutheran Church at West Brookfield, O., was forced in and the roof carried off. abstract: JOHN LYLY, writing the epistle dedicatory to his famous Euphues, nearly three hundred years ago, said, "It is a world to see howe Englishmen desire to heare finer speech than theyr language will allow," adding, as If conscious of the sins of extravagance in phraseology into which an attempt to gratify that desire had led him, "but I let passe theyr finenesse, which can no way excuse my folly." It is, perhaps, with the intention of conveying a like reproach that the author of this volume has placed upon his title-page the motto "What! crave ye wine, and have Nilus to drink of ?" Be this as it may, the one great result, if not the main purpose of his work, is the showing how great is the wealth, the strength, and the beauty of the English language in its purity. In the introductory lecture, indeed, he speaks of the series as but preparatory to a course upon the English tongue. But the course so prepared would be a complete, systematic and profound examination of the entire field of English philology, which, comparatively underworked as it yet is, stretches out too broadly and lies too far away from the beaten track of daily life for a man so well acquainted with the world as Mr. MARSH, to seek companions in it, except among the few who, like himself, have the taste, the learning, and the opportunity for its cultivation. These lectures are addressed, and we add at once, well adapted to the many. Not the foolish and the idle many, but the intelligent and the thoughtful, who, however small their comparative numbers must ever be, form in this country, we are happy to believe, a larger proportion of the whole public than in any other. To the people of such a country the study of its language, for the purpose of acquiring the fullest comprehension of its genius and its capacity, would seem to have peculiar attractions. Indeed, it appears almost a necessity, while we continue to assume the varied functions which Mr. MARSH, with that sly humor which occasionally enlivens his page, attributes to us. "Every man among us," he says, "is a divine, a statesman, a physician and a lawyer to himself, as well as a counselor to his neighbors, on all the interests involved in the sciences appropriately belonging to those professions: We all read books, magazines, newspapers; all attend learned lectures; and too many of us, indeed, write the one and deliver the other." Among the too many of us who are thus superfluous, however, the most jealous criticism could not place Mr. MARSH; for we do not remember to have read a work of this kind which conveyed more unmistakeably the impression, not only of the entire competence of its author, but of his possession of a rich reserved fund of knowledge and of intellectual resource. How few men now-a days write a book into which they do not appear to have put all they know, to the last scrap, upon its subject! -- to say nothing of somewhat that they do not know.

abstract: Pioneers have occasion every day to complain tha "California is getting old prematurely," that  every day this virgin land verges more and more into the stale and stupid ways of the East. Prices drop down to the New York standard-our customs are conforming to the habits of countries that are moss bound and done growing. Even with our sports modern civilization threatens to interfere. abstract: The "Royal Government" of Tuscany, as the present provisional organization calls itself, has indeed a difficult path before as well as behind it. abstract: For some time past the poor unfortunates confined in the Lunatic Asylum on Blackwell's Island have been very often cooped up in miserably narrow apartments, sometimes two and three together. This was owing to the large increase in the number of patients, for all of whom there was not sufficient room. The facts were duly presented to the Board of Governors, who, after the usual delays in that circumlocutional establishment, determined to remedy the matter. Accordingly $30,000 were appropriated for the purpose of building a new wing to the asylum, with sufficient room to comfortably accommodate two or three hundred more inmates, and proposals were advertised for. On Tuesday evening the Board appointed Supervisor THOS. LITTLE Architect and Superintendent of the work, which will be immediately commenced. A great portion of the stone necessary will be taken from the Island quarries, and much of the labor furnished by the occupants of the various institutions. It is thought that the expense of the whole work will not fall short of $50,000, or $20,000 in excess of the appropriation.

abstract: The commercial policy of taxing our railways to support our canals, has been sufficiently illuminated to convince any reasonable being that its immediate results will be commercially disastrous. But there is another department ...
lead_paragraph: The commercial policy of taxing our railways to support our canals, has been sufficiently illuminated to convince any reasonable being that its immediate results will be commercially disastrous. But there is another department of the subject, circumscribed by no local and temporary issues, but reaching far into the future as a positive cause of respective degeneracy and reform in the usefulness and economy of canals and railways. It is probable that the public, after punishing itself long enough by paying the unnecessary expenses of working and repairing these internal improvements, will reform them both. A more speedy and straightforward method than that likely to result from the Pro Rata scheme would, however, be desirable.

abstract: -- Mr. SHERMAN's bee-line Mileage bill, mentioned in the late Congressional proceedings, met, as might have been predicted, with the disapprobation of many who love, not their country less, but money more. Mr. Congressman, no doubt, finds it quite delightful, once or twice a year, to take a trip across, or even around, the country, accompanied by Mrs. Congressman and the little "members," all at the public expense. Very pleasant it must be to the zealous patriot, who sacrifices himself on the altar of his country's service -- service unrewarded, too, except by the trifling bagatelle of three thousand dollars a year -- to retire to his pillow in Washington, after the expiration of one session, and waking up the next morning to another, to find that, by an interesting fiction of constructive mileage, he has during the night been spirited, by Ben Hassan's Genii express, across the Continent to his home and back again, without jar or jolt. His admiration for the arrangement is of course increased when he learns that his entire family have accompanied him unconsciously on this quiet nocturnal journey. Very fine this may be for Mr. Congressman, but a cause of most just complaint on the part of those whose purses provide the lubrication for the wheels of his aerial chariot; who have a right at least to demand inspection of the genii's receipt before they pay for the chimerical excursion. Some of the most honorable names that have been connected with our national legislature in years gone by have conscientiously refused to join in such plunder of the treasury. And it is a cause of congratulation, that the spirit of these patriots has descended to so many on whom their official mantle has fallen, that Mr. SHERMAN's economical measure finds abundant support, and even adoption.

abstract: The change of time for holding the Republican National Convention will have the effect, if not of reducing the number of candidates, of checking the zeal and obstinacy with which they will be pressed. Nearly every State has a favorite already in the field, and the lapse of so long an interval before the meeting of the Convention would tend naturally to strengthen the confidence of each in the success of its own candidate. The Convention is now summoned for the 16th of May, which leaves some ten weeks still for preliminary discussion.

abstract: The Opposition Stale Convention of Kentucky, which was in session at Frankfort last week, adopted a platform denouncing the House of Representatives and the National Administration, and urging the necessity of the organization of a National Union Party.
lead_paragraph: The Opposition Stale Convention of Kentucky, which was in session at Frankfort last week, adopted a platform denouncing the House of Representatives and the National Administration, and urging the necessity of the organization of a National Union Party. The resolutions appended to the platform declare the supremacy of the Federal Constitution, the necessity of observing the precepts inculcated in the Farewell Address of WASHINGTON, and of enforcing the Fugitive Slave law. In addition to these, the following were of the resolutions which were unanimously adopted:

abstract: The New-Bedford Standard tells of a young lady, Miss James, residing at Fair Haven, Mass., who was so low with disease of the heart and lungs, that her life was despaired of. She heard that Rev. Joseph K. Bellows, of this City, a Second Advent minister, was in town, and became impressed with the idea that she would recover if he would pray with her.
lead_paragraph: The New-Bedford Standard tells of a young lady, Miss James, residing at Fair Haven, Mass., who was so low with disease of the heart and lungs, that her life was despaired of. She heard that Rev. Joseph K. Bellows, of this City, a Second Advent minister, was in town, and became impressed with the idea that she would recover if he would pray with her. He was called, and the mother of the young lady states that the invalid was as cold and rigid as marble before he began to pray, but that when he had finished, she perspired freely. Miss James describes her sensations during the prayer as similar to those of a person receiving a galvanic shock. That night she passed comfortably, and in the morning she arose and dressed herself without assistance, and on the following Sabbath the attended church. She is now enjoying the best of health, and relishes the heartiest food.

abstract: The steamship Empire City arrived at this port yesterday from New-Orleans and Havana, having left the latter port on the 24th ult. The news from Havana has been mainly anticipated. The Empire City left in port the American steamers Daniel Webster, to sail same day for Aspinwall, and Isabel for Charleston, on the 25th, at 8 A.M. The W.I. mail Steamship Company's steamer Teviot, Capt. GILLIES, last from St. Thomas, left same morning at 7 A.M. for Vera Cruz, reporting the non-arrival at St. Thomas of the steamer Trent from Aspinwall, and four days over due at the former port.

abstract: -- Yesterday's rain did a good deal towards aiding the City Inspector in his efforts to clean the streets. It was rumored during the forenoon that the Common Council had applied for an injunction against the weather, -- to prevent any such outrageous attempts to wash the streets without first securing the assent and approval of the Common Council. A suspension of the rain a little after noon gave plausibility to the report, and a good deal of excitement prevailed for a time. It was subsequently ascertained. however, that the rumor was untrue.

abstract: FLUSHING RAILROAD -- REDUCTION IN FARES. -- Alderman CHARLICK, who for a year past has been the principal proprietor of the Flushing Railroad, has sold out his interest to E.D. LITCHFIELD, Esq. The new proprietor appears to meet with a very favorable reception, and yesterday he responded to the good feeling expressed, and to the wishes of those interested, by making a considerable reduction in the commutation fares, which will doubtless tend to a large increase of travel. The through fare is reduced from $90 to $65 a year, and quarterly and monthly tickets are correspondingly lower. This is an unusual change -- the general rule being to go to higher instead of lower rates.

abstract: "A Layman," in the TIMES of the 22d, has indulged himself in discoursing on the poverty of the country clergy of New-England, and the remedy for such a sad condition. He says they have an "air of poverty," their "homes are uncomfortable," their "children are ill-clad and ill-bred," their "wives pale, weary-looking and hard-worked." The remedy which he proposes for this doleful state of things is CELIBACY.
lead_paragraph: CONNEOTICUT, Friday, Feb. 24, 1860.

abstract: Between 5 and 6, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in an office on the second floor of No.90 Front-street, occupied by Mr. D. GILDERMEISTER. The flames had already made much progress in the interior of the building, and notwithstanding the firemen worked heartily, the entire building and its contents were consumed, but the adjoining warehouse escaped material injury. The warehouse was owned by Messrs. Ross W. WOOD & SON who had it insured for $7000 in the Hope Insurance Company, that amount being but $500 less than its estimated value.

abstract: Our correspondents with the United States Squadron on the African coast furnish us highly interesting details regarding the present condition of the Slave-trade. The advices extend to Dec. 20. It is stated in the most positive terms that the vessels now engaged on the African coast, in this piratical traffic, may be numbered by dozens, and that the larger part of them are owned by Americans, and have regular Custom-house clearances from this port.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondents with the United States Squadron on the African coast furnish us highly interesting details regarding the present condition of the Slave-trade. The advices extend to Dec. 20. It is stated in the most positive terms that the vessels now engaged on the African coast, in this piratical traffic, may be numbered by dozens, and that the larger part of them are owned by Americans, and have regular Custom-house clearances from this port. The captains of many of these craft claim to be engaged in the palm oil trade, out this pretext, our correspondents claim, is a transparent rent subterfuge, as the vessels have not the equipments necessary to carry on this traffic,nor is the oil for which they allege they come to the coast produced in sufficient quantities to furnish cargoes for a small fraction of the fleet which pretends to be waiting for it. To establish these facts we have full details of the recent seizures of the Tavernier, Orion and Bell. It is represented that if Our Government sincerely desire to suppress the business, numerous steamers of light draught should be placed on the coast, and that Congress should pass laws limititing the number of water-casks and rice bags which these vessels may carry.

abstract: Sir WILLIAM NAPIER, K.C.B., whose death is announced by the Edinburgh, was born at Castletown, in Ireland, in 1785. His father was Colonel the Honorable GEORGE NAPIER, and his mother the celebrated SARAH LENNOX, daughter of the second Duke of RICHMOND. When but fifteen years of age, Sir WILLIAM entered the army. He served at the siege of Copenhagen, followed Sir JOHN MOORE to the Spanish Peninsula in 1808, and was in command of the Forty-third Regiment at Salamanca, Neville, and Nice. The wounds which he received in the battles in which he was engaged, were emphatic proof of his daring and bravery as a soldier. For six years, from 1842 to 1848, when he was created a Military Knight, and became Colonel of the Twenty-seventh Regiment, Sir WILLIAM was Governor of Guernsey. In 1851 he was advanced to the rank of Lieutenant-General. The intervals of leisure which he enjoyed were devoted to recording the history of the wars in which he had taken part. To his pen we are indebted for the "History of the War in the Peninsula and in the South of France, from the year 1807 to 1814." The publication of this work, which consists of six volumes, was commenced in 1828. Among his other, but less formidable works, are "The Conquest of Scinde," "Life and Opinions of Sir Charles Napier," and "English Battles and Sieges in the Peninsula," the last of which was published in 1855, and comprises much of the matter embraced in his first historical work. Besides treating of these heavier themes, Sir WILLIAM's pen found relaxation in the composition of various reviews, and one or two works of fiction. Sir CHARLES NAPIER, the Conqueror of Scinde, was a brother of the Historian.

abstract: COMMENCEMENT OF THE NEW-YORK MEDICAL COLLEGE.--The Eighth Annual Commencement of the New-York Medical College was held in the lectureroom of the College in Thirteenth-street last evening. A large audience of ladies and gentlemen were in attendance.
lead_paragraph: COMMENCEMENT OF THE NEW-YORK MEDICAL COLLEGE.--The Eighth Annual Commencement of the New-York Medical College was held in the lectureroom of the College in Thirteenth-street last evening. A large audience of ladies and gentlemen were in attendance. PETTER COOPER the Vice-President of the Board of Trustees, presided, supported on either side by the Faculty of the College, and other members of the Board of Trustees. The exercises were opened by prayer from Rev. Dr. GALLAUDET, Rector of St. Anne's Church; after which the President of the Faculty, Dr. HORACE GREEN, conferred the degree of M.D. upon the graduating class, having first administered the customary Hippocratic oath. The class numbered twenty, from seven different States, as follows: New-York -- Lewis V. Beers, Alvin Banister Goodale, Alexander Hutchins, Simeon V. Pilgrim, Henry Wolf Reisberg, Henry M. Smith, Thos. Franklin Smith, Jas. S. Tyier, Thos. H. Whitney, Emil Divix, Robt. K. Tuthill. Maine -- John T.Bates, Daniel C. Marston. Virginia -- Henry R. Darden. Georgia -- Jas. Penfield Wyer. New Hampshire -- Francis L. Town. North Carolina -- Titus Hart. California -- T. Green. Turkey -- Hatchadoor Andonian. Ireland -- Bernard McEntee. Honorary degrees were also conferred upon the following gentlemen: Samuel T. Parker, New-York; Campbell Morfit, New-York; Thomas Garrett, Pennsylvania; Rev. A.G. Shears, Conn. SAMUEL J. TILDEN, Esq., was then introduced, and delivered a valedictory address to the Graduating Class, in which he spoke of the usefulness and dignity of the profession upon which they were about to enter, and counseled assiduous attention to its duties and requirements as the only means of achieving success and distinction. The temptations to the profession man in this country to depart from the legitimate line of his profession, were great, but from a long experience and intimacy with this class, the speaker said he had scarcely ever found a man who regretted the constancy of this devotion to his chosen calling, while he had found many, very many, who mourned their departure from it.

abstract: In the TIMES of Saturday, the 25th, was an article upon Senator BRODERICK, filling nearly three columns. Having known Mr. BRODERICK well during his life in California, and his history previous to going there, I cannot allow so gross an attack to pass without a distinct and unqualified contradiction of most of its material statements and conclusions.

abstract: -- The Edgefield (S.C.) Advertiser announces that the merchants of that village will go to Charleston for their supply of goods for the Spring market. It applauds their spirit and calls on the people to sustain them in thus refusing to patronize New-York. The Charleston merchants will profit by the change in two ways -- by enlarging their home business and by obtaining their supplies in New-York on better terms. The larger their purchases, the cheaper their rates. The only sufferers in the operation will be the village and country customers of the Edgefield merchants, who will, of course, be expected to support their patriotism by paying a small additional profit on their goods.

abstract: -- We receive every day three or four copies of a pamphlet, under the frank of some Member of Congress, which starts off with the startling announcement that "the political aspect of the country fills the public mind with painful apprehension." Suppose it does, what is to be gained by thrusting the fact in our faces half a dozen time a day? We should believe it just as readily upon one assurance as upon twenty. Besides, something of this "painful apprehension" ought to have been allayed by this time. The public mind cannot remain permanently in a state of alarm and excitement any more than the private mind. All such unnatural moods are temporary. They pass away always when the causes of them have disappeared. We do not believe that the assertion is half as true now, therefore, as it was when first made, -- consequently we don't care half as much about it. We hope, at all events, we shall be spared any further shower of pamphlets on the subject.

abstract: There are sundry points connected with the pending controversy between Mr. PILLSBURRY, the Superintendent of Police, and the majority of the Board, which ought not to escape public attention. The integrity and efficiency of the Department are in great danger of being utterly sacrificed to the supposed necessity of political partisanship; and nothing but a rigorous interposition of public sentiment can prevent the consummation of this disastrous result.

abstract: -- The Richmond Enquirer opens the crusade against the admission into the Charleston Convention of the Delegation appointed at Syracuse, and insists that the exclusion of Mayor WOOD's Delegates would "constitute an unwarrantable concession to Free Soil proclivities which would render the Convention a bye-word and reproach among honest men. "The Enquirer adds:

abstract: -- Gen. WALKER is turning his "grey eye" from war to letters. He is engaged in writing a book, and, after the manner of C[???]ESAR, proposes to make it a history of his own exploits. It is announced that he proposes to expound to the world the real purpose of his pertinacious attempts to invade and conquer Nicaragua An extract from the book, which has already seen the light, gives this explanation in a nut-shell. His object was to make Nicaragua a Slave State, outside of the Union. In his judgment the South cannot afford to send their slaves into the new territory, -- and the laws of the Union render it impossible for them to procure fresh supplies by importation; but they could carry on the Slave-trade between the Coast of Africa and Nicaragua, plant that region with Slavery, build up one or more Slave States there, and, when everything was ready for such a result, bring them into the Union. He thinks it a mere waste of time and strength for the South to be discussing her right to take slaves into the new Territories, when in fact she has none to take there. Did the General ever canvass the probability of being able to secure the admission of his new Slave States after he should have formed them? He attributes his failure to the opposition of the Federal Government, -- which is a high compliment to Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. WALKER is turning his "grey eye" from war to letters. He is engaged in writing a book, and, after the manner of C[???]ESAR, proposes to make it a history of his own exploits. He thinks it a mere waste of time and strength for the South to be discussing her right to take slaves into the new Territories, when in fact she has none to take there. Did the General ever canvass the probability of being able to secure the admission of his new Slave States after he should have formed them? He attributes his failure to the opposition of the Federal Government, -- which is a high compliment to Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration.

abstract: -- The well-merited benefit of Miss PATTI is to take place this evening at the Academy of Music. The less substantial rewards of success, the result of brilliant and original talent as an artiste, and of personal popularity, secured by a modesty of carriage notable for one so early triumphant, will scarcely be regarded by the public, and certainly not by herself, as an equivalent for the solid advantages of gold and silver. It is to be trusted that the Barber will welcome a generous houseful to the Academy.

abstract: The supply of car-wheels to railway equipment has become a distinct and extensive branch of the foundry business. Several very large establishments and many smaller ones are constantly employed in this single manufacture.
lead_paragraph: The supply of car-wheels to railway equipment has become a distinct and extensive branch of the foundry business. Several very large establishments and many smaller ones are constantly employed in this single manufacture. iron wheels, such as are almost exclusively used in Europe, are too expensive, according to our railway policy -- a reduction in first cost is the leading consideration. And the flanges of wrought wheels rapidly cut out on our most crooked roads rendering a harder material desirable. Steel tires which are, scientifically considered, the best known as to durability and shape, (roundness,) are very much more expensive -- our roads have not yet found it expedient to introduce them. The improvement we shall describe will furnish many of their advantages at a very cheap rate.

abstract: -- The Edgefield, (S.C.,) Advertiser draws from the failure of Col. MEMMINGER's mission to Virginia, a useful lesson. It hopes that the Legislature will hereafter "do nothing to place South Carolina in the lead of Southern action without the most mature deliberation as to the probable effects of so doing," and suggests that an appeal to the ballot-box should always precede any such action. Three times South Carolina has already attempted to lead off in the Disunion dance, and in every instance has been left to her amusement solitary and alone. She may well hesitate about repeating such mistakes hereafter.
lead_paragraph: -- The Edgefield, (S.C.,) Advertiser draws from the failure of Col. MEMMINGER's mission to Virginia, a useful lesson. abstract: NEW-YORK CRIES.--Among the most noticeable of these to stranger eyes and ears, are the race and habits of the costermongers, that shout through every street and peddle at every corner. A singular race they certainty are, in aims, ingenuity, perseverance and abiquity. They all possess these qualities in common, ...
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK CRIES.--Among the most noticeable of these to stranger eyes and ears, are the race and habits of the costermongers, that shout through every street and peddle at every corner. A singular race they certainty are, in aims, ingenuity, perseverance and abiquity. They all possess these qualities in common, from the little girl in summer, whose [???] compass, ranging from the radical stress on the penult to the final squeal on the ultimate of "red-ish-i-e-i-s," might be the song of a Lind or a Patti -- to the hogshead-sized roar of "Fine Princes' Bay Oysters," that rattle the shutters in narrow streets like a Winter blast. Between the two extremes, the costermongers' cries range in infinite variety, yet always with an element of sameness. All seem charged to the mouth with murderous malice against the purity of the English tongue. True disciples of HORNE TOOKE they are, whose famous answer, to the question how far a man might proceed in murdering the King's English without being hung for treason -- "I don't know; lam trying" -- seems to be the constant guide of their utterance. Oftenest their cry is like the inarticulate bray of beasts, though sometimes it gives utterance to absurdities; as when the newsboy cries -- "STEPHEN A. BRANCH, one saint" -- a character which even the distinguished "martyr" would not claim for himself. And if their cries are varied, the merchandise they vend is more so. In the lower business streets they supply fasting mouths with refreshment, in that great torrid zone of hunger which belts the day between the morning and evening meal that our long drawn out City affords its busy sons. Beneath booths, on sidewalk tables, and from baskets suspended from the neck, every variety of food is catered and prepared, even to the last stage of buttering and sugaring, for the stirring, busy throng. [???]etive New-York can't always stop to eat its lunch, but walks and eats at once. Mingled in monger medley with apple-stands and candy tables, are boxes of stereoscopic views, blank-books, pocket cutlery, and volumes from nobody's "great library," whereof "you may take your choice for fifty cents," and enjoy the pleasing certainty of having bestowed your money in unrequited charity. Taken as a class, street peddlers serve many purposes of use, as well as furnish themes for philosophic speculation on the trading element in the Yankee character.

abstract: The Police Commissioners met once more yesterday in mystic conclave, nobody being absent but their President, Mr. STILLMAN, and the proceedings were opened by Mayor WOOD, who, "in order to test the sense of the Board. moved a reconsideration of the action taken on the 16th January last, which it will be remembered deprived the General Superintendent of the power of assigning, detailing, and transferring policemen."

abstract: On Saturday of next week there will be a grand entertainment in aid of the widow and orphans of Mr. GEORGE WILKINS, formerly an agent connected with the establishment, who, it will be remembered, died suddenly in Boston. All the prominent managers of our City have volunteered their companies for the occasion, and there will be a dramatic matinee of a kind seldom witnessed. In the evening the entertainments are to conclude with a grand conceit, at which some of the most distinguished vocal and instrumental artists now in the country promise to assist. The kindly object for which so many worthy artists have come forward, will undoubtedly interest the public as much as the extraordinary programme that has been provided. Our country friends will have an opportunity seldom vouchsafed, of seeing nearly all our great Metropolitan celebrities in a single entertainment.

abstract: -- We are amazed to see that a bill has actually passed the Senate at Albany for doing something like justice to that much-abused and long enduring class, the wharf owners of New-York. All property holders in New-York, indeed, are sadly like Issachar, that patient ass, stooping between two burdens, but these unfortunate persons have been sufferers above all their tribe. The wharfage dues of New-York are to-day fixed by law at the rates established in 1801. More than half a century has passed. New-York has grown from a town into a metropolis; the world has been revolutionized, and the commerce of mankind quadrupled, but the legislative Rip Van Winkle who went to sleep on the wharves in 1801 has stubbornly refused to wake up and move on. It is time that he should be stirred with a very emphatic pole, for that desolate condition of our wharves over which everybody laments and moans, is simply beyond a remedy until our wharf-owners are allowed to put their property into a becoming state without beggaring themselves. To see wharf-assessments steadily rising while wharf-rates remain a tideless sea, has up to this time been the doom of the wharf-owner of New-York. The position is worse than unjust to the individuals interested; it is worse than absurd in itself. It is a disgraceful anomaly in our public law, and a serious drawback upon the real welfare of the City.
lead_paragraph: -- We are amazed to see that a bill has actually passed the Senate at Albany for doing something like justice to that much-abused and long enduring class, the wharf owners of New-York. abstract: In the State Senate the New-York Tax Levy was referred to the New-York Senators. Mr. MANIERRE introduced a bill to oblige the Superintendent of the Banking Department, in certain contingencies, to give the printing of notes to others than the American Bank Note Company. The bill authorizing the sale of the West Washington Market property to the City was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the State Senate the New-York Tax Levy was referred to the New-York Senators. Mr. MANIERRE introduced a bill to oblige the Superintendent of the Banking Department, in certain contingencies, to give the printing of notes to others than the American Bank Note Company. The bill authorizing the sale of the West Washington Market property to the City was passed. The remainder of the morning session was consumed by a discussion of the Canal bill -- Mr. GRANT taking occasion to review the Governor's Annual Message. During the evening session various bills were ordered to a third reading. To the Assembly a petition of 3,000 names was presented, praying for the passage of the Central Park Improvement bill. The Committee on Cities and Villages reported generally in favor of New-York City Railroads, and especially for the Seventh-avenue, Tenth-avenue, Broadway, Fourteenth-street and Avenue D Railroads. The bill to increase the powers of the Metropolitan Police Commissioners, and the New-York Amended Charter, were also reported favorably, but the latter, by a decisive vote, was recommitted. The Central Park Appropriation bill was, after a violent debate, passed by a a good majority. Among other bills passed were those authorizing public markets in Brooklyn, and to amend Hell Gate Pilot laws. A bill providing against accidents on railroads arising from defective bridges, &c., was reported.

abstract: By the arrival of the bark Mcndi, at this port, yesterday, we have dates from Liberia to Jan. 4. On the 2d January, STEPHEN ALLEN BENSON, with imposing ceremonies, was inaugurated President of the Republic of Liberia, for a term of two years. It is needless to state (says the Liberia Herald) that this is the third term of his Presidential career; elected twice-without an opponent, a thing rarely to be seen in our world. Never was there witnessed in Liberia a demonstration of more apparent good feeling, and common interest, and brotherly consideration, than was presented on Monday. DANIEL B. WARNER was inaugurated Vice-President of the Republic.

abstract: We add a fresh chapter this morning to the discreditable disclosures contained in our letters from the coast of Africa, published in yesterday's TIMES, concerning the Slave-trade. One of our correspondents from St. Paul de Loando gave a full account of the seizure of the bark Orion from New-York, --first by the United States steamship Portsmouth, which ...
lead_paragraph: We add a fresh chapter this morning to the discreditable disclosures contained in our letters from the coast of Africa, published in yesterday's TIMES, concerning the Slave-trade. One of our correspondents from St. Paul de Loando gave a full account of the seizure of the bark Orion from New-York, --first by the United States steamship Portsmouth, which allowed her to depart, for lack of proof, and then by the Mystic, Capt. LEROY, which detained her until Com. INMAN, of the Constellation, decided again to release her. She immediately proceeded to the Congo River, took in a large cargo of slaves, and started for home, -- when she was seized by the British steamer Pluto, and taken into St Helena.

abstract: It the North continues her present course of insult and aggression towards the South, Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, announces in his place in Congress that he will return to his constituents, "sound the alarm himself, kindle beacon fires on the hill-tops, and maintain the rights of the South with flaming dagger and blazing torch." We hope, for Mr. ASHMORE'S
lead_paragraph: It the North continues her present course of insult and aggression towards the South, Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, announces in his place in Congress that he will return to his constituents, "sound the alarm himself, kindle beacon fires on the hill-tops, and maintain the rights of the South with flaming dagger and blazing torch." We hope, for Mr. ASHMORE's own sake, that the North will do something to appease him, for we should really be sorry to see any gentleman of his age and position placed under the painful necessity of carrying out so laborious a programme as he has here traced for himself. The lighting of beacon fires on hill-tops is always a dirty, disagreeable job, and the places in which it would be of most use to light them are generally difficult of access, and very uncomfortable once you have reached them. Beacon lighting also necessitates exposure to night air, and loss of sleep. Besides which, as a means of diffusing intelligence it is clumsy and inefficient, as compared with the electric telegraph, which is in every respect a useful invention for such purposes. We advise Mr. ASHMORE to try it.

abstract: Chief-Justice ECKELS, who was sent out to preside over the United States Courts in Utah, with so much pride and pomp and circumstance, has given notice to Attorney-General BLACK that he intends to quit his post in the Spring and return home, because he thinks he does no good by remaining.
lead_paragraph: Chief-Justice ECKELS, who was sent out to preside over the United States Courts in Utah, with so much pride and pomp and circumstance, has given notice to Attorney-General BLACK that he intends to quit his post in the Spring and return home, because he thinks he does no good by remaining. There is no doubt that this is the best thing he can do, and the wonder is that he should have degraded his office by remaining in it so long. The Judges are held in thorough contempt by the Mormons, and nobody pays any respect to their decisions; and every day in which they consent to occupy this posttion only postpones the recovery of Utah to civilization and decency. As we have often maintained in these columns of late, the military forces of the United States are the only functionaries it can send to Salt Lake City with dignity or profit, and the only law it can attempt to administer with success is martial law.
headline: {'main': 'Law Among the Mormons.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Law Among the Mormons.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The proverb tells us that it is a "long lane which has no turning;" and the Legislature at Albany are now considering, with all the symptoms of speedy and favorable action, the one remedy to which we have long been looking forward for the enormous abuses of the railway system in this City.
lead_paragraph: The proverb tells us that it is a "long lane which has no turning;" and the Legislature at Albany are now considering, with all the symptoms of speedy and favorable action, the one remedy to which we have long been looking forward for the enormous abuses of the railway system in this City. Passengers of all ages, sexes, sorts and conditions; comfortless, afflicted, broken and downtrodden victims of corporate despotism! rejoice to learn that bills have been reported in the Assembly for the establishment of no less than five new railways in the streets of this City. If anything can bring our railway companies to the use of their own senses, or to a respect for ours, it will be just such a wholesome competition in the business of passenger-packing as is here more than threatened; and we trust the screw may be applied with energy.

abstract: The "Familiar Letters on Sunday-schools," from the pern of Rev. Dr. TYNG, continue to appear  regularly in the Ind pendent. The Doctor's last letter gives the following hints concerning family culture "Many families have I seen who were fixed in the sentiment, that the Sunday-school was not needful for their children, and that even greater benefits would be lost by sending them thither.
lead_paragraph: The "Familiar Letters on Sunday-schools," from the pern of Rev. Dr. TYNG, continue to appear regularly in the Ind pendent. The Doctor's last letter gives the following hints concerning family culture "Many families have I seen who were fixed in the sentiment, that the Sunday-school was not needful for their children, and that even greater benefits would be lost by sending them thither. The simple result has been, that these children, though in some cases belonging to Christian parents, and I believe conscientiously instructed at home, have grown up free from any influence of mine, or of the ministry, or of desire therefor, and, as a rule, voluntary strangers in maturity to the blessings of a day and a church which they had never been accustomed to love in their youth. I have mourned over this error in occasional determinations with exceeding sorrow -- longing to see every child and youth in the Church in actual, constant connection with blessings which I have been perfectly convinced could elsewhere never be supplied. I would entreat Christian parents to feel and to consider rightly upon this subject; and while in their prayers and efforts at home and in secret, they seek for the highest spiritual welfare of their children, to perceive and acknowledge how blessed and valuable is that helpful agency which the good providence of God has prepared for their aid and success in the Sunday-school."

abstract: We say the adieux; for young New-York was all smiles and waving handkerchiefs to our charming little prima donna last night, and it cannot be supposed that we shall let our solitary skylark soar away from us, even for a little while, without a certain degree of weeping and wailing and wringing of hands.
lead_paragraph: We say the adieux; for young New-York was all smiles and waving handkerchiefs to our charming little prima donna last night, and it cannot be supposed that we shall let our solitary skylark soar away from us, even for a little while, without a certain degree of weeping and wailing and wringing of hands. So as PATTI took her first farewell of us at midnight, beneath a shower of bouquets and applauses, she may expect to receive her second farewell at noon, in a tempest of tears and benedictions. Of course the thing will be disguised. Fashionable society doesn't go into the streets, casting ashes on its head and tearing its hair, after the Oriental fashion, even about such a pet as PATTI. We shall have Mme. COLSON, and BRIGNOLI, and AMODIO and STIGELLI, and the Orchestra, and the affecting chorus, all to say goodbye to this morning. But the truth may come out in the papers, which in the parlors bon ton must suppress. Young New-York will be inconsolable at half-past five o'clock P.M. this day for PATTI. There is a double reason for this. In the first place, PATTI. In the second place, PICCOLOMINI. PATTI is adored for herself; for her fresh, innocent, youthful voice, and laughter, and smile; for her delight in the delight she gives; for her pleasantly astonishing execution; for her past, her present, and her future. But she is also adored because she has consoled Young New-York for the loss of PICCOLOMINI!

abstract: Several weeks since we published a detailed statement of the condition of trade as exhibited by the activity in the different shipping and express establishments engaged in the transportation of merchandise to the South and Southwest.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks since we published a detailed statement of the condition of trade as exhibited by the activity in the different shipping and express establishments engaged in the transportation of merchandise to the South and Southwest. These data were obtained directly from the responsible agents of the various lines, and were brought down to the middle of January. Though no one attempted to discredit the facts then stated, some expressed the opinion that the Spring trade would "tell the story," -- in other words, that there had not been sufficient time for Southern merchants to make the necessary arrangements for changing the direction of their trade, and that a large falling off would be witnessed in the Spring business. In order to ascertain how far this opinion may have been well-founded, a second and thorough canvass has been made of the shipping lines engaged in the Southern carrying trade, the information, as in the former case, being sought exclusively of those who were fully qualified to impart it, from their direct connection with the business. Comparison has been made with the previous two months, and also with the corresponding period of the previous year.

abstract: We publish this morning some further evidence of the fact we have repeatedly stated, that the substantial business intercourse of this City with the South has not been in the least affected by the political panic which has prevailed. The utmost exertions of ultraists in ...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning some further evidence of the fact we have repeatedly stated, that the substantial business intercourse of this City with the South has not been in the least affected by the political panic which has prevailed. The utmost exertions of ultraists in both sections, -- of ambitious demagogues and Disunionists at the South, and of Abolitionists through the Herald and their other organs at the North, have produced no effect whatever upon the business relations of the two sections.

abstract: -- The President's official organ at Washington pronounces Mr. SEWARD's speech to be utterly shallow, and "beneath the ambition of school-boys in any clear debating society." This is in the recognized style of partisan criticism. The Constitution dislikes Mr. SEWARD's political sentiments: -- it feels bound, therefore, to pronounce everything he may say stupid, shallow, and beneath contempt. So, on the other hand, the Tribune dislikes DOUGLAS, and its Washington correspondent accordingly telegraphs that his speech in reply to SEWARD was "utterly contemptible," and the "most vulgar exhibition of political slang ever seen in the Senate." We do not suppose that either of these journals expresses its candid judgment upon either speech. Their criticism is the utterance of partisan feeling -- not of common sense. Their aim is to say -- not what they believe to be just and true, but what will produce the desired political effect. Whatever an opponent may say, is to be denounced: -- whatever may come from a party supporter, is to be commended and approved.

abstract: -- Memorials are now being circuluted in this City and Brooklyn for signatures, to be sent to the State Legislature, asking the enactment of a new sanitary system and code of health laws for New York and Brooklyn. A new sanitary system is importuned on the ground that the present one is entirely inefficient, and that some action should be taken to diminish the present immoradty, pauperism and vice. A healthful condition of streets, and a proper structure of tenement houses, it is alleged, might be brought about by the establishment of a competent aud judicious Health Bureau. The memorials have been already numerousiy signed.

abstract: Our modest neighbor, the Tribune, has been for a long time in the habit of giving variety and interest to its columns by paragraphs and clippings from our Paris, London and Washington correspondence -- duly displayed as original. This is all quite endurable, as the value it gives the Tribune far outweighs any injury it may do us. On Friday morning, however, we published a two-column letter from one of our correspondents on the coast of Africa, full of important revelations concerning the slave trade. On Saturday morning the Tribune publishes precisely the same letter, verbatim, following all our italic marks, &c., and coolly heads it "From our our Correspondent" This seems to us a little strong -- but as it is mainly a matter of taste, we have nothing to say against it. We only hope our neighbor will do it as rarely as convenient.
lead_paragraph: Our modest neighbor, the Tribune, has been for a long time in the habit of giving variety and interest to its columns by paragraphs and clippings from our Paris, London and Washington correspondence -- duly displayed as original. This is all quite endurable, as the value it gives the Tribune far outweighs any injury it may do us. On Friday morning, however, we published a two-column letter from one of our correspondents on the coast of Africa, full of important revelations concerning the slave trade. On Saturday morning the Tribune publishes precisely the same letter, verbatim, following all our italic marks, &c., and coolly heads it "From our our Correspondent" This seems to us a little strong -- but as it is mainly a matter of taste, we have nothing to say against it. We only hope our neighbor will do it as rarely as convenient.

abstract: A rumor prevailed in the City on Saturday, that all officers of the Army on furlough in New-York had been directed to report themselves directly at Washington, where orders were waiting them to join immediately their Regiments and proceed to the western frontier of Texas. The alarming condition of affairs on the Texas frontier, it was stated, had rendered this step necessary, but that the Government were moving very secretly in the matter. An inquiry at Governor's Island developed no further foundation for the rumor than that Major HOLMES had been instructed to detail forthwith to Regiments the recruits on the island. Gen. SCOTT says that he has not been advised of the issue of any sucn orders as those referred to, and that he believes none have been issued. The correctness or falsity of the rumor will doubtless be definitely known in a day or two.

abstract: The New-Orleans Picayune says: "We have accounts of terrible outrages and wholesale depredations committed in Chihuahua, by a robber chieftain, who is more formidable to the peaceful citizens than CORTINA has been to the inhabitants of the Rio Grande. Some account of his action has been given by us through the medium of the telegraph. The details are a bloody history of savage ferocity, which cannot but convince our Government that measures of a decided character must be taken to protect the Texan border. There is more than one CORTINA afoot. On the capture of the mining town of Parral, after the defeat of the Mayor of the City in the battle of which we have before made mention, the following atrocities were committed. abstract: We shall endeavor to publish, probably to-morrow morning, the speech of Judge DOUGLAS in reply to GOVSEWARD's exposition of the principles and views of the Republican Party, which we published at length on Thursday of last week. We gave on the same day, from our own reporters, a full telegraphic abstract of this reply, -- but as the two Senators seem to be regarded by their friends as having represented the two political parties on that occasion, it is only just and fair to present the speeches of both in full. Our readers can then have an opportunity of judging for themselves between the two.

abstract: The Africa, with Liverpool dates to the 18th ult., reached New-York on the morning of yesterday. The news is of little interest. The question of Savoyard annexation had been mooted in the House of Commons, where Lord JoHN RUSSELL had answered in terms, which only found a sensible interpretation, in a paragraph printed in the semi-official Post of the following morning.
lead_paragraph: The Africa, with Liverpool dates to the 18th ult., reached New-York on the morning of yesterday. The news is of little interest. The question of Savoyard annexation had been mooted in the House of Commons, where Lord JoHN RUSSELL had answered in terms, which only found a sensible interpretation, in a paragraph printed in the semi-official Post of the following morning. It was therein stated, that with the annexation of Central Italy to Piedmont it was no other than proper that Savoy and Nice should assume their geographical affinity with France; but that the French Government had expressed its willingness to refer the subject to the judgment of the Great Powers. When interrogated in regard to the proposed measure of ministerial reform, Lord JOHN RUSSELL announced that March 1 had been fixed upon for the introduction of the bill. He had also responded obscurely to an inquiry touching American coastwise navigation, as affecting the transhipment of goods at Panama. Sir WILLIAM NAPIER, the historian, was buried with unusual honors on the 17th ult. The news from the Continent embraces nothing more important than the circular reply of the French Foreign Minister, M. DE THOUVENEL, to the encyclical letter of the Pope. This paper reviews with excellent skill the various defects in the Papal administration, and indicates their tendency to impair the spiritual authority and efficacy of the head of the Church; and shows that while it might have been possible, when his Holmess was first advised to mitigate his rule in the Romagna, to have saved that portion of his States, it is now too late to do so. The reply, as well as a second document of similar purport, transmitted. directly to Rome, has won great applause for the new Secretary. There is nothing of moment from the seat of war in Morocco. Italy remains tranquil, awaiting the result of the election in the central provinces. Rumors to the effect that a note of M. DE THOUVENEL had been sent to Vienna, urging upon that Government the fulfillment of its engagements in reference to ameliorations to be introduced into the administration of Venetia, were circulated.

abstract: The raid of CORTINAS upon Brownsville, Texas, bas at last, by careful nursing, assumed folmidable proportions, and the depredations of a band of Texan and Mexican outlaws are made the immediate occasion for the demand of a million of money and the raising of Texas regiments of volunteers with which to repel Mexican invasion. Absurd and startling as this
lead_paragraph: The raid of CORTINAS upon Brownsville, Texas, bas at last, by careful nursing, assumed folmidable proportions, and the depredations of a band of Texan and Mexican outlaws are made the immediate occasion for the demand of a million of money and the raising of Texas regiments of volunteers with which to repel Mexican invasion. Absurd and startling as this story may appear, it is unhappily true. The active spirit of fillibusterism, and the extreme element in the South which is unresting in its schemes for the extension of the slave power on the one hand, with the apathy, ignorance and partisan passion of the North on the other, are surely and steadily driving the Government into a new Mexican war.

abstract: On the 17th, the day that the mail was made up in London, the remains of the late Sir WILLIAM NAPIER, author of the History of the Peninsular War, a work whose accuracy and truthfulness won the commendations of WELLINGTON, as its  graphic account of the events narrated has done those of every reader, were consigned to the earth in Norwood Cemetery, a few miles south of the British metropolis. In accordance with that simplicity which marked the habits of the deceased, as it did those of his gallant brother, the conqueror of Scinde, the funeral was as plain as if it had been that of a simple tradesman, nothing but the number of carriages which composed the m???nful cortege indicating that the remains of England's greatest military historian, and one of her most gallant soldiers, were being borne to their last resting-place. Such is said to have been the wish expressed in the will made by Sir WILLIAM two  years ago. The coffin was of plain oak, uncovered, and without even a nail to relieve its simplicity, and no sable plumes nodded above the hearse which bore it. Seven mourning coaches followed, and after these came ten private carriages. The procession left Scinde  House, at Clapham, in the vicinity of the metropolis, at 11 o'clock, and arrived at the cemetery a little after noon. The day was remarkably fine, but few strangers were assembled, and the whole number present, the mourners included, did not probably exceed fifty. The grave was an ordinary one, near the church, which is situated on the most elevated portion of the grounds; and no sermon was preached. Foremost among the mourners were the only son of the deceased, a fine youth, but who has the misfortune to be deaf  and dumb; his daughters, and the husband of one of them, Col. MACHMURDO, who served under the late Sir CHARLES JAMES NAPIER, in Scinde, where, at the battle of Meanee, he clove a Beloochee chief to the middle; and  Admiral Sir C. NAPIER, cousin to the deceased, and member for Southwark -- now the last of a trio of heroes. Among the spectators was a turbaned native of the East, who seemed to take much interest in the proceedings. Surprise at the unador???ed simplicity of the coffin and hearse seemed to be the predominant feeling among the onlookers, some contrasting it with the funeral of the Indian hero, who was buried at Portsmouth with military honors, and others observing that ere long the remains of the deceased would be exhumed, and interred in St. Paul's, as a tribute of respect from the British nation, at the expense of some of the foremost of whose public men there are two statues erected in London to "the bearded vision that swept Scinde."
