abstract: Both France and England have formally and fully recognized the right of every people to such a Government as they may choose--free from the coercion or intervention of foreign Powers. France gives the principle the widest possible application, and brings Savoy within its scope; England limits it to the case of a people in successful insurrection.

abstract: Mr. TAYLOR delivered this lecture on Saturday evening, at Clinton Hall, before the Young Men's Christian Union. The lecture was advertised to be delivered at the Cooper Institute, but for some reason the place was changed at the last hour. The room was full, not withstanding the unpleasant weather and the muddy streets. This lecture on HUMBOLDT was the same that Mr. TAYLOR was invited to deliver at Richmond, Va., and which invitation was afterwards withdrawn upon the ground that Mr. Taylor represented the great savan as an atheist. In the course of the lecture on Saturday evening Mr. Taylor after ??? using to the piety of HUMBOLDT as most sincere and profound, said that he had been denounced by certain bigots and shallow-pated persons for representing HUMBOLDT as an atheist; but that, since the audience had heard what he had just said upon this point respecting the subject af his discourse, he would not insult their understanding by replying to such a charge. [As this was taken by tne audience to be an allusion to the Virginia affair, the applause was loud and prolonged.] Mr. TAYLOR said that HUMBOLDT had a profound contempt for all show and hypocrisy in religious matters, and heartily despised both men and clergy who kept only one eye upon Heaven and the other upon the earth; but at the same time he, himself, was a most devout religious worshipper, an unadulterated Christian, and a pure and simple hearted man. The lecturer was loudly applauded throughout his remark.

abstract: By a fire which broke out on the first floor of the building No. 281 Canal-street, about four o'clock Saturday morning, Mr. J.C. REIMEIS, a tailor, lost stock valued at $3,000; insured in the New-Amsterdam Co. Mr.???, keeper of a lager-bier saloon in the basement, suffered to the amount of $200, and PATRICK DICKIE, the owner of the building, lost $400. Both were insured, the latter in the Jefferson Co. ... The dwelling-house No. 257 Seventh-avenue, was injured by fire Satuday afternoon, to the amount of $250. abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 16th of February, the Earl of AIRLIE moved for copies of all correspondence between the Government and Lord COWLEY and Mr. COBDEN, respecting the negotiation of the treaty of commerce with France. He stated that his object was to obtain some explanation of an article in the treaty which bound England not to prohibit the export of coal.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 16th of February, the Earl of AIRLIE moved for copies of all correspondence between the Government and Lord COWLEY and Mr. COBDEN, respecting the negotiation of the treaty of commerce with France. abstract: "ILLINOIS" AND "MOSES TAYLOR" IN COURT -- It seems that the extraordinary proceedings of this sale are to come before our Courts. Mr. W.C. BARNEY has brought a suit against MARSHALL O. ROBERTS, HORACE F. CLAEK and EDWARD N. DICKERSON, trustees, who advertised these steamships for sale. Mr. BARNEY claims that these trustees, by their auctioneer, M.O. ROBERTS, "wrongfully and fraudulently struck off and sold said steamships against the remonstrance of protest of said plaintiff, to the lower bidder for $25,000, and refused to sell the same to said plaintiff, although the said plaintiff was ready and able and willing to complete the purchase of said steamships," and "for this wrongful and fraudulent conduct of the said defendants, he claims damages in the sum of $200,000.   Hon. JOSEPH L. WHITE is Mr. BARNEY's counsel, and BOICE & COOPER  his Attorneys.

abstract: The Congress of the United States has for the last two months presented a spectacle by no means edifying to those who are determined to see nothing but what is excellent on the other side of the Atlantic. It was only on the 1st inst., after a session which commenced on the first Monday in December, that the House of Representatives was able to constitute a majority sufficiently large for the election of a Speak
lead_paragraph: The Congress of the United States has for the last two months presented a spectacle by no means edifying to those who are determined to see nothing but what is excellent on the other side of the Atlantic. It was only on the 1st inst., after a session which commenced on the first Monday in December, that the House of Representatives was able to constitute a majority sufficiently large for the election of a Speaker. It was not that the Speaker is of any particular consequence when he is appointed, but that the House is so split up by faction that neither side would make this concession to the other. The Speaker is ejected for two years only, and is not, as with us, a candidate for elevation to a post of dignity and honor. After the Congress shall have expired the Speaker will return to the ranks of his fellow-citizens, with only such distinction as the manner in which he has discharged his duty may have earned for him. Whichever side might succeed, nobody doubted that it would have placed in the chair a gentleman fully competent to the discharge of his duties, and it was therefore inexcusably childish to waste the session in disputes the result of which was certain to be utterly trivial.

abstract: ITEMS. -- An insane woman, named MARY GILLIN, was found wandering in the streets of the First Precinct Saturday night, and was taken in charge by Police-Surgeon BALL.... GEORGE RAYMOND, laborer, 20 years old, was found Saturday night by Officer BROWN, of the Second Precinct, with a stolen coat on his back, and he was committed to prison to answer for stealing the same.... A woman named ELIZA MCGEE was arrested in the Third Precinct Saturday night for attempting to pass a two dollar counterfeit bill on the Metacomet Bank, Fall River, Mass, at No. 151 Court-street. She was committed to answer.... CHARLES W. BAIED was instaped as Pastor of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, on Bergen Hill, last evening. Rev. ROBERT BAIRD, D D., and Rev N.P. PIERCE, President of the classis, took part in the proceedings.... On Friday evening last Rev.J.E. SEARLES, pastor of the york street Methodist Episcopal Chruch, was presented with $200 by his  congregation.

abstract: -- On Saturday evening the Annual Dinner of the Pioneer Clay Club came off at the Appollo Rooms. It was attended by upwards of one hundred persons, who sat down to a table loaded with every delicacy, and decorated with a fine bust of the immortal statesman, and with mottoes appropriate to the occasion. Wallace's Band furnished the music. At 9 o'clock the company passed into the supper room. Mr. JAMES M. MURRAY, President of the Club, took the chair, and after full justice had been done to the dinner, the President, in prefacing the toasts, made some happy remarks in relation to the history of the Club and its devotion to its namesake, whose interests it was established to promote twenty-one years ago, when the great statesman was in his prime. They had served him in life, and cherished his memory in death. Mr. MURRAY's remarks were loudly applauded. Letters were read from Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS, whose name brought forth great cheers, Speaker PENNINGTON, Mayor WOOD, GEO. BRIGGS and others, each one containing appropriate and patriotic seatiments. They were followed by speeches from C.E ???SLEEVE, A.J.BLEAKLY and JAS. WEBB, all of whom advanced strong Union sentiments, much to the gratification ot the assemblage. During the proceedings, Mr. GEO. ALKER, one of the founders of the organization, was presented with a beautiful gold medal, as a token of the regard of his associates, and Mrs. MURRAY, the President's wife, was made a life memner or her services in the Clay campaign as a Whig woman. The company separated at a late hour in good spirits.

abstract: The Sergeant-at-Arms of the New--York Assembly, by virtue of his office, is at least as solemn and important a person as any beadle in all England. Whoever doubts this proposition must have been corrupted, like those wicked old Whigs in Bank times, with British gold. And it is a crying shame, therefore, that while the meanest parish officer, who
lead_paragraph: The Sergeant-at-Arms of the New--York Assembly, by virtue of his office, is at least as solemn and important a person as any beadle in all England. Whoever doubts this proposition must have been corrupted, like those wicked old Whigs in Bank times, with British gold. And it is a crying shame, therefore, that while the meanest parish officer, who terrifies small boys and raps the pates of sleepy paupers in the most insignificant hamlet of Britain, is arrayed more gorgeously than Solomon in all his glory, the Sergeant-at-Arms of the New-York Assembly should go walking about the dignified aisles of the Legislative chamber like a mere member, or governor, or judge, in the blaek satin waistcoat and kerseymere trowsers of a vulgar civilization. He is not even as fair to see as any average militia sergeant; and his "arms" are the merest myth. In short, he no more resembles the splendid Sergeant-at-Arms whom our imperial State demands, than Queen VICTORIA, in her silk dress and French bonnet, resembles the sublime sovereigns depicted in our childhood's story-books, wearing crowns of gold forever on their heads, even when engaged in the comparatively human amusement of "eating bread and honey" in the royal kitchen. All these things one of our sage legislators, Mr. TUCKER, possibly a remote kinsman of the celebrated Thomas, who "cried for his supper," has gravely pondered; and much revolving them in his swift mind, finally brought forth on Friday last a motion to "purchase a sword, chapeau and belt for the Sergeant-at-Arms, and to require that officer to wear the same while the House is in session."

abstract: The Twenty-seventh-street Methodist Church devoted the entire day yesterday to Missionary Meetings. Services were held in the morning, when Rev. Dr.  PORTER preached; in the afternoon, when Drs. WISE and PORTER spoke, and in the evening, when a discourse was delivered by Rev. J. JONES, of Michigan. The remarks of Dr. WISE were peculiarly interesting. He took the ground that the missionary work is mainly done by the minority of the Church; that Christians can have for abstaining from missionary work neither the excuse of ignorance, of indifference, of not having been commanded to the work by God, or of lack of results.   He claimed that during the last fifty years there have been converted two hundred millions of heathen -- as many as there were converts existing two centuries  after the Christian era began. At the three meetings of the day and evening collections were taken up, which, with the contributions of the Sunday School, will swell the amount given by this Church this year for missionary purposes to eight hundred dollars.

abstract: So we are not to have the streets cleaned after all. Mr. SMITH, the man of machines, retires from the unequal contest. The City Inspector hired him to do the work,-Mayor WOOD promised to countersign his warrants, if the work was well done, and Comptroller HAWS promised to pay him the money on the same
lead_paragraph: So we are not to have the streets cleaned after all. Mr. SMITH, the man of machines, retires from the unequal contest. The City Inspector hired him to do the work,-Mayor WOOD promised to countersign his warrants, if the work was well done, and Comptroller HAWS promised to pay him the money on the same condition. He went vigorously at his Herculean task, -- and a broad smile of satisfaction and of hope passed over the public face at the prospect of having dean streets for a year.

abstract: -- Rev. HENRY GRATTAN GUINNESS proached again in the large hall of Cooper Institute yesterday afternoon and evening, by invitation of the Young Men's Christian Association. Both the sermons were especially devoted to young men. In the afternoon there were some thousands more went to the Institute than could gain admittance to the hall, and in the evening the place was filed, even to the entrances on either side. At the evening service his text was taken from the 26th verse of the 24th chapter of Acts, which he considered and applied to his audience as being the probable feeling of a large majority in relation to the welfare of their souls. "Go thy way for this time," was the thought that governed the action of the young in matters of religion. Even those who recognized the absolute necessity of making their peace with God, in the vigor of youth, with a world of  seeming pleasure before them were loth to give up what to them appeared to be the joys of life, and so put off the day of repentance and seeking after God until a more convenient season. The darger of delay and the awful consequences of a failure to find a convenient season, were presented by the preacher with peculiar earnestness; and his appeals to the young men to leave off the ways of sin and turn to the Saviour, were forcible and at times eloquent. Listening to Mr. GUINNESS of the first time it is difficult to understand to what he owes his great success as a preacher. The ideas and llusirations he presents lack originality. He speaks of sin and si???ners, of Christ and the way of salvation, in the stereoty ped words of the thousands of not strikingly successful preacners who have spoken before him, and who are speaking still. To an haoitual church-goer his expressions fall familiarly upon the ear, and his scriptural quotations affect the minds of his listeners as he prepares the way for them, and before he has given them utteranoe. Niether is has gesticulation vigorous or unusual, and although he is a man of commanding presence, he seems to be unconscious of it while speaking, for he never uses it for effect, as he might safely do. His peculiarity is a remarkable earnestness, an earnestness which is not shown by tension of the muscles, or by facial contortions.  He soeaks calmly and with dignity. His earnestness affects his hearers, and by the mellow tremulousness of his voice and the eager expression of his eye rivets the attention, and satisfies that he is thoroughly in earnest and goes about to do good.

Listening to Mr. GUINNESS of the first time it is difficult to understand to what he owes his great success as a preacher. The ideas and llusirations he presents lack originality. He speaks of sin and si???ners, of Christ and the way of salvation, in the stereoty ped words of the thousands of not strikingly successful preacners who have spoken before him, and who are speaking still. To an haoitual church-goer his expressions fall familiarly upon the ear, and his scriptural quotations affect the minds of his listeners as he prepares the way for them, and before he has given them utteranoe. Niether is has gesticulation vigorous or unusual, and although he is a man of commanding presence, he seems to be unconscious of it while speaking, for he never uses it for effect, as he might safely do. His peculiarity is a remarkable earnestness, an earnestness which is not shown by tension of the muscles, or by facial contortions. He soeaks calmly and with dignity. His earnestness affects his hearers, and by the mellow tremulousness of his voice and the eager expression of his eye rivets the attention, and satisfies that he is thoroughly in earnest and goes about to do good.

abstract: Mr. JOHN G. BOKER, a well-Known wine merchant of this City, and the original proprietor of the Dusseldorff Gallery, died on Saturday. His remains will be taken to Germany for interment. Two or three years since, Mr.BOKER's name figured conspicuously in the newspapers, in consequence of the elopement of his daughter with her father's coachman; a circumstance which brought the family relations into great notoriety, and which resulted in the total estrangement of the lady from her father.

abstract: The Tribune is quite as explicit on the subject of our Police difficulties as we could expect. It gives us to understand very distinctly that, in the controversy which Mayor WOOD has excited with the Superintendent, Mr. PILSBURY is to go overboard. It has discovered that the difference between them is upon " a matter of punctilio rather than of real im
lead_paragraph: The Tribune is quite as explicit on the subject of our Police difficulties as we could expect. It gives us to understand very distinctly that, in the controversy which Mayor WOOD has excited with the Superintendent, Mr. PILSBURY is to go overboard. It has discovered that the difference between them is upon " a matter of punctilio rather than of real importance," -- though it involves the authority of the Superintendent to command the force for whose conduct he is held responsible. It has made the discovery, also, that Mr. PILSBURY is not, after all, indispensable to the place, -- that in many respects he is not very well fitted for it, though it "does not mean to condemn the Commissioners for appointing him." This is prudent, -- inasmuch as the Tribune was in ecstasies with his appointment when it was made.

abstract: The season at the Academy of Music came to a triumphant close on Saturday, when the last Patti  matinee filled the building from pit to dome. The performances--although not at all what was announced--gave general satisfaction. COLSON and STIGELLI car ried off the honors of the principal piece--"Ernani"--and PATTI and BEIGNOLI sang deliciously in an act of "Martha." The company opens to-night in Philadelphia, and will not probably return to the City until Easter Monday.

abstract: Rev. Dr. BROWN, a returned missionary from Burmah, preached at 10 1/2 A.M., yesterday, in the Mount Olivet Baptist Church, corner of Sixth-avenue and Forty-first-street. His discourse was not of his experiences in the far-off land, but related to the sufferings of Christ on the Cross. John xii., 27, 28 was his text. He dwelt upon the acuteness of the feelings of Jesus as a man and the exaltation of his spirit as God; on the magnitude of the atonement which he made for the sins of men, and on the outies of Christians who inherited heaven through Him. The sermon was listened to very attentively by a Jarge congregation.

abstract: -Between Albany and Hudson the ice which has covered the river during the winter, has nearly all yielded to the violent rains and the mild temperature of the last week. From Hudson to Catskill the river is entirely open; to Crum Elbow -- four or five miles above Pougakeepsie -- there are occasional barriers to easy navigation, and between the latter place and this city the ice has vanished. Barges have been running to Newburgh for several days, and those which make regular trips between this city and Poughkeepsie will resume operations this week. The steamboat Norwich was to start for Rondout on Saturday, and it was confidently believed that her well-known ice cutting powers would enable her to accomplish the voyage to Albany without much difficulty should she undertake to force her way further than her first destination. Tnere can be little doubt that boats will be making trips between this city and Albany before the close of the present week.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. -- A regular meeting of this Board was held last night. A resolution was adopted requesting the representatives of Kings County, in the State Legislature, to oppose any act relative to the laying out of parks, which has not secured the sanction of the Common Council. The draft of an ordinance prohibiting the salting of streets and avenues was referred to the Railroad Committee for report. The Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies was directed to prepare proposals for the introduction of the Ridgewood water into each Station-house. New houses were ordered to be built for Engine Companies Nos. 1 and 21, according to plans submitted, the cost of each not to exceed $2,500 The Mayor's veto of the letter furnishing two Fire Department banners was superseded, and the banners ordered; as was also the Mayor's ??? of a resolution authorizing a Committee to go to Albany, and spend $500 illegally. The salaries of several clerks were raised, when the Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: Hon. K. RAYNER publishes a letter in the North Carolina Standard, correcting some errors in a report of his speech, and taking occasion to say that he is in favor of resisting the continued domination of the Democratic Party without compromise or conciliation, and that he would as soon "trust his slave-property to the Republican Party as to the Democratic Party as a political organization."
lead_paragraph: Hon. K. RAYNER publishes a letter in the North Carolina Standard, correcting some errors in a report of his speech, and taking occasion to say that he is in favor of resisting the continued domination of the Democratic Party without compromise or conciliation, and that he would as soon "trust his slave-property to the Republican Party as to the Democratic Party as a political organization." He speaks in high terms of commendation of Hon. H.W. DAVIS of Maryland -- saying that he is "unquestionably one of the most brilliant and intellectual men of the country," and that if there is any Abolitionism about him, he has never seen any evidence of it.

abstract: The Board of Police Commissioners yesterday accepted the resignation of their Superintendent. They permitted Mr. PILSBURY to leave the service, rather than leave him in possession of sufficient authority to make it either efficient or respectable.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Police Commissioners yesterday accepted the resignation of their Superintendent. They permitted Mr. PILSBURY to leave the service, rather than leave him in possession of sufficient authority to make it either efficient or respectable. Mr. Bowen. at the meeting on Saturday, said that if the control of the Police force was to be given to the Superintendent, the Board would become useless. Mr. Bowen knows better: -- he said this, not because he believed there was any reason or sense in it, but because it sounded a little like an excuse for his conduct. The Board retain the power over policemen, of trying them for misconduct, of prescribing rules for the government of the force, of doing everything which it was ever intended they should do. No man in his senses ever dreamed that they were to take charge of the details of the service. Mr. BOWEN might as well say the Secretaryship of War is a useless department, because the general is left to command his division.

abstract: The "Archbishop and Suffragans of the Ecclesiastical Province of New-York" may take heart of grace. The Pope having delivered his soul of one song of gratitude to his faithful shepherds in France, has now uttered another in praise of his equally faithful shepherds in Ireland. The turn of his American ...
lead_paragraph: The "Archbishop and Suffragans of the Ecclesiastical Province of New-York" may take heart of grace. The Pope having delivered his soul of one song of gratitude to his faithful shepherds in France, has now uttered another in praise of his equally faithful shepherds in Ireland. The turn of his American Pastors must be near at hand, and the secular world will no doubt be very soon edified with a bland and benevolent letter from His Holiness to his venerable brethren and his beloved children in Gotham, setting forth, in the sweet and conciliatory style which seems to have descended upon PIUS IX from his predecessor and namesake the Dominican author of the bull "In Cana Domini,' how deeply the Holy See feels the necessity of keeping the ports of Civita Vecchia and Ancona always open for the convenience of the clergy of New-York going about their lawful occasions; and how earnestly the Holy See is determined to fulfill this duty, even though its performance should entail ruin upon the Roman Church, maintain oppression in the Roman States, and plunge civilized Christendom into the calamities of war.

abstract: The safety of the Union was made to depend by the alarmists, last Autumn, upon the result of the elections in New-York. If this State gave a Republican majority, there was nothing surer than that a speedy dissolution would ensue, and consequent commercial ruin. When the election was over and the Union was found to have withstood the shock, the election ...
lead_paragraph: The safety of the Union was made to depend by the alarmists, last Autumn, upon the result of the elections in New-York. If this State gave a Republican majority, there was nothing surer than that a speedy dissolution would ensue, and consequent commercial ruin. When the election was over and the Union was found to have withstood the shock, the election of the Speaker was made the final test, under the strain of which the fabric was positively to go to pieces. If a Republican, or any man who did not cordially approve of Slavery, was chosen to fill the post of honor, no further postponement of the crisis could possibly be made. The pillars of the State were to topple over without fail, and all the banks to close.

abstract: Rev. Dr. King writes to the Missionary Board of Boston, under date of Athens, Dec. 29, that, believing his years to be nearly numbered, he has been laboring to finish the work which has been given him to do. In addition to his regular service in Greek, he has been occupied in printing five volumes of his own writings, one in French and four in modern Greek. He has sold large numbers of the New Testament and Ten Commandments in modern Greek, and has in press a new edition of Baxter's Saints' Rest, in the same language. His trial before the Greek authorities, on several charges, was to take place during the present month,

abstract: Mr. ALEXANDER CUMMINGS, the original proprietor of the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, announces his withdrawal from the establishment, after having been connected with it for 13 years. The editors in last evening's issue, say: "The announcement made above renders it perhaps desirable that a few words should be said concerning the new proprietorship of the Evening Bulletin, Messes. GIBSON PEACOCK and JAMES S. CHAMBERS, the former partners of Mr. CUMMINGS, remain in the firm, their respective interests being considerably increased. Messrs, F. FETHERSTON, CASPAR SOUNDER, Jr., ERNEST C. WALLACE and THOMAS J. WILLIAMSON, each of whom have long been employed in the office, have also become part proprietors, and will continue in their former positions, with renewed incentives to work for the prosperity of the paper and to add to the interest of its columns,"

abstract: Mr. LATHAM, the new Senator from California in the place of Mr. HAUN, was yesterday inducted into his seat in the Senate Chamber. Mr. SUMNER  moved a resolution calling for copies of correspondence ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. LATHAM, the new Senator from California in the place of Mr. HAUN, was yesterday inducted into his seat in the Senate Chamber. Mr. SUMNER moved a resolution calling for copies of correspondence relative to maritime law and neutral rights which may have passed between this and any foreign Government, since the Congress of Paris. The bill for more effectually executing the ninth article of the treaty with Spain was, on motion of Mr. MALLORY, made the special order for the 19th inst. The Armory bill coming up, Mr. FESSENDEN offered an amendment limiting the number of arms to be sold to the States. No further action was taken, the Senate passing to the consideration of the bill amending the act establishing the Court of Claims. Mr. BAYARD spoke in advocacy of the measure, as one calculated to hasten the awards of equity; while Messrs. HALE and TOOMBS proposed amendments. That offered by the latter prevailing, the Senate adjourned. The siege of the White House was opened in form by the Republicans in the House of Representatives. Mr. COVODE moved for a Special Committee to inquire into the application of Executive patronage to the control of legislation, so wording his resolve as to cover all the allegations which have been currently received touching the misconduct of the Administration in that particular. A scene of great excitement and violence ensued. Mr. FLORENCE of Pennsylvania, denounced the resolutions for vagueness, and for inculpating honest men. Mr. ASHMORE and others on the Democratic side were equally severe, and persisted in speaking long after the Chairman had decided debate to be out of order. A vote was at length obtained, and the resolutions carried. A resolution proposing a Special Committee upon the Pacific Railroad also prevailed. Another providing for the election of a Chaplain failed. A joint resolution, propounded by Mr. REAGAN of Texas, placing $5,000,000 at the disposal of the President to pay the expenses of volunteers sent to the Rio Grande, was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

abstract: The Common Council having succeeded in defeating the arrangement whereby Mr. Smith contracted to give us clean streets for $300,000 per annum, the City Inspector commenced yesterday to follow the directions of Alderman BOOLE's resolution, and clean the streets "as heretofore." At 6 o'clock last night some 250 men, with carts to match, were set to work in different parts of the City, to test once more the merits of the old-fashioned broom in ridding our pavements of their mountains of filth. It is the intention of Mr. Downing to increase the force as fast as practicable, until the streets are thoroughly cleaned, provided such a consummation shall prove to be within the range of possibility. At any rate, the "day's-work" system will be followed hereafter, until Mr. Delavan is otherwise ordered by "the Honorable the Common Council."
lead_paragraph: The Common Council having succeeded in defeating the arrangement whereby Mr. Smith contracted to give us clean streets for $300,000 per annum, the City Inspector commenced yesterday to follow the directions of Alderman BOOLE's resolution, and clean the streets "as heretofore." At any rate, the "day's-work" system will be followed hereafter, until Mr. Delavan is otherwise ordered by "the Honorable the Common Council."

abstract: The Urbana (Ohio) Citizen publishes a report of a very interesting case lately tried in that place under the seventh section of "An act to provide against the evils resulting from the sale of ??? liquors." passed May 1, 1854. By this section, the wife, child, parent, guardian, employer or other person who shall be injured in person, property or means of support, by an intoxicated person, has a right of action against the party who sold the liquor. If sold contrary to law. In the present cause, the ,plaintiff?, JANE BRUSH, alleged that she was the wife of REED BRUSH an intemperate man, and that the defendant. PETER LAWSON, though cognizant of the habits of her husband, sold him a pint of whisky on the 29th of April last, in violation of law, with which he became intoxicated, and in his drunken ??? chopped off the left foot of plaintiff. In compensation for this, she asks damages legations, and introduced testimony to substantiate his ??? and further offered to prove the immoral character of the plaintiff, but the Court -- PARSONS, J. -- decided the evidence on the latter point was in admissible the issue between the parties, and the Jury retired and after a short consultation, returned a verdict for he plaintiff, assessing her damages at $5,000.

abstract: The Committee of the Missouri Opposition Convention, Feb. 29, reported the following plaform of principles: Whilst we are not disposed to exaggerate the character of the evils which threaten us in the future, no one who is an attentive observer of passing events can fail to perceive that the heart of the nation is throbbing with the dread of impending calamity, arising not more from the bitterness of sectional ...
lead_paragraph: The Committee of the Missouri Opposition Convention, Feb. 29, reported the following plaform of principles: Whilst we are not disposed to exaggerate the character of the evils which threaten us in the future, no one who is an attentive observer of passing events can fail to perceive that the heart of the nation is throbbing with the dread of impending calamity, arising not more from the bitterness of sectional animosity than from the corruption and lawlessness of the political party which now holds the reins of government, directs the power of official station to perpetuate its own supremacy. Its leaders are active abettors of the fell spirit of disunion; many of them openly declaring that if the people should drive them from power, they would dissolve this glorious confederacy of States, Vain and impious threat -- a threat addressed to the fears of the timid, and the hopes of the lawless, and which can only serve to nerve the arms of the brave and patriotic citizens who have resolved that as loyal defenders of the Constitution and the Union their first duty to their country is to unite in driving that party from power; and that we declare that we are in favor of -- 1. The preservation of the Federal Union at all hazards. 2. The supremacy of the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws of the United States. 3. The unqualified recognition of the reserved rights of the States and of the people. 4. The cultivation and expansion of the resources of the country, by such protection to every useful pursuit and interest as is compatible with the general welfare, and equitable to all. 5. The strengthening of our National defences by the construction of a railroad to the Pacific Ocean. 6. The granting of free homesteads to those who will actually settle and improve the public domain. 7. The elevation to office of men of unwavering firmness, incorruptible integrity, undoubted ability and sound conservatism.

abstract: TENDENCY OF THE SPRINGFIELD AEMOEY. -- on Saturday evening the workmen engaged in the Springfield Armory met Gen. WHITNEY, the late Superintendent, at Armory Hall to take official leave of him. After Gen. WHITSEY had entered the room, escorted by a Committee of three which had been appointed to wait on him and request his attendance, Mr. SALMON ADAMS, the Chairman of the meeting, made a few remarks, and Mr. ERSKINE S. ALLEN, master armorer, Presented to Gen. WHITNEY, on behalf of the workmen, a silver pitcher and five goblets. Gen. WHITNEY replied appropriately, acknowledging the gift, referring to the incidents which had occurred during his term of office, approving the bill now before Congress giving to the National Armories the right to furnish arms for the State upon the payment of the cost of such arms, and concluding by thanking the workmen for their presence on the occasion. All the ladies and gentlemen present then shook hands with Gen. WHITNEY and the company separated.

abstract: QUEBEC, Tuesday, Feb. 28, 1860. The Provincial Parliament was opened this day  by His Excellency in person. abstract: Hon. GRANTLEY F. BERKELEY, an English sporting gentleman who honored our country by coming all the way from England last Summer to shoot buffaloes on our Western prairies, is writing an account of manners and customs in America. As he was in the country only a few weeks, and his attention was absorbed during most of that time by the woes and wants of his dogs, his observations very naturally lack profoundness and value; but as a general thing they are amusing, and now and then not absolutely destitute of common sense. Perhaps a few paragraphs from his last letter may interest our readers:

abstract: WASHINGTON, Monday, March 5. Mr. MILLSON, of Virginia, (Dem.,)was unwilling  that the House should seem to be indifferent to a usage coeval with our Government, and dignified by so many historical recollections. He therefore offered a resolution providing for the election of a Chaplain to-morrow, to officiate alternately with the Chaplain already elected by the Senate.

abstract: The Spring Book Trade gives pleasant indications of health and vigor. Most of the City Publishers are renewing their stock and issuing new works, in anticipation of an increased demand.
lead_paragraph: The Spring Book Trade gives pleasant indications of health and vigor. Most of the City Publishers are renewing their stock and issuing new works, in anticipation of an increased demand. The stagnation in this branch of trade, which followed the panic of 1857, and threw an immense mass of stock upon the hands of the publishers, has gradually disappeared under the reviving influence of a better financial condition, while the spirit of eager rivalry and active enterprise leaps into fresh life with the opening of the Spring. The book-counters bend beneath loads of handsome volumes, damp from the press; the accumulations of old stock have been worked off during the lull; the dust is brushed out of the corners of the shelves; printers hurry in and scamper out with specimen-sheets; authors' faces are broader and less despondent; the publishers' pockets are less lank, and their bank-accounts larger; the reading public, recovering from its indifference, reappears as the diligent seeker for novelties; and altogether the Trade is in a very satisfactory state.

abstract: The occupants of the large tenement house No. 185 Hester-street, were thrown into consternation yesterday by a cry that the building was on fire. An immediate rush was made for the roof by the women and children living in the upper part of the house, where, finding no means of escape, they stood scream ing frantically for help, while many of those in the ...
lead_paragraph: The occupants of the large tenement house No. 185 Hester-street, were thrown into consternation yesterday by a cry that the building was on fire. An immediate rush was made for the roof by the women and children living in the upper part of the house, where, finding no means of escape, they stood scream ing frantically for help, while many of those in the lower floor ran into the street, without waiting to inqu???e if there was cause for the panic. An investigation finally resulted in the discovery of smoke issuing from the back apartments on the third floor, occupied by JOHN G. FISHER, a German tailor. The door of the room had been locked, but it was at once broken open and a pile of furniture, papers, books, and other inflammable stuff, that had been saturated with alcohol, was found in flames. The fire was speedily extinguished with trifling damage, and as nothing was seen of FISHER, it was at first supposed that he had escaped. On looking into the adjoining room, however, the body of the man was discovered, suspended from the bars of a ventilator by a thin cord fastened to his neck. He was quite dead, but life could not have been long extinct. Coroner JACKMAN was summoned to hold an inquest, at which it appeared that deceased had resided in the same house over seven years, but had refused to hold any communication whatever with his neighbors He is represented to have been exceedingly morose in manner, not permitting even his brother, who resides in the neighborhood, to visit him. It the children in the house made a noise, it is said that he would rave with anger, and on one occasion, having caught in the hallway a little girl who had thus offended him, he set fire to her hair, burning her seriously. He was a widower, 35 years of age, and, by ??? and industry, had amassed several hundred dollars. It is supposed that he was insane when he committed his double crime, and a verdict of suicide by hanging was rendered.

abstract: The Charivari gives the following as a "true story:" Twenty years ago, three young men were walking together on the Boulevard. "Shall we go to breakfast?" said one. "With all my heart," replied the second. "But," chimed in the third, "where are the funds; which of us has a purse?" "I" exclaimed the others both at once, "but it is empty." "Caristi! and I am as hungry as a lawyer's clerk.
lead_paragraph: The Charivari gives the following as a "true story:" Twenty years ago, three young men were walking together on the Boulevard. "Shall we go to breakfast?" said one. "With all my heart," replied the second. "But," chimed in the third, "where are the funds; which of us has a purse?" "I" exclaimed the others both at once, "but it is empty." "Caristi! and I am as hungry as a lawyer's clerk. What's to be done?" "I have an idea," said the first speaker, "come with me." The three entered a music shop, and asked the proprietor whether he would buy a song. �A song? Diable! Whose is it?" "Ours." "Let me see it." "I will sing it to you." said the shortest of the three. He sat down to the piano and sung the piece offered for sale. "Well," said the publisher, "it is not bad -- I will give you 25 francs for it." "What, words and music, and all?" "Oh, certainly, the times are hard." "It is very little -- never mind -- shell out -- it will be enough to pay for our breakfast." The publisher paid the 25 francs, and the three friends went to breakfast together. Why this story? the reader will ask. Oh, nothing in the world but this -- the song was l'Andalouse! The publisher made 100,000 francs by his bargain. The author of the words was Alfred de Musset, the author of the music was Monpou, and the singer, Duprez. That's all.

abstract: Mr. BERTRAND CLOVER, of No. 6 South William-street, in this City, wrote a letter to Hon. LEWIS CASS Secretary of State, stating that he has large sums of money and much property legally and justly due him by the citizens of Nicaragua, but that he and his partner can obtain no satisfaction or redress because of the want of a settled government in that country. Several of his debtors are acting magistrates, and others influential and personal friends of President MARTINEZ. To establish his position with reference to the impossibility of collecting debts, he cites the murder of JOHN B. LAWLESS, Rev. Mr. WHEELER, and others, as showing the bitter hatred which the Niearaguans feel toward Americans. As Mr.CLOVER is nevertheless about to venture to go to Nicaragua, he appeale to Secretary CASS for protection. That official replies as follows:

abstract: -At Woonsocket, R.I., March 1, Mrs. DAVID DAVENPORT, residing on the "Globe Side," poisoned her infant, (five months old,) and then committed suicide by poisoning herself. Both mother and child died at an early hour next morning. There are various versions respecting the cause of this sad deed. Family troubles are at the bottom of it. Mrs. DAVENPORT attempted suicide previous to her marriage, about a year since. -- Providence Journal.
lead_paragraph: -At Woonsocket, R.I., March 1, Mrs. DAVID DAVENPORT, residing on the "Globe Side," poisoned her infant, (five months old,) and then committed suicide by poisoning herself. abstract: Mr. Pickering, a Boston broker, whose establishment had been broken into and robbed of $2,000, lately received a note stating that if Mr. Pickering would meet the writer at the corner of Park and Beacon streets, and pay him $150, he would return the money. The writer advised Mr. Pickering not to consult with the police, as he was a desperate man and would not be taken alive. By advice of the police Mr. Pickering proceeded to have the interview on the day mentioned, two officers of the detective police having at an early hour concealed themselves in the neighborhood to watch the operation but the writer of the note did not make his appearance, he having seen the officers as it subsequently appeared. A second appointment failed, but a third brought the parties together in Pemberton-square, and two police officers, who had concealed themselves in the Missionary Building, made an arrest of the rogue, who proved to be a Russian named Carl Julius Kruhse. He had on his person a passport, dated Riga, Aug. 27, 1857, which gave him liberty to visit and travel in the United States until Dec. 31, 1859. He is a man of about 35 years of age, dressed in medium style, and claimed, at his boarding-house in Hanover-avenue, to be a clerk by profession. He was held in $3,800 for trial.

abstract: Last night the House of Commons paused upon the threshold of the Navy Estimates to hold a conversation upon China, the result of which, to quote the words of Mr. BAILLIE COCHRANE, was--"After the reverse which we have recently experienced in China, it is necessary that some great demonstration shall be made with the view of retrieving our position in that country."
lead_paragraph: Last night the House of Commons paused upon the threshold of the Navy Estimates to hold a conversation upon China, the result of which, to quote the words of Mr. BAILLIE COCHRANE, was--"After the reverse which we have recently experienced in China, it is necessary that some great demonstration shall be made with the view of retrieving our position in that country." No party in the House says more than this, and no party says lees. Moreover, all parties agree that there shall be, upon some early occasion, a grand field day, in which all the details of this wonderful unanimity shall be fully debated, and when the blame of the late disaster shall be kept, like a shuttle-cock, in continual passage between the Ministerial and the Opposition benches.

abstract: The Rochester Union says the alarming affair at Adams' Basin, which occurred a few weeks since, and which led to the startling disclosure that an attempt had been made to destroy by poison a highly respectable family, has taken on a new and some what singular aspect recently. A complaint has been made against Mrs. LEWIS, the nurse, and she is under arrest, to be examined on a charge of having committed the dreadful crime. We have not the particulars of this part of the case, but understand that a party who knew nothing of the affair except upon information, applied to Justice DRESSER for a warrant against Mrs. LEWIS. As this magistrate had just concluded an examination which disclosed all the facts within his reach, and revealed nothing to implicate the lady, he, of course, refused to grant the application, and it was made elsewhere, and a warrant was obtained. Who gave the warrant we have not learned, but we have no doubt of the fact, and understand that a partial examination has taken place. Rumor alleges that this is a counter move made by the friends of the girl who has been committed to jail.

abstract: -- Two steamers left this port yesterday for Aspinwall with the California passengers and mails -- the Baltic, Capt. A.G. GRAY, from the old Collins pier, foot of Canal-street, at 4 o'clock P.M., having been detained by low water, which left the steamer aground at the usual hour for her departure, and the Vanderbilt steamer Ariel, from the Warren-street pier. Each carried a fair complement of passengers, the popularity of the Baltic securing much the larger share. The price of passage having been increased on both steamers by mutual agreement, there was a corresponding decrease in the demand for tickets, and a total absence of the bustle and excitement which have been observable heretofore on the departure of these steamers. The rates of fare on both lines were: For first cabin, $200; second cabin, $150, and steerage, $100; being an advance from $150, $100 and $50, respectively, for through tickets. A still further increase in the rates is predicted for the steamer of the 20th of March, when the North Atlantic steamers will have been entirely withdrawn. The hauling off of these fine ships, just as they had received a perfect equipment for the California trade, and so soon after they had achieved so enviable a reputation for reliability, comfort and speed, is cause of great chagrin and disappointment, not only to the officers and employes of the two ships, but to all California travelers. In anticipation of a settled order of things, under which system the swindling of passengers could be carried on, a large number of bogus ticket-offices have been opened near the foot of Canal-street, to waylay strangers going to the steamer. Their occupation is gone in this locality -- one gratifying result, at least, of the change.

abstract: The Polytechnic Institute is connected with the well-known American Institute, and holds its meetings weekly at the Cooper Union Buildings. Its object is the comparison and discussion of such facts as men of experience and scientific attainments deem of importance, and which have a pratical bearing upon the progress and welfare of our age. On Thursday evening of each week the savans of science discuss the previously appointed subject.
lead_paragraph: The Polytechnic Institute is connected with the well-known American Institute, and holds its meetings weekly at the Cooper Union Buildings. Its object is the comparison and discussion of such facts as men of experience and scientific attainments deem of importance, and which have a pratical bearing upon the progress and welfare of our age. On Thursday evening of each week the savans of science discuss the previously appointed subject. Nor are they merely theoretical men, but, on the contrary, they come fresh from the workshop, and they speak with the ardor of men that realize the full significance and the practical bearing of the subject under discussion. Mechanics, chemistry, geology, with their innumerable relations to the arts and practical life, all come in for their share of attention, and are fully discussed.

abstract: In the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, a communication was received from the Mayor, nominating JAMES SALMON to fill the vacancy in the Board of Commissioners for building a Court-house in the rear of the City Hall. The nomination was unanimously confirmed. The Board then adjourned, out of respect to the memory of the mother of Supervisor KENNEDY, whose death was announced in a resolution offered by Supervisor PURDY.

abstract: A fire occurred about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon among some bales of hay on the upper deck of the barge S.R. Mullen, lying at pier No. 34 North River, at the foot of Harrison-street. The flames were not extinguished until a damage of $1,500, upon which there was no insurance, had been done to the upper deck and gearing of the vessel. The steamboat South America, lying alongside of the barge, fortunately had steam on, and thus escaped the fire. As it was, her upper works, on the starboard side, were injured to the extent of $1,000. The steamboat was insured for $24,000 in various City companies, and was owned, as was also the barge, by Mr. WM.H. MELLEN. The hay is believed to have been fired by mischievous boys, and $200 will probably cover the loss upon it. Fifteen hundred bushels of oats, in the hold of the barge, were badly damaged by water. A steam fire-engine, which took a station on the adjoining pier, by stretching its hose over a schooner's bowsprit, and keeping it in position by means of guy ropes, poured a steady stream upon the fire, and did much towards extinguishing it.
lead_paragraph: A fire occurred about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon among some bales of hay on the upper deck of the barge S.R. Mullen, lying at pier No. 34 North River, at the foot of Harrison-street. The flames were not extinguished until a damage of $1,500, upon which there was no insurance, had been done to the upper deck and gearing of the vessel. The steamboat South America, lying alongside of the barge, fortunately had steam on, and thus escaped the fire. As it was, her upper works, on the starboard side, were injured to the extent of $1,000. The steamboat was insured for $24,000 in various City companies, and was owned, as was also the barge, by Mr. WM.H. MELLEN. The hay is believed to have been fired by mischievous boys, and $200 will probably cover the loss upon it. Fifteen hundred bushels of oats, in the hold of the barge, were badly damaged by water. A steam fire-engine, which took a station on the adjoining pier, by stretching its hose over a schooner's bowsprit, and keeping it in position by means of guy ropes, poured a steady stream upon the fire, and did much towards extinguishing it.

abstract: Twenty years ago the British Government was aroused to the pressing necessity of investigating the causes of the frightful mortality of her laboring population, and Commissioners of scientific men were delegated to traverse the realm and thoroughly explore its cities and towns and discover, if possible, the secret sources of death. England underwent a complete and thorough sanitary survey, and the admirable Reports of the Health of Towns Commissioners exhibit the result.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago the British Government was aroused to the pressing necessity of investigating the causes of the frightful mortality of her laboring population, and Commissioners of scientific men were delegated to traverse the realm and thoroughly explore its cities and towns and discover, if possible, the secret sources of death. England underwent a complete and thorough sanitary survey, and the admirable Reports of the Health of Towns Commissioners exhibit the result. These reports agree in attributing the fearful mortality among the poor to excessive crowding in ill-ventilated houses, defective house and land drainage, deficient supplies of pure water -- in a word, to causes capable of removal.

abstract: From the Mexican accounts to-day, via NewYork, there are symptoms that the Liberal Party are regaining a little strength. Should this change in their prospect continue, it will increase the chances of the American treaty being ratified by the Senate at Washington, and of a vote being obtained from the Lower House for the 800,000 essential to its fulfillment. lead_paragraph: From the Mexican accounts to-day, via NewYork, there are symptoms that the Liberal Party are regaining a little strength. Should this change in their prospect continue, it will increase the chances of the American treaty being ratified by the Senate at Washington, and of a vote being obtained from the Lower House for the 800,000 essential to its fulfillment. As Congress, however, has not yet organized, and there are only four months of the session remaining, great doubts may be entertained of any definitive settlement. As far as the foreign creditors are concerned, the uncertainly, perhaps, need cause little regret. When JUAREZ held sufficient power to afford other Governments some reasons which they might consider valid for dealing with him as the representative of the Mexican people, and when it was clearly believed that Mr. BUCHANAN would hold to his pledge that no purchases should be made from Mexico by the United States without due stipulations on behalf of the foreign bondli???ers there was good ground to regard the McLan??? treaty with favor. But the revelations since made have been calculated to excite dissatisfaction. It has been boldly avowed that of the �800,000 now proposed to be paid to JUAREZ �400,000 is to be returned to the United States in the shape of indemnities to American citizens, and that the whole of the remainder is to be appropriated by the Mexicans. And this is not all. The same organs congratulate the American people that the contemplated surrender of rights of way by Mexico to the United States will preclude any necessity for the American Government to commit themselves to the task of restoring order in Mexico generally, or indeed of taking any steps that would involve liabilities on their part either to the Mexican Government or to foreign nations. The power of transit and the command of eligible ports on the Atlantic and Pacific will, it is averred, fulfill every want that the American people can for the present entertain. Having military sway over these points, they can extend their operations at pleasure, and avow or disavow them as may be found expedient. "Sonora," it is remarked, "separated from the rest of Mexico by our transit line, can be occupied from California without trouble, and that province, from its mining wealth, is the one to be desired, while the southern districts, with their factions and their involvements, would bring nothing but annoyance." This doctrine would leave the Mexicans still to tear themselves to pieces, and to dishonor all their foreign obligations on the plea that they have no responsible Government. The argument resorted to in favor of the breach of faith with regard to the �800,000 is, that the purchase of rights of way is not a purchase of "territory," and that Mr. BUCHARAN's promise was intended only in the latter sense. If England were to sell to the Emperor of Russia the right of way from the Punjab to Calcutta, the Americans would probably question the logic that might pretend she had not parted with territory. Mexico must have sold something, because the Americans are not people to pay for an idea, and she has nothing to sell, except by consent of her creators. The bondholder have a claim on all the rove???ues of Mexico, and the �800,000 now to accrue is revenue of some land, either ordinary or extraordinary. Moreover, the retention of the �400,000 to meet the demands of American citizens, while the prior claims of British. French and Dutch citizens are disregarded, would stamp the whole arrangement as one of the most unjust upon record. At the same time it must be repeated that, although the friends of Mr. BUCHANAN have not disowned the intentions thus publicly attributed to his Cabinet, they have not formally admitted them. There is, consequently, room to hope that the respectable policy originally set forth by those who were entitled to express his views in this country, will yet be adhered to even in the face of popular clamor.

abstract: Fire Companies furnish a great safety valve through which much of the superfluous element of noise and riot escape, that otherwise might disturb the public peace even more seriously than the firemen themselves do. Your real fireman is a man of iron bones and India-rubber muscles, whose altar is his "tub," who snuffs the scent of smoke on the breeze from far, and on the instant becomes unconscious of every duty he owes to the world but that of reaching the conflagration with his machine in advance of any rival company. To convert the streets through which he "runs" into incipient bedlam, doesn't seem to be a part of his deliberate design, but only an incidental result of the general excitement to which his entire being is raised, which must find some vent, and so escapes as by the shortest passage through his lungs of hammered brass. He is known to possess too big a heart to knock down and run over innocent wayfarers whose path he crosses, with any malice aforethought, though he often performs the overt act with force and arms. That even nimble policemen cannot always escape his lightning movements, witness an officer jugernauted on Broadway yesterday by a hose carriage fireward bound. Though he escaped with only bloody bruises, and an enlarged causality, which would make a phrenologist stare, he seemed to relish the risk with much less fervor than the voluntary Hindoo victims of the heavy god are reputed to evince.

abstract: -- Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, whose merits as a delineator of a peculiar and excessively ludicrous phase of Yankee are well appreciated by the public, made her first appearance here, ast evening, after her recent provincial tour. The house was well attended, but the uncertainty concerning the appearance of the lady and her husband, Mr. BARNEY WILLIAMS -- owing to the known sickness of the latter, undoubtedly interfered with the full and liberal attendance which might have been anticipated under more favorable auspices. As it was Mr. BARNEY WILLIAMS was unable to make his appearance, and the labors of the evening, with its honors, fell upon Mrs. WILLIAMS. Three pieces were played: "Patience and Perseverance," -- which, we believe, is called new; �An Hour in Seville,� and �Perfection.� The first of these is a lame effort at a protean farce, and, although weak to the last degree, suffices as a vehicle for a couple of impersonations -- a Yankee girl and an Irish amazon -- by Mrs. WILLIAMS. Its success, which was of the quiet kind, must be ascribed to the very remarkable energy of this favorite artist. But to see her to decided advantage, the public should witness SELBY's farce of �An Hour in Seville,� wherein she has scope for her varied accomplishments. This was, of course, the success of the evening. The company engaged for the dramatic season here is not remarkable for its brilliancy. Probably it is reliable -- the qualification which managers never fail to dwell upon when their artists are not quite up to the metropolitan standard. Mrs. WILLIAMS was received with unbounded favor, and has undoubtedly entered upon a season of success. As the very best interpreter of the Yankee gal -- whatever may be said of the truthfulness of the picture -- and as an actress of unusual versatility, she deserves the approbation of the public.

abstract: The examination of WOOD, MURPHY, MURRAY, PERRY and BUCKLEY, was continued on Saturday before Justice NEWHALL of Lynn, and the government having finished its case, a large number of witnesses  were called for the defence. Their testimony was to the-effect that the parties were seen at times to do all in their power to preserve order, and that they appeared far from being desirous of inciting a riot. No decision was reached.

abstract: Complaints were made at the Mayor's office, yesterday, against JOHN SELOVER, JOHN E. ENRIGHT, and JOHN ELLIS -- three well-known characters -- for playing tricks upon strangers. It was the same old story, and the only fact worth mentioning is, that SELOVER could not be found when wanted by the officer; ENRIGHT managed to get free by outswearing the complainants; and ELLIS was made to disgorge. By the way, FOWLER, who was convicted and sentenced to the State prison some time ago, for similar practices, still remains at the Tombs, where he enjoys his otium and good dinners, confiding in the simplicity of justice and in the "higher law" of political influence.

abstract: Commodore STOCKTON has issued his manifesto regarding the railroad troubles in New-Jersey. He claims that the Joint Companies -- the Delaware and Raritan Canal, and the Camden and Amboy Railroad -- "have never done anything that they are not willing to proclaim from the top of the State House, if needs be." He then rehearses the history of the two companies, tells how he subscribed $400,000 to secure the Charter for the Canal, when it would otherwise have been forfeited, and sketches at length the process by which the consolidation of the two corporations was finally effected. The State, he claims, has reaffirmed its contract with the consolidated Company by the passage of numerous acts. "And where," he naively asks, "in looking over the vast field throughout the United States, now traveled by railroads and canals, will you find any achievements in the way of internal improvements which have conferred equal benefits on the people of the States in which they are found, at less cost? Where will you find a State the public works of which have been made a source of revenue sufficient to defray the whole annual expenses of the State Government? Where is there a State in which, besides defraying the expenses of the State Government, the revenues of her public works have contributed to construct its capital, its asylums, and its prisons? Could human wisdom devise a scheme more beneficial?" If the New-Jersey Road has lost the benefits which have accrued to it in times past from a participation in these privileges, Com. STOCKTON claims that it is itself to blame. The Consolidated Companies, he asserts most positively, were altogether innocent of any attempt to urge the State Legislature to the action which it has taken

abstract: The journeymen shoemakers of Philadelphia held a public meeting on Monday to express their sympathy with the Massachusetts strikers. Mr. W???.H. HARTMAN presided, and 200 workmen were present. A preamble and resolutions were read and adopted, expressing gratification at the stand taken by the cordwainers of New-England, and tendering to them the warmest sympathy of the cordwainers of Philadelphia for their success in the struggle. Mr. ISAAC J. NEAL, President of the Moulders' National Union, made an address, declaiming against the oppression of the laborer by the capitalist.

abstract: We are not a little gratified to see that the Tribune has taken up this subject for discussion, and hence are not inclined to find fault with the text it has selected for its first dissertation.
lead_paragraph: We are not a little gratified to see that the Tribune has taken up this subject for discussion, and hence are not inclined to find fault with the text it has selected for its first dissertation. It seems that Mr. LONGWORTH, of Cincinnati, has sent some baskets of his famous Catawba wine to our Minister at the Court of St. James for his private use, accompanying them with a liberal supply of samples, to be distributed by him to those who could appreciate it and aid in its circulation. This Mr. DALLAS declines to do, saying that he "cannot reconcile the duties of the Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States with those of a commission merchant." Such a reply, the Tribune asserts, Mr. LAWRENCE when Minister at the same Court would never have made. On the contrary, "not only Mr. LAWRENCE, but Mrs. LAWRENCE and Mr. BIGELOW LAWRENCE, and all attached to the Embassy, would have been more than happy to undertake the affair, which would have made quite a family piece of business." The editor accounts for this difference of the two men by the fact that, although the latter did not, in his youth, attend "for a single term a dancing school," and the former "was probably introduced to the mysteries of pigeon wing at a tender age," "Mr. GEORGE DALLAS is not a gentleman, and Mr. LAWRENCE was one. The process by which he proves and illustrates this assertion, some might object to. But it must be remembered that in presenting an entirely new topic, the Tribune cannot be expected to escape some of the errors that a longer and more careful study would prevent. Its novel position would also naturally create some little embarrassment. This attempt, however, should not be discouraged, but on the contrary should be generously supported. The effort to be witty, however, is not so promising. It is true there may be something side splitting in the stringing together of such words as "Prime Minister of his Highness the Duke of Kalbsbraten Pumpernickel, or of the Maid of Honor of Emillia Kunegunda Thomasina Chaaleria Emanuela Louisa Georgina, Princess of Saxe-Pumpernickel," and a recondite satire, also, in "callipash and callipee," -- still we are inclined to think these are designed as pleasant little pieces of alliteration.

abstract: At the meeting of the Historical Society last evening, it was announced that a series of lectures will shortly be given before the Society on the subject of Egyptian history, for the purpose of informing the members as to the propriety of purchasing the A???BOTT Egyptian collection. The munificent donation already referred to, as tendered by R.K. HAIGHT, consisting of costly works relating to the history of Egypt probably unsurpassed by any other collection in this country, was received. Autograph letters from HUMBOLDT and LAFAYETTE were also presented. The Society passed a unanimous vote of thanks to Mr. HAIGHT for his valuable gift. It was stated, and appeared to be the general opinion, that the liberality of the members would shortly enable the Society to add to its interesting properties the much-talked-of ABBOTT collection.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Historical Society last evening, it was announced that a series of lectures will shortly be given before the Society on the subject of Egyptian history, for the purpose of informing the members as to the propriety of purchasing the A???BOTT Egyptian collection. The munificent donation already referred to, as tendered by R.K. HAIGHT, consisting of costly works relating to the history of Egypt probably unsurpassed by any other collection in this country, was received. Autograph letters from HUMBOLDT and LAFAYETTE were also presented. The Society passed a unanimous vote of thanks to Mr. HAIGHT for his valuable gift. It was stated, and appeared to be the general opinion, that the liberality of the members would shortly enable the Society to add to its interesting properties the much-talked-of ABBOTT collection.

abstract: A shocking but painfully common casualty was repeated yesterday on the Delaware River. A new steamboat, named the Alfred Thomas, which had been built at Easton, to ply between Belvidere, New-Jersey, and Port Jervis, set out from Easton in the morning, to ascend the stream. There appears to have been a large number of passengers on board.
lead_paragraph: A shocking but painfully common casualty was repeated yesterday on the Delaware River. A new steamboat, named the Alfred Thomas, which had been built at Easton, to ply between Belvidere, New-Jersey, and Port Jervis, set out from Easton in the morning, to ascend the stream. There appears to have been a large number of passengers on board. Hardly had the boat passed from the sight of the starting place when the boiler exploded, tearing the hull to pieces, and violently scattering the passengers in all directions. The exact number of killed and wounded is still unascertained. Ten names of the dead have been given, and eleven of those seriously injured. It is feared the loss is much greater.

abstract: The Harlem Railroad Company, as all know, hold valuable franchises in this City for which the public have paid--but for which they have received no profit.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem Railroad Company, as all know, hold valuable franchises in this City for which the public have paid--but for which they have received no profit. The road have the entire monopoly of the Fourth-avenue, and have the right of way down to the Astor House, which they use to great benefit to themselves, at least. They are greedy for more, and take a very characteristic method of securing it. Very quietly last year they obtained the right to lay down another track through Madison-avenue, "whenever it should be opened." Very quietly they this year send men and money to Albany to have Madison-avenue opened; and by accident some owners of property hear of this, and at once send remonstrances to the gentlemen composing the Committee upon Cities and Villages in the Senate, to whom the proposed bill had been referred.

abstract: The German Turners gave a public exhibition yesterday, intended to show the practical use which can be made of certain descriptions of apparatus for saving life and property at fires. The place selected for the purpose was their Gymnasium in Orchardstreet, and the hour 4 o'clock P.M. A large crowd witnessed the experiments, testifying their admiration by shouts of applause at the successful termination of each feat.
lead_paragraph: The German Turners gave a public exhibition yesterday, intended to show the practical use which can be made of certain descriptions of apparatus for saving life and property at fires. The place selected for the purpose was their Gymnasium in Orchardstreet, and the hour 4 o'clock P.M. A large crowd witnessed the experiments, testifying their admiration by shouts of applause at the successful termination of each feat. The first thing tried was the canvas bag, which was similar to that used at a former trial at the City Hall, and which was then fully described. Mounting to the third story by means of their portable ladders, this instrument was hauled up by means of a cord, which was dropped for the purpose, and fastened to one of the open windows. One person after another, both adults and children, was then placed within its open mouth, and safely descended through It to the street, the lower end being held out at an angle which gradually retarded their velocity until they reached the ground. Various articles of furniture were also sent down in the same way without injury. The second were the story-ladders, strongly but lightly built, with a large curved hook at one end. Standing on the ground these ladders were raised by one man, who placed the hook over the window-sill of the second-story. He then mounted it, closely followed by one or two comrades, each having a strong canvas belt around his waist, attached to which, by a hook, was a roll of stout cord. While one held on to his companion by the belt to prevent his fall, the same ladder was instantly transferred to the third story, to which the two again mounted, entering the window, where they were supposed to be ready to rescue any person whose escape had been cut off, and pass him unharmed to the street by means of the canvas bag or he ladders.

abstract: THE SEASON AND THE PAVEMENTS.--The street and paving contractors are just now unusually busy making preparations for the opening of the Spring campaign, which so far as public works are concerned cannot commence until April. In the Sixth, Fifth and Fourth avenues, and in some of the cross streets, piles of blocks for the Belgian pavement are ...
lead_paragraph: THE SEASON AND THE PAVEMENTS. -- The street and paving contractors are just now unusually busy making preparations for the opening of the Spring campaign, which so far as public works are concerned cannot commence until April. In the Sixth, Fifth and Fourth avenues, and in some of the cross streets, piles of blocks for the Belgian pavement are accumulating, ready to be laid as soon as permission arrives from head-quarters. It is amusing, and possibly suggestive, to observe the different manner in which the stone is disposed of, according to the locality. In the Sixth-avenue, as in the Fourth, inhabited, it is to be presumed, only by the profanum vulgus, the blocks are discharged at the side of the carriage-way, where they have been left for weeks to collect the dirt and dust, and impede the current of water through the gutters, thus affording the finest facility for the filth to accumulate. In the Fifth-avenue, they are not only carefully but neatly piled in small, compact parcels, on the edge of the sidewalk, not at all impeding pedestrianism, even for crinoline, and leaving the entire width of the avenue free for the vehicles belonging to the monde who throng it. It is to be regretted that so much valuable time has been lost during the late pleasant weather, when our streets and avenues so much need repairing; but we learn from high authority that if any citizen of acknowledged responsibility will come forward and enter into proper bonds for a continuance of the present state of the weather, the high contracting powers will authorize their subjects to commence immediate operations. This opportunity for some one to earn the civic crown is so advantageous that we make the announcement gratuitously.

abstract: We perceive Mr. WOOD'S plan for a protective bureau for emigrants has been made a special order for the next meeting of the Common Council.
lead_paragraph: We perceive Mr. WOOD'S plan for a protective bureau for emigrants has been made a special order for the next meeting of the Common Council. We sincerely hope they will consign the project to the same grave with the day and night watch, the municipal distribution of flour and potatoes, and divers other products of our worthy Mayor's fertile imagination, which happily for the City have never been carried into execution. We discussed this emigrant bureau when the plan was first propounded, immediately after the election, and showed beyond question that it was entirely unnecessary, inasmuch as far more was done for emigrants by organizations already in existence, than the new scheme could ever effect under the most favorable circumstances. Testimony from various quarters, as to what the Commissioners of Emigration now do, and what the police did do, for emigrants and other strangers, under the orders of Superintendent PILSBURY, has since given ample confirmation to what we then stated.
headline: {'main': 'The Protective Bureau Scheme.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Protective Bureau Scheme.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Legislature seems inclined to made provision for the wants of the City in the matter of locomotion. The Committee of the Assembly has reported bills providing for five new lines of Railroad from the upper part of the City to the lower.
lead_paragraph: The Legislature seems inclined to made provision for the wants of the City in the matter of locomotion. The Committee of the Assembly has reported bills providing for five new lines of Railroad from the upper part of the City to the lower. The grants are made to certain persons named in the bills: the routes which the roads shall follow are prescribed: the consent of the Common Council is not asked, but that honorable body is required to furnish all needed aid for the construction of these roads, and never to grant permission for the construction of any others. Naturally enough, our City Government resents being thus summarily squelched, and measures have already been taken in the two Boards to protest energetically against the menaced action of the Legislature.

abstract: Now that the affairs of nations are shaping themselves so auspiciously for renewed peace confidence and commercial activity and success, the first urgent call of the new era is for greater and stronger help from the forces and materials of Nature--from heat, from electricity, from the metals and chemical agents,-- ...
lead_paragraph: Now that the affairs of nations are shaping themselves so auspiciously for renewed peace confidence and commercial activity and success, the first urgent call of the new era is for greater and stronger help from the forces and materials of Nature -- from heat, from electricity, from the metals and chemical agents, -- help to hasten and cheapen our manufactures, production, transportation and intercommunication. We want cheap bread, cheap iron, cheap locomotion, -- we want that great art of peace, that mother of useful arts -- cheap power. And the people which takes the lead in the commercial availability of its engineering and mechanical works, will lead the world. NAPOLEON is not only a diplomatist, a financier and a general -- he is an engineer; and in this leading department of commercial greatness he is marshaling a mightier force than the army of Italy -- the scientific workers and thinkers of France. England is preparing for the peaceful encounter with millions of money and the talent of all nations, encouraging the useful arts by Government schools and institutions, by adopting and monopolizing the services of men who are without honor in their own country, by covering the ocean with her iron screw ships, by cheapening the cost of speed and power, by pushing her railways and steamers into every path of commerce, and by doubling the production of her dominions through steam agriculture.
headline: {'main': 'Wants of a Commercial Age.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wants of a Commercial Age.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
