abstract: The annual Commencement of the Medical Department of the University of New-York was held last night, in the Chapel of the University building, in Washington-square. Long before the Chancel
lead_paragraph: The annual Commencement of the Medical Department of the University of New-York was held last night, in the Chapel of the University building, in Washington-square. Long before the Chancelor, with the members of the Faculty, made their appearance, every seat was filled, and there was scarcely standing-room in the aisles. As on all such interesting occasions, the ladies were present in large numbers, many, indeed most of them, betraying by their conversation that a son, a brother, a cousin or a friend among the graduates was foremost in her thoughts, in connection with the ceremonies of the evening. DODWORTH's fine band was in attendance, and played many popular tunes at intervals. The proceedings were opened with the reading of Scripture and a prayer by Dr. FFREIS, after which he proceeded to announce the list of graduates for the present year, as follows:

abstract: The subject of Arctic exploration is again engaging the attention of the American Geographical Society; and a report, cordially recommending the project, has recently been presented to that
lead_paragraph: The subject of Arctic exploration is again engaging the attention of the American Geographical Society; and a report, cordially recommending the project, has recently been presented to that body by Mr. EGBERT L. VIELE, chairman of the special committee appointed last year to consider the matter. The design of this new expedition is to continue the surveys of Dr. KANE, and to confirm his discovery of the open Polar Sea � a discovery which has been disputed in the Royal Geographical Society of London.

abstract: One of the most serious charges brought, at the South against Northern Abolitionists, has been that they were in favor of amalgamation, � the intermarriage of the blacks and whites. The Raleigh (N.C.) Democratic Press mentions a case, however, which shows that all the tendencies towards establishing such relations are not in the Northern States. A young lady, described as of "extraordinary beauty and superior attainments, � the daughter of wealthy and respectable parents in Sampson County, N.C., and who has hitherto moved in the most respectable society," � recently attempted to elope with a "negro fellow, the property of her cousin." It seems the plan was all arranged, � the two had started for the Railroad station, and it was only by the lady's endeavoring to borrow some money for her journey, that she was suspected, and finally constrained to confess the whole affair. She publicly expressed her determination, says the Press "to marry the black rascal when she got to the North." The same paper coolly says, "It is to be regretted that she acted so improperly and unbecoming a lady."
lead_paragraph: One of the most serious charges brought, at the South against Northern Abolitionists, has been that they were in favor of amalgamation, � the intermarriage of the blacks and whites. abstract: What title half the length of Broadway has to any other appellation than that of a rubbish yard, it is difficult to understand. It is no doubt necessary when a new building goes up, to occupy for some
lead_paragraph: What title half the length of Broadway has to any other appellation than that of a rubbish yard, it is difficult to understand. It is no doubt necessary when a new building goes up, to occupy for some time the street in front for depositing building materials. But who can explain the necessity of leaving the regulation of the sidewalk until after every nail in the house has been driven? Yet this is the course that builders on Broadway almost universally pursue. If a new house is to be erected, first the sidewalk is torn up, as an earnest of the builder's intentions; and there it remains, an impassable barrier to the current of public travel, till the house is finished and furnished even to the last nail and serew. The Reade-street widening operations have just broken out into Broadway, and among the earliest results is the commencement of an Egyptian pyramid of bricks across the sidewalk and half the street. If the obstruction were likely to be only temporary, it might be endurable in view of the advantages that will result from the widening of the cross streets. But an accumulation of this sort once begun is a chronic ill, so far as the present generation is concerned. Some of those new living, when in coming years they pass this spot, may say to their children's sons, reviving the memories of their youth, I remember when over the very piace where this huge pile now stands ran a busy thoroughfare, crowded with an active throng, a condition of things which possibly the youngest of his listoners may live to see renewed. If the evil occurread in but a single place, it might be proper to require builders to clear the sidewalk within a reasonable time after its first obstruction. But with a renewal of the nuisance in almost every block, and every week, the public passage is so seriously impeded as to render it highly necessary that permission should be extended to erect new buildings only on condition of continuing the obstruction the shortest possible time.

abstract: Mayor WOOD'S three organs, the Herald, Tribune and Daily News, are perfectly harmonious in their vindication of the action of the Police Commissioners, which has led to the re
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD'S three organs, the Herald, Tribune and Daily News, are perfectly harmonious in their vindication of the action of the Police Commissioners, which has led to the retirement of the Superintendent, and the substantial disorganization of the Department. It is edifying to see three organs, which have so few notes or tones in common, piping precisely the same tune, varied only by the temper and quality of the wind by which they are blown. The News denounces the one-man power, when it is to be wielded by any body but the immaculate FERNANDO; - the Herald rejoices in the overthrow of the "Pious PILSBURY," -- and the Tribune is gratified that the Department has got rid of a man who insisted upon "power" enough to perform the duties for which he is held responsible. Behold a "specimen brick" from each of the fraternal trio:

abstract: The first case disposed of yesterday in this Court was that of Louis Barnowfsky, a Pole, who was indicted, with Charles Murphy, for a grand larceny committed in the store of Hamill &Co., No. 540 Pearl-street, on the 25th January. The property stolen consisted of fifty pounds of se wing silk, worth $300. Barnowfsky was arrested on the spot; Murphy jumped from a window to avoid arrest and broke both his legs. He was taken to the City Hospital, where he now is. Yesterday Barnowfsky pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to four years and seven months in the State Prison.

abstract: We understand that all Charleston is in a bustle of preparation for the coming Democratic Convention. At all the hotels in the city, notice has been given to the regular boarders that their rooms will be wanted from the middle of April, � and that from that time they must make arrangements for their accommodation elsewhere. The army of Northerners which is expected to invade Charleston at that time, it is supposed, will so enrich the hotel-keepers of that goodly city that they can afford to retire from business, and lead thenceforward lives of dignified ease.

abstract: The proceedings of the Senate yesterday were almost entirely confined to the delivery of a speech by Mr. WADE, of Ohio, in response to a recent speech of Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia. Mr. WADE
lead_paragraph: The proceedings of the Senate yesterday were almost entirely confined to the delivery of a speech by Mr. WADE, of Ohio, in response to a recent speech of Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia. Mr. WADE represents the radical portion of the Republican Party, and gave utterance to many opinions which will scarcely find embodiment in the Chicago Platform. Much of the effect of his oratory is of course lost, with the absence of the peculiar manner which characterizes the Western Senator, and gives vigor to his massive and ponderous blows; but the speech as given at some length by our special reporter is well deserving of attention. In the House, where but a handful of members were present, Mr. VAN WYCK, of New-York, spoke on the sectional issue, with great spirit, directness, and shrewd sense. It was feared that his remarks would provoke an assault upon his person; and for a while the wildest confusion prevailed. The House, after listening to Mr. PERRY, of Maine, upon the same topic, adjourned without further incident.

abstract: The West Indian, published at Bridgetown, Barbados, under date of Feb. 15, contains a long account of a destructive fire at Bridgetown on the night of Feb. 13. The fire broke out in Mr. ALLEYNE'S lum
lead_paragraph: The West Indian, published at Bridgetown, Barbados, under date of Feb. 15, contains a long account of a destructive fire at Bridgetown on the night of Feb. 13. The fire broke out in Mr. ALLEYNE'S lumber-yard, from which it spread to Mr. JONES', adjoining, and Messrs. BARROW & DUMMENTT's dry goods establishment in High-street; and before any effectual means of checking it were available, it became uncontrollable. From BARROW & DUMMENTT'S it spread to the ice-house. It then seized upon the large buildings of the Commissariat Office and the houses on the opposite side of High-street, which were soon enveloped in flames. On the other side the fire spread from ALLEYNE'S and JONES' lumber and coal yards, across Stable-street to Messrs. THROWBRIDGE'S stores, into Mar[???]hill-street in the east and the Green on the south.

abstract: The criminal records of Paris preserve the name of an individual who committed murder as a short and easy cut to suicide. He was weary of life, but lacked the courage to "snip the fatal thread" himself, so he killed the first person he met in the street, and gave himself up to justice with the assured hope, as he fancied, that he would be sent to the guillotine. He was deceived, poor fellow, for the court pronounced him merely insane, and sent him to Charenton. If there are any persons of the like mind in New-York, we can recommend them to try the good offices of Senor CAMECHO, the Consul of Venezuela in this City, and secure themselves an occupation in that country. So incessant is the round of wars and revolutions in the Republic, that they may rely on finding a chance to "shuffle off this mortal coil" within a week of their landing. To less desperate people the same gentleman also addresses himself. He offers to receive and forward gratuitously to La Guayra, Caracas, Porto Cabello, and other Venezuelan ports, all kinds of information relative to American manufactures and American commerce, and thus to foster mercantile relations with that  country. We wish the Consul all possible success in his undertaking; but we cannot help fancying that, excepting as a certain cure in cases of confirmed ennui, life in Venezuela is not just now exactly in a condition to tempt the outside world into making its better acqnaintance.

abstract: Martin vs. The Mayor, &c., and three other cases. � In these cases judgments were originally rendered in favor of the plaintiffs in the Marine Court. The Comptroller, under the Tax Levy act of 1859, made a motion to open the judgments, in the Court of Common Pleas, upon affidavits alleging his belief in the existence of collusion and fraud in obtaining the judgments. The Court of Common Pleas held that in cases like these, where only it became cognizant of the judgment by the filing of a transcript in the office of its clerk, it would not interfere to set the judgment aside, and denied the motion. A similar motion was then made in the Marine Court, in each of these cases, for the purpose of vacating the judgments.

lead_paragraph: THINGS HARD TO BE UNDERSTOOD.--This was the theme of a lecture delivered last evening by Rev. T.L. BRECKENRIDGE, of Indiana, before the Christian Young Men's Lyceum, at the First Baptist Church in Broome-street. After repudiating the announcement in the Tribune of Tuesday, that those who went to hear him would hear the last lecture of the season he proceeded to say that some twenty years ago', while on a horseback journey from Zanesville, ohio, to Marietta he fell in with a gentleman of education, who claimed to be also a philosopher. The conversation turning upon religious subjects, his companion astonished him by the assertion that there were no thoughts in the Bible calculated to make a man, and that TOM PAINE was the greatest man that ever lived. He replied that he professed to be a Christian, and to believe in the Bible. His friend retorted by repeating his assertion that there were no thoughts in the Bible, and by asking whether it was not reasonable that God, if he intended to give a revelation to man, would not present it in such form that every man could understand it. To this question he was obliged then, to give an affirmative answer; but since that time he had learned something, and he now believed that there was not a thought of any human creature but what was in the Bible. Much of it was hard to understand, and that, to his mind, was the best proof of its authenticity and divinity. After reading PAINE or VOLTAIRE, one could understand all that the writer understood, but not so with the Bible. The speaker then proceeded to specify a large variety of things contained in the Bible, that were hard to be understood, such for instance as the existence of God, his attributes, purposes and decrees; the creation of matter, the Trinity of the Godhead, the regeneration of the human soul, the resurrection of the body, &c., &c. � all of them hard to be understood, but none the less true. We were not asked to understand these things, but to believe them. Many anecdotes were related illustrative of his argument, one of which relating to DANIEL WEBSTER was as follows: A disbeliever lin Divine Revelation once addressed him saying "Mr. WEBSTER, you are a man of too much intellect to believe that one is three, or three is one." "Sir," said Mr. WEBSTER, "the Bible teaches me that there are three persons in the Godhead, and I am not vain enough to profess to understand the mathematics of Heaven." The speaker closed by saying that many of his hearers might be disposed to ask why he had made a public lecture approach so near to a sermon. He would tell them why: Public lectures, in his opinion, had become a nuisance, a disgrace, and a curse; and the reason they had become so was because they had too too often trampled upon the sacred precincts of the Word of God. He believed in science, in education, and in the diffusion of knowledge, � but it must all be based upon the word of God; if not, it was useless, and worse than useless � it was untrue.

abstract: MENA ZEHL, a young German woman, who had been married but three months, had an altercation with her husband on Tuesday evening with reference to the ownership of $12, saved from their mutual earnings as shoemaker and laundress, which was on deposit in a Savings Bank. The young wife insisted that she was entitled to the cash, whill her husband stoutly contended that it belonged to him. Without a reconciliation the husband left home, and on returning in a short time was horrified to discover that dead, suspended by the neck to a clothes-line post on the roof of the building. Coroner JACKMAN held on inquest, which resulted in a verdict of "suicide by hanging."

lead_paragraph: Among the many very odd notions of law and politics, which the discussions on Slavery have been the means of bringing to light, Senator BROWN'S theory of international obligations may be set down as decidedly the most striking and original. He is indignant, as are most of his neighbors and constituents, at the steady flow of fugitive slaves into Canada, through the instrumentality of the underground railroad, and he agrees with Gov. WISE about the propriety of making the matter a cause of war with Great Britain. Says this great publicist:

abstract: John Dufly vs George B. Schenck. � This was an action by the plaintiff, who was formerly United States Consul at Galway, to recover damages of the defendant for an assault and battery, under the following circumstances: The plaintiff states that on the 9th day of November, 1857, he went on board the steamship Alabama, then lying in this port, bound for Savannah, and paid his passage money to the proper officer; that subsequently, while the vessel was off Sandy Hook, he was assaulted by the defendant, who was then Captain of the steamer, and at his command, was suspended in a small boat from the side of the steamer, and there imprisoned for "the space of an hour;" that he was beaten with lists and heavy pistols; that, although he had paid his passage money, he was finally set ashore in a "dreary and desolate region," where he suffered much from privation, &c., &c.; that he was compelled to wade to the shore when the boat had reached a fordable point, a pistol being put to his head, and he ordered to perform that feat; that his trunk was thrown overboard and lost. For all this abuse he thought $10,000 a fair forfeit.

abstract: Items. � The alarm of fire, Wednesday evening, proceeded from the fringe factory of WM. PRIME, No. 88 Fulton-street. The fire was extinguished with loss of about $100. The loss is covered by insurance ...House No. 34 Scholes-street was robbed Tuesday night of property valued at $30....WM. MATHEWS, seaman, 40 years old, was found dead in Baltic, near Summer-street, Tuesday night. It is supposed that he died in a fit....A young fellow named WM. DICK was brought before Justice CORNWELL yesterday on a charge of biting off a piece of EDWARD RILEY's thumb. He was convicted and sent to the Penitentiary for six months....C.P. SMITH, Esq., has been reelected President of the Board of Education. The Board of Education has directed that Public School-house No. 13 shall be rebuilt on the plan of No.15, so that each department, male, female and primary, shall occupy one floor.

abstract: Bench warrants were issued last December from the Erie County Court of Oyer and Terminer for the apprehension of James Kelly and Edward Price, principals in a prize fight which occurred a few day's previous in Canada. Price's home is in Boston, but Kel
lead_paragraph: Bench warrants were issued last December from the Erie County Court of Oyer and Terminer for the apprehension of James Kelly and Edward Price, principals in a prize fight which occurred a few day's previous in Canada. Price's home is in Boston, but Kelly makes this City his abiding place, and consequently the police have been seeking him diligently ever since. He, however, successfully eluded their search until yesterday afternoon, when Detective Eustace surprised him at his house, corner of Eighth-avenue and Thirty-seventh-street, and managed to secure his arrest. The prisoner was brought down to head-quarters, where numbers of sporting men soon congregated to sympathize with him and devise means for his release. Finally Judge RUSSELL happened to come in, by chance of course, and was prevailed upon, at the earnest solicitation of Kelly's friends, to open Court and admit the prisoner to bail. The accommodating Judge fixed the surety at $l,000 for Kelly's eppearance, on Monday next, before the Court at Buffalo, and Peter Hamill, of No. 387 East Tenth-street, became his bondsman. Other devotees of the ring have also been indicted by the Buffalo authorities for participating in the same fight, and some of them, including John Morissey and Tom O'Donnel, have been arrested, tried and fined in sums of $200 and $300 upon conviction of the offence. Deputy-Sheriff Tyler, of Buffalo, who was present to take Kelly to that city, was not well pleased with the action of the City Judge.

abstract: The Democratic Ratification Meeting held here to-night was one of the largest ever held in this city. Hundreds were unable to get into Masonic Hall. Dr. McCook presided, with a large number of Vice-Presidents. The meeting was first addressed by Judge SHANNON, who was greeted with universal applause. He spoke with great feeling and effect relative to the proceedings of the State Convention at Reading. His speech was eminently conservative, strongly anti-Seward, and expressive of earnest feeling for a united Democracy. Gov. SAMUEL W. BLACK, of Nebraska, also made a brilliant speech of two hours' duration, reviewing the Slavery question throughout, making points of telling effect. Several other speeches were made. The utmost harmony prevailed, and the greatest enthusiasm was manifested.

His speech was eminently conservative, strongly anti-Seward, and expressive of earnest feeling for a united Democracy. Gov. SAMUEL W. BLACK, of Nebraska, also made a brilliant speech of two hours' duration, reviewing the Slavery question throughout, making points of telling effect. Several other speeches were made. The utmost harmony prevailed, and the greatest enthusiasm was manifested.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met last evening, pursuant to adjournment, and after a quiet session of a little over half an hour, adjourned until Monday. The usual routine of petitions was presented, and of course they were appropriately referred, the President assuming ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met last evening, pursuant to adjournment, and after a quiet session of a little over half an hour, adjourned until Monday. The usual routine of petitions was presented, and of course they were appropriately referred, the President assuming [???] con the authority thus to dispose of them. One of the petitioners, however, whose name the reporter could not catch -- for the reporter's table is so placed that nothing which ought to be unsaid is ever heard -- was particularly fortunate. He had engaged to pave a portion of Eighty-eighth street, and to have it completed within a precise time. He now petitioned for an extension of time on account of "the lateness of the season, and the scarcity of material," and as he had passed the Board of Aldermen, his appeal to the Councilmen could not go unheeded. The time asked for was granted, and the only addition to the assessment list, for those who are interested, will consistin the additional pay of the Inspector, with the possibility of further calls, by reason of "the lateness of the season, or the scarcity of material."

abstract: The Nova Scotian, from Liverpool on the 22d ult., put into St. Johns, Newfoundland, last evening, short of coal. Her advices are four days later. The American ship Luna, from New-Orleans ...
lead_paragraph: The Nova Scotian, from Liverpool on the 22d ult., put into St. Johns, Newfoundland, last evening, short of coal. Her advices are four days later. The American ship Luna, from New-Orleans for Havre, had been cast away on the French coast, and, of eighty-eight passengers and twenty-two seamen on board, but two were saved. A vote upon Mr. DISRAELI'S motion to anticipate the consideration of the French Treaty had resulted in favor of the Ministry by a majority of 63. This was thought to indicate the feeling of the House of Commons towards the treaty, and its chances of ratification. From China we have the gratifying intelligence that the damages suffered in 1856 by American citizens in China are in a fair way to liquidation. The first installment of the indemni-ty is ready for payment, and the remainder will follow at an early day.

abstract: The new Police bill which is now before the Legislature, reducing the Board to three members, if it is intended to remedy the defects of the present system, as recently revealed, must give the superintendent the absolute control of ...
lead_paragraph: The new Police bill which is now before the Legislature, reducing the Board to three members, if it is intended to remedy the defects of the present system, as recently revealed, must give the superintendent the absolute control of the force, simply making him responsible to the Commission for the proper exercise of his authority, and removable by them for good cause, proved by public investigation in the usual manner. We care not who succeeds Mr. PILSBURY in the post, unless this is done the Police will never be what it ought to be. It is as ridiculous to attempt to govern it by the direct orders of three persons as it would be to command an army by the same means. The supreme power; from which there should be no appeal, must be lodged in the hands of some one man. To giving it to the Mayor, as under the old system, there is the standing and insurmountable objection that the Mayor is generally a professional politican, occupied during the whole of his official term either in intriguing for reflection or for some other species of political advancement. To expect him, under such circumstances, in a City like New-York, to religiously abstain from all at tempts to use a body of 2,000 men for the ad vancement of his own ends, is to expect him to be a much nobler animal than any that has yet figured on the political stage, in this part of the world at least. The commanding officer of such a police as New-York is entitled to have should be well paid and hold his office during good behavior. He should have no hopes or fears outside the line of his duty, and he should be removed after trial and conviction for any interference, direct or indirect, in politics; and his control over the men should be similar to that exercised over a regiment of the line by its Colonel.
headline: {'main': 'A Police System.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Police System.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The examination in the case of CHAS. RITTER, who was killed on board the sloop-of-war Brooklyn, in November last, was brought to a conclusion at Staten Island late on Wednesday night. In addition to the testimony heretofore published, the evidence of Corporals POWELL and HAYES, privates BERRY and MCLAUGHLIN, Chief-Engineer FOLLANSBEE; DUNLY, seaman; GRAHAM, commander of Marines, and BROWN, sailmaker, was taken for the defence. The testimony tended mainly to show that RITTER came to his death not from any violence used by RAY or others, but if at all, by the application of the gag which was applied by COOPER, by order of RAY. The evidence in favor of the mild and humane character of RAY was unanimous. There can be little doubt that the gag was the cause of RITTER's death, as he died in fifteen minutes after it was applied, and that the gag was used without authority, as the captain has testified that no one had a right to use it without orders from him.
lead_paragraph: The examination in the case of CHAS. RITTER, who was killed on board the sloop-of-war Brooklyn, in November last, was brought to a conclusion at Staten Island late on Wednesday night. The testimony tended mainly to show that RITTER came to his death not from any violence used by RAY or others, but if at all, by the application of the gag which was applied by COOPER, by order of RAY. The evidence in favor of the mild and humane character of RAY was unanimous. There can be little doubt that the gag was the cause of RITTER's death, as he died in fifteen minutes after it was applied, and that the gag was used without authority, as the captain has testified that no one had a right to use it without orders from him.

abstract: The bill providing for a Government Printingoffice was to-day reported from the Committee on Printing, and aided by a report soon to be made from the Committee on Public Expenditures, the probabilities ...
lead_paragraph: The bill providing for a Government Printingoffice was to-day reported from the Committee on Printing, and aided by a report soon to be made from the Committee on Public Expenditures, the probabilities are it will lead to some change in the present mode of having printing done. The contract system has been exploded. The Superintendent reports that under this system work was so badly done that some books will have to be reprinted. Another fact worthy of notice is that the contractors never cease to be claimants for additional compensation. Estimates were sent in to-day by the Superintendent of Printing for deficiencies running back to the Thirty-fifth, the Thirty-fourth and the Thirty-third Congresses.

abstract: We published yesterday a dispatch from Mr. FREDERICK A. AIKEN, giving an account of a fight, or an attempted fight, between Col. LANDER, Superintendent of the Overland ...
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a dispatch from Mr. FREDERICK A. AIKEN, giving an account of a fight, or an attempted fight, between Col. LANDER, Superintendent of the Overland >Wagon-road expedition, and WILLIAM J. MAGRAW, freight contractor, a late Superintendent of the same concern. The affair appears to have possessed all the elements necessary to constitute a Washington row, pushing, scuffling, pointing of pistols, calling of names, and great disturbance of peaceable bystanders. It, however, possesses nothing to distinguish it from the most of these encounters, except Col. LANDER's final address to the vanquished or the peaceable MAGRAW, to which we cannot help calling attention, as it appears to be a compendium of the "code" as in force amongst the Washington gentility. LANDER, according to his friend's story, informed MAGRAW that he was "a liar, coward and scoundrel," and then offered to fight anybody in the crowd whom this intelligence might startle or annoy. As nobody seemed to be in the least overcome by it, he delivered his final apostrophe to MAGRAW himself, as follows:

abstract: Commodore STOCKTON'S manifesto has brought out a reply from Messrs. DARCY, GREGORY, JACKSON and others, a Committee of the Directors of the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. The document is addressed to the Legislature of New-Jersey, and combats the Commodore at all points. The Committee accumulates testimony to prove a  united design" between the Hoboken Land Improvement Company and the Joint Companies against the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company; charge the Commodore with the commission of material mistakes in the' interpretation of their contracts, and add: "Surely the most open evidence is furnished of cooperation and congratulation by 'the members of the Joint Companies, attached to Mr. STEVENS by the ties of consanguinity or friendship." Mr. R.F. STOCKTON'S himself, may not have been quite as conpicuous a participant in these scenes; still his quo animo is shown by his manifesto, and especially by his taunt at the discontinuance of Mr. STEVENS' subside, 'that the stockholders of the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company will regret that they recklessly disturbed their contract with Mr. STEVENS."

abstract: If there be one thing upon which our British kinsfolk pride themselves more particularly than upon another, it is the innate reverence which is supposed to be felt by every well-constituted British mind at once for the majesty ...
lead_paragraph: If there be one thing upon which our British kinsfolk pride themselves more particularly than upon another, it is the innate reverence which is supposed to be felt by every well-constituted British mind at once for the majesty of the law and for the sanctity of private rights. Bland and persuasive British publicists do not hesitate to assure the world, whenever Spain winces at the sight of the meteor flag floating from the Rook of Gibraltar, or the isles of Greece, "where burning SAPPHO loved and sung," lift up their Phil-Hellenic outcry against the protecting Lion, that the freedom of the seas would never be safe for a moment if England were not its absolute mistress; and that the great objection which Englishmen feel to the increase of the maritime power of other nations is founded upon their disinterested conviction that no other people in Christendom can be trusted to rule the waves on principles of universal equity. Political philosophers, reasoning in the classic shades of the Whig "Athenaeum" and the Tory "Carlton," upon the secrets of Government, are continually lost in amazement over the fact that countries like the United States should continue to preserve even the semblance of civilization, surrendered over as they are to the passions of the populace, and the fickle impulses of the vulgar mind, with no ballast of solid personal privileges or venerable vested wrongs, grown almost rights by the sheer force of time and habit. It is not astonishing, then, that publicists and philoso-phers both should be slightly staggered � not to say confounded � whenever a sudden turn in the wheel of the national fortune brings them face to face with something merely human and imperfect in the constitution of British society. Just as Walcheren calamities, Crimean blunders, Chinese catastrophes, Great Eastern failures sorely try the true Briton's faith in the immeasurable superiority of the "practical Anglo-Saxon " over less favored races of men in dealing with the details and facts of life, so must Bristol mobs and Gordon riots sharply test his equally solemn faith in the lawabiding genius of his people. There is, therefore, nothing very surprising in the down-right dead-lock to which the Home Administration of England has just been brought by the orgies of a crew of bacchanalian Protestants in the heart of the great metropolis. Things on the whole run so smoothly in London between the authorities and the people, the law gets itself executed in the main so steadily and unconcernedly, that when the Home Secretary, and the Commissioner of the Police, and the Magistrates, un-expectedly find themselves confronted with a horde of howling rowdies shouting out their husky anathemas against golden candlesticks, green silk chasubles, intoned prayers, and the apparatus of Puseyism generally, crowding into churches where the rites of unpopular clerical craze are carried on, singing comic songs during divine service, plucking choristers by the coat-tail, and pelting parsons with peas-it is the most natural thing in life that the dignitaries of order should be brought up, in the slang of the road, "all standing." Yet we of New-York who do duty so constantly in the British Press as the model "bad boys" of Christendom, and who have gradually wrought ourselves up to the belief that ours is a kind of Topsy among cities, "so wicked" that it is useless for us to try to mend our ways, may be forgiven for finding a mild satisfaction in the discomfiture and humiliation of our stately cousins, who are so very liberal of their moral lectures whenever our patriotic youth undertake to criticise a foreign actor with brickbats in Astor-place, or to settle a political difference with revolvers over a Dead Rabbit barricade.

abstract: It is not generally known, we presume, that, notwithstanding the multifarious duties which crowd upon the Commissioners, they are not insensible to the demands of science, and pay due regard to its claims. Many months ago, tables were prepared under the direction of Mr. CRAVEN, the Chief-Engineer. for ihe purpose of recording the temperature of the air and water at five different points on the line of the Aqueduct, viz., at the dam, at Tarrytown, at a point about five miles above the High Bridge, and at Eighty-sixth and Forty-second streets. The temperature of the air and water is taken three times daily the tables being forwarded and duly recorded, for permanent use, by Mr. WINDER, chief clerk in the office of Mr. CRAVEN. From the February record, as kept at Tarrytown, and which is within half a degree the counterpart of ihe other stations, we Rather that the temperature of the water in the aqueduct ranged from 33"째;;;;" to 35"째", while ihe temperature of the arrranged from 50"째" to 9"째" below zero -- the one varying only two degrees, the other sixty-eight: a fact for which philosophers must account. The water in the aqueduct has only varied one inch during the month, viz., from 4 feet 6 inches to 4 feet 7 inches.

abstract: The monthly return of the Receiver of Taxes, which was presented to the Comptroller yesterday, presents, in one sense, a remarkable state of facts-- viz.; that never, or as near to never as the oldest inhabitant can recollect, has there been at this season so ...
lead_paragraph: The monthly return of the Receiver of Taxes, which was presented to the Comptroller yesterday, presents, in one sense, a remarkable state of facts-- viz.; that never, or as near to never as the oldest inhabitant can recollect, has there been at this season so small an amount of uncollected taxes for the year. It may, perhaps, be accounted for by the unusual abundance of money, and the low rates at which it has for many months sought employment; or that parties owing for taxes chose to save the twelve per cent. added to the bills of delinquents.

abstract: William Gordon keeps an establishment for the manufacture of coats at No. 18 West Thirty-sixthstreet, and employs a number of girls to work on his sewing machines. His seamstresses allege that they have been greatly inconvenienced and imposed upon ...
lead_paragraph: William Gordon keeps an establishment for the manufacture of coats at No. 18 West Thirty-sixthstreet, and employs a number of girls to work on his sewing machines. His seamstresses allege that they have been greatly inconvenienced and imposed upon for weeks past by the failure of their employer to give them their wages. At length, becoming weary of his promises, four of the young ladies, named Mary Dalrymple, Mary T. Morton, Josephine Marun, and Catharine Kelly, decided upon following him to the wholesale clothing store of Messrs. O. B. Tweed & Co., Nos. 120 and 128 Duanestreet, for whom he manufactured clothing, and there demand their wages at the moment he received payment for his work from the proprietors of the establishment. Yesterday they put their plan into operation, and the relation of their wrongs at once secured for them the sympathy of the clothing dealers' employes, several of whom held Mr. Gordon, while Mr. King, the book keeper, it is said, dispossessed him of $86 87 which had just been paid him. The young women said that $38 50 would cover their demands against Gordon, and that sum was accordingly handed to them, while the balance, $48 37, was returned to Gordon. The girls left the place elated with their success, and Gordon, considerably excited and more chap fallen, started for Jeflerson Market police Court, where he asked Justice quackenoush to issue. a warrant for King's arrest on a charge of rebbery, A fiet hearing all the circumstances, the magistrate refosed to entertain such a complaint, buy, sent for the accused to appear and answer a charge and battery.

abstract: A bill incorporating the "New-York and Brooklyn Cab Company" was the other day submitted to the Legislature. This Company proposes to carry a single passenger any distance in this City within the limits bounded by ...
lead_paragraph: A bill incorporating the "New-York and Brooklyn Cab Company" was the other day submitted to the Legislature. This Company proposes to carry a single passenger any distance in this City within the limits bounded by the North and East Rivers and Forty-second-street, for twenty-five cents; each additional passenger to pay fifteen cents. The same rates of fare are to rule in Brooklyn, and transfer tickets will be issued so that one paying fifty cents on this side of the river may take a cab belonging to the Company in Brooklyn, and be carried immediately, and without added charge, to his destination. These rates are so low when compared with the extortionate prices which the law permits hackdrivers in general to ask for their services, that a doubt arises as to whether they would be remunerative. The doubt, however, hardly constitutes a ground of objection to the organization of the company, and if Mr. A.A. MYERS, who introduced the bill, will only give it a gentle shake occasionally, that it may not slumber too soundly on the Speaker's table, steady its feeble steps until it manages to totter through the lower House, and then consign it to the mercy of some gentle Senator, who shall ultimately send us the bantling for further training, he will secure the gratitude of a long suffering community.

abstract: SENT TO JAIL. � Three Germans, named E. GOTTLEIB, HENEY LEUR and EDWARD LERT, were tried before Justice CORNWELL yesterday, on a complaint preferred by Inspector WHITE, of the Eighth Precinct, for having violated a city ordinance by skinning a cow which had died of disease. They were found guilty, and sentenced to pay a fine of $50 each, or in default of payment to be sent to the jail for fifty days. Not being able to pay the fine they were locked up.

abstract: We are again indebted to Adams' Express for New-Orleans papers, through in four days. The last Picayune announces that the Southwestern Agent of this Company has been compelled to issue a public caution against the sending of letters by express, that act being a viola tion of the postal law. It seems that Southern m[???]chants have essayed to improve the opportunity of rapid communication which private enterprise has furnished. Their letters, however, must await the slow motions of the Government agents. Express Companies can legally carry only newspaper packages, or such letters as relate to parcels conveyed by the express, unless in a Government envelope.

abstract: Opening of A NEW SCHOOL.--The new Schoolhouse for Ward School No.20, situated in Broomestreet, between Clinton and Suffolk streets, was opened publicly yesterday morning. Mr. GEORGE G. HA. LOCK, Chairman of the Board of School Officers, presided.
lead_paragraph: Opening of A NEW SCHOOL.--The new Schoolhouse for Ward School No.20, situated in Broomestreet, between Clinton and Suffolk streets, was opened publicly yesterday morning. Mr. GEORGE G. HA. LOCK, Chairman of the Board of School Officers, presided. A portion of the Scriptures was read by Mr. WITHINGTON, and, after prayer by Rev. T.R. SMITH, a hymn was sung by all present. The concluding exercises consisted of addresses and singing by the children, who, as well as their parents, enjoyed the occasion greatly. It is a Primary School. Miss HOLBROOK is to act as Principal. Mr. G.W. THURBER, the Chairman of the Building Committee, read a report showing the cost of the building and site to have been $30,973. The building is 50 feet front and rear and 88 feet deep. The first floor will be used as the janitor's apartments and a playground for the children. The second floor is litted up for a large room for assembling the children, a teachers' room and a meeting room for the school officers; and the third floor is divided into class rooms. The entire building is treated by hot water.

abstract: JUDGE STUMP AGAIN. � One of those little episodes that will happen sometimes in "the best regulated families" came off last night at the City Hotel, Annapolis. The particulars, as furnished by an eyewitness, are briefly these: Judge STUMP and Col. MCKAIG happened to meet in the rear yard. when Col. MCKAIG saluted the Judge in a friendly way, who replied, "I will speak to no man who would sign a report without reading the testimony." Col. M. replied, "If you say that I signed the report to oust you without reading the testimony, you are a ---- liar!" Whereupon Judge STUMP raised his cane and struck at the Colonel. The latter returned the blow with a light stick he had in his hand. The Judge stepped back and fell over a stick of wood, when friends interfered and prevented any serious Injury. The Judge then lit his cigar and rnoved off as cool as a cucumber, but It is believed that Col. M. will not be let off without "a new trial." � Baltimore Patriot.
lead_paragraph: JUDGE STUMP AGAIN. � One of those little episodes that will happen sometimes in "the best regulated families" came off last night at the City Hotel, Annapolis. The particulars, as furnished by an eyewitness, are briefly these: Judge STUMP and Col. MCKAIG happened to meet in the rear yard. when Col. MCKAIG saluted the Judge in a friendly way, who replied, "I will speak to no man who would sign a report without reading the testimony." Col. M. replied, "If you say that I signed the report to oust you without reading the testimony, you are a ---- liar!" Whereupon Judge STUMP raised his cane and struck at the Colonel. The latter returned the blow with a light stick he had in his hand. The Judge stepped back and fell over a stick of wood, when friends interfered and prevented any serious Injury. The Judge then lit his cigar and rnoved off as cool as a cucumber, but It is believed that Col. M. will not be let off without "a new trial." � Baltimore Patriot.

abstract: The Fifty-third Annval Commencement of the College of Physicians and Surgeons took place at Dr. PARKER'S Church, in Fourth-avenue, last evening.
lead_paragraph: The Fifty-third Annval Commencement of the College of Physicians and Surgeons took place at Dr. PARKER'S Church, in Fourth-avenue, last evening. The graduating class and their friends occupied reserved seats in the centre aisle, the Trustees, Faculty, and some of the Regents of the University occu. pied the pulpit, and agreeable interludes of music occurred throughout the evening.

abstract: Sir John Bowring, writing from Paris to a friend, on the 7th ult., says:--"My visit has been a most gratifying and satisfactory one. I had hardly arrived when I received an invitation from the Emperor to a private ...
lead_paragraph: Sir John Bowring, writing from Paris to a friend, on the 7th ult., says:--"My visit has been a most gratifying and satisfactory one. I had hardly arrived when I received an invitation from the Emperor to a private which lasted long in when he spoke to me of his general policy, and of his commercial views specially. The reception was singularly cordial, and nothing could be more decided than his purposes of amity, nor more frank than his explanations on every subject. I never before found in him so much warmth of expression, contirming all that you have heard from me as to the value he attached to the English alliance, which is, and has ever been, the corner-stone of his political aspirations. I believe the information I gave him on many subjects will essentially help the good work, which progresses in spite of all opposition, and which will be a security of peace and mutual prosperity, such as nothing but an alliance of common interests could ever afford. I was invited to dine with the society of political economists, which consists of about a hundred members who have been the apostles of free trade, among whom are the soundest and most influential statesmen of France. They favored me with marked attention while, at their request, I drew a sketch of the beneficent influences of emancipated commerce upon our social and political condition; in truth, we are entering upon a great era which has been ushered in by the unflinching courage of a great man, and I venture to hope that as all liberties are brothers and sisters. Napoleon III. will add the final wreath to his coronal, and give France institutions worthy of her civilization."

abstract: A number of pastoral changes are to take place this Spring. The South Baptist Church in this City (Rev. Mr. BURLINGHAM'S) has engaged the services of Rev. A.B. EARLE for the delivery of a series of week-day evening sermons.
lead_paragraph: A number of pastoral changes are to take place this Spring. The South Baptist Church in this City (Rev. Mr. BURLINGHAM'S) has engaged the services of Rev. A.B. EARLE for the delivery of a series of week-day evening sermons. There is a strong religious interest in this congregation. Rev. JAMES PRATT, the successor of Rev. DUDLEY TYNG in St. Stephen's Church, Philadelphia, has accepted a call to the Rectorship of a church in Chicago, at a salary of $4,000 Rev. ORLANDO WITHERSPOON, Assistant Rector of Trinity Church, in New-Haven, has received a call to the Rectorship of Trinity Church in Norwich, Conn., and will probably accept. Rev. J.S. EVERINGHAM has resigned the charge of the Baptist Church at South Batta. N.Y., to accept a call from Victory, N.Y. Rev. E.S. WALKER has resigned his charge of the Baptist Church at Dansville, N.Y. Rev. L.E. SPOFFORD has resigned his pastorship of the Baptist church at Morris, Otsego county, in this State. Rt. Rev. Dr. SWEENY has been appointed Bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese of the province of New-Brunswick. Very Rev. J.V. BROWN, of Tennessee, having been appointed Vicar General of that diocese, has removed his residence from Chattanooga to Nashville.

abstract: Charles Brown, alias Michael Sheehan was put on trial this morning charged with an aasault with a dangerous weapon. The accused was one of the crew of the bark Manflower.
lead_paragraph: Charles Brown, alias Michael Sheehan was put on trial this morning charged with an aasault with a dangerous weapon. The accused was one of the crew of the bark Manflower. The mate of the bark testified that on Nov. 20 last, the bark sailed from this port for Barbados, the defendant being one of the crew; that about 4 o'clock that afternoon he gave this man orders to clear up some things about ceck, when the man gave a surly answer and finally threatened to put a knife into him, whereupon the mate took up a rope's end to strike him and the man-then drew his knife, and the mate then took a belaying pin and as the man sprung at him with the knife he struck him three times with the pin, but the man struck him with the knife in the left side, infl[???]ting a severe wound. The man was then put in irons and he and the mate sent back to the City.

abstract: To write a first-rate notice of one's own father is not a difficult task; filial feeling wields a fluent pen, and familiarity with the subject that he writes about is a manifest advantage to him whom the cacoethes scribendi has fastened upon. But to perform it well requires nice discrimination and excellent taste. The tendency in such biographics is generally either to panygyric or to painfully apparent candor. To tell a simple, unvarnished story, � "nothing extenuate, nor aught set down in malice," � is the happy mean which few who essay this style of writing are content with. The author of the work that we have before us, with rare judgment, in choice language, and modestly withal, gives to the world, and especially to "the people called Methodists," to whom he dedicates it, a history of JABEZ BUNTING, which has none of the offensive characteristics alluded to. The subject of the memoir lives o'er again his childhood � his school-days � the period of his early manhood, when, studying for the medical profession, he was converted, trained for the service of Methodism, and entered into the ministry ; and the days of his early ministry in London, Manchester, Sheffield and Liverpool. Here the first volume ends � published separately to avoid delay � but to be followed soon by a second, which those who shall have read the first will look for with eagerness.

abstract: The grand Benefit Festival in aid of the widow and family of the late Mr. GEORGE WILKINS, commences to-day at 1 o'clock, and the fashionable world will have its last Lenten opportunity of making the Academy of Music beautiful with its presence.
lead_paragraph: The grand Benefit Festival in aid of the widow and family of the late Mr. GEORGE WILKINS, commences to-day at 1 o'clock, and the fashionable world will have its last Lenten opportunity of making the Academy of Music beautiful with its presence. From the number of tickets already sold there is no longer the slightest doubt of the pecuniary result of this well-timed entertainment. If the day should be fine there will be a gathering such as is seldon witnessed even in Fourteenth-street. And the occasion really justifies the enthusiasm that prevails concerning it. In the first place the object is a laudable one, and appeals to the kindly sympathies of every one who can appreciate the miseries that sudden death brings to a family of unprovided little ones; in the second place, the entertainments are of the most varied and extraordinary character; in the third place, the price of admission is put at the very low standard of fifty cents. The Matinee opens with the comedy of "Everybody's Friend," performed by all the prominent members of Mr. WALLACK'S admirable company; after this comes the Protean piece called "In and Out of Place," with Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS; then the Musical Extravaganza of "Jenny Lind," with Mrs. JOHN WOOD, Mr. JEFFERSON, Mr. DAVENPORT, and other members of the Winter Garden Company. These pieces, it will be perceived, embrace the names of nearly all the dramatic celebrities now in the city. The Festival concludes with a miscellaneous soiree, commencing (at 8 o'clock) with the 4th act of "I Trovatore," in which Mme. ALBERTINI, Signor BEAU CARDS, Mme. D'ORMY, and Signor ARDAVANI will sustain the principal roles. Signor MUZIO conducts the orchestra. After the opera there will be the first pait of a concert, in which Mrs. C.M. BRINCKERHOFF Mr. S.B. MILLS, Mr. ERNEST PERRING, and Mme. GRAEVER-JOHNSON will assist; then an act from the "School for Scaotdal," with Mr. BLAKE as Sir Peter, Mr. JORDAN as Charles Surface, and Mrs. KATE BUCK-LAND as Lady Teazle. The famous screen scene will be given. This will be followed by the second part of the concert, in which Mr. SAAR, Mr. COOK, and Mr. HENRY DRAPER will assist. The entertainments conclude with a Minstrel selection by GEORGE CHRISTY and his band. With such a programme there is no room for comment.

abstract: We published yesterday a resolution of the Virginia Legislature, finally disposing of the South Carolina and Mississippi invitation to a disunion Conference, in which the folly of convening assemblies at crises such as that in ...
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a resolution of the Virginia Legislature, finally disposing of the South Carolina and Mississippi invitation to a disunion Conference, in which the folly of convening assemblies at crises such as that in which we now live, which can only debate and advise and which have no power to act, is formally and fully recognized. In short, Virginia refuses to have anything to do with any disunion scheme, and will not even debate it.

abstract: Dr. ELLIS subscribes fully to the doctrine that the prevention of disease is more important than its cure, and sets out to give his views with regard to the reforms which must be grafted on society in this country before we may be properly termed a healthy people. He will not assert now, � though he has asserted it before � that the American people are degenerated, but he points out in detail the many errors of diet and of social habit to which we are enslaved, and the measures which should be taken to correct them. There is little That is novel in this volume: it is an assertion and enforcement of wellknown truths that renders it valuable.

abstract: This is purely a book of controversial theology and we shall scarcely be expected, therefore, to enter very largely into its argument. It is free, however, from the heat and passion which sometimes characterize works of its class, and so ...
lead_paragraph: This is purely a book of controversial theology and we shall scarcely be expected, therefore, to enter very largely into its argument. It is free, however, from the heat and passion which sometimes characterize works of its class, and so far as its tone and temper are concerned, is eminently candid and judicial. The author is a lawyer of considerable distinction, and has filled various public positions of trust and responsibility. He was trained a Baptist, and became a member of that Church in 1840. His first impressions in favor of the Catholic Church were received while attending High Mass as spectator in 1843, at Fort Vancouver, where he was temporarily located. The fervor and devotion of the worshippers and the character of the service touched him profoundly, and directed his studies to an inquiry into the validity of the claims of the Catholic Church to be the only true form of Christian society. He first read the discussion between CAMPBELL and PURCELL, and was not at all satisfied with the arguments there adduced in favor of Protestantism. He resolved, therefore, to pursue the investigation for himself, which he did for about a year and a half � the result being his full conversion to the Roman Catholic faith. In this volume he sets forth at length the reasons which led him to this conclusion. The habits of a lawyer are manifest in his mode of examining testimony, and occasionally there is an appearance of technical adherence to legal rules which does, not seem quite appropriate to such a discussion. The work evinces marked ability, and will undoubtedly exert a decided influence.

abstract: The history of an event of such importance as the commercial treaty with France as shown by the official correspondence, will be read with considerable interest. It appears that Mr. Cobden, when on the point of starting for Paris, some time ago, had an ...
lead_paragraph: The history of an event of such importance as the commercial treaty with France as shown by the official correspondence, will be read with considerable interest. It appears that Mr. Cobden, when on the point of starting for Paris, some time ago, had an interview with Lord John Russell, to whom be suggested the importance of binding England and France still more closely together by the bonds of trade and commerce. His lordship gladly took up the proposal, and the member for Rochdale proceeded to the French capital, and lost no time in placing himself in communication with M. Rouher. Mr. Cobden acted in a private capacity during these preliminary negotiations, but, as soon as the bases of a treaty were drawn up Lord Cowley, in consequence of conversations he had had with the Emperor and Count Walewski, forwarded a dispatch to Lord John Russell on the subject, in which he urged that if the proposals for a treaty were to be prosecuted, the matter "could not be intrusted to better hands than those of Mr. Cobden." The result was that, on the 17th of January, Lord Cowley and Mr. Cobden were appointed joint plenipotentiaries, and six days afterwards the treaty was signed. On the 31st of January, Lord John Russell conveyed to the two plenipotentiaries, "Her Majesty's entire approval of the able and judicious manner in which they had carried to a successful issue the important negotiations for placing the commercial relations between England and France on an improved footing."

abstract: During the severe gale and snow storm which prevailed on Thursday, the packet-ship De Witt Clinton, bound from Liverpool to New-York, went ashore on the New-Jersey coast, eight miles below the village of Squan. The vessel contained a valuable cargo, and carried a large number of passengers. Information was speedily conveyed by signals to the shore, but the remoteness of the point from the life-saving apparatus, and the sparseness of the population, prevented any active measures. Fortunately, the steamship Quaker City, on her voyage hither from Havana, observed the vessel, and hailed and dispatched the steamtug Jacob Bell, which proceeded at once to the rescue. The Clinton was found to have bilged, but was lying very easily,and there was reason to believe that she might be saved after discharging a portion of her cargo. The passengers were all taken off by the pilot-boat Christian Bergh (No. 13) which came up opportunely, and last evening reached Quarantine in safety.

abstract: In an octavo volume of only 310 pages, Mr. TUTTLE gives an exceedingly comprehensive and, both from the nature of the subject and his method of treating it, exceedingly interesting account of the creation and its laws. He has endeavored to trace received facts to their legitimate sources, and found, with their aid, as perfect a system as possible. He shows the origin of the universe, of life, of kingdoms, divisions, classes and species of the living world, of man from the animal world, and of mind; and at the close he argues from all that has gone before that man is an immortal being, and that his immortal state is controlled by laws as immutable as those which govern his physical state. The line of argument is well-defined and ably supported, the deduction indisputable. An appendix full of valuable information, prepared by Mr. DATUS KELLY, is added, and the illustrations are well-executed and very much in point.

abstract: Phillip U. Searle vs. Jacob H.V. Cockrofi. - This action was brought to recover a balance claimed to be due the plaintiff from the defendant upon certain transfers of bills of lading for salt and for other goods. Plaintiff claimed that he transferred the bills as security for advances; while the defendant claimed that they were purchased absolutely, at prices agreed upon. Among the securities claimed to have been transferred, were bills of lading with a policy of insurance upon the cargo of the brig Guerriere, shortly to arrive in this port. The vessel never arriving a loss accrues, which was adjusted and $645 of it paid to the defendant, the policy having been for $1,000. The plaintiff claimed that this policy was transferred as security for a loan of $500. The defendant averred, as stated, that it was an absolute purchase. The amount claimed was about $2 000. The cause was tried in the Superior Court, before Justice BOSWORTH, and resulted in a verdict for plaintiff for $2,368 The Court made an allowance of $100 on the verdict.

abstract: The Ladies' Mount Vernon Association having fully secured, by purchase, the homestead of WASHINGTON, yesterday afternoon, for the first time, paid an official visit to the spot, in the steamer Thomas Collyer.
lead_paragraph: The Ladies' Mount Vernon Association having fully secured, by purchase, the homestead of WASHINGTON, yesterday afternoon, for the first time, paid an official visit to the spot, in the steamer Thomas Collyer. An invitation was the day previous extended to both Houses of Congress to accompany them in this trip, which was accepted, and the Senate, for the purpose of complying with the invitation, met an hour earlier than usual, while it was understood that the House would likewise have an early adjournment. An earnest bebate, however, unfortunately springing up in both Houses, neither body thought it politic to adjourn, and for this reason, we regret to say, there were but thirty of the House in attendance, and only one Senator. The members of the Press, during the passage down the river, individually and collectively, expressed to Mr. JOHN COCHRANE, of New-York, their appreciation of his kindness in so efficiently interposing in their behalf at the wharf, as the Captain of the boat took upon himself to exclude the members of the Press invited to go down, and his manner was so extraordinarily offensive as to excite the greatest indignation, and respect alone for the ladies on the boat prevented his being roughly handled. The Marine Band was in attendance, and interested the company with numerous national airs. Reaching the tomb the company separated, spending an hour in viewing the grounds and various interesting relics. About twilight the party again gathered about the tomb, when the band executed in fine style "Washington's Grave." As is customary, every one brought away some token of remembrance of their visit to the venerated spot.

abstract: One of the possible evils that may result from the institution of an elective Judiciary finds its full illustration in the characteristics of the present City Judge of New-York, whose unfitness for the bench he occupies is evinced by nothing more than by the very quality of smartness and severity which he apparently deems his most distinguished judicial merit. Public attention has often been called to the almost inhuman severity of the sentences he passes upon some of the friendless prisoners whose violations of the law have placed them in his power; while towards others a lenity is exercised quite incompatible with the ends of justice. The indecent zeal with which Judge RUSSELL recently hastened to the assistance of the notorious KELLY, arrested for participation in a brutal fight, and the willingness which he manifested to gratify the friends of the culprit, and hold a Court on the spot for his liberation, have excited no little indignation in that old-fashioned portion of the public which regards the duties of the judicial office as inconsistent with the position of bottle-holder to a bully in a fight.

abstract: of a History of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, condensed from the standard work of REID and KILLEN, by Rev. SAMUEL D. ALEXANDER. The work was written at the instance of the late J. ADDISON ALEXANDER, D.D., the brother of the author, and has been prepared with a great deal of painstaking. It simply gives the main thread of the history, so as to bring it within the reach of those to whom the more expensive original is not accessible. The history of the Irish Presbyterian Church is, to all intents and purposes, the history of the Presbyterian Church of the province of Ulster. To that province it was once almost altogether confined, though now Presbyterianism is more generally diffused. The volume will be read with interest by the descendants in this country of the Irish Presbyterians.

abstract: In the Senate Mr. FITCH introduced a bill to provide for the public printing, and Mr. BRIGHT another for the enlargement of the grounds around the capitol.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate Mr. FITCH introduced a bill to provide for the public printing, and Mr. BRIGHT another for the enlargement of the grounds around the capitol. Petitions for a revised tariff were presented by Mr. CAMERON. The bill granting a pension to the widow of Gen. SMITH was passed, with an amendment making similar grants to the wdiows oi Gens. MACOMB and RILEY. Mr. THADDEUS HYATT was brought to the bar of the Senate, where he replied in writing to the questions heretofore propounded to him. He took the ground, which he endeavored to sustain by numerous citations of parliamentary and legal precedents, that the Senate possesses no power to compel his attendance, and that while he might consent to answer the interrogatories of the committee, he should do so under protest. The answer occupied two hours in the reading, and was frequently interrupted by motions on both the Republican and Democratic sides, to refer the papers to a Committee. At the close, Mr. MASON moved a resolution, which was adopted, that HYATT be placed in the custody of the Sergeant-at-Arms until the Committee should be ready to take his testimony. The Speaker of the House announced the Special Committees upon the Pacific Railroad, and Mr. COVODE'S Investigation into the abuse of Executive Patronage. Mr. CARTER endeavored vainly to obtain a hearing in reply to Mr. ADRAIN upon the Seventh Regiment Entertainment. Mr. GURLEY'S bill reforming the Printing coming up at a subsequent stage of the proceedings, provoked a violent discussion, in which the Democrats took a leading part, declaring that the measure had nothing reformatory in its character; that it was in fact an attempt to coerce the Senate Printer into a bargain with the Printer of the House, and to enable the latter to acquire plunder otherwise beyond his reach. The bill was finally, on motion of Mr. BARKSDALE of Mississippi, laid on the table by a vote of 98 to 65.

abstract: The Tribune protests that it has no love for Mayor WOOD, but it avows its strong wish that he might obtain a seat in the Charleston Convention, in order to effect the demolition of ...
lead_paragraph: The Tribune protests that it has no love for Mayor WOOD, but it avows its strong wish that he might obtain a seat in the Charleston Convention, in order to effect the demolition of that "wretched and contemptible faction, the Softs," whom it hopes to see "consigned to that final destruction which befits political humbugs and hypocrites." It regrets, however, that the signs are not promising just now, and that the Softs are likely to triumph after all.

abstract: Commodore David Geisinger, of the United States Navy, died at his residence in Philadelphia, March 5. He was in his 70th year, and was among the oldest officers of the Navy. His commission as Captain was dated May 24, 1838. In the War of 1812 he was an active participant, and was on board the wasp during her cruise on the English coast in 1814. upon the capture of the Atalanta by the Wasp, Mr. Geisinger was put in command of her, and to this circumstance he owed his life, for the Wasp was never heard of afterwards. Commodore Geisinger was for many years stationed at the Naval Asylum in Philadelphia. His rank was seventh among the Captains of the Reserved List.
lead_paragraph: Commodore David Geisinger, of the United States Navy, died at his residence in Philadelphia, March 5. He was in his 70th year, and was among the oldest officers of the Navy. abstract: Yesterday was the day appointed for the opening of the bids for the working of the Eleventh-avenue from One Hundred and Seventh to One Hundred and Forty-fourth street, and also for the building of two ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was the day appointed for the opening of the bids for the working of the Eleventh-avenue from One Hundred and Seventh to One Hundred and Forty-fourth street, and also for the building of two steam fire engines, to be placed in charge of the members of Southwark Company No. 38 and Engine Company No. 29. With reference to the Eleventh-avenue contract, to which allusion was made a day or two since, there were nine bids, ranging from $13,-719 to $21,931, and the contract has not yet been awarded, though Mr. WALKER will undoubtedly claim it, if, by some mathematical or astronomical process, he can get rid of twenty-four hours, for it is a remarkable fact that in two bids involving an amount of $14,000 (nearly) there is only a variation of seventy-five cents, and it occurs in this wise: the bid of GEO.A. BUCKINGHAM &Co., amounting to $13,719 75. In drawing up the specifications, the quantity of rock to be excavated, of earth to be carted away, and of filling, is estimated by surveyors, on whose report the specifications are drawn up. In addition to this is to be estimated the pay of an inspector at $2 per day for the time fixed on by the contractor. Messrs. BUCKINGHAM & Co. agree to complete the work in six months. Mr. WALKER does not specify any length of time, but this by usage, and as well understood by contractors, means 12 months, or 312 days, and is so construed invariably. But here come the mathematical and astronomical calculations. The year 1860 happens, thanks to his Imperial Highness NAPOLEON I, to contain 366 days, therefore Mr. BUCKINGHAM, actually gains twenty-four hours on his opponent, as there are 314 working days in this year, and thus, though the mean of his contract is seventy-five cents higher than that of Mr. WALKER, he will probably secure it by the difference in time, to which of course he is entitled, as that will reduce the inspector's pay by one day, or two dollars, making his bid the lowest by twenty-five cents. This is probably as close calculation as ever came under the observation of any offcial, and we recommend to high contracting parties who may hereafter put in bids for Corporation jobs, not to forget that every fourth year contains 366 days. The Street Commissioner, who, as every one knows, is an accomplished scholar, and a graduate with high honors at West Point, intends to devote his attention to this problem, thus singularly presented, and when we shall have received his decision, it will, we doubt not, whichever way it may tend, teach contractors to look more carefully at the almanac. The contract for building a carriage for Hose Co. No. 2, was awarded to C.E. HARTSHORN, the only bidder, and we emphasise this because the opening of the bids for the construction of the steam-engines for Nos. 38 and 29, was postponed for the reason that there was but one bidder. But � and everything has its but � Messrs. LEE & LARNED, who own the patent for the rotary-pump, which is the main feature of the steam fire engines, of course control that patent, and were about to put in a bid, but under the circumstances, and in view of the fact that they were the patentees, and of course could be the only bidders, th Street Commissioner withdrew the proposals before the hour announced for the reception of bids.

abstract: The Democracy of North Carolina seem to be engaged in active preparations for the coming contest. The papers come to us filled with reports of their meetings.
lead_paragraph: The Democracy of North Carolina seem to be engaged in active preparations for the coming contest. The papers come to us filled with reports of their meetings. In Warren County, on the 6th, Mr. THORNTON made a speech, calling on the Opposition to unite with the Democracy in saving the Union by putting down the Republicans, and spoke in terms of high eulogy of CHARLES O'CONOR, of this City. "Dr. LAMBERT, of New-York," also made a speech, stating that the Democrats of that State and of Pennsylvania also greatly preferred a Southern candidate over a Northern one, and saying that if the Southern States should be assailed, the North would send 200,000 men, armed and equipped at their own expense, to their assistance. A great number of resolutions were adopted, one of them requesting he Governor to call the Legislature together to provide for the menacing aspect of public affairs. In Halifax, a meeting censured the action of HENRY WINTER DAVIS, declared themselves in favor of the Union, and resolved to support the nominee of the Charleston Convention. In Greene, Jackson, Edgecombe, Orange, Montgomery and Davidson, meetings have been held, at which similar resolutions were adopted.

lead_paragraph: The correspondence between the Postmasters-General of Great Britain, the United States, and Canada, has been submitted to the House of Assembly, here, by the Ministry. The results of the arrangement made can be summed up briefly � the Uni-[???] get their European mails carried with greater celerity than heretofore, oftener in the week, and at a cheaper rate. Canada gets little but the honor of being the carrier of this correspondence. whatever that may be worth.

abstract: Application of Mary Ann Desmond. - This was a habeas corpus, granted by Justice SUTHERLAND, at Chambers, for the relief of Peter Brady, a seaman on board the United States steamship Brooklyn, now lying at Quarantine. The petition upon which the writ was granted alleged that Brady was there confined by the officers of the ship, on the pretence to prevent his desertion. It also set forth that he was in double chains - immured to an extent beyond all reason and bounds.

abstract: Whatever may be the political results of the recent attempt of the Western Powers to coerce China into joining the great family of nations, it is ...
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be the political results of the recent attempt of the Western Powers to coerce China into joining the great family of nations, it is certain to add largely to our knowledge or that remote and mysterious Empire. Shrewd observers and cultivated scholars have accompanied the various expeditions by which this endeavor has been prosecuted, and although their pursuit of knowledge has been obstructed by very formidable obstacles, they have been able, nevertheless, to bring back much new and interesting information concerning the country and its people. M. HUE'S book on China gives, perhaps, a more intimate and satisfactory account of Chinese society, � the habits, sentiments and modes of life which prevail there, � than any work of its day; and since that time other travelers, their special attention being directed to other points, have greatly enlarged our knowledge of China. Mr. WINGROVE COOKE, the special correspondent of the London Times, has given most graphic and spirited pictures of scenes and incidents that passed under his observation, and illustrated various phases of Chinese life and character. We presume that we shall have books upon China from some of the accomplished literary gentlemen who accompanied the French Embassy, and we hope that our countryman, Mr. REED, inferior to none of the representatives of other nations in China in judgment and literary ability, will also publish some popular account of his observations and proceedings in that country. There is no good reason why Blue Books and the archives of the State Department should entomb the knowledge which these various Expeditions have gathered concerning the oldest, most populous and most wonderful nation of the earth.

abstract: There is more of the historical and didactic than of the descriptive in Mr. NORTON'S notes of travel. Probably he has recognized the truth that in Italy there is little of art or nature that the world has not already been made acquainted with. They were written during the years 1855, 1856 and 1857, in various parts of "the boot," but most of them at Rome, Naples, Venice, and Orvieto, and the minor portion of them appeared in The Crayon, in 1856. The principal interest of the reader will centre in the author's searching investigation of some of the corrupt doctrines of the Church of Rome. While condemning many of its practices he expresses a feeling of warm regard for many of its members. He speaks cheerfully and hopefully of the future of Italy. The work is full of interesting information and will be read with interest.

abstract: BODIES FOUND. � The body of TIMOTHY SHAY, a boy who was drowned several months ago by the upsetting of a boat in the East River, was recovered yesterday off the foot of Congress-street. The body of a new-born infant was found yesterday morning in a lot near Hicks and Rapelyea streets. An inquest was held, and the jury rendered a verdict that death was the result of causes to them unknown.
lead_paragraph: BODIES FOUND. � The body of TIMOTHY SHAY, a boy who was drowned several months ago by the upsetting of a boat in the East River, was recovered yesterday off the foot of Congress-street. abstract: The NEW-YORK TIMES is the youngest of the daily newspapers of the City of New-York. The first number was issued on the 18th of September, 1851,-- ...
lead_paragraph: The NEW-YORK TIMES is the youngest of the daily newspapers of the City of New-York. The first number was issued on the 18th of September, 1851,-- so that it has only just completed the eighth year of its publication. But it has already become one of the most widely known and most firmly established daily journals of the United States. Its circulation is quite as large as that of any other daily of its class in the City of New-York, � and in reputation for enterprise, energy, and reliability, it may fairly challenge comparison with any other newspaper in the country.
