abstract: A model of the sculptures of Eleusis, which were discovered while digging the foundation of a school-house at the ancient city, is attacting great attention at the Academic des Beaux Arts, in Paris.
lead_paragraph: A model of the sculptures of Eleusis, which were discovered while digging the foundation of a school-house at the ancient city, is attacting great attention at the Academic des Beaux Arts, in Paris. These sculptures are evidently the remains of the tempie of Triptolemus. Only three personages have as yet been discovered. The bas-relief, of which they form the subject, is supposed to have been the frontispiece of the temple. Ceres is bestowing on Triptolemus the grain destined to spring up in the plain of Rharius, that sacred field where the first seed was sown, and where the first fruit was gathered. Nothing can be more graceful than the figure of Triptolemus, just verging into manhood, and combining the bashfulness of youth with the determination not to shrink from the obligation of homage to the goddess, which her bounty has bestowed upon him. While extending one hand to receive the sacred deposit, he gathers up with the other the folds of his dress with a gesture so graceful and full of dignity, that every artist who beholds turns away in despair. Proserpine, meanwhile, standing behind the youth, places her hand upon his head to bestow upon him the mystical gift of genius, and completes the group. In spite of the enormous sums offered by the French Government, as well as by King Otho, the "municipal authorities" of Eleusis refused to allow these pieces to be removed.

abstract: If we were to announce that the unequaled humorist had suddenly returned to this world and had written a new volume of poems just published in this City, the press would have its iron hands full in supplying the demand for it. The volume whose title we have given above is composed of dramatic sketches, odes, political satires and miscellaneous fugitives (with a few exceptions) not contained in the former collections of the works o[???] TOM HOOD ï¿½ to all intents and purposes, new efforts of the versatile genius of the poet. They are characterized by the same peculiarities which have charmed and amused us before in his more celebrated creations, and come to us in such a readable shape that we cannot speak otherwise than well of them.

abstract: LAW. - we trust that the attention of the parties interested may be directed to certain provisions in the amendments now pending in the Legislature to the Metropolitan Police Law. It is proposed to reduce the number of Commissioners to three, ï¿½ to have these three appointed in April for two, four and six years respectively, but to retain in the Board the power of detailing members of the force for duty. Now we are confident that a very little study of the case will suffice to convince impartial persons of the impossibility of establishing or maintaining an effective police under such a system. The Superintendent is to be the active commander of the department. Its fidelity, efficiency and discipline will depend entirely upon him, and upon the due maintenance of his authority. If members of the force look beyond him for their orders, and learn to depend upon others for directions, they will cease to respect or obey his commands.

abstract: That every man is reminded by the lives of great men of the original capacity for improvement and high attainment which he, in common with his fellow-men, possesses, the Poet assures us and experience declares. More than this, it titillates the fancy, especially of those who are just starting in life, to have their own powers thus recalled to them, and to compare their own progress, step by step, with that of the famous who have gone before. Especially full of interest are the early efforts, the points of departure, the first indications of talent, perhaps unappreciated at the time they were given, of those who have since left "foot-prints." School-days of eminent men! The title itself commends the book. A dull writer would have made an entertaining volume of it, and the author is by no means a dull writer. Restricting his design to the great men of Great Britain, he has divided his work into two parts. In the first he sketches the Progress of Education, commencing with the dark age of the history of the realm, and continues it to the present time, illustrating every period of it by an account of the education of each Sovereign, his early habits and tastes. The second section comes more strictly within the purview of the title. It gives us interesting incidents in the youth of all the great writers, jurists, statesmen, orators, divines, and soldiers of the land, whose names have lived after them. The best of it is, that the anecdotes are all authentic. 'Tis but a common proof that Truth in narrative is not only stranger but more entertaining than Fiction.

abstract: Pine and Palmer vs. Willett. ï¿½ This action was reported in the TIMES of the 6th inst., since which time it has been on trial before Justice MONCRIEF, in the Superior Court. The action was one of replevin, the plaintiffs alleging that the defendant had wrongfully seized their property in execution. The trial now resulted in a verdict for the defendant, and the Jury assessed his damages at $7 71.

abstract: The world-wide fame of the lady who wrote it will secure for this little work a very extensive circulation; yet few women will look to find many practical directions in which it will be novel to them. AS FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE herself says, every woman is a nurse � a nurse by nature. A nurse, like a poet, is born, not manufactured. Fashion and folly may amuse the fair, when fashion and folly reign; but "When pain and anguish wring the brow," the instinct of nature teaches woman where her place is, and how to fill it. Yet poets born may profit by rules of rhetoric, and the experience of FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE will not be without value; only let it be borne in mind that when the authoress undertakes to tell what nursing is, and what it is not, her design is not to furnish a nurse's vade-mecum, "a rule of thought" �  in her own phraseology � "by which nurses can teach themselves to nurse." The book is printed in clear type, with marginal index, on 140 octavo pages, and has a covering that will endure considerable rough usage in the sick-room.

abstract: The ladies of America have at last delivered Mount Vernon from the presence of Mr. JOHN A. WASHINGTON. The estate now belongs to their fair and indefatigable Association, and on ...
lead_paragraph: The ladies of America have at last delivered Mount Vernon from the presence of Mr. JOHN A. WASHINGTON. The estate now belongs to their fair and indefatigable Association, and on Wednesday afternoon they went down from the capital to inspect their purchase. They had invited Congress to accompany them, but that patriotic and intelligent body, after making its arrangements to go, was unfortunately detained by stress of talk: "an earnest debate," says one of the Washington journals, in true nautical style, "unfortunately springing up in both Houses." So but thirty representatives and a single Senator (possibly the bachelor Mr. CLINGMAN) were found to do honor to the occasion, to the ladies and to the Father of his Country. Conspicuous among this little band, however, we are happy to say was Mr. JOHN COCHRANK, of New-York, who appears to have been decidedly the hero of the day. Before leaving the wharf this gallant gentleman signalized himself by a successful defence of the liberty of the Press. The steamboat captain having conceived frantic ideas of his own importance, undertook to suppress the scribes of journalism, no doub[???] regarding them as very suspicious Pharisees and more than probable Sadducees. Mr. COCHRANE interfered, saved the reporters from expulsion and the Captain from a thrashing; pacified the warring parties, and so built himself, let us hope, like GODIVA, "an everlasting name." On the way home, after what appears to have been a cheerful kind of pic-nic, Mr. COCHRANE again came forward, and made a most affecting and appropriate speech � full of " bated breath," of "sombre thought," and of "patriotic emotions." The aim of this speech, so far as we can apprehend it, was the eminently creditable one of paying honors due to the female sex for its triumphs that day consummated over the selfishness and indifference of male America. In attaining this object, Mr. COCHRANE threw out a few rather astonishing observations. For instance, he declared that the voices of the women of America "came up from the vast deep crying for aid," which fact we confess was new to us; and added the very natural remark that on hearing these submarine calls for help from drowning beauty, the fathers and brothers of the involuntary mermaids "felt the electric spark." We should think they would!

abstract: It seems to be generally understood, that a movement is on foot which, unless checked, will pretty certainly plunge us into another war with Mexico.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be generally understood, that a movement is on foot which, unless checked, will pretty certainly plunge us into another war with Mexico. The maraudings of the freebooter CORTINAS, with his band, have been cultivated to the point which calls for the interposition of Gen. HOUSTON on behalf of the State of Texas; and the prompt demand of Senator WIGFALL, that the Federal Government shall at once appropriate some millions of dollars to pay the expense of HOUSTON'S contemplated movements, indicates the manner in which we are to be dragged into the impending war. The appropriation will undoubtedly be refused, but this will not in the slightest degree affect the result. It will only afford an additional pretext to the Texan fillibusters for protecting themselves, crossing the frontier, involving the two countries in actual hostilities, and then turning the whole affair over to the General Government.

abstract: The excitement about "the Omnibus or Gridiron Railroad bill" has about subsided.  It was announced in the House this morning, and took the usual reference to the Committee on Cities and villages.

abstract: -This question has come up again in Philadelphia. The Committee of ninety-six, appointed at the meeting last Summer, has prepared a memorial to the Legislature of Pennsylvania, setting forth the right of citizens to enjoy the privilege of railroad travel Sunday, and representing "that the increased area of the consolidated city of Philadelphia, with the increased and daily increasing population within its limits � with the toiling masses who fill the workshops, the foundries the manufactories, and other places where the mechanical skill and ingenuity of the artisan, the tradesman and the laborer, contribute to the flattering and flourishing prosperity of the city and the Commonwealth � all tend to render the law burdensome and oppressive, restricting the facilities of intercourse of one section of the city with the other; restraining the tolling thousands from the enjoyment of that recreation which the institution of the observance of the Sunday had intended; closing the avenues and highways to the poor man's conveyance where the rich man's carriage may travel with impunity."
lead_paragraph: -This question has come up again in Philadelphia. abstract: Signs of returning animation are everywhere visible among the steamboats and other floating craft which congregate about the piers of West-street.
lead_paragraph: Signs of returning animation are everywhere visible among the steamboats and other floating craft which congregate about the piers of West-street. The shrill sound of steam escaping from overcharged boilers, the ring of bells on board of departing steamers, and the impatient rush of heavily laden carts towards the various piers, give proof that Spring navigation has opened in earnest on the Hudson. The breaking up of the ice has been earlier by two weeks than it was last year, and has found a few of the boats, and only a few, prepared for the early resumption of business.

abstract: In the case of Alexander N. Meliotta, charged with an outrage of a fearful character on a very young female child, the jury, after ten hours' consultation, returned a verdict of guilty. The Court sentenced him to fifteen years and seven months in the State Prison.

abstract: Cigars and other property, valued in the aggregate at $150, were stolen on Wednesday night from the wholesale liquor and cigar store No. 149 Duauestreet, kept by David M. Hollister, the front door of which had been forced.
lead_paragraph: Cigars and other property, valued in the aggregate at $150, were stolen on Wednesday night from the wholesale liquor and cigar store No. 149 Duauestreet, kept by David M. Hollister, the front door of which had been forced. Early yesterday morning, two negroes, named Wm. H Forest alias Becker, and Thomas Williams were arrested by Officers Bennett and Horbelt, of the Fifth Ward, on a charge of having perpetrated the burglary, and Forest subsequently confessed his guilt, adding that Williams and himself had a confederate in the transaction, who had absconded with the largest part of the property. Two boxes of cigars, alleged to be a portion of those stolen, were recovered from John Collins, who keeps a cigar-store at No. 71 West Broadway, and he was also apprehended. Justice OSBORNE, before whom the two negroes were taken, committed them to answer, and detained Collins as a witness. Forest is said to have been released from Sing Sing only four months ago, where he served a term of ten years for a similar offence to that with which he is now charged. Williams, his alleged confederate, was in custody a week since on a charge of having burglariously entered the grocery, No. 11 Thomas street, but the evidence against him proved insufficient and he was discharged.... The dwelling of Patrick Gilmore, No. 715 Washington-street, was opened by means of false keys on the 2d inst., and furniture, clothing and money were stolen. A lad named James Kennedy, with an unknown confederate, are alleged to have been lurking about the premises on the day in question, and yesterday, Kennedy was arrested on suspicion of having stolen the property. Justice QUACKENBUSH, before whom the prisoner was taken, committed him for trial.

abstract: When Mr. CONKLING, a member of the Assembly of New-York from this City, undertook, the other day, to drag the Central Park into an arena of partisan squabbles and personal conflicts, by vague and general assaults ...
lead_paragraph: When Mr. CONKLING, a member of the Assembly of New-York from this City, undertook, the other day, to drag the Central Park into an arena of partisan squabbles and personal conflicts, by vague and general assaults upon the character and conduct of the gentlemen composing the Park Commission, we stigmatized the proceeding as utterly and indecently inconsistent with his position and his duties. The Assembly evidently took the same view of the matter, and inflicted upon the offending member the chastisement of throwing out his "motion of inquiry," based on these indefinite and impertinent charges, by an overwhelming majority. Nothing has since been heard from Mr. CONKLING, but a person whose name was freely used by him at the time, and from whom he professed to have received accusations against the Commissioners, which he declined to produce, has recognized the extremely undesirable character of his own position in this matter, and attempts, in a letter which we this morning publish, to put himself right upon the record. This person, Mr. ROBERT J. DILLON, was for a short time a member of the Central Park Commission, but resigned his position and retired to private life at a time when, according to his own statement, he was convinced that a majority of the Board were violating their oaths of office and wasting the public money. That Mr. DILLON, in these circumstances, should have left the Central Park Board, is certainly to be regretted, since any intention he may have cherished of protecting the public interests against his fellow-Commissioners, could have been much more efficiently and honorably carried out had he appeared in the attitude of an active Commissioner, defending the public right, than it can be now when he occupies the always dubious position of a disappointed man, criticizing the conduct of his former colleagues. However, quit the Commission Mr. DILLON certainly did; and, as he is now simply a private citizen, he has suffered his angry enthusiasm to run away with him a little, in his imagination that the TIMES has "charged him with a responsibility" for anything whatsoever in connection with this matter of the Central Park at Albany. What we said was, that Mr. CONKLING, who, as a member of the Assembly, is in a position to make his statements of importance to the public, had "foisted upon Mr. DILLON an indirect responsibility for his own insinuations." We called not upon Mr. DILLON to produce himself, but upon Mr. CONKLING, who had evidently employed Mr. DILLON to collect and prefer charges against the Commission, to produce Mr. DILLON as his authority for "open and specific" accusations against this important board of public officers. Mr. CONKLING has not responded to our summons. Mr. DILLON has volunteered to do so, and "takes the responsibility" of a certain letter which Mr. CONKLING read in the Assembly as proceeding from his pen. To this we have no sort of objection. We trust that Mr. DILLON, like Mr. JOHN SMITH, or Mr. JABEZ BROWN, will always �take the responsibility" of his own letters; but it exhibits a curious confusion of ideas in Mr. DILLON'S mind, that he should suppose it to be his duty to take this responsibility on the present occasion in any distinct and defiant manner before the public. The public has really no sort of concern, at present, either with Mr. DILLON or with Mr.DILLON's letters. His charges against the Commissioners of the Central Park are simply attacks made by one private citizen occupying no public post upon the character of other private citizens filling public stations of importance. The gentlemen whom he accuses of "violating their oaths," and whose "removal for malfeasance" he therefore demands, may deal with him in their private capacity. The public can pay no attention to the matter until some officially important person shall "take the responsibility," which Mr. CONKLING so completely shirked, and which Mr. DILLON, we regret to say, cannot be allowed to assume, however eagerly he may desire to do so. Thus much for the relations of Mr. DILLON with the public and with the Park. So far as the TIMES is concerned, Mr. DILLON has a right to our opinion upon the charges which he advances for our consideration. He favors us with an account of the letter which he wrote to somebody, and which Mr. CONKLING having read, declined to indorse. In this letter, says Mr. DILLON;

abstract: The proposition made at a recent meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration by ELIJAH F. PURDY, for the abolition of the commutation tax on emigrant passengers, is full of interest to the tax-payer and the emigrant. This commutation tax is not paid directly by the emigrant, but by the shippers. Thus, for all aliens arriving at this port, who have never been to this country previously, the shippers are bound to pay into the Emigration fund the sum of two dollars each. Unless paid within a specified time, this sum becomes a lien upon the ship, which is liable to attachment and sale for its recovery. Of course this tax is reimbursed to the shippers by the passage-money.

abstract: Dingeldine vs. Birdsull. -ï¿½ This was an action to recover an alleged excess of commissions, under the statute. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant had received of him $200 more than lawful rates. The case was reported in the TIMES of Friday, at which time it was on trial before Judge DALY, in the Common Pleas. The jury now gave a verdict for the plaintiff for the amount claimed.

abstract: Most of the sketches of which this volume is composed were originally published in the Spirit of the Times, under the title of "Camp-fire Stories," and some of them were reprinted in other periodicals. They are pleasant, sprightly, and sometimes, perhaps, rather highly colored pictures of hunting life among the Everglades of Florida. The writer evidently loves nature, and the character of the tales gives him frequent opportunity of indulging his passion. His narratives of hairbreadth escapes in fores, and in field are exceedingly interesting; the dialogue of the negroes, Indians and backwoodsmen who are strung upon the thread of his story has more of significance in it than the senseless gibberish which is commonly put into the mouths of such characters in the novels of the day; and the book is presented to the public in a neat and attractive garb.
lead_paragraph: Most of the sketches of which this volume is composed were originally published in the Spirit of the Times, under the title of "Camp-fire Stories," and some of them were reprinted in other periodicals. abstract: -About 1-1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the carriage-factory of Messrs. SHERMAN & DEAN, situated at the upper end of Main-street, Poughkeepsie. Owing to the high wind which prevailed at the time, and the delay experienced in procuring water, the flames gained much headway before the firemen could make effectual efforts to check them. The factory, with the valuable stock of carriages, wagons and sleighs which it contained, together with the tools of the workmen, was entirely consumed. The blacksmith shop of Mr. CLARK, and a large barn in the rear owned by Mr. THOMAS PLATTO, were also destroyed. It was said that two valuable horses in the latter building were lost. A new fire engine-house adjoining the factory, and the paint-shop of Mr. WILSON SHIELDS, were so much injured that it will be necessary to rebuild them. Messrs. SHENNAN & DEAN estimate the value of their stock which was destroyed at from $8,000 to $10,000. They have but a small insurance upon it. On the building, however, which was valued at $3,000, they held policies to the amount of $1,800. The engine-house which was so badly injured cost $3,000, and the blacksmith's-shop and contents were estimated to be worth $400. The latter is partially insured.

abstract: From the extensive currency which has been given to the eloquent extract from Mr. EVERETT's Dudley Observatory Oration, and like personal experiences, an impression prevails in the public mind that this bold headland, which lies directly in the path of vessels making passages to and from Europe and this country, is an unlighted rock Such is not the case. There is a fine white light exhibited on this Cape, which can be seen at a distance of 17 miles seaward from the deck of a passing ship. The lighthouse stands near the beacon (which has been somewhat reduced in height) to which Mr. EVERETT refers, and of course has been erected since Mr. E. made the passage to which he alludes in the oration. Cape Race should not be confounded with Cape Sable, the scene of the wreck of the ill-fated Hungarian. The former is the southeast extremity of Newfoundland, the latter the southeast extremity of Nova Scotia -- the distance between the two being some 500 miles. ï¿½ Boston Traveler.

abstract: We have more than once taken occasion to commend this monthly as one of very great value to all who desire to read the most substantia! and instructive portions of the foreign magazine lirerature of the day. It is edited with judgment and discrimination, � aiming more at what is solid and substantially useful, than what is pleasant and entertaining for the moment. Its extracts are thus made up primarily of the more elaborate portions of the foreign reviews and magazines, though light literature is not entirely neglected in its pages. Each month the editor gives also an agreeable summary of literary intelligence. The portraits of distinguished persons, � mainly those connected in some conspicuous way with current events, � form a marked and attractive feature of the work. They are well executed in mezzotint, generally from photographs or other accurate likenesses.

abstract: ST. LOUIS, Mo., Saturday, March 10. The Republican State Convention assembled at  Mercantile Library Hall yesterday afternoon. B. GRATZ BROWN called the Convention to order and was afterward chosen President. The attendance was very small, less than 200 being present. But one County in the State sent regularly-elected delegates.

abstract: The President's home organ, the Constitution, declines to surrender one line of its space "to notice of a man whom a gentleman of high honor and standing, both social and political, has pronounced to his face, on the floor of the House, to be a 'liar and a scoundrel."'
lead_paragraph: The President's home organ, the Constitution, declines to surrender one line of its space "to notice of a man whom a gentleman of high honor and standing, both social and political, has pronounced to his face, on the floor of the House, to be a 'liar and a scoundrel."' The Constitution is getting fastidious. If it proposes to act upon a general principle of this kind, and never to notice anybody whom somebody else may pronounce a "liar and a scoundrel," its columns will be a good deal more destitute of personal allusions than they have ever been hitherto.

abstract: The most important incident of the past fortnight was the murder of Capt. LIONEL LAMBERT, of her Britannic Majesty's war steamer Vi[???]en. On the 8th of February, at 3 o'clock, P.M., Capt. LAMBERT was playing at billiards with some of the officers of his vessel, in the "Hotel de Europa." At a little past [???] he left his companions, saying that he was going to take a bath, and would meet them so as to take the 6 o'clock train to Callao. It appears that he went to the river, and must there have been attacked by several persons and foully murdered. His skull was broken in two places, the blow on the back of t he head apparently having been made by an axe or hatchet. His forehead was badly cut, and his arms and wrists were black and scarred, as if he had had a fearful struggle with his murderers. When Capt. LAMBERT was found in the river in front of the Carnal, about half a mile from where he was preparing to bathe, he had on only his pantaloons and shirt, both torn and bloody. His pantaloons were cut in various places; his vest was found near where he was undressing; his watch, finger-rings and gold shirt-buttons and any money he might have had were missing. On his person, or near where the body was discovered, was only found a closed dispatch addressed to Capt. MILLER, and an English novel. Capt. LAMBERT was only 26 years of age, and distinguished himself in the Crimean war. He was a kind-hearted, convivial man, and probably had not an enemy on the coast. His remains were interred on the 10th, in the English cemetery of Bellavista, near Callao, the cortege being swelled by the diplomatic corps, the officers of the various men-of-war and of foreign merchant-vessels in port, by all the leading British merchants in Lima and Callao, and by an immense concourse of foreign sailors and ar[???]sans. Several persons, cholos, have been arrested for the murder, but no evidence had as yet been elicited of their guilt, except that one of them had the Captain's cap in his possession. And if found and convicted unless the British Government interferes, the murderers will only be punished by a short imprisonment, and then an amnesty or revolution will set them free to do more murder. Capital punishment in Peru, where, of all countries pretending to civilization, life is less secure, has been abolished, and murderers have con[???]quently but little fear of punishment. Three distinguished foreigners have been murdered in Lima within the past two years, and nobody has yet been punished for the crimes. Her Britannic Majesty's Chargs [???] Affaires, Mr. SULLIVAN, was the first victim -- then, only two months since, the Chilian Minister, Se[???]or IRARRAZABAL, and now Capt. LAMBERT.
lead_paragraph: The most important incident of the past fortnight was the murder of Capt. LIONEL LAMBERT, of her Britannic Majesty's war steamer Vi[???]en. On the 8th of February, at 3 o'clock, P.M., Capt. LAMBERT was playing at billiards with some of the officers of his vessel, in the "Hotel de Europa." At a little past [???] he left his companions, saying that he was going to take a bath, and would meet them so as to take the 6 o'clock train to Callao. It appears that he went to the river, and must there have been attacked by several persons and foully murdered. His skull was broken in two places, the blow on the back of t he head apparently having been made by an axe or hatchet. His forehead was badly cut, and his arms and wrists were black and scarred, as if he had had a fearful struggle with his murderers. When Capt. LAMBERT was found in the river in front of the Carnal, about half a mile from where he was preparing to bathe, he had on only his pantaloons and shirt, both torn and bloody. His pantaloons were cut in various places; his vest was found near where he was undressing; his watch, finger-rings and gold shirt-buttons and any money he might have had were missing. On his person, or near where the body was discovered, was only found a closed dispatch addressed to Capt. MILLER, and an English novel. Capt. LAMBERT was only 26 years of age, and distinguished himself in the Crimean war. He was a kind-hearted, convivial man, and probably had not an enemy on the coast. His remains were interred on the 10th, in the English cemetery of Bellavista, near Callao, the cortege being swelled by the diplomatic corps, the officers of the various men-of-war and of foreign merchant-vessels in port, by all the leading British merchants in Lima and Callao, and by an immense concourse of foreign sailors and ar[???]sans. Several persons, cholos, have been arrested for the murder, but no evidence had as yet been elicited of their guilt, except that one of them had the Captain's cap in his possession. And if found and convicted unless the British Government interferes, the murderers will only be punished by a short imprisonment, and then an amnesty or revolution will set them free to do more murder. Capital punishment in Peru, where, of all countries pretending to civilization, life is less secure, has been abolished, and murderers have con[???]quently but little fear of punishment. Three distinguished foreigners have been murdered in Lima within the past two years, and nobody has yet been punished for the crimes. Her Britannic Majesty's Chargs [???] Affaires, Mr. SULLIVAN, was the first victim -- then, only two months since, the Chilian Minister, Se[???]or IRARRAZABAL, and now Capt. LAMBERT.

abstract: The friends of commerce and of peace, (and whoever loves the one can hardly hate the other,) all the world over, will rejoice at the defeat of the first organized attack made by the English Conservatives in Parliament upon the liberal Commercial Treaty recently negotiated by Her Majesty's ministers with the French Government. On the 20th of February, Mr. DISRAELI, as the organ of the ...
lead_paragraph: The friends of commerce and of peace, (and whoever loves the one can hardly hate the other,) all the world over, will rejoice at the defeat of the first organized attack made by the English Conservatives in Parliament upon the liberal Commercial Treaty recently negotiated by Her Majesty's ministers with the French Government. On the 20th of February, Mr. DISRAELI, as the organ of the Conservatives -- who on this occasion, and not for the first time, proved themselves to merit their title only in the fashion of the Latin groves, by the destructiveness of their policy -- moved that the House of Commons should refuse to go into Committee on the Customs acts required by the new treaty with France, until it should have first considered and assented to the engagements made in that treaty. The object of this motion, which was thrown forward under the guise so captivating to the British mind, of a "precedent" drawn from Mr. PITT's manner of subjecting to discussion his own Commercial Treaty, negotiated with France in 1787, was simply to force upon the House a general political discussion of the political bearings of the treaty. Mr. DISRAELI and his followers, representing the most accomplished panic-mongers of Great Britain, of course expected, in the event of their success upon this issue, to evoke all manner of frightful phantoms where with to scare the nation into Anti-Gallican convulsions strong enough to topple down the Palmerston Ministry. The spectre of the annexation of Savoy -- the supposition of a sacrifice by the Treaty of the belligerent rights of England, so absolute that even in time of war with France the colliers of Newcastle and Cardiff would find themselves compelled to coal up the imperial steamers, these were the matters which Mr. DISRAELI wished to drag at once into the foreground, before the sound commercial principles embodied in the treaty, and the vast commercial benefits which it involves for the future of both countries, could have time to impress themselves profoundly upon the mind of Parliament and of the country. The notion was sufficiently astute, and quite in the usual vein of its author -- whose theory and practice of Parliamentary tactics do not, we are sorry to say, very materially differ from those which find an unfortunate degree of favor at Washington. And it was executed with not less than Mr. DISRAELI's usual courage and cunning, and more than his usual condescending charity, since he blandly assured the Government that he was convinced they had only "inadvertently" violated the proprieties of Parliament, and that they might therefore accept his motion "with honor and with dignity;" which was as much as to say that he would not think of forcing them to resign, because, they had tripped on a question of precedent and form.

abstract: HIGHWAYMEN AND BURGLARS. -- The Police of the Third Precinct, on Saturday night, arrested two men, named PETER DONNELLY and PATHICK CAHILL, on suspicion of being the parties who, late one night last week, attempted to rob Mr. C. HAYS, near the Hamilton-avenue bridge. They were only prevented from accomplishing their purpose by the resolute defence which Mr. HAYS made. They were fully identified and committed to await the action of the Grand Jury. .... OWEN CONLEY and PATRICK MCARDLE, were arrested by the Second Precinct Police yesterday, and committed to answer a charge of burglary, preferred by the proprietor of a store at the corner of Jay and Water streets.

abstract: GEORGE LAW, in his mercantile relations, is a bullion philosopher--one who believes in the mollifying chink of gold--one who has faith unlimited in the sweet rustle and silvery invitation of current bankable paper. He has studied ...
lead_paragraph: GEORGE LAW, in his mercantile relations, is a bullion philosopher--one who believes in the mollifying chink of gold--one who has faith unlimited in the sweet rustle and silvery invitation of current bankable paper. He has studied human nature in its pecuniary aspect with amazing success; and in all his operations we find evidence that his estimates of market value and worth have been based on the profoundest calculations.

lead_paragraph: Monday evening, the occasion of commencing s new milk train on the Northern Railroad of NewJersey, running in and through Rockland County, was embraced by the directors of the Rockland County and New-Jersey Milk Association to invite a few friends to join them in an excursion to Spring Valley, under the direction of S.W. CANFIELD, Agent, and see the actual facts connected with their business, -- to satisfy themselves that the country is a grazing one; that there are no distilleries anywhere on the road, and no facilities for making anything but pure milk.

abstract: The State Comptroller has sent a communication to the Legislature on the condition and prospects of the State Treasury. The picture which he presents is not very cheerful. The total amount of money which is to be raised by tax for the service of the year, is $5,470,000, or three mills and seven-eighths of a mill upon every dollar of property in the State.
lead_paragraph: The State Comptroller has sent a communication to the Legislature on the condition and prospects of the State Treasury. The picture which he presents is not very cheerful. The total amount of money which is to be raised by tax for the service of the year, is $5,470,000, or three mills and seven-eighths of a mill upon every dollar of property in the State. The falling off in the revenues or the canals, and the increased interest to be paid upon the debts of the State, have rendered this augmented resort to taxation unavoidable.

abstract: Gen. CASTILLA, after having set up a President for Ecuadorian Guayaquil, in the person of the mulatto,  Gen. FRANCO, made a treaty with him, and then furnished him with arms and money with which to bring the Moreno Junta at Quito to terms, evacuated Guayaquil on the 12th February with all his force, and ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. CASTILLA, after having set up a President for Ecuadorian Guayaquil, in the person of the mulatto, Gen. FRANCO, made a treaty with him, and then furnished him with arms and money with which to bring the Moreno Junta at Quito to terms, evacuated Guayaquil on the 12th February with all his force, and arrived at Paita, Peru, with them on the 14th, on his way to Lima. CASTILLA, at the head of 6,000 men, has thus expended seven or eight millions of dollars in making a treaty with a chief who is only acknowledged in Ecuador by a small fraction of the people, whose acts will not be acknowledged by the majority, and who will be driven out of the country in less than three months. There seems to be no other assignable cause for this lame consummation than that CASTILLA found he had undertaken a task he was not equal to, and, therefore, backed out in as decent a manner as he could under cover of the cringing concession on paper made by FRANCO. On his departure, CASTILLA issued the usual bombastic bulletins to his army, in which he praises them for their gallant conduct in the occupation of the suburbs of Guayaquil, and finally of Guayaquil itself, as if torrents of blood had flown instead of the rivulets of champagne, in which FRANOO drowned the memory of his treason in peaceably admitting him to take his quarters in the town.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The Festival entertainments at the Academy of Music in aid of the family of the late Mr. GEORGE WILKINS were a complete success, and a very important sum, we are happy to say will be handed, over to Mrs. WILKINS. Considering the extent of the programme the performance passed off admirably, and there were but few disappointments. In the afternoon the Laura Keene company was no forthcoming, and in the evening several pianists and singers, who thought more of themselves than of the public, chose to take umbrage at something and refused to assist. No one missed the dramatci company, and no one would have cared about the others, had it not been for the inordinate and ominous delay which preceded the apology. A very worthy exception to the mutinous egotists was Mrs. C.M. BRINCKERHOFF, who, in the face of an irritated audience, more than fulfilled her promise, and succeeded in restoring good humor. The pianists who were to have performed publish a card elsewhere.

abstract: THE METHODIST MISSIONS IN CHINA.--REV. R.S. MACLAY, recently returned from a thirteen years' absence in the missionary field of China, connected with the Methodist Church, addressed the congregation of the Eighteenth-street Methodist Episcopal Church last evening, upon the subject of missionary labors in China. He spoke of the wide field lately opened up in the Chinese Empire for missionary labor, and promise of a rich harvest to the patient and energetic ...
lead_paragraph: THE METHODIST MISSIONS IN CHINA.--REV. R.S. MACLAY, recently returned from a thirteen years' absence in the missionary field of China, connected with the Methodist Church, addressed the congregation of the Eighteenth-street Methodist Episcopal Church last evening, upon the subject of missionary labors in China. He spoke of the wide field lately opened up in the Chinese Empire for missionary labor, and promise of a rich harvest to the patient and energetic laborer. The Church of Rome bad been there 200 years, and by a clause in the late treaty, inserted through the influence of France, annulling all former edicts against Christianity, that church would come in possession of immense wealth, by regaining possession of property formerly confiscated, thereby giving them an immense advantage over other sects; yet the Protestants had the advantage of them in this -- that they were new comers, not like the Catholics, objects of suspicion, and their open and above-board mode of doing business was much more congenial to the Chinese character; for if there was anything that the Chinese abhorred more than another, it was secrecy. For this cause they detested the Jesuits. He gave a flattering account of the success of the Methodist Mission at Foo-Chow, the central field of their labors, and said that during the past two years he had baptised sixty-two converts, all of whom were able to give a reason for the faith that was in them. He was followed by Dr. DURBIN, who spoke generally of the Missionary cause as connected with the M.E. Church. The annual collection for the Missionary cause was then taken up.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Paul Duorfar, a young German engaged as clerk in a wholesale trimmings-store, and residing at No. 55 Pitt-street, lost a poodle dog which he valued very highly. After having searched for it a long time in vain, he returned to his house about 8 o'clock, appearing to be much excited with reference to his loss. His wife Philopena, on the contrary, was pleased at getting rid of the troublesome animal, and expressed her exultation in no measured terms. This conduct on her part so incensed Duorfar that he drew a pocket-knife and thrust it about two inches in her right shoulder, inflicting a very painful wound. The injured woman made her way to the Thirteenth Ward Station-house, where Dr. Kimbark attended her. Meantime her husband had been arrested by Officer Simonton, and he was locked up in a cell for the night.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Paul Duorfar, a young German engaged as clerk in a wholesale trimmings-store, and residing at No. 55 Pitt-street, lost a poodle dog which he valued very highly. abstract: Who the deuce is "Glaucus?" Who's the man that's treading on my toes again, and writing newspaper letters from here for the TIMES? abstract: A writer in the Savannah Republican makes an announcement, which will, doubtless, shock if not prostrate the manufacturing interests of the North. The students and soldiers of South Carolina have resolved to discard every article of apparel of Northern make. Minerva and Juno are to be arrayed in Carolina homespun ...
lead_paragraph: A writer in the Savannah Republican makes an announcement, which will, doubtless, shock if not prostrate the manufacturing interests of the North. The students and soldiers of South Carolina have resolved to discard every article of apparel of Northern make. Minerva and Juno are to be arrayed in Carolina homespun and the first families' daughters adopt the patriotic mode. The Richland soldiers have ordered a new uniform from the Columbia mills, and sworn that no blood of theirs shall hereafter stain, on the battle-field, the fabrics which their foes have wrought.

abstract: the tone of conc[???]ation and Kindness which pervades Mr. ABBOTT's account of a trip to Cuba and the South, made last December, and of the impressions received by the author at the time with regard to Slavery, will tend to mollify the hostility which his free expression of opinion may excite. The first part of the volume consists of a journal giving the experiences and reflections of the writer. Of necessity he saw little in his journey of the actual working of Slavery, beyond what might be caught up in a speedy transit by railroad and steamer. He saw the country and its degree of culture, the houses and churches, the people and the property, and the newspapers, with their advertisements of human auction sales, and their Pro-Slavery pleas; but he spent no time on plantations, informing himself by actual inspection of the condition of the negro and of society at the South; he brings to us very little, in short, that we did not know before. The latter part of the book is a discourse, forcible, but not harsh, on the present aspect of political affairs. He dwells upon the aggressions of the South, exposes the fruits and philosophy of Slavery, enlarges upon the comparative results to the South and to the North of a dissolution of the Union, which he holds would be the sure forerunner of the emancipation of the slave, and declares that

The first part of the volume consists of a journal giving the experiences and reflections of the writer. Of necessity he saw little in his journey of the actual working of Slavery, beyond what might be caught up in a speedy transit by railroad and steamer. He saw the country and its degree of culture, the houses and churches, the people and the property, and the newspapers, with their advertisements of human auction sales, and their Pro-Slavery pleas; but he spent no time on plantations, informing himself by actual inspection of the condition of the negro and of society at the South; he brings to us very little, in short, that we did not know before. The latter part of the book is a discourse, forcible, but not harsh, on the present aspect of political affairs. He dwells upon the aggressions of the South, exposes the fruits and philosophy of Slavery, enlarges upon the comparative results to the South and to the North of a dissolution of the Union, which he holds would be the sure forerunner of the emancipation of the slave, and declares that

abstract: Mr. HOWARD FOUNTAIN, part proprietor of the factory at the corner of Fifty-fifth-street and Second-avenue, on Saturday, while screwing down a press, was caught by his coat collar in the main shaft of the engine and hurled against the ceiling with such force that the injuries to his head and thigh, both of which were shockingly mangled, caused his death in a few hours. A jury, summoned by Corone, GAMBLET rendered a verdict of accidental death.... ANTHONY ROUEN, a boy 47 years of age, while left alone in his mother's room, in Sixty-seventh-street, set his clothes on fire with a match. He died on the following day... JAMES R. MAR[???]HALL, a child living with his parents at No. 46 Watt-stree[???]t, was scalded about a week ago by the accidental overturning of a pan of hot water. The injuries he received resulted fatally on Sunday. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest in both cases..... CATHERINE SULLIVAN, a child 15 months old, living at No. 362 Cherry-street, was choked on Sunday by the Jodgment of a piece f meat in her throat. Coroner GAMBLE held the inquest.

abstract: The Joint Select Committee of the Legislature of Maine, appointed to investigate the defalcation of BENJAMIN D. PECK, late State Treasurer, has completed its report, which we find in the Boston papers of Saturday. The developments are extraordinary; the case involving not only the name of Mr. PECK, but those of NEAL DOW, DANIEL E. SOMES, member of Congress from the First District of Maine, and other prominent men in the State.
lead_paragraph: The Joint Select Committee of the Legislature of Maine, appointed to investigate the defalcation of BENJAMIN D. PECK, late State Treasurer, has completed its report, which we find in the Boston papers of Saturday. The developments are extraordinary; the case involving not only the name of Mr. PECK, but those of NEAL DOW, DANIEL E. SOMES, member of Congress from the First District of Maine, and other prominent men in the State. The Committee have held nearly fifty protracted sessions, extending through a period of two months, and has taken an immense amount of testimony. The amount of the defalcation is officially stated at $[???]4,023 99.

abstract: On motion of Mr. J.M. MURPHY, of this City, the Senate of New-York on the 3d inst. adopted a preamble and resolutions calling upon the Commissioners of the Central Park (who had already handed in to the Legislature a remarkably clear and detailed report of their proceedings and their plans) to reply to a series of questions on the matter of their trust.
lead_paragraph: On motion of Mr. J.M. MURPHY, of this City, the Senate of New-York on the 3d inst. adopted a preamble and resolutions calling upon the Commissioners of the Central Park (who had already handed in to the Legislature a remarkably clear and detailed report of their proceedings and their plans) to reply to a series of questions on the matter of their trust. These questions were rather in the nature of an [???]nquisition than an inquiry; and from their one and temper might be very easily mistaken or an arraignment of the Board to which they were addressed. They can only be compared in this respect with that singular letter of Mr. ROBERT J. DILLON, which we published on Saturday, and in which the same unfortunate officials are charged with "malfeasance," in that [???]hey dared to adopt a plan which Mr. DILLON considers a "mutilation and a deformity." Indeed, if Mr. DILLON were not a private citizen, he might be naturally assumed to be the author of the Senatorial questions as well as of his own ex-cathedral epistle. The first of these interrogations, for instance, dashes off in the following style, with an impetuosity which quite disregards the ordinary requisitions of Syntax: "What reasons for having adopted and undertaken a plan for the Park, the execution of which exceeds the limitations of the Legislature by the act of 1857?"

abstract: The Boston Traveller records the death of Deacon Ebenezer Clapp, a direct descendant in the fourth generation of the Pilgrim stock. He died at Dorchester, Mass., of old age, a few days since. The Traveller says: "He was born on the 25th of August, 1771, and was a son of Noah Clapp, who graduated at Harvard in 1735, and was for forty-one years town clerk of Dorchester. His grandfather, Deacon Jonathan Clapp, was born in 1673, and was the son of Nathaniel Clapp, born in 1640. Nathaniel was the son of Nicholas Clapp, one of the first settlers in this ancient town. Thus the recently deceased gentlemen was only the fourth generation from the first settlers, and probably was the last person of that generation. Born a short time previous to the Revolution, the earliest event he remembered was the burning of Charleston, and the Battle of Bunker Hill, which he w[???]nessed from Jones' Hill, Dorchester. He always took delight in narrating his recollections of that period. At the age of fifteen years and a half, he volunteered in the army raised by Gen. Lincoln for the suppression of Shay's Rebellion, and was the last survivor of the Dorchester Company.

abstract: Egbert Dem ng, Trustee. &c., vs. The New-York Marble Company, Henry Dwight and James R. B[???]ne, Trustees, &c. -- This is an action brought to restrain the defendants. Henry Dwight and James R. Baine, from any further interference, as trustees or otherwise, with the property of the New-York Marble Company, on the ground of alleged fraud and in[???]gement on the part of the defendants -- and for the appointment of a Receiver of the assets of the Company, for the benefit of creditors and others interested in the Company. The plaintiffs applied for an injunction, and a receiver pendente lite. After bearing, the Court ordered a temporary injunction, and an order of reference to Joseph Neilson, Esq., to appoint a Receiver. An able opinion was rendered by Justice ALLEN, of the Supreme Court, before whom the cause was heard, on granting the motion.

abstract: Judge COLLAMER, of Vermont, made a very able speech upon the Slavery question in the Senate of the United States a few days since. It was marked by historical research, logical ability and excellent temper. In the course of it he said that the Republican Party propose to restore the Missouri Compromise line.
lead_paragraph: Judge COLLAMER, of Vermont, made a very able speech upon the Slavery question in the Senate of the United States a few days since. It was marked by historical research, logical ability and excellent temper. In the course of it he said that the Republican Party propose to restore the Missouri Compromise line. "What," said he, "is the proposition of the Republican Party? Nothing more, nothing less than to restore that line." We doubt very much whether upon this point he spoke the general sentiment of the Republican Party. It was unquestionably the repeal of that Compromise which called the Republican Party into existence; they resisted the effort to blot it out, but it does not follow that they would favor its restoration.

abstract: -- On the morning of the 4th inst., a serious [???]bance occurred on the British ship Aramingo, Capt. L.P. CASSAN. lying in the stream at Charleston. The crew of the vessel is composed of negroes. The second mate ordered the boatswaid to take in some clothes which were [???]ung up to dry, as it did not look well to have them out on the Sa[???]th. The boatswain replied that the mate might attend to it himself, and on his disregarding the order when it structed, the captain ordered him to be ironed. The two mates seized him, when CHARLES HENRY, another of the crew, came forward to his assistance. HENRY seized a crowhar, which was immediately [???] from him by the captain. This part of the disturbance took place on the poop-deck. HENRY, being deprived of his weapon, jumped on the main deck, and, from the cook's gatlery, securing the meat [???] called on the rest of the crew to help to kill the officers, at[???]ching most oporobrious epithets to their names, and returned himself to the encounter. On the approach of HENRY with the axe, the first mate, Mr. S.C. COLESBERY, drew his revolver and shot him, after which quiet was soon restored. CLAIR and HENRY were after wards arrested and lodged in the Guard House. Dr. MICHEL attended the wounded man at the Guard House, but the injury is slight, the b[???] having struck one of the lower right ribs and glances off. The negroes were held for examination. One of them had previously warned the captain that it was the intention of the crew to rise in mutiny and seize the vessel when she got to sea, but no attention was paid to the story.

abstract: Frederick Schuhardt, et al. vs. John Roth et. al. -- This was a motion before the Special Term of the Supreme Court on the part of defendants to vacate a judgment and execution for irregularity. It appeared that plaintiff's attorneys resided in New-York, and defendants' attorneys in Troy. The time to answer expired Jan. 16, 1860. On that day defendants' attorney, at Troy, obtained an order extending the time to answer twenty days, and duly served such answer by mail; that is, by depositing the same in the Post-office at Troy, directed to Plaintiff's attorneys, at New-York, and paying postage. The order was not received by plaintiff's attorneys until 18th January, after they had, on that morning, entered judgment in the action, and issued execution, and they then gave defendants' attorneys notice that the papers so served would be disregarded.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Schuhardt, et al. vs. John Roth et. al. -- This was a motion before the Special Term of the Supreme Court on the part of defendants to vacate a judgment and execution for irregularity. It appeared that plaintiff's attorneys resided in New-York, and defendants' attorneys in Troy. The time to answer expired Jan. 16, 1860. The order was not received by plaintiff's attorneys until 18th January, after they had, on that morning, entered judgment in the action, and issued execution, and they then gave defendants' attorneys notice that the papers so served would be disregarded.

abstract: The Convention of the Friends of Union Prayer Meetings met yesterday morning, in the Sansom street Baptist Church, the President, W.E. DODGE, in the Chair. The morning was chiefly consumed in the reading and consideration of the report of the committee, in relation to "the carrying out, in every proper way, and to every possible extent, the principles of Christian union." After alluding to the benefits which have resulted from union prayer meetings, in bringing together those of various denominations to worship in the same sanctuary, thereby destroying, in a great measure, the spirit of sectarianism, the paper recommended, among other things. the establishment of a system by which informal social gatherings may take place for an interchange of views and prayer, the number at each not to exceed ten or fifteen. It was also recommended that the pulpit and the Press he urged to advocate the subject of Christian Union, and that as anding committee be appointed, composed of the oldest and most experienced in the body, to carry out the recommendations embodied in the report. A series of resolutions, appended to the paper, were, after its acceptance, taken up for consideration, and were passed, when the report had been so amended as to strike out that portion of it suggesting social informal gatherings of different danominations, which it was thought by some of the delegates would have the effect to revive, rather than deaden, sectarianism. Rev. Dr. NEVIN offered a resolution recommending that the second month be devoted to the subject of Christian unity, which was being discussed at the hour of adjournment.

abstract: A warrant was yesterday issued by Justice OSBORN for the apprehension of Capt. H.S. Ackerman, Mr. Wm. Jones and Don Jose Perrians, of Cuba, on a charge of conspiring to defraud, preferred by Mr. Antonio Pelletier of this City. The complainant alleges that on the 1st of february he purchased for $5,500 the bark white Cloud from Francis Trowbridge, and that Capt. Ackerman acted as broker in the transaction, receiving for his services a commission of $150. Subsequently, for his convenience, Mr. Pelletier avers that he executed a bill of sale for the vessel to Mr. Jones, receiving from that individual a power of attorney giving [???] exclusive control over the bark. Meantime preparations were in progress under Mr. Pelletier's direction, for the departure of the vessel, but with in a day or two he has been informed that Mr. Jones has executed a bill of sale for the bark to Mr. Albert B. Mulbridge. This proceeding on the part of Mr. Jones he characterized as an attempt to defraud him of his rights. Ackerman is charged with complicity in the transaction, as also is Don Jose Perrians, who is said to have furnished money for the purpose of cancelling liabilities for ship's supplies, incurred at the request of the complainant, and on account of which the Sheriff has claims against the vessel. Yesterday Mr. Jones was arrested by Officer McCord, of the Lower Police Court, upon the complaint, and was held for examination. His alleged co-conspirators have not been arrested.
lead_paragraph: A warrant was yesterday issued by Justice OSBORN for the apprehension of Capt. H.S. Ackerman, Mr. Wm. Jones and Don Jose Perrians, of Cuba, on a charge of conspiring to defraud, preferred by Mr. Antonio Pelletier of this City. The complainant alleges that on the 1st of february he purchased for $5,500 the bark white Cloud from Francis Trowbridge, and that Capt. Ackerman acted as broker in the transaction, receiving for his services a commission of $150. Subsequently, for his convenience, Mr. Pelletier avers that he executed a bill of sale for the vessel to Mr. Jones, receiving from that individual a power of attorney giving [???] exclusive control over the bark. Meantime preparations were in progress under Mr. Pelletier's direction, for the departure of the vessel, but with in a day or two he has been informed that Mr. Jones has executed a bill of sale for the bark to Mr. Albert B. Mulbridge. This proceeding on the part of Mr. Jones he characterized as an attempt to defraud him of his rights. Ackerman is charged with complicity in the transaction, as also is Don Jose Perrians, who is said to have furnished money for the purpose of cancelling liabilities for ship's supplies, incurred at the request of the complainant, and on account of which the Sheriff has claims against the vessel. Yesterday Mr. Jones was arrested by Officer McCord, of the Lower Police Court, upon the complaint, and was held for examination. His alleged co-conspirators have not been arrested.

abstract: Mr. HYATT again figured before the Senate today, and proceedings were interesting. In the general view of the subject, the Senate was nearly unanimous in maintaining its constitutional power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the consequent power to compel them to testify. Mr. DOOLITTLE conceded it to be vitally important that this power should not be disclaimed as requested by HYATT.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, March 12.

abstract: The steamer Ondine, from Dublin to London, came in collision with the schooner Heroine, off Beechey Head, about 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, Feb. 19. In twenty minutes no traces of her were left. Twenty one passengers and crew were saved in the jollyboat, about 30 went down in the steamer, and the captain, with 20 others, were lost in a life-boat.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Ondine, from Dublin to London, came in collision with the schooner Heroine, off Beechey Head, about 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, Feb. 19. In twenty minutes no traces of her were left. Twenty one passengers and crew were saved in the jollyboat, about 30 went down in the steamer, and the captain, with 20 others, were lost in a life-boat.

abstract: Considering the vast and almost universal employment of steam as a mechanical agent in the manufactures and commerce of the City, one would suppose that more method in its use, move system in its development and application would be employed. If we walk through the work-a-day part of the City and note the countless exhausts proceeding from iron and brazen throats, hear the shrill whistle of the saw, or the duller boom of the hammer, and see the mighty genii which exerts all this force, slowly uncoiling in sinuous wreaths from its prison, the supposition would be that great care and oversight must be employed to preserve so vast a motor unimpaired in its effects; and considering the expense attending its introduction and use, be led to the inference that every means which science had adopted, or ingenuity developed, would be employed to make it saving and economical in its action; that leaky joints were stopped and no more leakages permitted; that fuel was economically and properly burnt, and that the whole of the vast machine on which the welfare and prosperity of thousands depend, would be upon a scale of minuteness and efficiency which had no parallel in any other mechanical force.

abstract: By the arrival of the America at Halifax, we have Liverpool news to Feb. 25, and telegraphic advices from Queenstown to the 26th. The proceedings of Parliament had been interesting. In the House of Commons, on the 24th, Mr. BRIGHT had made a very able speech in defence of the Commercial Treaty with France. The London Herald intimates that the reward of his services to the Ministry on this and other occasions will be the Postmaster-Generalship, vacated by the Earl or E[???]n, who goes as special Plenipotentiary to China. Mr. DUCANE's motion, of the same general character as that of Mr. DISRAELI previously rejected, was defeated by a majority of 116. The Budget was to come up for formal discussion on the 27th ult. Mr. HADFIELD had inquired in the Commons, whether the Government was apprized of the approaching international prize-fight, and what measures had been taken to prevent it. The Home Secretary replied that the only step taken or practicable was to prohibit the fight within the limits of the Metropolitan Police District. Rumors from the Continent indicate the early likelihood of a renewed collision in Italy. Austria is rapidly arming along the Mincio, while the armament of Piedmont proceeds with unabated rapidity. The King of Sardinia, who remains at Milan, had addressed a letter to the Pope in behalf of the Umbrian provinces, and had received a sharp negative in reply. A statement that under the pressure of Russian and Prussian interposition, the Emperor of France had resolved to abandon the project of the annexation of Central Italy to Sardinia, was current and credited. A more questionable rumor of a strict alliance having just been formed between the Courts of Vienna and St. Petersburg, was also in circulation. The terms offered by Marshal O'DONNELL to the Moors, but rejected, involved a payment by them of $25,000,000 and the cession of conquered territory. Hostilities were about to be renewed. From China we hear that the provisions of the American Treaty relative to the opening of the ports of Swatow and Kiawan, have been fulfilled, vessels of all nations now being admitted thither.

He thought that the present aspect of our civilization, in regard ...
lead_paragraph: The first half-hour of the time of the meeting was consumed by reading an elaborate paper by Prof. RUBEN upon the power of the wedge. At 8 o'clock the subject of the evening, viz., "The adulteration of food and drink," was taken up. Dr. STEPHENS read a paper upon the subject. He thought that the present aspect of our civilization, in regard to the adulteration of articles of food and drink, would be amusing to the philosopher, if it were not for the unmitigated dishonesty revealed, and the injury to life and health produced thereby. We were as a people inclined to bogus articles. We put bogus money in our pockets, trod in bogus shoes, clothed in bogus cloth, and wore bogus hats. We drank bogus coffee, with Canadian chickory, Ohio peas and New-England beans, for our breakfast. At our corner grocery we can buy coffee from eight to twenty cents per pound, according to our taste or the condition of our purse, and all from the same original bag of Java or Lagunyra. We can purchase "Canton teas" in the market, where the proportion of genuine tea plant leaves to other shrubs and herbs and leaves, is about as 1 to 10. Perhaps we have palmed upon us a Water street mixture of damaged teas, with clover leaves and a wisp of some highly-flavored article of tea, to illude the olfactory organs. Do we know how much logwood, or Nicaragua wood, we purchase with our Cayenne pepper? -- how much India meal with our g[???]er? -- and, with our other spices, how much, of spice be[???]nes from which the essential oil has already been extracted by di[???]tilloin. Good Yankee whiteoak acorns are strangely metamorp[???]osed into nutmegs, which otherwise. with care and culture, would have made splendid pasture oaks, and given to Yankee grandchildren the means of ship-building from native growth of timber. One may be par[???]ed for smoking a good Long Island cabbage, and for enjoying the pleasing illusion that be is induiging in a real Havana, but he submitted whether it would not be better and more conducive to true b[???]genics, to eat toe cabbage and omit the smoking? In these days of cant and sharp driving of bargan[???]s, the satire of the following may not be too cutting: "John, have you sanded the sugar?" "Yes." " Watered the rum?" "Yes." 'Dampered the tobacco?" "Yes." "Mealed the ginger?" "Yes." "Sottened the molasses?" "Yes." "Swept out the store?" "Yes." " Then come to prayers." The Doctor sat down amid the laughter and cheering of his auditory.

abstract: The Northampton (Mass.) Courier says: "At the recent term of the Superior Court two of the oldest members of the Hampshire Bar were present -- Laban Marcy. Esq., of Greenwich, and Epap[???]ras Clark. Esq., of Enheld. Mr. Marcy is 80 years of age, and Mr. Clark about 68. Notwithstanding Mr. Marcy's advanced age, he is as active as many men at 50 years, and conducted a case at this term, standing while questioning witnesses, in conformity with the [???] of the Court. He has been in the practice of law at Greenwich fifty-one years.

abstract: THE VICTIM OF A WINDFALL. -- WILLLIAM BROWN, a fruit-peddler, residing at No. 37 Park-street, was apprehended on Saturday, on suspicion of having stolen a silver-plated tea-service and two dozen silver-plated knives, the whole valued at $100, which were found in his possession. The prisoner alleges that while he was passing through Park-row with his cart, on the 20th ult., one JOHN DUNSWORTH came running by at the top of his speed, pursued by another man, and that a box containing the property in question was thrown by the fugitive into his vehicle. For a long time BROWN debated the question whether he should retain the property or deliver it to the Police, but his conscientious scruples on the subject were finally overcome, and he deposited the goods for safe-keeping with a porter of one of the City Banks, with whom he was acquainted, expecting to call for them when his necessities required him to do so. On Friday last he procured a portion of the silver-ware with the purpose of pawning it, but became intoxicated before he succeeded in his intention, and was only able to reach the front door of his dwelling, where he lay down in a drunken stupor with the property scattered around him. While he was thus insensible, a Mrs. O'FEELY happening along, seized the goods and started off. When the sleeper came to his senses he missed the property, and finally learned what had become of it. His demand for its surrender, however, proved unsuccessful, so he asked the intervention of the police, who, after much exertion, at last induced Mrs. O'FEELY to give it up. The matter resulted, however, in the arrest of the claimant, on the supposition that he had stolen it. Subsequently the remainder of the property was obtained from the Mercantile Bank. BROWN, who has heretofore borne a good reputation, admits that he acted improperly in retaining the goods under the circumstances, and says that his mind has been sadly exercised on the subject ever since. The man DUNS- WORTH, whom BROWN accuses with having thrown the goods into his cart, and thus become the cause of his misfortune, was apprehended on a charge of stealing a case of Bohemian glass-ware, and was endeavoring to escape arrest at the time of the alleged transaction. He, last Friday, pleaded guilty to having committed the offence, and was sentenced to the Penitentiary for six months. BROWN is detained for examination, and the silver-ware may be seen at the Sixth Precinct Station-house.

abstract: in preparing a new edition of his Footfalls on the Boundary of Another World, has publicly advertised for well-authenticated ghost stories. According to a tale told by the Pittsburgh papers, he can be accommodated with on excellent one at short notice. Some days since the Pittsburgh Dispatch published a very circumstantial narrative of the appearance of the apparition of a Benedictine monk to a novice at St. Vincent's Abbey, near Lat robe, Pa. The story is confirmed in a formal letter, addressed to the editor of that paper, by "B. WIMER, Abbot," who writes from St. Vincent's, under date of Feb. 26, in the following extraordinary strain:

abstract: Play was resumed last evening in the telegraphic match between the New-York and Boston Chess Clubs with the dispatch, by New-York, at 6:40 o'clock, of their seventeenth move in game first At 6:48 Boston telegraphed her eighteenth move in game second. At the close of the play for the evening (11 o'clock) six additional moves had been made on each game. Boston telegraphed a proposition to play through Tuesday night, and New-York acquiesced.

abstract: Catalogues of sales of coins, autographs and private libraries, to be disposed of this Spring, are in preparation. In addition to those of the APPLETONS and BANGS, MERWIN & Co., Messrs, LEAVITT & Co. have issued their semi-annual Trade-Sale Catalogue, a volume of 380 pages comprising 8,000 distinct titles, and about 1,000,000 volumes. This sale will commence on Thursday, 29th instant, continuing for a week. Messrs. THOMAS & SONS, of Philadelphia, have also put forth a catalogue of valuable invoices.

abstract: It is scarcely to be realized, and yet it is strictly true, that the entire line of Aqueduct from High Bridge to Croton Dam, upwards of thirty miles, must be examined and repaired, and these repairs are needed in the space of seventy hours, and this for the reason that the present reservoirs only hold three days' supply of water. Twice in each year the water is o[???]awn off on Wednesday at noon and let on at noon on Saturday, and during this brief time, the entire line of Aqueduct must be traversed, carefully examined, and repairs made; and it has happened on more than one occasion that parties engaged in making repairs which were imperatively necessary have been overtaken by the water, which had been let on, and a few months ago the men had to run five miles before they could get out of the Aqueduct.
lead_paragraph: It is scarcely to be realized, and yet it is strictly true, that the entire line of Aqueduct from High Bridge to Croton Dam, upwards of thirty miles, must be examined and repaired, and these repairs are needed in the space of seventy hours, and this for the reason that the present reservoirs only hold three days' supply of water. abstract: Various law projects, destined to work important changes in the civil administration of England, will be brought before Parliament in the course of this session. The opening speech of the Queen has already announced them; works exchanged in the House of Lords on Tuesday last give us reason to hope that they will this time be submitted to debate, and perhaps disposed of.
lead_paragraph: Various law projects, destined to work important changes in the civil administration of England, will be brought before Parliament in the course of this session. The opening speech of the Queen has already announced them; works exchanged in the House of Lords on Tuesday last give us reason to hope that they will this time be submitted to debate, and perhaps disposed of. First comes a law rendering less difficult and expensive than at present the alienation of landed property; next follows some legislation on the subject of bankruptcy; and, lastly, a law (de procedure) which is to put a stop, as far as possible, to the numerous abuses which seem to be inherent to the administration of justice in England.

abstract: The Morning Chronicle publishes the following in the second edition: "Intelligence just received from a sure source in Vienna is to the following effect: Russia has decided on renewing her old alliance with Austria. The treaty is on the point of being signed, and will be carried to St. Petersburgh by Prince ALEXANDER of Hesse. We have excellent reasons for believing that its provisions will be found to be as follows:
lead_paragraph: The Morning Chronicle publishes the following in the second edition: "Intelligence just received from a sure source in Vienna is to the following effect: Russia has decided on renewing her old alliance with Austria. The treaty is on the point of being signed, and will be carried to St. Petersburgh by Prince ALEXANDER of Hesse. We have excellent reasons for believing that its provisions will be found to be as follows: The most ample concessions as to all that relates to the holy places in Jerusalem will be made by Austria to Russia. Second -- With a view to eventualities, that have every probability of being refused, Austria agrees to conform her policy to that of Russia as to the Danubian provinces and Servia. Third -- AS compensation for these concessions in the East, Russia will guarantee to Austria the whole of her territory, including Hungary and Venetia, against insurrection or foreign foes."

abstract: Mr. E.Y. ROBBINS, whose lectures on Sanitary Science have lately attracted so much attention in Boston, delivered an introductory to a series of lectures upon the same subject, which he proposes to deliver in this City, at the University Medical College, last evening. The lecturer was introduced by PETER COOPER, Esq., to a small audience of ladies and gentlemen, who realized the want of attention to ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. E.Y. ROBBINS, whose lectures on Sanitary Science have lately attracted so much attention in Boston, delivered an introductory to a series of lectures upon the same subject, which he proposes to deliver in this City, at the University Medical College, last evening. The lecturer was introduced by PETER COOPER, Esq., to a small audience of ladies and gentlemen, who realized the want of attention to sanitary science, so prevalent in this City, by being compelled to sit shivering in a large hall without a fire. He commenced by saying that the average duration of human life depended upon the sanitary conditions which surrounded us -- the air we breathe, the food we eat, &c. The health reports of Boston and Providence proved that those who lived in crowded tenements did not live so long by 20 years as those who lived in spacious and well-ventilated houses. The reports of Mr. CHADWICK, the English statistician, proved the same fact. The blood which is impelled through the system is constantly carrying off the decayed particles of the human organism, at the rate of from six to seven pounds daily, about three pounds of which is carbonic acid, and the remainder decomposed animal matter. The whole body is renewed on an average once in 30 days.

abstract: -- There is great complaint of the boxes affixed to the lampposts in the streets for the reception of letters. The principal objection to them is that letters deposited in them are not secure. The lid can be raised, and with pincers letters can be caught and withdrawn. On several occasions persons have been caught in the act of robbing these boxes. It seems very strange that the Post-office authorities should have adopted boxes, and incurred the expense of distributing them through the City, without having first made inquiry into their safety and utility. The experiment of introducing an effective and convenient City delivery ought certainly to be tried under every advantage. The Courrier des Etats Unis says that this style of boxes was brought from Philadelphia, and that those used at Toronto are much the best used on this side the ocean. They are three or four feet high, and letters dropped in through the opening at the top fall to the bottom, from which they are taken through a door, of which the official keeps the key.
