abstract: -- The Norfolk, Va., Da[???] "On Friday last, a woman living a near ne[???]ghbor to a respectable farmer, sent a small boy to his house to request him to come to her house, between 8 and 9 o'lock at night, as she wanted to see him on important business. He went according to appointment, but fearing that all was not right, took a neighbor and his little son with him. He knocked at the [???] lightly, when she asked who it was; he said: "It is I who you sent for to-day.' The light in the house was put out, the door opened and immediately be received the contents of a pistol, a ball. which proved afterwards to have entered his liver. The man who was shot started home, but f[???]l when about fifty yards from his house; was carried home by his neighbor, and died in about twenty-four hours. The woman, who is in jail, is named Mary Simpson, says she shot him for breaking in her house; but the neighbor who accompanied Mr. BUDD, (the man killed,) says he only knocked at the door ge[???]tly. and a small button on the inside was not even bursted off. It seems Miss SIMPSON lived by herself on the land adjoining Mr. BUDD which was owned by a man [???]med [???], who a few days previous had a difficulty with BUDD. which resulted in a fight. O[???] Court day, last Monday, this man, TULLY LILLESTON, went to the jail to visit this women. The excitement against him was so great, that he was prohibited from going to the jail again. and suspicion that he was either the person that shot BUDD or instigated it, soon spread, and it is said if any one had proposed it, he would have been lynched."

abstract: Capt. EDMUND B. MALLET, late of the ship John -Cattle, of Thomaston, Me., who was sent home from Acapulco, by the American Consul, upon a charge of shooting Mr. Perry, the first mate of the ship, off the port of Acapulco, arrived by the steamer Atlantic, with two of the seamen, who were also sent home as witnesses. They were taken in charge by the U.S. Marshal, and, upon the papers attested by the ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. EDMUND B. MALLET, late of the ship John -Cattle, of Thomaston, Me., who was sent home from Acapulco, by the American Consul, upon a charge of shooting Mr. Perry, the first mate of the ship, off the port of Acapulco, arrived by the steamer Atlantic, with two of the seamen, who were also sent home as witnesses. They were taken in charge by the U.S. Marshal, and, upon the papers attested by the Consul, the Captain and witnesses were temporarily committed. Yesterday, the U.S. District-Attoraey having examined the papers, a regular commitment was made out, and the examination of the case was set down for this forenoon. The ship John Cuttle sailed from New-York en the 10th of August last, with a cargo of coal for Acapulco for the Pacific Mall Steamship Co. The voyage was a long and some what harassing one on account of adverse winds and weather, and the ship did not arrive off her port of destination until the 8th of February, 165 days from New-York. The Captain and mate had occasional differentiates during the latter part of the voyage, the cause of which does not appear. On the 7th of February the Captain exhibited strange conduct, challenging the mate to a fist combat on the main deck, which the crew were invited to witness. As the mate would not strike the first blow -- so states one of the witnesses -- the fight was dropped, and the captain became calm. The same evening the mate went off duty, calling the crew to witness the fact. On the following morning he resumed duty, again calling the men as witnesses. In the afternoon some words arose about the bearings of the land, the captain walking the poop-deck, athwart ships, in an uneasy mood. The mate advised him to get some sleep, but the captain said he could not sleep. Afterwards, about 3 1/2 o'clock, it being the mate's watch, the captain appeared on the deck smoking a pipe, and saying he "felt queer." The mate told him if he would put his pipe away he would feel better. The captain went below, the mate remarking that too captain was crazy. Shortly afterwards he came up with a loaded revolver, emerging from the after companion way, and fired at the mate, who ran below, followed by the captain, who continued to discharge his pistol at him. The mate ran through the cabin, going forward on the main deck, where a fourth shot was fired, the mate falling near the forward house. The captain then gave up the charge of the ship to the second mate, and on the following day he was placed in irons by the crew. The ship reached Acapuleo on the 10th of February, where the facts were reported to the American Consul, who took the captain into custody.

abstract: The London Morning Chronicle off-sets the famous Russo-French Alliance, which was last year flashed upon the world from the columns of the Times, with a new diplomatic portent of its own. It informs us, of course "on the best authority" from Vienna, that Russia has decided to renew her old relations with Austria; and that a treaty of alliance has been signed between those Powers on the principle ...
lead_paragraph: The London Morning Chronicle off-sets the famous Russo-French Alliance, which was last year flashed upon the world from the columns of the Times, with a new diplomatic portent of its own. It informs us, of course "on the best authority" from Vienna, that Russia has decided to renew her old relations with Austria; and that a treaty of alliance has been signed between those Powers on the principle of mutual support in the name of the rights of princes and the doctrines of legitimacy. By the terms of this treaty, it is said, Austria agrees to surrender the East to the policy of the Czar, in return for a guarantee by Russia of the Austrian dominion over Hungary and Venetia.

abstract: The ill-fated steamship is reported to have been seen by a coasting vessel, off Liverpool, about 6 P.M. on Sunday, 19th ult, apparently steering N.N.W., which, unless she were at a distance of at least twenty-five miles from the coast, must have been nearly four points off her true course. At three o'clock on the following morning, a man named BARRY NICKERSON, residing on Cape Sable, descried, exactly in the direction of the reef known as the "Horse Race," what he took to be the lights of a steamer. These lights when first seen were stationary, and remained immovably in the same position, as our informant thinks, for more than half an hour, when they appeared to move very swiftly in a north westerly direction, and in the course of ten or fifteen minutes became once more stationary. Mr. HENRY NICKERSON, who resides on Fish Island, states that he first saw the light in the position which the wreck now occupies, at four o'clock, and comprehending that some unknown vessel was in distress, aroused his son and a neighbor, crossed in a fishing skiff the inlet which divides the island from Cape Sable, and, in the hope of attracting the attention of the crew, exhibited a lighted lantern from the highest point of land that could be found.

abstract: The Board of Fire Commissioners of Baltimore in their Annual Report, recently submitted to the Corporation of that city, set forth that during the past year they have fully organized the paid Fire Department, in accordance with the ordinances of the Common Council, with economy and efficiency, and without interference to any considerable extent on the part of members of the volunteer Department.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Fire Commissioners of Baltimore in their Annual Report, recently submitted to the Corporation of that city, set forth that during the past year they have fully organized the paid Fire Department, in accordance with the ordinances of the Common Council, with economy and efficiency, and without interference to any considerable extent on the part of members of the volunteer Department. There are now in active service seven Steam Engine Companies, and two Hook and Ladder Companies. The Commissioners commend the usefulness of the Fire Alarm Telegraph and the conduct of he members of the Department under the new sys[???]em. There is no more lawless rioting, they say, arising out of the bitter feuds of rival companies, but with good feeling, harmonious action, and generous rivalry, the firemen perform their duties. The total cost of the Department is less, in proportion to its service and efficiency, than that of any other fire department in the country, and is a less tax on the City and citizens than the old volunteer Department. Experience proves that the Paid Steam Fire Department can be supported at a [???]ess cost than that which it has superseded. The total cost of the Department since its organization to Jan. 1, 1860 -- a little over a year -- was $123,185 33. including the outlay for construction and purchase of all the property now belonging to the Department. The total current expenses were $32,131 14, and the estimate for the present year is $47,500, of which $36,000 is for salaries. The reformation in the discipline of the department and morals of its members has been followed by a corresponding diminution of the number of fires and of the loss of property. The insurance companies have made a reduction in consequence: the public pay, probably, on an average twenty-five per cent, less on insurances effected since the organization of the new Department. The Commissioners ask for more fire alarm signal-boxes and additional hose, and acknowledge their obligations for the cooperation of the Mayor and citizens of Baltimore.

abstract: Very few persons have considered or spent much time in reflecting that lounging makes up a necessary part of almost every human being's existence. Some persons, it is true, lounge a great deal more than others -- do little more indeed than lounge through life; but everybody has his moments of abandon, and no one ever yet saw that man or woman who did not love to lounge a little -- excepting, perhaps, dyspeptic old misers and bilious cantankerous old maids.
lead_paragraph: Very few persons have considered or spent much time in reflecting that lounging makes up a necessary part of almost every human being's existence. abstract: A Philadelphian, says the Ledger, has just completed an engine for the running of passenger cars by compressed air. The engine has two cylinders, made of gun metal, each 3 [???]ches in diamter and 12 inch stroke, and are supplied with WI[???]GAND's patent cut-off so that the pressure in the cylinders can be regulated with great nicety. The cylinders are connected with the wheels of the car by rods, in the same manner as now in use in the construction of locomotives, and, by an outside arrangement, the air is admitted to the cylinders in the same way as steam. Under the bo[???]y of the car are placed 8 iron pipes, each 20 feet long and 8 inches in diameter, and, combined, are made to bear a pressure of 1,200 pounds -- much more, it is believed, than is necessary to run a car one trip. The air is compressed in these pipes by means of an air-pump, at the station, to be worked by a steam-engine. A[???] experiment will soon be made with this engine, and it is confidently expected that it will perform all the work required of it. The use of it will cost. It is believed, less than steam, and, in Summer, will be much more agreeable to those who ride in the cars.

abstract: The work of exhuming the bodies from the burial ground of the First Baptist Church in La Grangeplace, Philadelphia, is nearly completed. This church-yard is among the oldest in the city. Gov. Ward, of Rhode Island, who died in the city during the first session of the Continental Congress, was buried under the Church.
lead_paragraph: The work of exhuming the bodies from the burial ground of the First Baptist Church in La Grangeplace, Philadelphia, is nearly completed. This church-yard is among the oldest in the city. Gov. Ward, of Rhode Island, who died in the city during the first session of the Continental Congress, was buried under the Church. One tomb-stone, bearing the scarcely legible name of Thomas Morgan, is dated 1722. The arcaives of the Church show that since the year 1816 not less than eleven hundred bodies have been laid in this single grave-yard. In many of the graves no human ashes remained. The last vestige of the bones had crumbled, and returned to its constituent dust. In others was found merely a few fibres of decayed wood, a dozen or two of nails, and the remains of the metal embellishments of what was once a coffin. One exception occurred, where a petrified body was brought to light -- the body of a man -- which, though a hundred years entombed, was singularly lifelike.

abstract: The Report of the Board of officers to the investigate affairs of the several Navy Yards has been transmitted to the House of Representatives by the Secretary of the Navy, in response to a resolution of that body. They say that all the troubles are owing to the system on which the yards are organized, and not to a want of proper administrative talent in the heads of department. In their opinion the Commandant should be considered in the same position as if in command of a ship. The privilege or authority granted the master workmen of selecting their own mechanics, has led them into the error of attempting of govern them independently of the executive authority of the Board; and this has been productive of much disorder. Besides, master mechanics have been overruled in their convictions of ho[???]ly to the Government by outside [???]ence. The Investigating Board reco[???]nd that the yards be under [???] military rule, and the commandant alone be held responsible for a faithful performance of duties of all those under his command. The master workmen should be nominated by the Commandant, and appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, after a strict and careful examination [???] their moral, o[???]vslcal, and mechanical qualification. The master workmen to be cirected to nominate to the heads of their respective departments the men to be employed by them. The Board make other recommondations, clearly defining the duties of of the respective officers, -- Inte[???], 8th.

abstract: KINGSTON, Jamaica, January, 1800. The Planters of Jamaica constitute no longer  the over-ruling oligarchy, or "Plantocracy," that they once actually were, and are still somewhat insolently designated in the bitterness of party spirit Poverty may not have humbled their pride or changed their belief; in their own homes and on  their own estates, and in public whenever an opportunity offers, they wage, under different guises the old war against free labor.

abstract: The most striking evidence of what an enormous role Science has come to play in the scheme of modern civilization is furnished in the statistics of scientific periodical publications. There are now over ONE HUNDRED periodicals exclusively devoted to speculative and experimental science! Among the chief French scientific issues are the elaborate Comptes ...
lead_paragraph: The most striking evidence of what an enormous role Science has come to play in the scheme of modern civilization is furnished in the statistics of scientific periodical publications. There are now over ONE HUNDRED periodicals exclusively devoted to speculative and experimental science! Among the chief French scientific issues are the elaborate Comptes Rendus, the Annales du Museum, the Repertoire de Chemie, etc. Germany contributes endless chiv -- Archiv der Natur geschichte,der Mathematik, LI[???]BIG's Annalen, POGGENDORFF's Annalen. Foremost among British publications are the London, Edinburg and Dublin Journal of Science and the Edmburg New Philosophical Journal; while Silliman's Journal, Runkle's Mathematical Monthly, etc., chronicle scientific advance in the United States. Taking into account the well-defined relations between speculative opinions and the practical achievements of a nation, the stupendous significance of the millionfold discoveries, researches and experiments recorded in these scientific journals becomes apparent. It is not too much to say that the whole surface and substance of modern life is under, going a ceaseless transformation through the manifold ministries which science is daily em[???]oding in the forms and operations of manufacture and of art.

lead_paragraph: The "wonderful tale of Washoe" appears to be gradually crystallizing within the limits of probability. It is hardly to be doubted that silver mines of great value have really been discovered in the vicinity of Carson City in California, and of course we may expect to see a certain flush of speculation follow the public demonstration of the fact on both coasts of the Continent. Our people are, perhaps, not quite so susceptible to attacks of this sort as they were before the crashes of 1857, but there is [???]ife enough still left in their speculative nerves to respond after a fashion to such enticements as the story of silver ore assaying $2,000 to the ton.

lead_paragraph: We have had occasion so often to lament the gradual disappearance of the American flag from the steam-traffic between the Old. World and the New, that we rejoice proportionately in being able to chronicle the return to the lists of Transatlantic competition of those famous but most unfortunate Collins ships, in which we all took a national pride, when they first put the Cunarders to their mettle, and promised us the empire of the seas. The Adriatic is advertised in our columns to-day on the route to France, under the auspices of the North Atlantic Steamship Company. The enormous and steady increase of our commercial relations with France, and through France with the Continent, has fully tasked the capacity of the one American steamship line, which through good report and evil report, has honorably and singly maintained the traditions of our enterprise on the Atlantic; and the Adriatic will figure rather as a companion than as a rival or the Fulton and the Arago. Indeed, the best that can be asked for the newcomers is that they may sustain the reputation which these stanch and well-managed steamers have not suffered us wholly to forfeit. Should they do so, it is possible that we may pluck up courage enough one of these days to challenge even our British cousins once more to a fresh trial of temper, endurance and skill, and that an American steamship discharging in Liverpool docks may cease to be what now it is -- a memory, and almost a myth.

abstract: --It is stated in the Liverpool Albion of the 18th of February that the British Queen recently, in a conversation with Lord PALMERSTON, in which the French Treaty was warmly discussed, and somewhat too urgently pressed upon her Majesty, handed his Lordship a slip of paper, on which was written the letters "AAB[???]YLET," and told him that if he would form them into a single word they would aptly convey her Majeaty's views with regard to the treaty. The Albion promised to give its readers the word the next week, but before the appointed time arrived the New-York sailed with our last mails from Europe. It is suggested that the word is probably "betrayal." It is further suggested that the statement is a canard; of which, indeed we have very little doubt.

abstract: LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--Mr. BOURCICAULT'S new three-act piece called " Vanity Fair" was produced here on Monday night. It is not, as people have supposed, an adaptation from THACKEHAY'S novel, but a clever version of a French piece. The title is a good one, locally and generally. The scene, although laid in Paris, might as well be in NewYork, and the two words " Vanity Fair" convey closely ...
lead_paragraph: LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--Mr. BOURCICAULT'S new three-act piece called " Vanity Fair" was produced here on Monday night. It is not, as people have supposed, an adaptation from THACKEHAY'S novel, but a clever version of a French piece. The title is a good one, locally and generally. The scene, although laid in Paris, might as well be in NewYork, and the two words " Vanity Fair" convey closely an idea of what the plot Illustrates. Mr. BOURCICAULT, in his "tag" at the end of the play, called it "a poor unpretending comedy." We are disposed to regard it as something more. It is poor, undoubtedly, in plot, but the characterization is frequently forcible, and the language always terse and epigrammatic. In these days, when the attention of the author is directed more to the stage carpenter and the scene painter than to the public, it is refreshing, at least, to have a piece with some pretensions to literary merit. There are passages of quiet humor in the work which would not disgrace an author of greater reputation than Mr. BOURCICAULT; but they are, we fear, too fine and subtle to take deep hold of a miscellaneous audience. A public accustomed to gloat over sensation pieces can scarcely be expected to enjoy the comparatively sterling merit of a play like "Vanity Fair." Whatever its positive success with the public, we have no hesitation in recording our opinion that it is, so far as dialogue and characterization are concerned, one of Mr. BOURCICAULT's best recent successes.

abstract: While Miss Jane E. Parisen, of No. 96 Caroline-street, was passing through Chatham-street on Monday evening, she felt the hand of a thief in her pocket, and seizing his arm, managed to hold him, despite his efforts to disengage himself, until Mr. John Folsom, of N0. 210 Sullivan-street, came to her assistance and effected the young man's arrest. The prisoner, who gives his name as James Dubois, during the scuffle with Mr. Folsom, struck that gentleman a severe blow in the face, and also tore his clothes. He was taken before Judge CONNOLLY, who committed him to answer a charge of assault and battery, and also one of pocket-picking.

abstract: ITEMS.--The Trustees and Teachers of the Packer Institute attended the funeral of Prof. GRAY, yesterday, previous to which the Trustees adopted suitable resolutions, manifesting their respect for the deceased .... One arm of a man was found in City Hailsquare, at an early hour yesterday morning, by Detective VAN WAGNER.
lead_paragraph: ITEMS.--The Trustees and Teachers of the Packer Institute attended the funeral of Prof. GRAY, yesterday, previous to which the Trustees adopted suitable resolutions, manifesting their respect for the deceased .... One arm of a man was found in City Hailsquare, at an early hour yesterday morning, by Detective VAN WAGNER. It was placed in the care of the Coroner.... Mrs. H.W. BEECHER has so far recovered from her late accident as to be able to ride out.... Coroner HORTON held an inquest, yesterday, on the body of a woman named JULIA RAY, who died at No.4 Raymond-street, from the effects of intoxicating drink.... PETER G. TAYLOR was renominated for Alderman by the Republicans, of the Fourth Ward last night, and SAMUEL BOOTH was renominated by the same party for Supervisor.... The Ashland Club, of this city, are making arrangements to open a regular hard-cider cabin for use during the present campaign.

abstract: Further inquiries among the merchants fully confirm all our statements with regard to the prosperity of our Southern trade. Although the Southern  market was overstocked last year, the merchants of the Slaveholding States have purchased quite as largely as ever of the New-York importers this year. The predictions of the members of the leading drygoods firms, made before business had fairly opened ...
lead_paragraph: Further inquiries among the merchants fully confirm all our statements with regard to the prosperity of our Southern trade. Although the Southern market was overstocked last year, the merchants of the Slaveholding States have purchased quite as largely as ever of the New-York importers this year. The predictions of the members of the leading drygoods firms, made before business had fairly opened in January, as published in the TIMES of that date have been completely verified. While trade has, in some instances, been diverted from its former channels, so that our importers have been brought into more immediate contact with buyers from the other side of Mason and Dixon's line, without the intervention, to so large an extent, of the New-York jobbers, the quantity of goods sold and shipped, or crowded together now awaiting shipment to Southern ports, is in the aggregate quite as large as was sent to the same places of destination last year. It is with the greatest difficulty, and only by paying their carmen extra rates of compensation, that the merchants succeed in transhipping their dry goods to the South. The unprecedentedly large cotton crop of the past season, and the ready market which the staple has found this year in Europe, (with an increasing demand from the New-England mills,) has given the Southerners -- especially those of the cotton-growing States -- the means of making extensive purchases; and the agricultural States of the South, such as Virginia, Kentucky, parts of Tennessee and Missouri are financially prosperous only in a less degree. Had not the money-market been so easy, and had there in consequence been Jess goods sold to Southern purchasers than usual, the organs of disunion would not have failed to ascribe the falling off in the trade to the Harper's Ferry affair, and to the political sentiments of the people of the South. We have been assured by merchants of standing in this City that their contact with Southerners, in the course of their business transactions with them the present season, has convinced them that the sentiments of the great mass of the people in the slave-holding Statesare very much misrepresented, not only by newspapers in the interest of party, but by their own Senators and Representatives in Congress. A customer from the region of Red River, in Arkansas, as asked the other day by a member of a very extensive cloth-importing firm, with which he was trading, whether he had hesitated at all to come North to buy goods, in consequence of the aspect of political affairs. He replied that the sentiment of the people he dwelt among was not at all that of the politicians who undertook to speak for them; that it was well understood that the present excitement was purposely aroused for political ends; and that politics and trade had nothing to do with each other, even if this were not so. We have heard similar statements repeatedly, that tradesmen from the Southern States, except in isolated instances, do not inquire into the political sentiments of those whom it is to their advantage to deal with. That they, indeed, transact business extensively with those whose sentiments are known to be Anti-Slavery, the every-day experience of the last month furnishes abundant evidence. A week ago Mr. BOWEN, of the extensive firm of BOWEN, HOLMES & Co., a gentleman whose political proclivities are decided and have never been concealed -- was conversing with a Kentuckian who visited him for the first time, and desired to purchase a heavy bill of goods, when a gentleman entered the store and asked to see a member of the firm. Mr. BOWEN looked up and told him what his name was. The gentleman wanted to buy a sik dress for his wife. Mr. BOWEN told him that they did not sell at retail. "Well," said the gentleman, turning to go, "I'm sorry. I wanted to buy of a firm that sells its goods and not its principles!" Mr. BOWEN immediately referred him to one of his partners, and the dress was sold him. The Kentuckian sat still and heard all this, yet apparently not at all disturbed by it, resumed his negotiations, and before he left the store had made arrangements for the purchase of a large assortment of goods.

abstract: The North American, having left Liverpool Feb. 29, and Queenstown, March 1, has brought to Portland news from Europe four days later than previous advices. The reported loss of the American ship Luna is confirmed. Of 107 persons on board, but two reached the shore, and one of the two died shortly after. A tremendous gale had again visited the British coast, doing much damage to shipping, ...
lead_paragraph: The North American, having left Liverpool Feb. 29, and Queenstown, March 1, has brought to Portland news from Europe four days later than previous advices. The reported loss of the American ship Luna is confirmed. Of 107 persons on board, but two reached the shore, and one of the two died shortly after. A tremendous gale had again visited the British coast, doing much damage to shipping, American vessels not escaping. In relation to the rumor received by the America, via Queenstown, of a new Austro-Russian alliance, the Morning Chronicle, with which the story originated, had reaffirmed it, and found an indorser in the Morning Herald. Our latest dispatches state that, while the tale was authoritatively denied by the Paris Press, and at Vienna, it is as strongly reiterated by the Chronicle. M. DE THOUVENEL, in explanation of the views of the Emperor upon the latest developments of the Italian question, had addressed a note to the Ambassador at Vienna, stating that, while France might regard the present moment as improper for a dissolution of the Papal States, it would insist upon the question adjusting itself without external intervention. The project of a General Congress appeared to be finally abandoned. The Russian Ambassador at Turin, in the course of an interview with Count CAVOUR, had warned the Sardinian Premier that his master could not regard with indifference any steps Piedmont might, in the present threatening state of the Continent, take to hasten the absorption of Central Italy. The French Foreign Secretary had addressed a note to the same Government, containing similar language. The condition of Venetia was distressing. A change of Governors had taken place, and an order had been issued obliging all persons supposed to be disaffected toward the Austrian rule, to be enrolled in the army, and subjected to strict military discipline. The proceedings of the British Parliament had been interesting. On the 27th ult., the budget was discussed by the Comons in Committee of the Whole, when Mr. GLADSTONE and others spoke upon the new tariff, and the resolution relative to wine and spirits was adopted by a decisive majority. From Morocco, we learn that the Spaniards had bombarded the towns of Larache and Arcilla, inflicting great damage. The prospect of a practical realization of the Japan Treaty appears to be promising, the Japanese Government having given orders to enforce it forthwith.

abstract: The vote in the Senate, to-day, making th Homestead bill the special order for Thursday, is regarded by some as indicative of its strength before that body. But I know such not to be the fact. Several Senators who voted to make it the special order will vote ultimately against the bill. Its passage would prove ruinous to those who have been speculating in land warrants.

abstract: BUSINESS AT THE MAYOR'S OFFICE--TICKETSWINDLERS SET AT LIBERTY.--Before the Marshal yesterday was arraigned a German, with a name so long as to be unutterable, who had received some nine hundred francs for three steerage tickets to California, from as many luckless Frenchmen, who were bound to that land of promise. He gave them tickets for New-Orleans instead, and even those were good ...
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS AT THE MAYOR'S OFFICE--TICKETSWINDLERS SET AT LIBERTY.--Before the Marshal yesterday was arraigned a German, with a name so long as to be unutterable, who had received some nine hundred francs for three steerage tickets to California, from as many luckless Frenchmen, who were bound to that land of promise. He gave them tickets for New-Orleans instead, and even those were good for nothing, and some good-hearted friend brought them before the Marshal for relief. The guilty parties, for there were three or four engaged in the swindle, were arrested and compelled to disgorge, and from the difficulty experienced in raising the money, the inference would seem fair that a portion of it at least had found its way into some other than a legitimate channel. It was, however, raised and paid over, and all parties left the office -- the Frenchmen rejoicing in the recovery of their money and ready to shout Vive L'Amerique -- the swindlers exceedingly crest-fallen and dejected. This office, by the way, is run down by female operatives and servants who have been defrauded out of their hard-earned wages, and who think the Mayor has the power to redress their wrongs. There were over twenty cases of this nature yesterday, swindling sums of from fifty cents to two dollars and a-half, and each for fairly-earned and hard-earned wages. It seems to us that when our legislators have finished off their Railroad, and other bills which involve amounts as immense as their interests, they might find a little leisure to devote to that portion of their constituency, about whom so much is said, and for whom nothing is ever done. Some of them would sleep better if they would place in the power of the over-worked and wretchedly-paid female operatives some means to collect their miserable wages without the expense and delay which now attend any attempt at enforced collection through the aid of the law.

abstract: -- Certain members of the Common Council, at the last meeting, expressed their emphatic opposition to any interference by the Legislature with the prerogatives of the Corporation as far as gas and pipe laying in this City are concerned. Certainly there is good ground for jealousy between the Municipal and State lawmakers in regard to both. Probably the interests of the people would be better cared for if the rival bodies had less to do with either.

abstract: Our Albany Correspondent writes that if the friends of Sanitary Reform in this City desire the enactment of the pending bill for its promotion, they must attend in person and urge it upon the attention of members. There seems to be no special hostility to its passage in the Legislature, -- indeed, there is a general willingness to see it passed. But so many schemes are constantly crowded upon the notice of members by the parties interested, that projects of merely public utility are lost sight of and crowded out of place, unless those who appreciate their importance take pains to remind others of it also. Our City Government would render their constituents a special service, and expend the public money much more judiciously than they sometimes do, if they would send a delegation to Albany to urge the passage of the bill now before the Legislature.

abstract: -- Mr. FREDERIC BROWN, [???]ormerly of Portland, in the State of Maine, but now of Louisiana, thinks that his character would smell much, sweeter on the Southern wind were he called by any other name. So he has prayed the Legislature of his adopted State, in consideration of the fact that "the acts of old JOHAN BROWN, of Abolition notoriety, have affixed a stigma to the name of BROWN which renders it intolerable to himself and his family," graciously to permit him henceforth to undo himself BROWN, and to call himself SOUTHGATE. The Legislature, kind souls! have had pity on the pains of this poor Maine-iac, and he now wears the much more appropriate designation which he desired.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. FREDERIC BROWN, [???]ormerly of Portland, in the State of Maine, but now of Louisiana, thinks that his character would smell much, sweeter on the Southern wind were he called by any other name. The Legislature, kind souls! have had pity on the pains of this poor Maine-iac, and he now wears the much more appropriate designation which he desired.

abstract: Vanacrvoort vs. Gould. -- A report of this case was given in yesterday's TIMES. The value of the leasehold interest in question is alleged to be $15,000 to $20,000. The motion made yesterday, to dismiss the complaint, on the ground, among others, that the conveyance to the plaintiff, by the wife of the defendant, was void, was this morning denied. The question turned upon the point as to whether the Statutes of 1848 and 1849, giving to married women the right to hold and convey real property as if single applied to property acquired before the passage of the act, or only to property acquired under, or subsequent to, that enactment. Today further evidence is being given, The case is still on.
lead_paragraph: Vanacrvoort vs. Gould. -- A report of this case was given in yesterday's TIMES. The value of the leasehold interest in question is alleged to be $15,000 to $20,000. The motion made yesterday, to dismiss the complaint, on the ground, among others, that the conveyance to the plaintiff, by the wife of the defendant, was void, was this morning denied. The question turned upon the point as to whether the Statutes of 1848 and 1849, giving to married women the right to hold and convey real property as if single applied to property acquired before the passage of the act, or only to property acquired under, or subsequent to, that enactment. Today further evidence is being given, The case is still on.

abstract: -- At the regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen of Boston, on Monday evening, a check for $10,300 was received from Mr. JAMES LAWRENCE, being the amount of the legacy, with interest, bequeathed by the late ABBOTT LAW-PENCE for the use of the Public Library at Boston. abstract: It is intimated in quarters favorable to the scheme of imposing tolls upon railroad freight, that this should not be done unless the roads are at the same time permitted to raise their fares. This proposition resolves the whole scheme into a plan for levying, upon the traveling public, taxes for the support of Government. It makes the injustice of, the whole project still more transparent, although it does not really change its character.

abstract: The TIMES report of the proceedings of the annual meeting of the Church of the Puritans left the members busily engaged at 12 P.M. of Monday with little prospects of adjournment. It will be recollected that at that time there was under consideration the ques-- tion of disposing of the reports of the Trustees. The majority report censured the course pursued by unauthorized ...
lead_paragraph: The TIMES report of the proceedings of the annual meeting of the Church of the Puritans left the members busily engaged at 12 P.M. of Monday with little prospects of adjournment. It will be recollected that at that time there was under consideration the ques-- tion of disposing of the reports of the Trustees. The majority report censured the course pursued by unauthorized parties in endeavoring to gain pecuniary aid for the Church in England through the efforts of Miss JOHNSTONE. The minority report was silent on the subject. The Society, after a long and animated if not acrimonious discussion, resolved to strike out of the majority report all that portion not haying direct reference to the finances of the society, and ordered both reports on file. This action was effected by the same close vote that elected Trustees -- 33 in favor to 31 against. The time of holding the annual meeting was changed to the last Monday in April.

abstract: It seems to us that some of the Republicans in the Senate are endeavoring to make a martyr of Mr. THADDEUS HYATT to very little purpose. Mr. SUMNER has opposed his committal to prison for refusing to answer, on the ground that the power exercised in summoning him before the Senate at all was unconstitutional, and that in refusing to attend to answer he was in the right. Mr. SUMNER alleges the inquiry into the alleged conspiracy which resulted in the Harper's Ferry riot, to be an exercise of "judicial power" -- a power which, under the Constitution, the Senate does not possess.
lead_paragraph: It seems to us that some of the Republicans in the Senate are endeavoring to make a martyr of Mr. THADDEUS HYATT to very little purpose. abstract: "Judging by the Tribune and TIMES of yesterday, the editors of those papers must have been fast asleep when the railroad train stopped in the Assembly, and so they failed to get seats in 'the omnibus.' The Tribune and TIMES must have had large interests in the five Assembly bills, or they wouldn't feel so bad at their being knocked off the track."

abstract: PRACTICAL AMALGAMATION. -- The Hartford Times, of Tuesday evening, tells of an interesting couple which left that city on Monday, for New-York. It says the parties lived in Bridgeport, where Mrs. -- some three years ago became a widow. She had two or three children, now nearly grown up. Some property, it is said, reverted to her on the death of her husband, and she had also the benefit of $5,000 insured on her husband's life. Some months ago she was found to be intimate with a certain very black negro of Bridgeport, and it was soon known that this negro was getting possession of her money and property. Finally the negro found it prudent to leave, and went to New-York, where he opened a restaurant. Ere many weeks Mrs. -- manifested what was believed to be an intention to follow him; and one day last week, being all prepared, she started to the railroad depot, but was prevented by her friends. At this Mrs. -- told them she was already married to FRANCIS, the negro -- adding that the ceremony was legally performed in New-York last Fall! Upon learning this, the lady's friends, knowing that she claimed to have received a spirit communication from her husband in the spirit world, sanctioning the vile arrangement, at once resolved to prevent it by establishing the fact that she was "insane;" and she was brought to this city last week, to be placed under Dr. BUTLBR's care at the Retreat. No sufficient authority being shown the Doctor for her detention, they had to take her back. Last evening, however, she was brought back here, with the certificates of three Bridgeport physicians that she was insane. This morning the negro, her husband, appeared at the Retreat to claim her, and Dr. BUTLER decided that he could not detain her at the Retreat for want of authority, and the negro sailed off with her in triumph. Her insanity appears to be extremely doubtful. She is quite handsome, if not beautiful, while her husband is of ebony blackness.
lead_paragraph: PRACTICAL AMALGAMATION. -- The Hartford Times, of Tuesday evening, tells of an interesting couple which left that city on Monday, for New-York. abstract: Catharine N. Forrest vs. Edwin Forrest. -- In this noted case, it will be remembered that the amount of alimony which Mrs. Forrest should be entitled to receive from her husband has remained hitherto unsettled. It was referred to a Referee to ascertain and report the proper amount. Sometime since his report was made, fixing the amount at $4,000 per annum, and an application made to the Special Term of the Superior Court to confirm this report. Justice MONCRIEF has rendered his decision, confirming the report.

abstract: M. THOUVENEL, the new French Minister of Foreign Affairs, is fast building up for himself a most enviable reputation, and strengthening the position of the French Government with the public opinion of the world, by his admirable diplomatic papers on the Italian question. We publish to-day two of these documents, in the form of dispatches addressed to the French envoys at Rome and at Vienna; and in which M. THOUVENEL re-...
lead_paragraph: M. THOUVENEL, the new French Minister of Foreign Affairs, is fast building up for himself a most enviable reputation, and strengthening the position of the French Government with the public opinion of the world, by his admirable diplomatic papers on the Italian question. We publish to-day two of these documents, in the form of dispatches addressed to the French envoys at Rome and at Vienna; and in which M. THOUVENEL reviews, with singular clearness and moderation, the course of events since the signature of the peace of Villafranca; explains the actual attitude of the French Government; and suggests both to Kaiser and to Pope, with a most deferential delicacy, the only way of real escape from the present perplexity of Italian affairs which is open to Europe and to themselves.

abstract: Mr. FOSTER presented to the Senate yesterday, petitions signed by the leading manufacturers of Connecticut, asking that the tariff law might be so amended that their interests should be more ef- fectually protected. A bill to amend the act regulating the carriage of passengers in steamships and other vessels, was reported by Mr.BAYARD, who urged immediate action, on the ground that the decency and morality of the country were involved.
lead_paragraph: Mr. FOSTER presented to the Senate yesterday, petitions signed by the leading manufacturers of Connecticut, asking that the tariff law might be so amended that their interests should be more ef- fectually protected. A bill to amend the act regulating the carriage of passengers in steamships and other vessels, was reported by Mr.BAYARD, who urged immediate action, on the ground that the decency and morality of the country were involved. Some objections were made to considering the bill at that time, by Senators who had petitions to present, but later in the day it was passed. On taking up the Military Academy bill the amendment of Mr. WIGFALL, making appropriation for a regiment of mounted volunteers for the defence of the frontier of Texas, was adopted by a vote of 27 to 19. In the House the resolution directing an inquiry into the legislation necessary to guarantee a citizen going into another State upon lawful business, all his rights, was referred again to the Committee on the Judiciary; with power to act. Mr. NELSON, from the same Committee, reported a bill declaring null and void that law in Deseret and Utah which allows the existence of polygamy, and subjecting those guilty of the offence to a fine of $500, and imprisonment for not less than two nor more than four years. It was ordered to be printed. A running debate ensued on the question of appropriating $40,000 for the suppression of the Slave-trade, as recommended by the Secretary of the Treasury. When the bill making appropriations for the Indian Department was taken up, Mr. CURRY, of Alabama, reviewed the question of the jurisdiction of Congress over the Territories, in a speech of marked ability.

abstract: THE IMLAY-STREET EXPLOSION. -- Coroner HORTON, with a jury, yesterday commenced to hold an inquest on the body of JOHN HAZLETINE, killed on Monday last by the explosion of a boiler in a foundry on Imlay-street, Red Hook. The evidence thus far taken goes to show that the explosion was caused through the carelessness of the deceased. He was in charge of the boilers, and permitted the water to get too low, and then turned the water on. After examining several witnesses, the case was adjourned over to Friday next, some of the jurors desiring testimony as to the competency of the engineer.

abstract: The steamship Circassian of the Lever line, from Galway March 3, called yesterday at St. Johns, N.F. The news transmitted thence by telegraph is important. On the 1st inst. the Ministerial Reform bill was brought forward in the House of Commons by Lord JOHN RUSSELL. It makes a ten-pound qualification in the counties, and six pounds in the boroughs; and, conceding only one member to each of the smaller boroughs, leaves a residuum to strengthen the representations of large towns. Two additional members are given to Ireland, and two to Scotland. The Liberals are said to be much dissatisfied with the bill. On the same day the French Corps Legislatif was opened by the Emperor in a speech of momentous interest. Referring to Italy, he declared that Tuscany could not be annexed to Piedmont, but must be erected into a separate kingdom. Modena and Parma should be left at liberty to consolidate with Sardinia, and, under certain contingencies, the Romagna also. The safety of France, he said, required the addition of Savoy to her boundaries, a measure which the great Powers, he trusted, would upon reflection find no reason to oppose. The effect of the speech was to cause a trifling decline, both on the Bourse and on the London Stock market. The English journals are loud against the Savoy scheme. Prince LUCIEN BONAPARTE, of poetical antecedents, is spoken of as the Napoleonic candidate for the Etrurian crown. From Italy we learn that while the Pope begins to see the necessity of concessions to his rebel subjects, he had just threatened the King of Sardinia with excommunication. There is nothing new from Morocco. The conditions of peace presented by Marshal O'DONNELL are regarded by the Spanish journals as exorbitant, especial objection being made to the contemplated extension of conquered territory.

abstract: To say that we are all disappointed wouldn't begin to express our feelings. To be sure, the rain has steadily fallen for the past few days, and we might have known that the probabilities of fair weather were few and far between; but "in our mental mind" we fully concluded that the great demonstration so successfully inaugurated last Wednesday would be carried forward to a glorious termination to-day.

abstract: A lecture was delivered on this subject last evening, in the German Presbyterian Church, Sixth-street, near Second-avenue, by Dr. HITCHCOCK. The lecturer commenced by stating the problem to be to determine the laws of civilization. There are three erroneous theories: 1. The Pantheistic. 2. The Humanistic. 3. The Materialistic. These all agree that barbarism was the original state of man. The true philosophy of history stands opposed to all these, and, giving to man his proper freedom, discerns all the workings of the divine hand.

abstract: The old adage of "give an inch and take an ell" is daily verified in this department. The ordinance regulating the construction of vaults in front of stores and dwelling-houses limits them to the outer edge of the sidewalk, except by special permission from the Croton Department, and this on payment of a speci- fied fee for the permission.
lead_paragraph: The old adage of "give an inch and take an ell" is daily verified in this department. The ordinance regulating the construction of vaults in front of stores and dwelling-houses limits them to the outer edge of the sidewalk, except by special permission from the Croton Department, and this on payment of a speci- fied fee for the permission. Of late, however, and especially since the mania for marble stores and broad vaults has seized the merchants of New-York, the owners and builders have gradually encroached upon the streets, or rather the substratum of the streets, until, in one case at least, the walls of the vaults on either side of the street approach within four feet of each other. This may seem, to the casual reader, very unimportant, but when it is taken into consideration that sewers, gas-pipes and water-pipes must be laid or repaired, it will readily be seen how much wrong may be done by this encroachment upon the underground rights of the City. In one case -- we do not choose to name the street, lest some of the Insurance Companies might demand a cancellation of their policies -- the vaults are so far extended beneath the street, that it was found impossible to place a fire-hydrant at the point designated; and in another case, a party now about erecting a marble store, had the conscience to ask permission to build a vault twenty-nine feet wide, which is exactly half the width of the street. There is now more than one street running across Broadway and below Reade-street, where, if any accident should happen to the gas or Croton pipes, immense damage might be caused by reason of the vault mania.

abstract: I have been in this ancient capital since Monday last. It has been quite a stormy and excited week. The legislative session closes to night at 12 o'clock, when, by the Constitution, an adjournment must take place sine die. Never before in the history of our State has there been so strong an outside pressure.

abstract: The bill for the location of the Schuyler countyseat at Havana was before the Senate Committee today. It will be favorably reported, and seems certain to pass the Senate. abstract: Let a civic crown be instantly voted to the City Marshal! This official yesterday promptly revoked the license of an omnibus driver, and fined him five dollars in addition, for insolence and extortion, on the complaint of an injured passenger. That in this City, ruled by a feudal aristocracy of car-proprietors and omnibus men, such a thing as a right should be recognized in one of the pariah class of passengers, is serious matter for rejoicing to the whole of that miserable order.

abstract: In advance of the action of Conventions, the position of parties can be determined only by watching the drift of public sentiment. Judged by this standard, the Democrats of the South seem more and more inclined to repudiate Judge DOUGLAS, and to insist upon their own Pro-Slavery programme, pure et simple, as the basis of their action in the coming contest.
lead_paragraph: In advance of the action of Conventions, the position of parties can be determined only by watching the drift of public sentiment. Judged by this standard, the Democrats of the South seem more and more inclined to repudiate Judge DOUGLAS, and to insist upon their own Pro-Slavery programme, pure et simple, as the basis of their action in the coming contest. Mr. CURRY, of Alabama, says that a victory upon any other platform would be barren and worthless; that Slavery must expand or die out, and that Congress must protect its extension into new Territories, against the hostility alike of the legislatures and the people. Alabama, Mississippi and one or two other Southern States have taken ground against DOUGLAS and his doctrines, and have indicated a purpose to bolt in the event of his nomination.

abstract: The Emperor NAPOLEON has spoken out his mind on the Italian question as it at present stands, and the sensitive Exchanges of Paris and London have answered the Imperial blast with a shiver and a fall. The French Sovereign declares for the annexation of Parma and Modena to the growing kingdom of Upper Italy; hints at the possibility that the Emilian provinces of the Holy See may be forced by circumstances to follow their example; begs the great Powers to reflect upon the importance to France of the frontier of Savoy; and demands for Tuscany an independent political existence, under a ruler to be chosen by the Tuscan people. It will be impossible, of course, to form any just estimate, either of the policy involved in this programme, or of the effect which it is likely to produce upon the public opinion of Europe, until we shall have received the speech itself of the Emperor in full. Words are things with men like the third NAPOLEON; and upon the phraseology of these propositions their influence will very largely depend. None of them are absolutely novel; nor can it be said that any of them will fall unexpectedly upon the diplomacy of the Old World. The latest letters of the French Foreign Minister, M. THOUVENEL, to the French Envoys at Rome and at Vienna, had very plainly foreshadowed the hopeless divergence now admitted in the Imperial speech, between the passionate schemes of the legitimist policy, and that patient recognition of established facts, which is the key-note of the diplomacy of the ruler of France. Neither the Pope nor the Kaiser, then, will learn anything new from the language which NAPOLEON has now used. Its only force, so far as they are concerned, consists in the decision with which it commits France finally and publicly to an absolutely passive attitude towards the people of Central Italy; and with which in so committing France, it makes any thought of armed intervention on the part of any other power inadmissible and absurd.

abstract: The Cunard steamer Australasian, probably the largest screw-steamer afloat, unless the Great Eastern be considered as belonging to this class, arrived at this port on Wednesday from Liverpool, with a heavy cargo of valuable merchandise. She was built in 1857, at Glasgow, by Messrs. J. G. THOMSON, for the Australian matl contract service. After a most successful rial trip to Alexandria, she made the voyage to Australia, carrying the mail down the Red Sea.
lead_paragraph: The Cunard steamer Australasian, probably the largest screw-steamer afloat, unless the Great Eastern be considered as belonging to this class, arrived at this port on Wednesday from Liverpool, with a heavy cargo of valuable merchandise. She was built in 1857, at Glasgow, by Messrs. J. G. THOMSON, for the Australian matl contract service. After a most successful rial trip to Alexandria, she made the voyage to Australia, carrying the mail down the Red Sea. Having unfortunately lost the mail contract, through inability to fulfill its terms, the Company for which she was originally constructed went into liquidation, and the steamer returned to England under canvas, making the trip in ninety days, during twenty of which she was becalmed. Soon afterwards she was purchased at private sale by the Cunard Company, and placed in their line of screw steamers between Liverpool and New-York. She is of great strength, and is fitted with every modern improvement, having accommodations for 211 first-class passengers, and cargo and store space for 1,050 tons, besides room in her bunkers for 1,500 tons of coal. Her cabins and saloons are fitted up in the most elegant and substantial manner, with particular reference to ventilation, as the vessel was intended for navigation in the tropics. For officers and crew, which number 113, there is ample provision as regards rooms. The length of keel and fore-rake of the Australasian is 320 feet, being 331 feet over all; breadth 42 feet 1 inch, depth to spar deck 31 feet 6 inches. Tonnage -- gross register 1,760, or 2,010 tons of builder's measurement. The engines are direct-acting, of 700 (nominal) horse-power, with inverted cylinders of 90 inches diameter, and 3 1/2 feet stroke, fitted with THOMSON's patent expansion valves. She has two tubular boilers, brass tubes, also a supplementary boiler for ship's use. There are two air-pumps to each engine, with condensers attached. The screw is 19 feet in diameter, with 34 feet pitch. Her speed en the Admiralty trip was 14 knots.

abstract: POLITICAL. -- The City Republican Convention was held last evening at No. 9 Court-street. Every delegate elected to the Convention was present, and the business was disposed of without any unnecessary delay. The following nominations were made: For Collector of Taxes and Assessments, THOMAS W. FIELD, Eighteenth Ward; for Street Commissioner, JOHN WILLIAMS, Tenth Ward; for Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies, JAMES C. DURYEA. A Committee was appointed to notify the candidates of their nomination, and the Convention adjourned, to meet at the call of the Chairman.
lead_paragraph: POLITICAL. -- The City Republican Convention was held last evening at No. 9 Court-street. Every delegate elected to the Convention was present, and the business was disposed of without any unnecessary delay. The following nominations were made: For Collector of Taxes and Assessments, THOMAS W. lead_paragraph: The session of this Convention was continued at the Astor House yesterday, about 60 Delegates being present, representing not quite one-half of the tanning interest in this State and Pennsylvania. The minutes of Wednesday's session were read, from which it appeared that the following gentlemen were elected permanent officers of the organization: President, LEWIS NORTHRUP, New-York; Vice-President, WYNCOOP KIERSTED, New-York; Secretary, S.W. JACKSON, New-York; Assistant-Secretary, JOHN C. PITT, New-York; Treasurer, L.H. ALLISON, New-York. The objects of the Convention are sufficiently indicated in the following preamble and resolution, offered by the President, and unanimously adopted:

abstract: Mr. D.H. TETU, of Kamarouska, Canada, who has been exhibing two of the species of the white whale from the St. Lawrence, last evening made a statement before the Polytechnic Club of the American Institute. The name, he said, given to this fish by the French Canadian is "White Porpoise," but is denominated in all the works on natural history that he had consulted, the "White Whale." We find the white whale in the St. Lawrence River opposite the Village of St. Rochs, situated sixty miles below Quebec, and as far down as Father Point, a distance of about 200 miles. It is also found in immense quantities in the rivers emptying into Hudson's Bay This cetaceous animal became, soon after the discovery of Canada, an article of commerce which entitled the first colonists, who engaged in catching it, to a special protection on the part of the French Government. In 1707 there were no less than eight companies established at different points of the river for carrying on this business, whom the inhabitants protected by their edicts and ordinances. The oil of the white w halt was then worth only a franc a gallon. Its skin was somehow considered of little value, but owing to the facility with which it was taken, the quantity alone sufficed to make it sought after, and to render the pursuit profitable to those engaged in it, among whom a company of six farmers, at River Orielle Point, was particularly distinguished. During the year 1710, this Company took eight hundred. Some years later it killed thousands; but the number gradually diminished every year, and, whether from the increasing navigation of the river proving a cause of alarm to this valuable fish, or from some of those hidden causes which the depths of ocean veil from us, they ceased to live together in large shoals, and dispersed into all parts of the river. It cannot, however, be said that they are less numerous in the St. Lawrence than heretofore; on the contrary, the number is much greater, and their species belongs exclusively to that river. It is the largest and most profitable of those which live permanently in Canadian waters. This fish was formerly taken in inclosures made of light and flexible poles fixed in the beach. Stakes are now used to make the inclosures only at Point Orielle, St. Anne and Isle-aux-Coudres. But, for some years past, another method has been adopted, and no doubt if it had been on a more extended scale it would have yielded immense profits. Mr. TETU had for several years past adopted the system of taking this fish in nets near the River Saguenay. After repeated experiments he discovered the proper manner to clarify the oil, and to manufacture leather out of its skin. This oil is extremely pure and inodorous, and gives a brilliant light, only surpassed by gas. It is superior to any other for the use of light-houses, because it does not coagulate even in the most intense cold, and its limpidity renders it invaluable for greasing leather, and for lubricating machinery. Appreciated as such by the great Exhibition of Paris and London, of Canada and New-York, it has gained testimonials and medals which sufficiently attest the great success obtained.

abstract: The announcement that JOHN MITCHEL would deliver a lecture on the Emperor NAPOLEON, at Cooper Institute, last evening, drew together a very large number of the lecturer's friends and admirers. The appearance of Mr. MITCHEL upon the platform was the signal for a round of most enthusiastic applause and cheers -- the cheering, accompanied by the waving of hats and handkerchiefs, continuing for several minutes. As soon as quiet was restored, Mr. MITCHEL went forward to the desk and delivered his lecture, in substance as follows:

abstract: Peter Brunck, the mate of the ship Bernard, was arrested last evening by the Harbor Police, on a charge of having stolen 400 pounds of cotton from on board that vessel, while she lay at Pier No. 6 North River....The Police of the Eighth Ward made an irruption, between 8 and 9 o'clock, upon the unfortunate women who frequent Canal-street and Broadway, and twenty-two of them, from 17 to 35 years of age, were looked up. The very indecorous conduct of these females for some time has induced this step on the part of Capt. Turnbull....Mr. G. Chevalier, while leaving Laura Keene's Theatre, accompanied by his wife was surrounded by pickpockets, one of whom took his wallet from his pocket. It contained a very valuable diamond-pin, and over $100 in cash.....Elizabeth Stewart, a young married woman, residing at No. 37 Muloerry-street, believing that she had been ill-treated by her husband, swallowed an ounce of laudanum, with the hope of ending her life. She was removed to the New-York Hospital and placed under Dr. Harris' care. Her condition is precarious....A piece of state fell from the roof of No. 64 Front-street, and struck the head of Patrick Gilroy, one of the laborers employed in repairing the building, inflicting a shocking scalp-wound. Dr. Andrews attended the injured man, and he was afterwards removed to his home.

The very indecorous conduct of these females for some time has induced this step on the part of Capt. Turnbull....Mr. G. She was removed to the New-York Hospital and placed under Dr. Harris' care. Her condition is precarious....A piece of state fell from the roof of No. 64 Front-street, and struck the head of Patrick Gilroy, one of the laborers employed in repairing the building, inflicting a shocking scalp-wound. abstract: When Mr. WISE resigned the gubernatorial seat of Virginia to his successor, we hoped that the political Jack Ketch of the Old Dominion might be about to retire from office with her pyrotechnic Palinurus. The country, while it lamented the passionate obstinacy with which the hero of Harper's Ferry had pursued his purpose of putting to death a fanatic whom death was sure to invest with the martyr's aureole, could yet make allowances for the author of this stupendous blunder, and did, in fact, make them. It is not only a Virginian, but, we fear, an American trait to exaggerate every emotion, and to sacrifice the gravest considerations of sense and dignity to the ecstasy of an intense sensation; and when we saw that Virginia had gone simply mad with mingled rage and fear, we could not fairly demand that Virginian statesmen should risk their influence and their future in an attempt to stem the furious torrent of the popular folly. We deplored the infatuation before which those who should have ruled the people felt themselves constrained to bow; but we knew that even a Virginian Governor is, after all, a man of like passions with ourselves, and we felt that it would be neither charitable nor just to expect of a provincial Executive, at such a moment, the courageous discretion which we might have had a right to look for from a statesman of loftier position dealing with a more reasonable because a more powerful community. It is a mere truism to say that all human passions become exasperated exactly in proportion as the circle in which they move is narrowed. A village mob is, of all imaginable mobs, the least amenable to any argument but force; and such is the constitution of society in Virginia that, for all practical purposes, the whole State was converted by the Harper's Ferry excitement into a mere hive of village mobs. Governor WISE must have been a very great man, indeed, if he was to find in himself the strength to resist and disregard the angry clamors of this hive. And as we had no reason to insist that Gov. WISE should be a very great man, we could afford to see him throw the reins for a time on the popular neck, without berating him immoderately. But the deed which Virginia proposes to do to-day, is far worse than the blunder which brought JOHN BROWN to the gallows, and the Governor of Virginia who has sanctioned it has dealt in cold blood a heavier blow at the character of his own Commonwealth, and at the peace of the country, than was struck by WISE in the fever of the popular rage.

abstract: IMPORTANT TO CHUCH-GOERS.?In the City Hall Park, yesterday morning, an inventive genius had on exhibition a contrivance for the benefit of those hard of hearing, which attracted the attention of the evercurious crowd. The instrument was nothing less than a great reservoir for the collection of sound, connected with a series of distributing pipes for conveying to many different ears at once.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT TO CHUCH-GOERS.?In the City Hall Park, yesterday morning, an inventive genius had on exhibition a contrivance for the benefit of those hard of hearing, which attracted the attention of the evercurious crowd. The instrument was nothing less than a great reservoir for the collection of sound, connected with a series of distributing pipes for conveying to many different ears at once. It is designed for use in churches, one of which, in this City, has already adopted it. The funnel-shaped vessel is placed before the pulpit, and catches the words as fast as they drop from the speaker's lips. From the bottom of the funnel, pipes are laid beneath the floor, to the various parts of the house occupied by those whose hearing is defective, and these terminate in ear-pieces attached to the side of the pew. The inventor did not explain whether these extremities are furnished, like gas-burners, with stop-cocks to enable the hearer to "turn off" the sermon when the odor of any part thereof becomes objectionable. It is to be presumed, however, that such an arrangement is furnished, so that the amount of spiritual light which each auditor requires may he easily regulated by himself. Of course, in this event, a verb-ometer should be provided for each pew, that no man may be called upon to pay for more preaching than he actually consumes. From this new invention a light seems to dawn upon the progress of church conveniences. For many who now stay away from church, because they are too lazy to go, or too poor to afford fitting apparel, can have the "gospel brought to their own door." In fact, the adoption of the new contrivances would save everybody the necessity of leaving home to hear the sermon. The laying of "mains" from the various churches through the principal streets would furnish all an opportunity to introduce "preaching" into their houses as conveniently as they now introduce water or gas, doing away, perhaps, in some instances, with necessity of the latter element altogether. Not least among those benefited by the adoption of this plan would be the clergyman himself, who could preach the church reservoir full, at his convenience through the week, and hoist the gate at the proper time on Sunday. Nor should so useful an invention be confined to the use of churches alone. Great reservoirs might be made throughout the City, replenished by conduits from Ward-rooms, corner groceries, and other centres of public discussion, and having pipes leading to ear pieces in the Common Council Chamber. Had this plan been in operation during the late two months of mud, the complaining cries that went up from the whole City, centering in the Council Chamber, would have made a din that the City fathers must have silenced by granting the clamorous petition for cleaner streets, before they could have proceeded with their own snug counsels of personal plunder. That the denizens of the City Hall, when once this invention is brought to their notice, will speedily adopt it, no one can doubt who has observed the facilities they extend to the modern political craft of "pipe layers," whose experience in the art of tabular interments would enable them quickly to complete the work.

abstract: Great Britain, France, Prussia, almost all the first-class European States, have recognized the right of their subjects to renounce their allegiance, and to become citizens of the United States; not so Spain. Whoever has the misfortune to be born beneath the banner of Castile and Leon must always remain subject to the Second ISABELLA and her heirs must always be liable to obey their behests, and to share their uncertain fate.
lead_paragraph: Great Britain, France, Prussia, almost all the first-class European States, have recognized the right of their subjects to renounce their allegiance, and to become citizens of the United States; not so Spain. Whoever has the misfortune to be born beneath the banner of Castile and Leon must always remain subject to the Second ISABELLA and her heirs must always be liable to obey their behests, and to share their uncertain fate. Once a Spaniard, always a Spaniard. No matter how early he may forsake her soil, or how long he may absent himself from it -- no matter how solemnly he may have abjured her authority, or how binding may be the obligations which he has contracted to his adopted country -- the Spaniard, nevertheless, becomes a son of Spain once more, the moment he ventures within her borders. A case has recently occurred in Cuba in point of this immutable policy. One GAVINO DE LIANO, born a Creole of Cuba, emigrated to the United States with his parents at the age of nine years, and became in common with them a naturalized citizen of our Republic. Sometime since he had occasion to return to his native island; but hardly had he set foot within the shadow of the Moro when he was summoned by the authorities to render military service to the crown of Spain as a conscript, or to pay a certain sum of money as the price of exemption. Regarding himself as a citizen of the United States, and not as a subject of the Spanish crown, DE LIANO bluntly refused either to render the required service, or to countenance the imposition by purchasing exemption from it. This contumacy led to his immediate arrest, and that again to an appeal in his behalf, made to Mr. HELM, our Consul-General at Havana, who promptly put himself into communication with the Cuban Government touching the particular outrage perpetrated on DE LIANO, and the rights of adopted American citizens in general. But the Consul-General's remonstrance produced no effect. The representative of Spanish royalty, instead of ordering the liberation of the recusant, replied after the following fashion, through Gen. SERRANO, to the application of Mr. HELM. Spain does not release her natural born subjects, who choose to go abroad and become adopted citizens of other States, from the obligation of military service, unless such subjects consent to pay a pecuniary consideration for exemption from said obligation; therefore the party whose case has been laid before the Cuban Executive cannot be released from custody, since he refuses to accept the alternative which the laws of her Majesty ISABELLA the Second offer to him, and to all other persons similarly circumstanced. Gen. SERRANO's response called forth a rejoinder from the Consul-General, in which that functionary manfully protested against the injustice of the Spanish law, and the detention of DE LIANO in prison, declaring at the same time that the United States Government would not submit to such a construction of the natural and acquired rights of its citizens as that propounded by the Cuban authorities. What resulted from Mr. HELM's last reclamation we are not informed, but from the known arrogance and obstinacy of Spanish officials, we may safely conclude that it proved as ineffectual as the first, and that DE LIANO is still in durance vile, unless he has yielded to the pressure of despotism, and at once freed himself from the dungeon and the obligation by payment of the pecuniary equivalent. It the Cuban Executive has continued deaf to the appeals of Mr. HELM, that official has of course nothing further to do with the matter than to forward a report of the case to Washington, where it will doubtless receive the prompt attention usually bestowed by our Foreign Secretary upon cases within this category. Whether DE LIANO remains a captive or submits to purchase his liberty. Mr. CASS' duty, however, will still be the same -- namely, to bring his grievances, through our Envoy in Spain, before the Madrid Administration, and to demand not only their immediate redress, but the total renunciation on the part of Spain of any such pretensions as these put forward against DE LIANO.

abstract: We do not know whether anything will or will not be done by the Legislature at this session concerning City Railroads. The friends of the "Gridiron bill" hope that the explosion caused by that demonstration will suffice to kill all attempts that may be made to charter any roads for this City. But there are still pending in the Assembly fire bills for City Railroads, -- each granting to certain specified persons the right to build and operate a Railroad through a certain portion of the streets of the City. The grant is absolute, and vests in the parties named the complete control over the roads which it authorizes them to build.

abstract: The United States vs. Charles Brown. The prisoner was convicted a day or two since of an assault with a dangerous weapon (with a knife) on the mate of the bark Mayflower, on which he was a seaman. His counsel made a motion for a new trial, which was this morning denied by the Court.

abstract: The death of Hon. Lewis C. Levin was announced by telegraph yesterday. Mr. Levin died at his residence in Philadelphia, on Wednesday. His age was 52. He was a native of Charleston, S.C., was educated at the South, and practiced law in Maryland, Lousiana and Kentucky. The Philadelphia Press says:

abstract: For some days past great excitement has existed in Washington in consequence of the discovery by JOHN W. FORNEY, Esq., Clerk of the House of Representatives, of a deficit in Post-office scrip to the amount of $200,000. After a thorough investigation into the affair, suspicion rested upon S.C. BOYINGTON, a clerk under Mr. FORNEY. He, however, had meantime fled from Washington, and a telegraphic dispatch having been sent yesterday to Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct, giving a full description of the suspected party, that officer while passing along Broadway last evening in company with Detective JOURDAN, observed a man standing upon the steps of tae International Hotel, whom he suspected of being the individual sought. The confused manner of the man at being addressed as Mr. BOYINGTON confirmed their suspicions, and he was immediately taken into custody. The prisoner is now in the Sixth Ward Station-house. He admitted to Capt. DOWLING that his name was BOYINGTON, although he had registered himself on the hotel-book as Mr. Snowden.
