abstract: THE LATE EXPLOSION AT RED HOOK -- VERDICT OF THE CORONER's JURY. -- The Coroner's inquest on the body of JOHN HAZLETON, killed by a recent explosion of a boiler in Imlay-street, Red Hook, was concluded yesterday, when the following verdict was rendered: "That the deceased, JOHN HAZLETON, came to his death by accidental injuries, the result of an explosion on the 12th day of March, 1860, at the Atlantic Foundary, situated between Van Brunt and Imlay streets, in the Twelfth Ward, in the city of Brooklyn, the result of negligence or carelessness on his part in allowing the water to become low and in the sudden introduction of cold water. And the jury further find the proprietors of the Atlantic Foundry censurable in employing a laboring man in the capacity of an engineer." The testimony was to the effect that the deceased was not a practical engineer, though he had charge of the engine.
lead_paragraph: THE LATE EXPLOSION AT RED HOOK -- VERDICT OF THE CORONER's JURY. -- The Coroner's inquest on the body of JOHN HAZLETON, killed by a recent explosion of a boiler in Imlay-street, Red Hook, was concluded yesterday, when the following verdict was rendered: "That the deceased, JOHN HAZLETON, came to his death by accidental injuries, the result of an explosion on the 12th day of March, 1860, at the Atlantic Foundary, situated between Van Brunt and Imlay streets, in the Twelfth Ward, in the city of Brooklyn, the result of negligence or carelessness on his part in allowing the water to become low and in the sudden introduction of cold water. And the jury further find the proprietors of the Atlantic Foundry censurable in employing a laboring man in the capacity of an engineer." The testimony was to the effect that the deceased was not a practical engineer, though he had charge of the engine.

abstract: The Omnibus proprietors were near feeling the need, only a week ago, of a good deal of public sympathy and support, when the ruin of their business was threatened by the "Gridiron Railroad." The danger has for the present passed away, but it is not at all unlikely it may return; and if they wish the public to stand by them when it does return, we strongly recommend the Consolidated Stage Company to strike from their rules that extraordinary one which came to light at the Mayor's Office on Thursday, by which a driver is obliged to stop the omnibus, and turn all the passengers into the street, in ease one of them tails or refuses to pay his fare.

abstract: The Academy of St. Petersburg has published the result of the examination into which KOEPPEN, the well-known statistician, has gone with regard to the true area and amount of population of the Russian Empire. He gives an area to Russia, including Siberia, but not Mantchouria and the smaller islands on the coast of the Pacific, of 383,500 to 384,000 German square miles, each of which is equal to about 22 English square miles. To this must be added the Kingdom of Poland, with 2,320, and the Grand Duchy of Finland, with 6,844 square miles, the latter alone being consequently larger than Great Britain and Ireland. The sum total of the population amounts to 67,500,000, of which 52,317,836 live in the Russian provinces in Europe; 4,852,055 in Poland; 1,636,915 in Finland; 3,734,584 in the Caucasian provinces; 3,778,157 in West, and 1,088,561 in East Siberia; and, finally, 54,000 in America. The important and interesting divisions of the population, according to race, language and creed, are not given.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of St. Petersburg has published the result of the examination into which KOEPPEN, the well-known statistician, has gone with regard to the true area and amount of population of the Russian Empire. The important and interesting divisions of the population, according to race, language and creed, are not given.

abstract: Mr. MAX MARETZEK returned to the City on Thursday evening, laden with health, honors and money. His season in Havana has been one of unprecedented brilliancy, and his successes, artistically and pecuniarily, greater than ever. The new tenor, ERNANI, created a perfect furore, and was declared to be the only worthy successor to SALVI the Havanese have ever had. We shall soon have an opportunity to judge for ourselves, for Mr. MARETZEK commences operations at the Winter Garden immediately on the termination of Lent. The prima donna will, of course, be Mad. FABBRI, concerning whom the public has already heard sufficient to feel the deepest interest in her debut. In musical circles there is but one opinion of her rare powers. Mr. MARETZEK means work this season, and that, modestly interpreted, signifies good artists, good operas, and plenty of both. We shall probably be astonished with the extraordinary phenomena of two or three new works in as many weeks. An amusing illustration of the energy of the "indomitable" was furnished on the return voyage. The steamship was detained for a few hours at Key West -- where they break ships and put up green turtle. MARETZEK, with a few artists, extemporized a concert, and the Key Westers rewarded his enterprise by attending en masse. The place contains about twenty-five houses, and the concert realized upwards of four hundred dollars. In New-York, where they put up ships and eat green turtle, he could scarcely have done better.

abstract: It is beginning to be known, even in circles where sporting newspapers are never seen, that the fight between TOM SAYERS and HEENAN, called the "Benicia Boy," is to take place on the day named; and it is evident to every one who observes what is passing in society, that both in Great Britain and the United States this battle is regarded with an unusually deep and extensive interest. The explanation of this change of sentiment towards prize-fighting is to be found, we think, in various circumstances. In the first place, the international character which has been ascribed to the approaching contest gives to it an importance which an ordinary match between two Englishmen, arranged perhaps for the benefit of a few sporting publicans, could not claim. We are by no means sure that this match has not attained its worldwide fame contrary to the intention of the parties principally concerned. It is of course the business of TOM SAYERS, as champion of England, to answer all worthy challengers; but we believe that his opponent rather declines the honor which has been thrust upon him of representing the pugilism of America. He is reported to have said that he has come to England to fight TOM SAYERS, because he wishes to fight him, and for no other reason. Nevertheless, the public appears to be determined to look upon the "Benicia Boy" as the champion of the United States, and to treat the issue of this fight as a matter of national importance.

abstract: The Cunard steamer Asia left Liverpool on the afternoon of the 3d inst., with highly interesting news -- a digest of which will be found in a supplement accompanying the present issue of the TIMES. A brief abstract has already been received from the Circassian, which left Galway on the morning of the same day. The Reform bill, introduced by Lord JOHN RUSSELL, is diversely handled by the Press. In the main, it is regarded as an imperfect and temporizing measure; but as much as can be hoped for with the present Ministerial combination. The excitement caused by the project of annexing Savoy to France runs high in England, where it has been the subject of animated discussion in the House of Commons. There is little doubt, however, of the plan being realized, either with or without the consent of Piedmont. Indeed, if the latter refuse, as is anticipated, to accept the new programme for Italy, the forfeiture of the province in question will doubtless be the penalty of her contumacy. In the Duchies, in the meantime, the popular vote upon the question of annexation to Sardinia was about to be taken. The intelligence from Morocco is unimportant. Another trifling advantage had been secured by the Spanish arms. There is little of interest from the Continent generally, beyond the telegraphic summary already given.

abstract: SANITARY SCIENCE. -- A Committee, consisting of several prominent and influential citizens, have advertised a course of four lectures on Sanitary Science, at the Cooper Institute, by E.Y. ROBBINS, Esq., commencing on Monday evening next. These lectures produced a decided sensation in Boston, and their value cannot be over-estimated in New-York. The mass of statistical information they present respecting the causes of disease and death in our large cities, the great mortality among children, the reduction of the average age at death in New-York from 26 years, as in 1810, to 15 years, as in 1859, should arouse our citizens to action in removing the causes of this frightful mortality. Mr. ROBBINS, we have reason to believe, is amply qualified to present the subject in its true light, and to point out the remedies to be applied. These lectures merit general attention.
lead_paragraph: SANITARY SCIENCE. -- A Committee, consisting of several prominent and influential citizens, have advertised a course of four lectures on Sanitary Science, at the Cooper Institute, by E.Y. lead_paragraph: Further progress was made with the Budget. An attempt was made to amend the resolution reducing the duties on silk, unless provision be made in the French treaty for the simultaneous admission into France of English manufactured silks and ribbons on equal terms. The amendment was rejected by a large majority.

abstract: Both Houses of the Legislature have passed an act amending the Act of 1839, by which theatres, &c., are required to have the Mayor's license, paying the fees therefor into the treasury of the House of Refuge. The Board of Trustees of that Institution were empowered to prosecute offenders, sue out injunctions, and restrain in various ways unlawful exhibitions. The new law, as we have already explained, simply extends the provisions of the act to a large class of public performances, such as negro minstrels, "beer garden" the atricals, &c., which have come into being since the original act was passed. The fees, penalties, and the modes of enforcing them, are substantially the same as before. A clause is added, however, which is consistent with all our legislation, excepting "the first day of the week, called Sunday," from the authorized time for these public sports. And this arouses the old cry of "civil and religious liberty," under which the newsboys were to be allowed to continue their Sunday clamor, and the liquor dealers were to persist in their Sunday dramming.

The fees, penalties, and the modes of enforcing them, are substantially the same as before. A clause is added, however, which is consistent with all our legislation, excepting "the first day of the week, called Sunday," from the authorized time for these public sports. And this arouses the old cry of "civil and religious liberty," under which the newsboys were to be allowed to continue their Sunday clamor, and the liquor dealers were to persist in their Sunday dramming.

abstract: The London Morning Chronicle ad[???]er[???] to its statement that the Austro-Russian treaty of alliance was prepared for signature on the terms published in its columns, but, owing to the determined attitude which had been taken against it, some modifications had been agreed upon, and the treaty would be carried out in a more harmless form. The Chronicle now states that Russia is not to aid Austria in Italy, but will act with her in any complication that may arise in regard to the countries on the Danube, or to affairs in Hungary. It also announces that the Prince of HESSE had quitted V[???]a for St. Petersburg, with the draft of the modified treaty for signature.

abstract: The news which we are receiving from Venetia could not be of a more deplorable character. The grave and imposing demonstrations which have taken place in every city during the month of January against Austrian domination have determined the Cabinet of Vienna to invest the police with more power, in order  that this agitation may be checked by all means, not excluding force, arbitrary punishment, deportation or terror.

abstract: Many years before the war of the Revolution, there stood a time-worn edifice, of mouldering brick and crumbling stone, in the now magnificent pleasure-ground which we call the Central Park of New-York. Isolated and bleak, in those days, with no attempt at ornament upon its rude walls, the old house had been untenanted for years, when Hugh Garrbolt saw fit to make it his habitation. No one then living could say to whom it belonged, or by whom it had been built; though gray-haired men told that it had sprung as from the earth, unmade by mortal hands, and fit only for the lurking place of smugglers, desperadoes or demons. The last man, within their recollection, who had lived there before Hugh Garrbolt made it his home, died there alone; nor was he known to be dead until a wandering hunter, demanding shelter at its iron-bound door and prison-like windows, and receiving no reply, forced an entrance from the rear; and, after striking a light with flint and steel, beheld a human skeleton, clad in decaying leathern garments, seated in an oaken chair in ghostly grimness.
lead_paragraph: Many years before the war of the Revolution, there stood a time-worn edifice, of mouldering brick and crumbling stone, in the now magnificent pleasure-ground which we call the Central Park of New-York. Isolated and bleak, in those days, with no attempt at ornament upon its rude walls, the old house had been untenanted for years, when Hugh Garrbolt saw fit to make it his habitation. No one then living could say to whom it belonged, or by whom it had been built; though gray-haired men told that it had sprung as from the earth, unmade by mortal hands, and fit only for the lurking place of smugglers, desperadoes or demons. The last man, within their recollection, who had lived there before Hugh Garrbolt made it his home, died there alone; nor was he known to be dead until a wandering hunter, demanding shelter at its iron-bound door and prison-like windows, and receiving no reply, forced an entrance from the rear; and, after striking a light with flint and steel, beheld a human skeleton, clad in decaying leathern garments, seated in an oaken chair in ghostly grimness.

abstract: The Third NAPOLEON is taking his first step in that career of territorial annexation which the founder of his family pursued with such unexampled energy and to so disastrous a termination. He had already doubled the commerce, multiplied the colonies, almost created the navy of France. He had made the nation peaceful beyond all precedent in making it beyond all precedent prosperous. He had made the nation powerful in renewing for it the glory of its most magnificent military past. He has now undertaken to consolidate it more firmly than ever by extending its frontiers towards the line which bounds the language and the manners of the French. The acquisition of Savoy has been announced from the imperial throne to be a duly devolving upon the ruler of France, from the actual position of European politics; and the declaration -- received with acclamations of delight in France, as the language of a sovereign too truly and too frankly French to shrink from asserting the right of France to reconstruct, in her own interest, that map of her dominions which Europe, in 1815, drew up expressly to thwart her progress and to cripple her action -- has been heard with alarm in England by no inconsiderable portion of the English Press and of English public men, as a voice from the grave so sternly closed with the rock of St. Helena. The visions which appalled the contemporaries of PITT and CASTLEREAGH have risen up once more before the eyes of their descendants. Once more the British Parliament echoes with denunciations of a BONAPARTE, stretching his despotic sceptre over the Continent; arming France from the Atlantic to the Alps within her "natural boundaries," and preparing universal monarchy in the territorial consolidation of the formidable race which has so often before given law to Europe. A moment's reflection should suffice to demonstrate the absurdity of these anticipations, and the injustice which they have led Englishmen of rank and sense to do the heir of the Napoleonic name. Nothing in the whole strange story of the present Emperor of the French is more plainly marked with the original peculiarities of his own genius and policy, nothing could less resemble the conduct in like cases of his great predecessor, than his course with regard to this very question of Savoy.
lead_paragraph: The Third NAPOLEON is taking his first step in that career of territorial annexation which the founder of his family pursued with such unexampled energy and to so disastrous a termination. The acquisition of Savoy has been announced from the imperial throne to be a duly devolving upon the ruler of France, from the actual position of European politics; and the declaration -- received with acclamations of delight in France, as the language of a sovereign too truly and too frankly French to shrink from asserting the right of France to reconstruct, in her own interest, that map of her dominions which Europe, in 1815, drew up expressly to thwart her progress and to cripple her action -- has been heard with alarm in England by no inconsiderable portion of the English Press and of English public men, as a voice from the grave so sternly closed with the rock of St. Helena. The visions which appalled the contemporaries of PITT and CASTLEREAGH have risen up once more before the eyes of their descendants. Once more the British Parliament echoes with denunciations of a BONAPARTE, stretching his despotic sceptre over the Continent; arming France from the Atlantic to the Alps within her "natural boundaries," and preparing universal monarchy in the territorial consolidation of the formidable race which has so often before given law to Europe. A moment's reflection should suffice to demonstrate the absurdity of these anticipations, and the injustice which they have led Englishmen of rank and sense to do the heir of the Napoleonic name. Nothing in the whole strange story of the present Emperor of the French is more plainly marked with the original peculiarities of his own genius and policy, nothing could less resemble the conduct in like cases of his great predecessor, than his course with regard to this very question of Savoy.

abstract: Most men, when going to sleep, take off the covering they wore in the day-time, and then tuck in the bed-clothes around the neck, which becoming too warm, gets open or thrown off; and the next day these people are trying in vain to remember when they were impatient. The ounce of prevention, which is worth more than a pound of cure, is to tie a handkerchief around the neck before going to sleep.

abstract: Hon. A.B. Meek, of Alabama, well known as an author, a chess player, and a politician, has taken his leave of the Speakership of the Alabama House. In his valedictory address, Mr. Meek dwelt upon the beauties of the new railroad system inaugurated in that State, "by which," he said "the mountain-barriers of the North are to be overleaped by the Fire-horse, and the sands of the South are to glitter in the tight of his flashing eyes." Mr. Meek retired immediately after uttering this sentiment.

abstract: -- It has been a matter of universal regret that, owing to the extreme and unconquerable aversion of Mr. IRVING during the last twenty years of his life, to sit for his portrait, no valuable and reliable likeness of him was in existence. Fortunately a daguerreotype, taken at the age of 65, has recently been discovered, and from this Mr. BRADY, the well-known daguerrian artist, has made a magnified copy which has been carefully painted in oil, and the result, according to the testimony of his immediate relatives and friends, is the best likeness ever made of Mr. IRVING, -- the only one, indeed, which presents him as he was during the latter years of his life. It is certainly a most exlent picture. It will be soon exhibited to the public at Mr. BRADY's Rooms.

abstract: The change which has come over the dream of HENRY A. WISE since he descended into private life is one of the most remarkable events of the present season. During the John Brown excitement he had so many proofs ...
lead_paragraph: The change which has come over the dream of HENRY A. WISE since he descended into private life is one of the most remarkable events of the present season. During the John Brown excitement he had so many proofs in his possession that the whole North had subscribed for the purchase of JOHN BROWN's outfit, and was anxiously hoping for the success of his enterprise, that his detestation of us knew no bounds. His sacred frenzy reached a climax when the medical students reached Richmond, on their way home from Philadelphia. Their appearance led to the delivery of a speech, which surpassed for folly and profanity anything which has ever issued in modern times from the lips of any man occupying a more dignified official position than the chieftainship of a tribe of savages. He hailed with frantic delight the resolution of the students to shake off Northern dust from the soles of their feet, and quit the polluted nest of Philadelphia; and threatened himself to invade the North and Canada with twelve men. He offered to attack the Cunard steamers with a small boat of his own, and forcibly seize and abduct a negro passenger; then volunteered on behalf of Virginia to declare war against Great Britain, because she did not maintain a large frontier guard in Canada for the arrest and prompt return of runaway Southern slaves. He shortly afterwards brought his absurdity to a climax by formally notifying the Governor of Ohio that, in case he heard of any Abolitionist conspiracy being formed in that State for the violation of the laws of Virginia, he should not resort to legal means for its punishment, but would incontinently levy an armed force and invade it. There were few persons at all solicitous about the credit of Virginia, not to speak of the United States, who were not disposed to veil Mr. WISE's performances during the last two months of his tenure of office, under the charitable hypothesis that his always excitable brain had given way under the pressure of the Harper's Ferry insurrection; that, in short, the perils and the responsibilities of that memorable campaign had proved too much for an organization which was always better fitted for the arduous labors of the stump than for the great exigencies of the battle-field; and they received the speech to the students as the final confirmation of their theory.

abstract: St. Patrick's Day in the evening was celebrated throughout the City in a great variety of ways, and at a large number of places, but nowhere by a larger and more enthausiastic assemblage than that which gathered at the Academy of Music to listen to a lecture by Rev. Dr. CAHILL, on the fidelity of the Irish
lead_paragraph: St. Patrick's Day in the evening was celebrated throughout the City in a great variety of ways, and at a large number of places, but nowhere by a larger and more enthausiastic assemblage than that which gathered at the Academy of Music to listen to a lecture by Rev. Dr. CAHILL, on the fidelity of the Irish people to freedom and to the faith of their fathers. Long before 6 o'clock, the time for opening the doors of the Academy, a crowd of men and women gathered about the building, eager for entrance; and when, at 8 o'clock, the speaker made his appearance on the stage, he was greeted with prolonged, enthusiastic and boisterous applause from every seat and standing place in the vast theatre. As soon as the audience permitted him a hearing, he began by telling them that he never was so overpowered in his life. He had addressed large assemblies since he had been here, and before he came here, but never before had be spoken in so large a building or to so large an audience as he saw before him. He had been delighted beyond measure as the sights he had witnessed that day. Never had he felt more proud of Irishman than when gazing upon the long procession of his countrymen, marching through the streets with their banners, their caps of liberty, their national emblems, and, above all, the stars and stripes of their adopted country floating by the side of every banner. And when he saw the-men uncover their heads as they passed by the statue of WASHINGTON, thus showing their reverence for the great and good pater patrioe, he felt that as citizens of this land of liberty, they would prove no less faithful and patriotic than they had been in the land of their birth. Although he had seen 200,000 men under arms, yet to his mind, as he looked upon this noble procession, so quiet, so orderly, so befitting the time and the occasion, it seemed the largest and best drilled army he had ever seen. Each man in the ranks, seen through the tears that came unbidden to his eyes, seemed the noblest, the bravest, and the best of human kind. And we have gathered here to night, said he to continue the celebration of this great festival of St. Patrick. All of you will agree with me, that this is a great day for Ireland, and in may estimation it is also a great day for the whole Christian world. It has been the custom of all nations, in all ages of the world, to celebrate the great events in their history, and to honor the birth-days of their heroes, their poets, their artists and their men of science. But what is history, what is poetry, what is art, what is science, compared to Christianity? This is a Christian festival. The anniversary of St. Patrick is the anniversary of the introduction of Christianity into Ireland. The speaker here gave a sketch of the life of St. Patrick; how he was captured on the coast of Africa by Irish pirates and taken to Ireland at the age of 16, and then condemned to tend swine. But what would seem to have been a great misfortune to him, proved to be one of the most glorious event in the history of the world. He entered upon the work of converting the Irish nation to Christianity, and met with astonishing success. From the time of his death, which occurred about A.D. 441, Ireland was for several centuries the seminary of Europe, occupying the highest position in the arts and sciences, and being unrivaled in her religious devotion. About the fifth century commenced the reign of the Kings of Ireland, of whom there were five, and who, he regretted to say, laid the foundations of those divisions that have more or less distracted the Irish people from that time to this. He had often thought what a pity it was that JULIUS CAESAR, when he conquered England, 75 years before Christ, had not also conquered Ireland, and given unity to her people. Why was it that the Irish people, so united in religious faith, should forever be divided in political sentiments? He would tell them why, it was because their religious teachers never betrayed them, while their politicians always did. The divisions fomented by the Irish Kings at length brought on the invasion of the Danes, who became masters of the country, and for two centuries persecuted the people, burnt their churches and libraries -- of which they had the finest in Europe -- and finally reduced them almost to a state of barbarism. At last the aid of England was called in, and she in turn, after having got possession of the country, continued the persecutions of the Irish people; and the truth of history compelled him to admit that the Catholic Kings of England had persecuted the Irish to nearly as great extent as the Protestant Kings. King JOHN, a Catholic, was the great tyrant, and the worst foe to her religion that Ireland ever had. A bad man, a Catholic, was the worst man in the world; to the natural evil of his heart he added a base hypocrisy. The lecturer proceeded to sketch the history of Ireland during the reigns of successive English monarchs, down to the present time -- showing how persistently, and with what unsparing [???]gor she had been persecuted, and trodden down by her rulers; and with what unflinching firmness, patience, courage, and God-like heroism, she had endured it all, and stood up for the ancient faith of her fathers, and for the glorious liberty which was the natural inheritance of that faith. He exhorted his hearers to continue to stand up for the true faith, and as the providence of God had ordained that they should be dispersed over the earth, let every man, wherever he may go, be a missionary in the cause of religion, and a champion of liberty.

abstract: The absence of the Archbishop in Charlestion did not interfere with the customary celebration of the fete of the Irish Apostle in the cathedral which bears his name in Mott-street. The day devoted to the good Saint's commemoration is, be it understood, not alone a holiday; it is a holy day likewise, and the faithful are bound to hear mass as on Sunday. Yesterday there were special services in all the Roman Catholic Churches in the City. In the cathedral a grand high mass was celebrated by Bishop LOUGHLIN, of Brooklyn. He was assisted by Father STARRS, the Vicar-General; Fathers DOYLE and WOOD officiated as deacon and sub-deacon, and Father MCEVOY acted as master of the ceremonies. A large body of clerics, [???]among whom was Archdeacon MCCARROW, occupied seats within the sanctuary. Father MAGUIRE, of Washington, preached the sermon, the text of which was taken from the forty-fourth chapter of Ecclesiasticus. It was a panegyric on St. Patrick, and closed by an eloquent appeal to follow the Saint's example, and abide by his teachings.

abstract: The Hamburg screw-steamer Teutonia, Capt TAVRE, arrived at this port yesterday, having sailed from Hamburg on the 1st and Southampton on the 5th of March. She brings us London journals of that date,--two days later than those hitherto received.
lead_paragraph: The Hamburg screw-steamer Teutonia, Capt TAVRE, arrived at this port yesterday, having sailed from Hamburg on the 1st and Southampton on the 5th of March. She brings us London journals of that date,--two days later than those hitherto received. She brings 44 passengers -- has had moderate weather with variable winds, and took a pilot from boat No. [???], inside of the light ship, yesterday morning. She was detained five hours by fog, and arrived off the Battery at 1:45 P.M. She brings as passengers Paul Engels, Wm. Salem and family, Jas. Kidd, Mrs. Salem and family, F. Straut, and 244 steerage.

abstract: Saturday was duly observed throughout the city by the Sons of St. Patrick. Several Irish Societies paraded through the pricipal streets, and in the Roman Catholic Churches a High Mass was observed. The associations which celebrated the day in Brooklyn comprised the Erin Fraternal Beneficial Society, under command of Marshals JAMES BRADLEE and JAMES MC-KINNNY; the shamrock Beneficial Association, Marshals JAMES EGAN and MICHAEL FARBELL; and the Laborers Union Beneficial Association, Marshals MICHAEL KEENE and JOHN GILL. The military, which took the fight of the line, consisted of the Ringgold Horse Guard, Capt. URBAN, and Emmett Artillery, Capt. JOHNSON. The procession passed through the principal streets, which were full of people. It was an uncommonly fine display. In Court-street, near the City Hall, a difficulty arose between some of the man at the head of the procession and same car-drivers who did not like to stand still while the column was passing. One of the Marshals struck the horses with his sword, but there was no damage

abstract: BALTIMORE, Thursday, March 15, 1860. Our city was thrown into a painful excitement  to-day, in consequence of the report that a serious accident had occurred on the Northern Central Railroad. It appears that the passenger train which left Calvert Station at 8 o'clock this morning, ran off the track some ten miles out, near a small town called Texas.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Thursday, March 15, 1860.

abstract: -- The body of JOANNA MORRISSEY, mother of JOHN MORRISSEY, the noted pug[???]st, was found yesterday morning about 6 o'clock, in the Poesiankill Creek, near the Second-street crossing. The body had the appearance of being in the water all right, and it is supported that in attempting to cross the Second-street bridge, she lost the way, walked into the creek and was drowned. Mrs. MORRISSEY was a women of very unsteady habits, and has probably engrossed the attention of our police magistrates more than any other single person. She has repeatedly served terms in the Benitentiary. During nearly a year past the unfortunate women has been an inmate of the County Home, which she left only a day or two ago, and has since been quite intoxicated. All efforts to reform her were beyond power. Coroner MADDEN took charge of the remains, and Dr. BURTON made a post mortem examination. The inquest was held yesterday afternoon, and the jury brought in a verdict that JOANNA MORRISSEY came to her death by accidental drowning. -- Troy Arena, 15.

abstract: ITEMS. -- Dr. SAMUEL BOYD, Health Officer, died on Saturday last from consumption. He was 54 years of age, and during his life occupied several public positions of trust. The Health Wardens of the city held a meeting Saturday, and adopted resolutions of respect, and the members of the Board of Aldermen and the Kings County Medical Society (of which he was for some time President) will attend his funeral to-day in a body .... A boy named TIMOTHY KELLY accidentally fell into a cistern of hot swill in MANLY's distillery, corner of Gold and Tillary streets, Saturday. He was rescued promptly, but not before he had been seriously scalded, and taken to the City Hospital.... Mrs. BURWICK, residing at the corner of Remsen and South streets, (E.D.,) was fatally burned, Friday night last, by the explosion of a fluid lamp.... The annual dinner of the St. Patrick's Society will be given this evening, at Montague Hall .... The artists of this city will give their first annual reception on Wednesday evening next, in DODWORTH's Assembly Rooms, Montague-street.

abstract: A meeting of delegates representing the various trades in the City was held last evening at GEO. KUPPER'S saloon, No. 229 East Eleventh-street, to devise means for extending sympathy and material aid to
lead_paragraph: A meeting of delegates representing the various trades in the City was held last evening at GEO. KUPPER'S saloon, No. 229 East Eleventh-street, to devise means for extending sympathy and material aid to the Lynn shoemakers and other strikers in Massachusetts. About forty delegates were present, on behalf of the printers, shoemakers, hatters, carpenters, and men of other trades. GEORGE GRIMM was called to the chair, explained the objects of the meeting, and exhorted his countrymen, the Germans, to cooperate with the English shoemakers of this City in lending their assistance to their brethren in Massachusetts, and also in protecting their own interests at home.

abstract: Commenting a few days ago on Gen. Cass' letter to Mr. DALLAS about the Slave-trade, and the policy of the American Government in reference to it, we dwelt upon the manifest absurdity of citing the act of Congress making it piracy, in controversies with Great Britain, ...
lead_paragraph: Commenting a few days ago on Gen. Cass' letter to Mr. DALLAS about the Slave-trade, and the policy of the American Government in reference to it, we dwelt upon the manifest absurdity of citing the act of Congress making it piracy, in controversies with Great Britain, as proof of our abhorrence of it, inasmuch as no conviction under that act has ever taken place. We added, moreover, that the second evidence of our "soundness on the goose," which we are rather fond of producing, -- the presence of a squadron on the slave coast, -- also partook in a remarkable degree of the character of humbug, for two reasons. The first is, that, though it is notorious that the Slave-trade is flourishing, our squadron never catches any slavers, and makes no great exertions to do so; and the second is, that, were it ever so anxious to execute the laws, it could not succeed, because the ships of which it is composed are utterly unfitted for the service in which they are nominally engaged.

abstract: The case of Capt. E.B. Mallett, of the ship John Cuttle, of Thomaston, Me., charged with shooting his first mate on the high seas, came up for examination on Saturday, before United States Commissioner BETTS. J.L. McLane, Esq., conducted the case for ...
lead_paragraph: The case of Capt. E.B. Mallett, of the ship John Cuttle, of Thomaston, Me., charged with shooting his first mate on the high seas, came up for examination on Saturday, before United States Commissioner BETTS. J.L. McLane, Esq., conducted the case for the United States Government; and Messrs. Benedict, Burr and Benedict, were employes for the defence. Depositions of six of the crew were taken, by Mr. McMicken, the American Consul at Acapulco, two of which were those of two witnesses (John Pinkerton and Andrew Elwell) who accompanied the Captain to this port.

abstract: To see the procession was the great desire of all the Hibernians who did not constitute a part of it, and the line of march was thronged. Especially was this the case in the Park. The crowd packed the broad open space is front of the City Hall, and it was with the greatest difficulty that room was made for the
lead_paragraph: To see the procession was the great desire of all the Hibernians who did not constitute a part of it, and the line of march was thronged. Especially was this the case in the Park. The crowd packed the broad open space is front of the City Hall, and it was with the greatest difficulty that room was made for the procession to pass. Every available place was occupied, and the boys seemed to think that THOM's statue of the Father of his Country was placed there especially for their accommodation. They testified their affection for the statuesque hero by holding on by his legs, his hands, his coat-tails, and hugging him about the body. One urchin perched himself on the shoulder, and embraced the venerated forehead of WASHINGTON with a pair of ragged and dirty arms that might well have vivified the stone brow with a flush of indignation. The boy proved to be "Patience on a monument," for though the procession was advertised to start at 11 o'clock, the line was not formed until after 12.

abstract: The great question of the day is  where shall the Democratic Convention meet? What action it shall take has become a matter of comparative indifference.
lead_paragraph: The great question of the day is where shall the Democratic Convention meet? What action it shall take has become a matter of comparative indifference. Whether DOUGLAS, or STEPHENS, HUNTER or WISE is to be the candidate, seems suddenly to have passed from the public mind. The great topic discussed is, what city shall have the honor and the profit of feeding and lodging the weary and the hungry hordes who are expected to congregate on that occasion?

abstract: The detectives, on Saturday, found active emploment in apprehending well-known pickpockets, who were busy among the spectators of the procession. A dozen or more were locked up at headquarters
lead_paragraph: The detectives, on Saturday, found active emploment in apprehending well-known pickpockets, who were busy among the spectators of the procession. A dozen or more were locked up at headquarters until evening, when those who had not been detected in the act of stealing were discharged, while the others were disposed of by the magistrates. Two of the pickpockets, whose pictures are in the Rogues' Collection, had had their likenesses "turned" some months ago, upon their repeated assurances of having reformed. Officer WATERS, of the Second Predinct, arrested ANDREW MCCLUSKY, a young butcher, who succeeded in jerking a watch from the fob of Mr. GEORGE H. TIMPSON, a gentleman residing in Morrisania, as he was looking at the procession from in front of the TIMES Office. MCCLUSKY was committed for trial by Justice QUACKENBUSH. A confederate, to whom he passed the watch, escaped.

abstract: The State Senate has hit upon a, new expedient for replenishing the State Treasury. The proposition hitherto has been to toll the Railroad freights:--the Senate has now voted to tax passengers instead. The bill which that ...
lead_paragraph: The State Senate has hit upon a, new expedient for replenishing the State Treasury. The proposition hitherto has been to toll the Railroad freights:--the Senate has now voted to tax passengers instead. The bill which that body has passed preserves the form of a tolling bill, without any of its substance. It makes no attempt to check or control the competition of the Railroads with the Canals in the carrying of freights: that is abandoned entirely. The Railroads are merely told that they must hand over a certain sum to the State Treasury; -- and then they are allowed to raise their rates of fare for passengers from two cents to two and a half per mile, to make up their deficiency. In other words, the traveling public is to be taxed half a cent a mile for the benefit of the State Treasury. Any person who wishes to go by Railroad from Albany to Buffalo must first pay his fare, -- reimburse the Railroad Company for the labor and expense of carrying him thither, -- and then pay the State one dollar and eighty cents, for no other reason than that the State happens to need the money! The State, in its necessities, seems to have turned highwayman. It stations its agents upon the Railways, and compels every unhappy traveler who may happen to pass, to stand and deliver.

abstract: The Society of Friendly Sons of St. Patrick gathered at the Metropolitan Hotel on Saturday evening for the purpose of doing honor to the memory of the patron saint of Ireland, and celebrating the seventy-sixth anniversary of their own organization. The dinner, which was served in the grand banquet hall of the hotel, and, under the immediate personal superintendence of Mr. WARREN LELAND, more than sustained the excellent reputation of this popular house. In the arrangement of the tables there was a change from the usual form, in regard to those intended for the principal officers and guests. The tables were elevated some twelve or fourteen inches above the others, and placed so that those who occupied them filled a square and sat face to face. The table ornaments were, many of them, prepared especially for the occasion and suggestive of the events which the Society had met to commemorate. The statuette of St. Patrick, in sugar, placed temptingly in front of the President, Hon. Judge DALY, excited considerable curiosity, after a remark from the Judge drew attention to the fact that the artist had expanded the robes of his favorite by a hoop of the most fashionable dimensions. Accepting the artist's idea of the style of St. Patrick's dress, it was considered another irrefragable proof that there has never been anything thought, said, sung or done that was not first thought, said, sung or done in Ireland. The Hall itself was tastefully decorated with the flags of several nations,' the most prominent among them being the Green Flag and the Stars and Stripes. The instrumental music for the occasion was furnished by Dodworth's Band. When the President took his seat there were more than 200 persons seated around the tables.

abstract: -- Mr. ROBBINS continues his lectures upon the necessity and the means of promoting the health of large towns this evening. There is no subject which merits more attention from the great body of our citizens than this: and we have reason to believe that Mr. BOBBINS is admirably qualified to discuss it with ability and intelligence. We hope his lectures will be well attended, and that they may produce a decided impression upon the public mind.

abstract: AN UNFOUNDED CHARGE.--Mr. H.S. BOYINGTON, who was apprehended up Friday night on suspicion of having been a defaulter to the United States in the sum of $200,000, was on Saturday discharged
lead_paragraph: AN UNFOUNDED CHARGE.--Mr. H.S. BOYINGTON, who was apprehended up Friday night on suspicion of having been a defaulter to the United States in the sum of $200,000, was on Saturday discharged from custody. Mr. FORNEY, under whom Mr. B. had until recently been employed as a deputy clerk, in the House of Representatives, having telegraphed that there was no complaint against him. Mr. BOYINGTON was for seven or eight years a clerk in the Pension Office, but resigned that position for the one under Mr. FORNEY. He says that business of a private character induced him to visit this City, and he denies the truth of the story that has been circulated against him.

abstract: At a meeting of the Croton Board on Saturday it was decided, in view of the past and present favorable state of the weather, to resume work on streets and sewers next Wednesday, which is ten days earlier than the time prescribed by the ordinances, except (as in this instance) otherwise ordered by the Board. No street paving nor sewer building can be done from November to April, unless the Board choose to make general exceptions. This will be good news to thousands of laborers who have been anxiously waiting for the resumption of work, and who have grumbled considerably at the delay.

abstract: ST. Louis, Wednesday, March 14, 1860. Missouri politics now present some curious con  trasts and complications. The present State Legislature is intensely Democratic, and ardently ProSlavery; and while in the commercial metropolis of Missouri an avowed Republican Convention is ...
lead_paragraph: ST. Louis, Wednesday, March 14, 1860. Missouri politics now present some curious con trasts and complications. The present State Legislature is intensely Democratic, and ardently ProSlavery; and while in the commercial metropolis of Missouri an avowed Republican Convention is held, which indorses the Philadelphia Platform of '56, in Jefferson City, the political capital, during the same week, a bill is passed more cruel towards the free colored people of the State than was the Edict of Nantes upon the Protestants of France. The law provides for the reduction into Slavery of all the adult free negroes to be found in Missouri on Sept. 1, 1861. It is a sweeping and arbitrary mode of ridding the slaveholder of the constant insecurity of property which the presence and prosperity of free negroes in a slave community occasions. Although perfectly consistent with the new theory of the beneficence of Slavery, it is somewhat opposed to all law and right reason, unless it be the Rob Roy code of ethics:

abstract: We have two day's later intelligence from Europe, by the Teutonia, which arrived yesterday. She adds no news of special importance to that preciously received. She brings, however, the dispatches of the French Government to its Ministers in Turin and London, of which mention was ...
lead_paragraph: We have two day's later intelligence from Europe, by the Teutonia, which arrived yesterday. She adds no news of special importance to that preciously received. She brings, however, the dispatches of the French Government to its Ministers in Turin and London, of which mention was made by the Asia's news. They are able and decidedly important. The Emperor informs the King of Sardinia that he stands ready to sustain him fully, if he shall see fit to follow the policy which he indicates, -- but that he must rely upon his own strength entirely if he decides to take another course. He thinks that Tuscany should not be annexed to Sardinia, but that Parma and Modena may. The telegraph states that Count CAVOUR has replied to this advice, declining to follow it: -- this, however, is not yet quite certain. The French Secretary repeats the sentiment that the annexation of Savoy is a geographical necessity for France; and we have on the one hand an energetic protest against it on the part of England -- as calculated to arouse the suspicions and menace the peace of Europe; and on the other a declaration from Austria that she will not oppose the measure. The possibilities of trouble growing out of this question had slightly affected the London market; and it is stated that public feeling in Paris was not quite satisfied. Count DE MORNY's speech, at the opening of the Corps Legislatif, discusses the subject of Free Trade, -- saying that it will not answer until Protection has prepared the way for it, and that the new commercial treaty has been carefully adapted to this principle. The elections were to be held in Central Italy on the subject of annexation, and the result would be known on the 20th. Spain does not propose to hold the territory conquered from Morocco.

abstract: Prof. ELIE CHARLIER delivers to-night the first of four lectures in the French language, upon topics connected with French literature, at the Spingler Institute. He is known as one of the most accomplished teachers in our City, and is a very vigorous and eloquent speaker. His subjects are interesting. "Victor Hugo" being his theme to-night; and the lectures promise to be unusually attractive. But they have additional claims to public favor. Prof. C.'s special object in delivering them is to raise a small sum of money in aid of a Protestant church in the parish of Landouzy la Ville, in France, of which his father has for thirteen years been the pastor. His parishioners are basket-makers or small farmers, and the church grew up in the early days of the Reformation. It is commended to the Christian public of this country by some of the clergymen best known among us, and appeals strongly to public favor. Prof. C. proposes to devote the proceeds of his lectures to its aid.

abstract: It is understood that orders went out from  our Government by the steamer Brooklyn  which has just sailed from Norfolk with Mr.  McLANE for Vera Cruz, that no respect is to ...
lead_paragraph: It is understood that orders went out from our Government by the steamer Brooklyn which has just sailed from Norfolk with Mr. McLANE for Vera Cruz, that no respect is to be paid to any blockade of Mexican ports by MIRAMON. If this report be true, our Government has given itself unnecessary trouble. MIRAMON is about as likely to blockade Vera Cruz as he is to blockade New-Orleans; and the fact that we have thus taken steps to prevent what is most unlikely to occur, curiously illustrates our existing means of information in regard to the Mexican question. We have no mail facilities with that country, no regular communication, indeed, of any kind, and sometimes more than thirty days elapse without our receiving one word of intelligence from Mexico, at this most critical moment of her existence.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Monday, March 19. The New-Orleans papers of Thursday, received  here by express, give the details of the Mexican news brought by the Star of the West. MIRAMON approached Vera Cruz on the 29th ult., with 5,000 men, a numerous train of artillery and ammunition stores, and encamped four miles from the city.

abstract: The work of paving the Fifth and Sixth avenues with Belgian pavement was commenced yesterday, by order of the Board, much to the delight of the hundreds of applicants for places, and the thousands of laborers who have managed to worry through the Winter in anticipation of the Spring work. The Croton Office was crowded yesterday with applicants, but it was remarkable that there was no application for any but chief positions, every man who had voted feeling himself competent for a leading place. Some twenty will be gratified, in due season, while several hundred will suffer the pangs of political neglect.

abstract: The Republican Party, as represented in the Senate, is assuming a very serious responsibility to the country by its course upon the treaties dependent upon its action. It seems to have decided that this present Administration shall not have the credit of closing any of ...
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party, as represented in the Senate, is assuming a very serious responsibility to the country by its course upon the treaties dependent upon its action. It seems to have decided that this present Administration shall not have the credit of closing any of the quarrels which have so long threatened to involve us in still more serious difficulties with foreign powers, and to prevent such a result it rejects all steps to end them.

abstract: Thanks to New-York Aldermen, Congressional Caucuses, and State Legislatures, there has been silently growing up in this country, through the last decade of our history, a decided disposition on the part of every honest and ...
lead_paragraph: Thanks to New-York Aldermen, Congressional Caucuses, and State Legislatures, there has been silently growing up in this country, through the last decade of our history, a decided disposition on the part of every honest and thoughtful person, to extol the monarchical at the expense of the democratic theory of government. The "One-Man-Power," at which our fathers shuddered as at the aspect of the Parent of Evil himself, has become a familiar synonym for the secret of public order and national progress with many a man who would be startled, could he look his own thoughts fully in the face, to see how far he has traveled on the road, not exactly perhaps to Rome, as she is, but certainly to Russia, as she was. We need hardly say that we are as blind worshippers of things as they are, even in this Empire City and State of the Model Republic, In fact, did we venture such an assertion, we might be rapidly and decisively "put down" from our own columns. But we cannot bring contemporary history fairly up for trial without seeing that the system of "concentrated political responsibility" has been fully put to the test in at least one conspicuous instance, and also that it has signally failed within our own times.
headline: {'main': 'The One-Man-Power.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The One-Man-Power.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The Rome correspondent of the Boston Transcript, writing of the statue of JOSIAH QUINCY, says: "I was at Mr. QUINCY's house in Cambridge on the seventieth anniversary of his birthday, in company with CHARLES SUMNER and CHARLES DICKENS. His vigor, activity and animated sympathy with the young were the prominent theme of his visitors, as they continue to be, after the further lapse of 16 or 18 years. He was then considered very young-looking for his age; and I fancy that they who knew him most intimately then will be most forcibly struck with the resemblance in the statue. The rare nobility of the head, faithfully given, not idealized; the characteristic dignity of the features, just relaxing into a benignant smile; the classic elegance of the carriage, which the power of the artist has rescued from the modern dangers of stiffness and awkwardness, and clothed with grace; in a word, the manifold individualities of this scholar and patriot, stereotyped upon the clay, yet warmed into harmonious life and movement, attest the genius of the artist, the love of the quondam pupil, the veneration of the fellow-citizen, the appreciation of the man."
lead_paragraph: -- The Rome correspondent of the Boston Transcript, writing of the statue of JOSIAH QUINCY, says: "I was at Mr. QUINCY's house in Cambridge on the seventieth anniversary of his birthday, in company with CHARLES SUMNER and CHARLES DICKENS. He was then considered very young-looking for his age; and I fancy that they who knew him most intimately then will be most forcibly struck with the resemblance in the statue. The rare nobility of the head, faithfully given, not idealized; the characteristic dignity of the features, just relaxing into a benignant smile; the classic elegance of the carriage, which the power of the artist has rescued from the modern dangers of stiffness and awkwardness, and clothed with grace; in a word, the manifold individualities of this scholar and patriot, stereotyped upon the clay, yet warmed into harmonious life and movement, attest the genius of the artist, the love of the quondam pupil, the veneration of the fellow-citizen, the appreciation of the man."

abstract: -- A New-York Correspondent of the Charleston Courier says: "MOSES H. GRINNELL, a leading partner, for a number of years, in the house of GRINNELL, MINTURN & Co., will soon withdraw from the concern, and return with his family to Europe, to spend considerable time. Mr. GRINNELL has sold his splendid residence at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The house of GRINNRLL, MINTURN, & Co., will retain its old name, as Mr. ROBERT B. MINTURN, his son, and a son of MOSES H. GRINNELL, will continue to [???] partners in it. HENRY GRINNELL has not been connected with the house for several years, and none of his sons were ever partners in the concern."
lead_paragraph: -- A New-York Correspondent of the Charleston Courier says: "MOSES H. GRINNELL, a leading partner, for a number of years, in the house of GRINNELL, MINTURN & Co., will soon withdraw from the concern, and return with his family to Europe, to spend considerable time. Mr. GRINNELL has sold his splendid residence at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The house of GRINNRLL, MINTURN, & Co., will retain its old name, as Mr. ROBERT B. MINTURN, his son, and a son of MOSES H. GRINNELL, will continue to [???] partners in it. HENRY GRINNELL has not been connected with the house for several years, and none of his sons were ever partners in the concern."

lead_paragraph: At the opening of the Special Term of the Supreme Court, held by Justice INGRAHAM, yesterday, the Court-room was thronged with counsel in attendance upon the case of the New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company vs. Schuyler, better known as "The Omnibus Suit." Many of the leading counsel of the City were present. This famous cause had been specially set down for trial yesterday.

abstract: A few days since, in making repairs in the upper story of the building now occupied by the Register and Comptroller, the workmen found under the eaves of the roof a large pile of books, papers, , which seemed to be useless.
lead_paragraph: A few days since, in making repairs in the upper story of the building now occupied by the Register and Comptroller, the workmen found under the eaves of the roof a large pile of books, papers, , which seemed to be useless. The Comptroller, however, on being informed of the discovery, instituted a personal examination, and found among them some interesting relics of the past concerning the City and Trinity Church. We have been favored with an inspection of them, and from one bundle, containing the "Accounts of the Church Wardens for the City of New-York of the Minister and Poor Tax, audited and approved by the Justices and Vestry men" -- we glean a few items of interest. The accounts themselves are all written on long, narrow, but very heavy payer, originally white, but now embrowned by age. The ink is as fresh and black as when the accounts were first written, and the chirography would gladden the eyes of the best modern penman.

abstract: The telegraph this morning seems to assure us that the American Government has interfered with the strong hand in behalf of liberal principles in Mexico. While the Senate is wasting precious time in partisan twaddle over the treaty negotiated by Mr. MCLANE, MIRAMON, it appears, has been steadily marching upon Vera Cruz. On reaching the environs of that city the young clerical leader proceeded to an immediate assault of the defences, which was gallantly repulsed by the Liberal forces. Those of our contemporaries who have been busily engaged for the last two months decrying the representatives of the Mexican democracy as the dregs and offscourings of a mongrel population, will doubtless be astonished to learn that these contemptible cohorts have succeeded in defeating the army of the Episcopal champion of Mexican monarchy. They will, no doubt, be more indignant still on learning that the steamer Gen. Miramon has arrived at New-Orleans, a prize to the American squadron. No details of this capture have yet reached us; but we may safely say that if Mr. BUCHANAN has given orders to our forces in the Gulf to recognize no blockade established in the name of MIRAMON, and to punish any attempt, in his name, at interference with the American flag, he has taken a step which will command the immediate sympathy of all well-informed and loyal citizens of the United States. We sincerely trust that fuller dispatches yet to be received may put this construction upon the important news which reaches us to-day.

abstract: Professor CHARLIER delivered the first of his four French lectures to a very excellent audience last evening, in the Spingler Institute. After stating the motive which prompted him to deliver these lectures, -- the hope of aiding to rebuild the Protestan Church of which his father is pastor, -- he said the first evening would be devoted to VICTOR HUGO, whose poetic genius was essentially material and practical contrasted with that of LAMARTINE, which is sentimental and ideal. He gave a rapid and graphic sketch of his life, from its commencement when he was a devoted Loyalist, through his successive changes of sentiment, first of detestation, then toleration, and finally admiration of the First NAPOLEON, until the present time, when he is so warm a Republican that he refuses to accept the amnesty of NAPOLEON III., whom he styled the Little, but who threatens, even in spite of VICTOR HUGO, to become the Great. Professor CHARLIER sketched the general character of his writings, both prose and poetry, and closed by reading some of the finest passages of the latter. He was listened to with very great interest to the close, and his own remarks, as well as his admirable reading of the extracts which he quoted, elicited frequent applause. He is a very energetic and vigorous speaker, -- and as a lecturer unusually interesting and attractive. His next lecture will be at the same place, on Thursday evening, upon LAMARTINE.
lead_paragraph: Professor CHARLIER delivered the first of his four French lectures to a very excellent audience last evening, in the Spingler Institute. abstract: We have important news from Mexico. The details of the news by the Star of the West are at hand. By telegraph from New-Orleans we learn that the Mexican war steamers General Miramon and Marquez are at that port, in charge of Lieutenants MINOR and CHAPMAN, of the Saratoga.
lead_paragraph: We have important news from Mexico. The details of the news by the Star of the West are at hand. By telegraph from New-Orleans we learn that the Mexican war steamers General Miramon and Marquez are at that port, in charge of Lieutenants MINOR and CHAPMAN, of the Saratoga. Both were captured off Anton Lizardo, on the morning of the 6th inst., after a brief action, and with only a slight loss, and are prizes to the United States. The Marquez has on board a portion of the prisoners taken, and the U.S. ship Preble was to bring the remainder. MIRAMON, on the 29th ult., with 5,000 men, a numerous train of artillery and plentiful stores of ammunition, encamped within four miles of Vera Cruz and laid siege to the city. The garrison, composed of between 3,000 and 4,000 men, was commanded by Gen. IGLESJAS. Col. VIVALDO, who was in command of one of the principal forts on the Southern side, was detected in a conspiracy to blow up the fort on MIRAMON's approach, and was condemned to four years' imprisonment. Thirty conspirators were banished from the city. The Savannah, Saratoga and Preble were anchored under the walls or San Juan d'Ulloa, and English, Spanish and French vessels were at Sacrificios. Capt. TURNER, of the Saratoga, visited MIRAMON's camp in behalf of the American citizens. On the night of the 7th inst. MIRAMON made an attack upon the city in force, but was repulsed by the Liberals. The latter were confident of their ability to withstand every assault. Alvarado is reported to be in the possession of MIRAMON. The Exequatur of the American Consul at Vera Cruz has been revoked. The action of the American squadron had created great excitement in Vera Cruz.

abstract: It must be evident to every citizen who has the slightest regard for the welfare of this Metropolis, that New-York is in great need of an efficient, well-organized Health Department; and if it be not soon obtained, some wide-spread ...
lead_paragraph: It must be evident to every citizen who has the slightest regard for the welfare of this Metropolis, that New-York is in great need of an efficient, well-organized Health Department; and if it be not soon obtained, some wide-spread and devastating epidemic, spontaneously generated from the accumulated causes of disease in our midst, will, sooner or later, force such an organization upon our authorities whether they will or no. As long as Death works his ravages among the poor, no hand but that of pure and disinterested benevolence will be raised to stay the progress of the destroyer. But the time must soon come (if it has not indeed already come, though unawares) when the diseases that riot daily in the tenement-house, like hot-house plants in genial soil, must contaminate the air of the mansion but a block away, and its occupants will fall sick of pestilential diseases which they never knew before.

abstract: Nothing can be more natural than that a French Theatre should be established at New-York. We are more given to the study of the French language than the people of any other great city in the world, outside of France; we drift at once to Paris whenever we cross the Atlantic, as naturally as hadji to Mecca, or politicians to Washington. Our annual importations of French silks, French wines, French gloves, French boots, French preserves, French goods and chattels generally, is so enormous that even the Tribune, usually so tolerant of the failings of its fellow-creatures, cannot forbear an annual outcry over our reckless national extravagance. Nay, the Tribune itself condescends to France in the matter of social philosophy, and abandons its theory of protection to native industry in favor of the foreign nonsense of FOURIER and LOUIS BLANC. In theatrical matters especially we have long kept up an immense commerce with France. Has not all the Wallack-going world been weeping and wailing here for the last two months over the romantic sorrows of a "poor young man" from France, although it is unquestionable that we have no lack of "poor young men" in New-York, and morally probable that they must, all of them, between their washerwomen's bills and their blighted affections, have their own sorrows more or less romantic? Why should we not establish, then, a direct intercourse between the French Theatre and ourselves, and take the claret of the French drama in its original purity instead of dashing it with the beer of the British stage? This is a question which has been often asked, and which M. FREDERIC MANNSTEIN Seems at last in a fair way to answer for us.

abstract: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday held an inquest on the body of CATHARINE MCGUIRE, a domestic in the family of Mr. EDWARD A. SMITH, in Fifty-eight-street, near Second-avenue. A post-mortem examination of the body resulted in the discovery of four ounces of laudanum in her stomach, and the jury found a verdict of death by suicide. The girl was 35 years of age, and it is supposed that continued ill-health impelled her to the act....AUGUST LEVERMANN. whom JOHN EAGAN, bar-tender in the porter-house of JAMES EAGAN, corner of First-street and Second-avenue, beat brutally on Saturday night, died at the Hospital yesterday morning. The post-mortem examination showed that a fracture of the skull four and a half inches in length was the immediate cause of death. The jury rendered a verdict holding EAGAN responsible for the homicide, and he was committed to answer.

abstract: The Eleventh Annual Report of the Board of Ten Governors, was yesterday finished, and dispatched to Albany. It contains many important particulars regarding the present Alms House system, and is very lengthy.
lead_paragraph: The Eleventh Annual Report of the Board of Ten Governors, was yesterday finished, and dispatched to Albany. It contains many important particulars regarding the present Alms House system, and is very lengthy. Favorable comment is made upon the improved condition of the various institutions, and their management. The total number under the care of the Board on the last Saturday of 1859 was 7,982, a larger number than at any one previous time. The expenditures for the support of the institutions were $592,835 07, but the cost of new buildings, improvements and additions to old ones, ran the total up to $793,524 87. Among the expenses are the following: Salaries, $151,118 28; flour, $66,842 16; milk, $16,746 72; coal, $59,350 59; new buildings, $111,972 12; donations to out-door poor, $28,646 04; colored paupers. $12,457 74; refreshments, $10,701 90. There were admitted to the Almshouse 3,731, of whom but 713 were natives. There were 2,438 natives of Ireland, the balance being from other foreign countries. In 1858 there were 159 more admissions to the Almshouse than in 1859. Following is a comparative statement of admissions during the last 10 years:

abstract: -- An order was passed in both branches of the Legislature, on Saturday last, demanding of the Mechanics' Bank, Portland, the payment to the State by Wednesday noon, of $1,100, which is the amount of a check given by Mr. PECK upon the Mechanics' Bank, after the defalcation had been made public, and after the officers of the Bank had been requested to honor no more of his drafts. They had previously discounted a note for Mr. PECK, which was protested, and the check was given to the officers in part payment of the note, although they were aware, when they secured the check, that Mr. PECK was a defaulter. As the Bank exists by a charter from the State, it is exceedingly probable that the money will be promptly forthcoming. Mr. PECK was arrested by the Sheriff of Kennebec, on Saturday, on indictment, and lodged in the Augusta jail. The penalty provided by law for Mr. PECK's defalcation is only a pecuniary one in damages -- to the amount of the defalcation -- and the arrest is made in order to force a disclosure.

abstract: The telegraph informs us that Gov. STEWART, of Missouri, has vetoed the bill passed by the Legislature, expelling free negroes from the State under penalty of being reduced to slavery. He has partially saved his State from a deep and a lasting disgrace.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph informs us that Gov. STEWART, of Missouri, has vetoed the bill passed by the Legislature, expelling free negroes from the State under penalty of being reduced to slavery. He has partially saved his State from a deep and a lasting disgrace. Nothing has ever told so sad a tale of the relapse of the Slave States towards barbarism, -- of their utter destitution of a high-toned sense of justice and of honor, -- as the measures which have been brought forward in their Legislatures, with the support of a portion of their people, for treading down under the heel of remorseless power the small remnants of right left to this unhappy race. No merely savage community would ever dream of such atrocious injustice. The untutored cruelty of the human heart is incapable of acts so shocking to every instinct of nature. Nothing but an inverted Christianity, -- a civilization turned backward upon itself, -- a cruelty born of logic and trained to a hardy defiance of conscience and of all human feeling, could ever prompt a community to so gross a violation of the plainest principles of justice and of common right.

abstract: INCIDENTS OF CITY LIFE.--A bed in the house of Mr. CARROLL, NO. 296 Stanton-street, caught fire on Saturday night in consequenee of a lamp having been placed near it, and three children who were asleep there were rescued by Officer SUTTON of the Eleventh ...
lead_paragraph: INCIDENTS OF CITY LIFE.--A bed in the house of Mr. CARROLL, NO. 296 Stanton-street, caught fire on Saturday night in consequenee of a lamp having been placed near it, and three children who were asleep there were rescued by Officer SUTTON of the Eleventh Precinct....MARY SMITH, cook on the canal boat Plymouth, lying at Pier No. 5, East River, was shockingly misused in a Water-street saloon, on Sunday night. Officer LOGAN found her afterwards lying insensible in Chatham-street and took her to the Hospital, where she lies in a critical condition....CORNELIUS COLLINS, while driving a light wagon through the New Bowery, ran his vehicle over CHARLES DILLO, a boy three years of age, and injured him severely. Officer TOOLE, of the Fourth Precinct, arrested COLLINS on a charge of reckless driving....JOHN KAYLOR, of No. 163 Prince-street, for some unknown cause, attempted to commit suicide on Sunday night by swallowing a large quantity of laudanum. Dr. KENNEDY administered an antidote which will probably save the life of the attempted suicide.....ISAAC SELOVER, the keeper of an alleged ticket swindling shop in Cedar-street, was arrested yesterday, charged with having defrauded Messrs. JOST SCHOULER, DAVID LANDIS and JACOB LEVZENGER, who had recently arrived in this City from Ohio, of $150, by giving them steerage passage tickets for California instead of first-class tickets, for which they had paid. Justice KELLY held the prisoner in $1,000..... JAMES MCAVOY, a United States soldier, was taken from his quarters at Governor's Island yesterday by Officer BURDETT, of the Harbor Police, and removed to Richmond County, where he was charged with assaulting in a brutal manner a Mrs. WALTRASS, and also with inciting a riot....THOS. SCANLON, a First Ward rowdy, was arrested last evening for picking the pockets of a man named JAMES CREIGHTON, who had become intoxicated and fallen asleep on the Battery.

abstract: ITEMS.--The body of a child was found yesterday at the door of No. 113 Clinton-street....Dr. SAMUEL BOYD, late Health Officer, was buried yesterday in the Cemetery of the Evergreens.
lead_paragraph: ITEMS.--The body of a child was found yesterday at the door of No. 113 Clinton-street....Dr. SAMUEL BOYD, late Health Officer, was buried yesterday in the Cemetery of the Evergreens. Members of the Board of Aldermen, Kings County Medical Society, Health Wardens and numerous citizens attended the funeral....The house of THOMAS SEWALL, corner of Degraw-street and Cheever-place, was robbed, Sunday night, of property valued at about $100....JOHN WILLIAMS, laborer, fell from the third story of his house, corner of Hamilton-avenue and Henry-street, to the sidewalk, yesterday, and broke one of his arms. He was taken to the Long Island College Hospital....A boy named WM. E. HICKLEY, was fatally injured at the corner of South First and Seventh streets, yesterday, by a heavy counter falling upon him, and died soon after; he was carried home....The body of an infant was found in a cigar-box on Schenectady-avenue, yesterday, by the Police....The funeral of DAVID A. BOKEE took place yesterday, at 4 o'clock P.M., from his late residence, No. 143 Hicks street....The body of an unknown man was found in the water off Conover-street, South Brooklyn, last evening. The Coroner was notified....Rev. CHARLES S. ROBINSON will be installed as Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church this evening....Two men have been arrested, by the Police in the East District, for attempting to kill JOHN WALTER, whom the Police found, late Sunday night, lying on the side-walk in Cook-street, near Graham-avenue, bleeding and insensible. The parties accused will be examined to-day....HENRY POOLE had one of his fingers bitten off by a horse, yesterday, in the Eastern District. He was trying to back the animal at the time.

abstract: House-owners and tax-payers who venerate Webster or Walker will possibly be surprised at hearing announced, by authority, a new definition for the word "street."
lead_paragraph: House-owners and tax-payers who venerate Webster or Walker will possibly be surprised at hearing announced, by authority, a new definition for the word "street." This is specially important to tax-payers, as, unless they have fully comprehended the authoritative definition of the word, they may find their property sold over their heads, far some unheard of improvement. The streets of New-York, as they used to be, comprised the space between opposite houses, but the sapient representatives of the million of residents in New-York have found a distinction without a difference. By virtue of State laws and ordinances, all of recent date, the streets of New-York have been subdivided into three departments. To the Croton Aqueduct Board is intrusted the care of paving, repairing or repaving them; to the Street Department is allotted the work of laying curb and gutter stones and repairing the same, also of grading; and to the City Inspector is given the awful responsibility of cleaning them. Then -- thanks to the Circumlocution system adopted by our City Fathers -- if a gentleman or a neighborhood require a street to be paved, even at their own expense, they have to consult the heads of these departments, each of which must act independently of the other. If the Croton Board award a contract for paving a street, it can only be done with the assent of the Street Commissioner, who regulates the curbing and guttering, and so on, ad infinitum. The acting President of the Croton Board, desirous of knowing exactly the extent of his powers and duties with reference to the streets, addressed a letter a few days since to the Counsel to the Corporation on the subject. The essential portion of his reply is appended:
