abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--In "the pursuit of the highest order of dramatic art"--to quote from Mr. STUART'S programme--the management of this establishment arrived last night at a dramatic version of LONGFEL LOW'S charming "Evangeline." The poem itself possesses a sufficient number of provocations to theatrical industry.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN.--In "the pursuit of the highest order of dramatic art"--to quote from Mr. STUART'S programme--the management of this establishment arrived last night at a dramatic version of LONGFEL LOW'S charming "Evangeline." The poem itself possesses a sufficient number of provocations to theatrical industry. It is not all remarkable, therefore, that the right man -- or rather woman -- has been found to do the proper offices for it. Mrs. BATEMAN, who undertakes the task, has discharged it with more than common ability. She has succeeded, undoubtedly, in framing an actable play. The means by which this has been effected are neither startling nor new, being derived mainly from a correct knowledge of the machinery of the dramatic art, rather than fresh invention or piquant characterization. Mr. LONGFELLOW's major poems are perhaps more susceptible of dramatic treatment than those of almost any other writer. The distinguished author of "Evangeline" is never neglectful of scenic opportunities, of effective contrasts of individualities, of well-marked domestic groupings -- elements in themselves of dramatic success. The real difficulty in the way of a perfect transcription of his poems is to be found in the sustained narrative tone that pervades them, and to interrupt which involves an operation of much delicacy and danger. Although Mrs. BATEMAN has performed this operation with the commonest of instruments, she has in many respects been most fortunate and happy in the result.

abstract: The trial of SHEEHAN, for the murder of DECKER, of Hudson, at DAN RICE's Show, at Coxsackie, last Summer, was commenced on Thursday, at Catskill, Greene County, and ended on Friday night. The Jury brought in a verdict of "Manslaughter in the third degree." WILKINSON, who was in the affray, plead guilty to manslaughter in the third degree. Both prisoners were sentenced, by Judge HOGEROOM, to three years and six months' imprisonment at Sing Sing. RIVERS, who had been indicted on the same charge, was discharged, no evidence appearing against him. On the same day, a notorious colored thief, canvicted of larceny, was sentenced to Sing Sing for the term of two years and six month.

abstract: -- The Assembly is busy debating the propriety of abolishing capital punishment. It will be time enough for us to argue the general question when they begin to act; but, in the mean time, we cannot help impressing upon them the necessity of preserving, in any substitute for capital punishment, that certainty of its execution which is the only excellence which everybody acknowledges capital punishment to possess. Imprisonment for life would be a farce if the pardoning power were, as at present, to be every two years placed in the hands of a new man. The difficulty of finding something to take its place is not a reason for maintaining a punishment in itself bad, but it is a subject which calls for mature consideration before making any change.
lead_paragraph: -- The Assembly is busy debating the propriety of abolishing capital punishment. abstract: The simple statement of the fact that there are over one hundred thousand young men, between the ages of fifteen and forty, in the City of New-York, is of itself sufficient to attract the attention and command the consideration of every thoughtful, intelligent, and Christian mind.
lead_paragraph: The simple statement of the fact that there are over one hundred thousand young men, between the ages of fifteen and forty, in the City of New-York, is of itself sufficient to attract the attention and command the consideration of every thoughtful, intelligent, and Christian mind. Even the most superficial observer of the formation of society must be aware of the great influence such a large body must exert in the tide of human affairs; but to the Philanthropist and Christian, the questions -- Of what elements is this class composed? What is the social, mental, and spiritual condition of this great mass of human beings? -- are of the deepest interest. To any person engaged in active life and mingling in the business of this great Metropolis, these questions when proposed receive a quick, and oftentimes a painful answer. The innumerable cases of hopeless ruin and degradation of some of our most promising young men, and the many reports and statistics of the police records, leave no room for conjecture as to the condition and prospects of a great number of the class of whom we speak, and also prove most clearly the imminent dangers to which all young men are exposed.

lead_paragraph: An incidental debate took place in the Prussian Chamber of Representatives, on the 1st inst. A petition was submitted to the Chamber by 383 inhabitants of Breslau, in favor of the national and constitutional interests of Italy. In its report, the Committee expressed its sympathies for the national cause of Italy; it did not conceal the displeasure that would be felt in Prussia if any intervention took place, but it proposed to pass to the order of the day, convinced that the Government would share its opinion, which is that of the immense majority of the Pross[???]an people it, moreover, stated, in support of its conclusions, that no petition in a contrary sense had been presented to the Chamber. The following discussion ensued:

abstract: the Constitution, he intended to commit perjury. [Loud applause and lau[???]er.] I am not exaggerating. If I had stood here to-night, and affirmed in your presence that the great statesman of the Empire State would have obeyed that clause you would have flashed back upon me the epithet -- Standerer!" I am obliged to believe, judging by the record of his life, by the testimony of his fellow-citizens, that that very Constitution which he has sworn scores of times to support -- that very Constitution which he says comes from hands almost divine -- that when he swore to support it, he intended to commit perjury. Is that a Union to which you can welcome men when they get to be 21 years old? It seems to me not. I would like to vote. I would like to add my quota to the civil influence of my country directly. Show me how I can without jeopardizing my self-respect -- without swearing an oath which you know I would not and ought not to mean to keep -- and I will vote for WM. H. SEWARD for President to-morrow. And yet I would rather see a Democratic President. [Loud laughter ]. And I will tell you why. If there is a Republican President elected in 1860. You will all be looking to the Administration. You will all be waiting to see what law can do -- what L[???]ty fettered can do against Slavery unb[???]. Agitation will be lulled. Everything like free and unuttered action will cease. We shall wait. But let DOUGLAS or any other Democrat be elected, and every man in the Free States will arm himself for the snuggle with the Slave power. Insurrection will break out upon the mountains -- an insurrection of thought in the pulpits -- and we shall make greater Anti-Slavery progress in four years than we should do in forty years under such a programme as under WM H. SEWARD's speech of the last month. Well, again, and I hasten to my conclusion. There is another law of God's kingdom, and it is this: Slavery is an expensive and wasteful system. It cannot be love. God fixed it that justice should be expediency, and that villany should be bankruptcy. He fixed that when he settled the laws of his kingdom. Therefore, the further a man attempts to rob his brother man, in the first place, that brother man resists -- the rights of insurrection. Mark you, I am not asking the slave to rise. I am not urging him to rise. I only say take off your foot. I only take off your foot, and leave the Anglo-Saxon and the African to lay out their own institutions by the vigor of their own manhood. But, in addition to that, there is a pecuniary motive. South Carolina, for instance, stands in the keen competition of the nineteenth century. What is that? All of us are trying to make our living. We get up early, and lie down late. We educate our braine to the utmost. We harness the steam, and send the lightning upon our errands. We do everything. The little child, when he first begins to patter, goes to do something; and the man bending under eighty years contributes his mite. We all work. New-York works, from the Hudson back to the falls; and when she has eaten and clothed herself, about how much does she lay up? Perhaps four per cent. upon her capital. Now, South Carolina has half idle by aristocratic taste and finish. The other half is in chains -- does not work from motive, but from compulsion. Of course the work is performed to disadvantage. The consequence is that there is not more than one man in four in South Carolina working to-day. The other three-fourths live upon it -- three men living upon the work of one's unskilled labor. How much do you suppose they lay up? As the Irishman said, "They lay up a loss" [Laughter.] Now suppose, as they threaten, that they should go out of the Union? Suppose to-morrow their purpose was carried out? As LYDIA MARIA CHILDS, you have heard of the town poor separating from the town That is South Carolina's proposition. Suppose they went out? This is a perfectly simple question. There is no mystery about it. They have got to support a general, a president, good police, a navy and an army. They must have the luxuries of government. A domestic government is infinitely more expensive than a despotic one. Russia does not cost halt as much as the Republic of North America. They must have a republican government, which is a very expensive luxury. In order to do that, they must have taxes. What have they to rest upon but labor? Now, if that labor is capable of bearing taxes, it must be intelligent labor. If it is unskilled, and cannot send one pound to Liverpool for less than 18 or 20 cents, what can be done? To day a dispute is going on in Virginia. To make labor worth anything, you must educate the man. "Educate," says a Southerner, -- "educate that slave, and my throat is not safe." He is right. You might as well heat a locomotive red-hot, jump upon the top of it, and ride in to a powder magazine, and you would be a prudent man compared with the slaveowner who educates his slave. Yet, South Carolina must do it before she can support the Republican system of the Nineteenth Century. Leave her to the dissolution of the Union, -- to the law of God's political economy. My good friend, the slaver does not ask your rifle. Take your awful Yankee proportions, Republican or Democrat, out of the light. That is all he asks. The light and heat of God's laws and justice will come down and will melt his chains without your assistance. Tear that parchment to pieces that claims -- [Cheers and hisses; the former predominating.] I have a great deal more patriotism than you have -- a good deal. Just look at it. I believe that Washington, Hancock, John Jay, Wyeth, Randolph; -- I believe that when they sat down and made that instrument they intended what they say they intended -- Liberty! [Immense cheering I believe that if you could raise them to-day from their graves, and show them the speech of WILLIAM H. SEWARD, they would say, "Children, for God's sake, believe that we did not mean it. Tear our mistaken parchment to pieces, and do us the justice to believe that if we could have seen our institution! prostituted to so much injustice, we could have wished them unmade or annihilated." [Applause.] Do I not do more to call to the memory of '76 than you do? I believe them -- you think them hypocrites! [Applause.] I say tear that parchment to tatters in honor of WASHINGTON! [Low hisses superseded by prolonged applause] Did you ever hear EDWARD EVERETT ring out with those clarioa tones of his that favorite phrase in describing "WASHINGTON that immortal rebel?" Well, JOHN BROWN, of Harper's Ferry, was just the same. [Hisses and applause.] You see we do not apply our logic rigidly to the line. You cannot bear justice and logic. But let me go on with what I have to say -- I want to finish my argument -- I am talking too long. [Cries of "Go on."] I was speaking of the influence of the Union. Why do I want to separate you from New-Orleans? For the reason, I want to put you, in relation to New-Orleans, just where Liverpool stands to-night. See the difference. The New-York pulpit, to-night, is one end of the magnetic telegraph -- the New-Orleans slave market is the other. That is not true of Liverpool. If I could separate New-York, politically, from New-Orleans, WM. H. SEWARD would care no more for the opinion of South Carolina than he does for PALMERSTON. The New-York Tribune would think as little of TOOMBS or of KEITT as it does of the thunders of the London Times. If you enter the villages of New-England, it is melancholy but it is true, that the pulpit is a vassal of wealth. I rode as I came to you along the railways of Connecticut, and by my side sat a Clergyman who, in the innocent frankness of his heart said to me, "Mr. SEWARD's speech is an awful disappointment. I wish he could have spoken bolder. If the ministers would only speak out, but then you know that our rich men won't let us." And I looked into his eyes and thought, are you the representative of the We should have the same language, the same religion, the same advantages, the same literature, the same commerce. But we should have comparative independence, in that our commerce would not poison every thing. To-day go into a factory village of New-England. What is the pulpit? It is only an appendix to the factory. It is only the rich man's kitchen. He buys the minister, and turns him out when he does not preach to suit him. Ladies and gentlemen, I do not mean any disparagement. I trace my lineage to Plymouth through an almost unbroken line of clergymen. I know the services the pulpit has rencered in New-England, and I know this, that the best thing my mother gave me was free lips, and I mean to use them. [Applause] A prostrate race lifts up its hands to us and says, "White men, free men, loaded with gifts, dowered with thought, give us at least the truth; it is the only weapon that is left us," and I mean, so far as I am concerned, that he shall have it. Gospel of the New Testament, and do you act with that unconcerned and verdant frankness, and confess that your soul lies in your pocket?" I honored him for his frankness -- I could not blame him harshly, and yet I knew he spoke the truth. I do not know, ladies and gentlemen, that it can be altered. I really do not. There is something in the organization of Democratic institutions that seems to render it inevitable that wealth will have a tremendous power, and wealth is chained to the wheel of the steam power. Your mercantile wealth -- your manufacturing wealth -- is but the vassal of an overgrown aristocracy, and beside it stands the moral representative of New-England, the pulpit, the second vassal of a vassal, the slave of a slave. I would separate New-York. That is true of Manchester and Lancashire; it is not true of Liverpool. If I could break the political bonds which bind you, New-York, like a fountain relieved from her mountain load, would look up and be a decent city. [Laughter and applause.] Free speech would not be bullied out of countenance. The pul[???] its would not be filled by dumb dogs at cannot bark. [Applause.] You would not be able to count on your ten fingers the only firms who keep their goods for sale, and not their principles. No; you would see American merchants filling the same spot that the Englishman does. Not independence. I know the weight that New-Orleans and Savannah have, even over the manufacturer. But I would break one of the bonds. Now see what I should gain. Let me count up what we should gain by the breaking of the Union. South Carolina would look at her slaves, saying: "If they choose to rise I have not the means of resistance." That is what Mexico said. That is what, the South American Republic said, and they freed them from fear. She would look into the eyes of her unskilled labor and say, "That way lies bankruptcy. If I want a broad government I have got to educate them."
lead_paragraph: the Constitution, he intended to commit perjury. [Loud applause and lau[???]er.] I am not exaggerating. If I had stood here to-night, and affirmed in your presence that the great statesman of the Empire State would have obeyed that clause you would have flashed back upon me the epithet -- Standerer!" I am obliged to believe, judging by the record of his life, by the testimony of his fellow-citizens, that that very Constitution which he has sworn scores of times to support -- that very Constitution which he says comes from hands almost divine -- that when he swore to support it, he intended to commit perjury. Is that a Union to which you can welcome men when they get to be 21 years old? It seems to me not. I would like to vote. I would like to add my quota to the civil influence of my country directly. Show me how I can without jeopardizing my self-respect -- without swearing an oath which you know I would not and ought not to mean to keep -- and I will vote for WM. H. SEWARD for President to-morrow. And yet I would rather see a Democratic President. [Loud laughter ]. And I will tell you why. If there is a Republican President elected in 1860. You will all be looking to the Administration. You will all be waiting to see what law can do -- what L[???]ty fettered can do against Slavery unb[???]. Agitation will be lulled. Everything like free and unuttered action will cease. We shall wait. But let DOUGLAS or any other Democrat be elected, and every man in the Free States will arm himself for the snuggle with the Slave power. Insurrection will break out upon the mountains -- an insurrection of thought in the pulpits -- and we shall make greater Anti-Slavery progress in four years than we should do in forty years under such a programme as under WM H. SEWARD's speech of the last month. Well, again, and I hasten to my conclusion. There is another law of God's kingdom, and it is this: Slavery is an expensive and wasteful system. It cannot be love. God fixed it that justice should be expediency, and that villany should be bankruptcy. He fixed that when he settled the laws of his kingdom. Therefore, the further a man attempts to rob his brother man, in the first place, that brother man resists -- the rights of insurrection. Mark you, I am not asking the slave to rise. I am not urging him to rise. I only say take off your foot. I only take off your foot, and leave the Anglo-Saxon and the African to lay out their own institutions by the vigor of their own manhood. But, in addition to that, there is a pecuniary motive. South Carolina, for instance, stands in the keen competition of the nineteenth century. What is that? All of us are trying to make our living. We get up early, and lie down late. We educate our braine to the utmost. We harness the steam, and send the lightning upon our errands. We do everything. The little child, when he first begins to patter, goes to do something; and the man bending under eighty years contributes his mite. We all work. New-York works, from the Hudson back to the falls; and when she has eaten and clothed herself, about how much does she lay up? Perhaps four per cent. upon her capital. Now, South Carolina has half idle by aristocratic taste and finish. The other half is in chains -- does not work from motive, but from compulsion. Of course the work is performed to disadvantage. The consequence is that there is not more than one man in four in South Carolina working to-day. The other three-fourths live upon it -- three men living upon the work of one's unskilled labor. How much do you suppose they lay up? As the Irishman said, "They lay up a loss" [Laughter.] Now suppose, as they threaten, that they should go out of the Union? Suppose to-morrow their purpose was carried out? As LYDIA MARIA CHILDS, you have heard of the town poor separating from the town That is South Carolina's proposition. Suppose they went out? This is a perfectly simple question. There is no mystery about it. They have got to support a general, a president, good police, a navy and an army. They must have the luxuries of government. A domestic government is infinitely more expensive than a despotic one. Russia does not cost halt as much as the Republic of North America. They must have a republican government, which is a very expensive luxury. In order to do that, they must have taxes. What have they to rest upon but labor? Now, if that labor is capable of bearing taxes, it must be intelligent labor. If it is unskilled, and cannot send one pound to Liverpool for less than 18 or 20 cents, what can be done? To day a dispute is going on in Virginia. To make labor worth anything, you must educate the man. "Educate," says a Southerner, -- "educate that slave, and my throat is not safe." He is right. You might as well heat a locomotive red-hot, jump upon the top of it, and ride in to a powder magazine, and you would be a prudent man compared with the slaveowner who educates his slave. Yet, South Carolina must do it before she can support the Republican system of the Nineteenth Century. Leave her to the dissolution of the Union, -- to the law of God's political economy. My good friend, the slaver does not ask your rifle. Take your awful Yankee proportions, Republican or Democrat, out of the light. That is all he asks. The light and heat of God's laws and justice will come down and will melt his chains without your assistance. Tear that parchment to pieces that claims -- [Cheers and hisses; the former predominating.] I have a great deal more patriotism than you have -- a good deal. Just look at it. I believe that Washington, Hancock, John Jay, Wyeth, Randolph; -- I believe that when they sat down and made that instrument they intended what they say they intended -- Liberty! [Immense cheering I believe that if you could raise them to-day from their graves, and show them the speech of WILLIAM H. SEWARD, they would say, "Children, for God's sake, believe that we did not mean it. Tear our mistaken parchment to pieces, and do us the justice to believe that if we could have seen our institution! prostituted to so much injustice, we could have wished them unmade or annihilated." [Applause.] Do I not do more to call to the memory of '76 than you do? I believe them -- you think them hypocrites! [Applause.] I say tear that parchment to tatters in honor of WASHINGTON! [Low hisses superseded by prolonged applause] Did you ever hear EDWARD EVERETT ring out with those clarioa tones of his that favorite phrase in describing "WASHINGTON that immortal rebel?" Well, JOHN BROWN, of Harper's Ferry, was just the same. [Hisses and applause.] You see we do not apply our logic rigidly to the line. You cannot bear justice and logic. But let me go on with what I have to say -- I want to finish my argument -- I am talking too long. [Cries of "Go on."] I was speaking of the influence of the Union. Why do I want to separate you from New-Orleans? For the reason, I want to put you, in relation to New-Orleans, just where Liverpool stands to-night. See the difference. The New-York pulpit, to-night, is one end of the magnetic telegraph -- the New-Orleans slave market is the other. That is not true of Liverpool. If I could separate New-York, politically, from New-Orleans, WM. H. SEWARD would care no more for the opinion of South Carolina than he does for PALMERSTON. The New-York Tribune would think as little of TOOMBS or of KEITT as it does of the thunders of the London Times. If you enter the villages of New-England, it is melancholy but it is true, that the pulpit is a vassal of wealth. I rode as I came to you along the railways of Connecticut, and by my side sat a Clergyman who, in the innocent frankness of his heart said to me, "Mr. SEWARD's speech is an awful disappointment. I wish he could have spoken bolder. If the ministers would only speak out, but then you know that our rich men won't let us." And I looked into his eyes and thought, are you the representative of the We should have the same language, the same religion, the same advantages, the same literature, the same commerce. But we should have comparative independence, in that our commerce would not poison every thing. To-day go into a factory village of New-England. What is the pulpit? It is only an appendix to the factory. It is only the rich man's kitchen. He buys the minister, and turns him out when he does not preach to suit him. abstract: DISAGREEMENT OF THE JURY. -- On Thursday and Friday last much excitement was created in Poughkeepsie by the trial of ISHMAEL FREEMAN, on a charge of murdering his wife in that city three or four months since, by administering arsenic to her, in order to obtain possession of her property. The case was tried before Judge EMMETT. It was testified that FREEMAN had acted very strangely in the affair. Mr. CHICHESTER, a druggist, swore that the prisoner came to his store and purchased arsenic, stating that at the time he had a shawl and green goggles on. When arrested, a shawl and goggles answering exactly to the description given of them, were found in the house. He was also recognized by three or four others standing on the stoop of the drug store. He also went round to the neighbors and stated that he thought some person would die, belonging to him, as he had had signs and presentments, stating, at the same time, that his wife was very sick. When his wife died, which was on a Saturday night about 5 o'clock, he stated that he should bury her the next day, as she had died in her full strength, and the body would not keep. The jury considered the case all night Thursday, and could not agree. They were discharged. Ten were for conviction and three for acquittal. It is said that the case will be tried at the next Court at Newburgh.
lead_paragraph: DISAGREEMENT OF THE JURY. -- On Thursday and Friday last much excitement was created in Poughkeepsie by the trial of ISHMAEL FREEMAN, on a charge of murdering his wife in that city three or four months since, by administering arsenic to her, in order to obtain possession of her property. The case was tried before Judge EMMETT. It was testified that FREEMAN had acted very strangely in the affair. Mr. CHICHESTER, a druggist, swore that the prisoner came to his store and purchased arsenic, stating that at the time he had a shawl and green goggles on. When arrested, a shawl and goggles answering exactly to the description given of them, were found in the house. He was also recognized by three or four others standing on the stoop of the drug store. He also went round to the neighbors and stated that he thought some person would die, belonging to him, as he had had signs and presentments, stating, at the same time, that his wife was very sick. When his wife died, which was on a Saturday night about 5 o'clock, he stated that he should bury her the next day, as she had died in her full strength, and the body would not keep. The jury considered the case all night Thursday, and could not agree. They were discharged. Ten were for conviction and three for acquittal. It is said that the case will be tried at the next Court at Newburgh.

abstract: The London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian writes: "The controversy on the Shakesperian an forgeries, with which the name of Mr. J.P. Collier has become painfully and prominently connected and to which I some time ago drew attention, in connection with alleged discoveries of Mr. Collier's among the Alleyne MSS. at Dulwich, rages fiercely among the literary antiquaries. The stilling of its angry waters will not be helped by the peppery article in this week's Athenoeum. At present, it is clear that the authorities of the British Museum have only done their duty in exposing the most impudent and elaborate deception since the days of Ireland; and though it may be matter of regret that this exposure should lay under grave suspicion a scholar so old and respected as Mr. Collier, it cannot be fairly alleged that Mr. Hamilton has strained the facts, or gone out of his way to apply them, for the purpose of giving a direction to these suspicions. While on the subject of literary antiquaries and their doings, I may remind you that some months since I called your readers' attention to the case of the so-called 'Milton MSS.' in the [???]ate Dawson Turner's collection (receipts for payments on accouut of Paradise Lost) which were sold at that antiquary's sale to an American collector for a high price. I then stated what has now, on investigation, been proved correct, that the Dawson Turner's 'receipts' were not the originals, but copies from originals in the possession of the Cu[???]lum family, by whom they were lent to Mr. Turner many years ago, for use in connection with a work on Milton he was then contemplating. These originals were kept by Mr. Turner for a [???]long while, and at last returned to their owners. It is probable that he had facsimiles executed perhaps for the purposes of his contemplated work, but these fac-s[???]nites were certainly never expressly so described by their possessor, and his family seem to have been under the impression that they were the original documents. The money received for them has, now, I believe, been repaid to the purchaser of the copies."

abstract: SECTION 1. The property, both real and personal, which any married woman now owns, as her sole and separate property; that which comes to her by descent, devise, bequest, gift or grant; that which she acquires by her trade, business, labor or services, carried on or performed on her sole or separate account;
lead_paragraph: SECTION 1. The property, both real and personal, which any married woman now owns, as her sole and separate property; that which comes to her by descent, devise, bequest, gift or grant; that which she acquires by her trade, business, labor or services, carried on or performed on her sole or separate account; that which a woman married in this State owns at the time of her marriage, and the rents, issues and proceeds of all such property, shall, notwithstanding her marriage, be and remain her sole and separate property, and may be used, collected and invested by her in her own name, and shall not be subject to the interference or control of her husband, or liable for his debts, except such debts as may have been contracted for the support of herself or her children, by her as his agent.

abstract: The claims of the late Mr. GEORGE WOOD upon the respect and admiration of the Bar, as well as of the public at large, are so very well known and well established, that we shall not be suspected of disputing them if we use the demonstration made on Monday, in the ...
lead_paragraph: The claims of the late Mr. GEORGE WOOD upon the respect and admiration of the Bar, as well as of the public at large, are so very well known and well established, that we shall not be suspected of disputing them if we use the demonstration made on Monday, in the Courts, in honor of his memory, as an occasion for protesting against the absurd and ridiculous profusion with which post-mortem honors are now-a-days distributed. When a lawyer of the standing of Mr. WOOD, or Judge OAKLEY, or Judge DUER, or NICHOLAS HILL, rests from his labors, everybody will acknowledge it to be eminently fit and proper that there should be some demonstration of mourning made in the scene of his labors and triumphs -- that the forensis strepitus, in which he delighted, and in which he shone, should be hushed during at least the "first dark day of nothingness." But all the value of any such honor, all its grace, and all its pathos, lie in its rarity. It is due to great advocates and great judges to reserve it exclusively for their memory, and both great advocates and great judges are few in number. One, or perhaps two, die in a lustrum to whom such a tribute is due, whose life and attainments have been such that the Courts of a great city may fittingly, becomingly and sensibly dismiss suitors from their bar, lay down the scales of justice, leave complaints unheard, wrongs unredresssed, and property in peril, as a solemn tribute to the memory of great talents, great attainments and high character, and a solemn recognition of the vanity of all worldly honors.

abstract: Our dispatches, this morning, add a little to our information concerning the participation of our Navy in the hostilities off Vera Cruz. It seems that the vessels captured and brought into New-Orleans were those which had come from Havana to aid MIRAMON in his contest against the Government forces besieged in Vera Cruz. On being hailed, they refused to show their colors, which subjected them, in theory at least, to the suspicion of being pirates, and rendered their capture justifiable. It would be premature to pronounce decisively upon the character of this bold and summary act, until we have fuller and more reliable reports of the circumstances by which it was attended.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches, this morning, add a little to our information concerning the participation of our Navy in the hostilities off Vera Cruz. abstract: The Paris Constitutionnel publishes an article on "French policy in Italy," signed "A. GRANDGUILLOT." It commences by stating that the speech delivered by the Emperor at the opening of the Legislative session, and the late dispatches of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, leave no uncertainty as to the future policy of the French Government in Italy.
lead_paragraph: The Paris Constitutionnel publishes an article on "French policy in Italy," signed "A. GRANDGUILLOT." It commences by stating that the speech delivered by the Emperor at the opening of the Legislative session, and the late dispatches of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, leave no uncertainty as to the future policy of the French Government in Italy. That policy, according to M. GRANDGUILLOT, has passed trough the various oscillations of the last twelve months with an unity and perseverance, the result of a decided will. He adds that it is sufficient to compare the august words pronounced at the origin of the question of which public opinion is expecting the conclusion, to be convinced that at present, after the war, the idea which presides at the negotiations for peace is in accord with the principles and the interests for the satisfaction of which the French army crossed the Alps. After this exordium the writer asks, why did France enter into a contest with Austria? He answers his own questions as follows:

abstract: The trial of Augustus Ranney, the Broadway book agent, charged with obtaining money under false pretences, was placed on the calendar for yesterday, but owing to the absence of his counsel, Jas. T. Brady, Esq., who was employed in another Court, was postponed till Friday.

abstract: an arrangement of man. It is a machinery that our fathers set up. It may be valuable machinery to a certain extent. I do not deny it. I do not stand up to cr[???]cie it. All I have to say is that up to the present moment it has neither secured liberty nor justice. It has neither advanced national character nor the character of our great men. CARLYLE says, "The great test of Governments is to educate men." Certainly, DANIEL WEBSTER said that with still greater epigramatic force, in savings "The merit of the Colonels was that they produced WASHINGTON." The fault of the Union is that it produced WEBSTER! [Hisses and applause.] Well, it is a sad record. God gave us the heaviest brain that he loaned this generation. From his New-Hampshire mother he took as much vigor of milk as most other men have. He promised to have run a race of distinguished and useful statesmanship, imbibing from the New-England and atmosphere the broadest and most generous principles of liberty. You sent him to the maelstrom of a union, potent enough to swallow up virtue stronger than his. You added him to the list of those that marked the partway of the Union -- the wreaks of good reputations -- the skeletons of statesmen who have betrayed their age. [S[???]sation.] It is no matter of rejoicing. One thing that I regret the Union so vastly is, that it makes the saddest record of the statesmanship of our generation to the last. The Union? Allow it all its merits, the question is, is there not something more valuable? To-day our best statesmen -- our foremost -- he is obliged to say by the necessities of his position, for instance, that JOHN BROWN was a criminal and was justly hung. Lay that record by the side of Mr. SEWARD's last speeches. It does not do here. What hope have you for the future? It is in the struggle of public opinion. How can it be created solely by preaching of rigid right and wrong? How can I create public opinion adequate to put down that Slave power? Only by laying down the most absolute principles of right -- only by ignoring color -- only by asserting that Slavery is a sin, and, if it is a sin, what is all legislation that endeavors to cover it? What says a million of people combined with GEORGE WASHINGTON in front of them, and marching to victory and to fame? The world says right! Glorious! Four millions of people combining under "bondage, compared with which one moment is heavier than ages such as our fathers rose to resist, put JOHN BROWN in front of them. He is a criminal not justly hung! Out of that discussion can you get virtue that will put down such a Slave Power as I have described to you? Never. Now, all I ask is, that each man shall make up his mind to this, that the slave has a right to his liberty. That is justice. That is right. If you can fit it in the Constitution, God grant you may save the Constitution to fit it. Dr. DAY told me two days ago, that he saw brought into his Missouri prison kidnapped from Kansas Territory a young black man 22 years old, his hands manacled together. He said I am a freeman -- my free papers are in my pocket. The United States officer who brought him in put his felon hand into that pocket, took out those papers, tore them to pieces, and flung them into the fire. The next morning those hands went down melted in the slave population for ever. No remedy -- no redress. Is it a single instance? I have seen the Chief Justice of Massachusetts sitting on the bench of the Supreme Court, with a fugitive slave in front of him, who had proved twice his right to liberty that any of us have. He was born free as, well as we; and he had added a second title by taking his life into his own hand, and by vindicating his worth for Freedom by flying a thousand miles, through all the perils of life and death, to the streets of Boston Which ought to have sheltered him. He looked into the face of the Justice of Massachusetts and said, Have you any refuge for me? And with a voice broken by emotion the representative of the law of Massachusetts said, "It is a hard case; I cannot vindicate it -- it is right, but I must announce the law." If that is the Government that you are willing to have your children brought up to live under, -- if the pulpits of thirty States can announce that as a thing almost sacred, -- it the statesmen have no other name for it but swine, although they cannot vindicate it as right, but only announce the law, -- then, I say, "side with the black man, and record traitor against my name -- side me with the rebel who has no purpose in life but to tear down that government." I do it in the name of all these 200 years of liberty which our father-thought they were to inaugurate. I do it for the future with the eyes of the race fixed upon us -- the normal school of self-government -- the last hope of humanity -- the great magnificent experiment of how 30,000,000 of people can shape their civil institutions. Mr. SEWARD closes his speech with a recommendation for every man to cultivate a respect for the Union. It you will allow me to close mine it will be impressed upon your own hearts and teach your children to love justice, to respect liberty, to claim free life, to let no commerce, however smiling, bribe them, to let no sacredness of parchment gag their lips, bu to swear on the altar which Christianity holds to every man the oath that the slave whom our fathers forgot, against whom they pledged their physical force -- sixty years of bondage that our fathers fastened upon them -- loss or no loss -- law or no law -- Constitution or no Constitution -- so far as in us lies, we will break those pillars and lift that race to a quality with ourselves. And may God help you to keep the oath. [Applause.]

abstract: -- We published yesterday morning Mayor WOOD's veto of a resolution adopted by the Board of Supervisors, to insert $150,000 in the Tax levy, for the erection of a building to accommodate the County Courts. It is not questioned that such accommodations are imperatively required; the only reason assigned by the Mayor for his veto is that a bill is pending in the Legislature for the erection of a new City Hall, at a cost of not less than $3,000,000.
lead_paragraph: -- We published yesterday morning Mayor WOOD's veto of a resolution adopted by the Board of Supervisors, to insert $150,000 in the Tax levy, for the erection of a building to accommodate the County Courts. It is not questioned that such accommodations are imperatively required; the only reason assigned by the Mayor for his veto is that a bill is pending in the Legislature for the erection of a new City Hall, at a cost of not less than $3,000,000.

abstract: POLITICAL. -- The Republican Assembly Conventions, to elect delegates to the State Convention, were held last evening, with the following result: First District. -- Delegates -- John G. Bergen, Charles A. Goddard; Alternates -- George W. Stillwell, Abraham Messerole. Second District. -- Delegates -- Lucien Birdseye, Charles Parker; Alternates -- John Cashow, Elias Hastings. Third District -- Delegates -- T. G Shearman, D.B. Hasbrouck; Alternates -- Ebenezer Rich, A.S. Wheeler. Fourth District. -- Delegates -- Thomas H. Rodman, William L. Rogers; Alternates -- George F.H. Youngs, John E. Cammeyer. Seventh District -- Adjourned to Saturday evening, without selecting delegates. The Republicans in the First Ward have made the following nominations: For Supervisor -- Luther Eanes. For Assessor -- George N. Mead. In the Tenth Ward, the Republicans have nominated: For Alderman -- C.J. Shepard. For Supervisor -- Wm. M. Thomas. In the Fourth Ward: For Alderman -- Peter G. Taylor. For Supervisor -- Samuel Booth. The second Primary meetings of the Democrats were held in the different Wards last evening.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic Democratic mass meeting was held in this town this evening. At an early hour the streets were thronged with the farmers from the neighboring towns, and long before the hour appointed for the meeting, the large hall which will seat over 2,000 persons was filled to overflowing.
lead_paragraph: NORWALK, Conn., Tuesday, March 20.

abstract: The Navy Department has received information that Gen. MIRAMON commenced the siege of Vera Cruz on the 5th inst., and that on the 6th Gen. lead_paragraph: The Navy Department has received information that Gen. MIRAMON commenced the siege of Vera Cruz on the 5th inst., and that on the 6th Gen. MABIN appeared before the city with two steamers, and, not showing his colors, Com. TURNER, U.S.N., of the Saratoga, with detachments from the Savannah and Preble, proceeded in the steamers Indianola and Wave to the anchorage of the steamers off Anton Lizardo, to ascertain their character: On approaching them one was seen moving off, and a shot was fired ahead to bring her to, and the Indianola sent to overhaul her.

abstract: A fire broke out in the crockery-store of J. MORTON, No. 233 Greenwich-street, about 8 o'clock last evening, and extended to the adjoining crockery-store of T. MORRISETT. A man named JOHN LARASUELL was seriously burned in endeavoring to extinguish the flames. Mr. MORTON's loss is about $5,000, and is covered by insurance; that of Mr. MORRISETT was inconsiderable. It is supposed that the fire was the work of an incendiary, and that another, which nearly consumed a stable occupied by OWEN BAYLEY, in the rear of No. 268 East Thirteenth-street, at 11 1/2 P.M., had a similar origin.

abstract: The Athenaeum was crowded to its utmost capacity last evening, on the occasion of WENDELL PHILLIPS' lecture, by an attentive and enthusiastic audience, notwithstanding the fact that a mob had been threatened, and that apprehending an attack, two churches had closed their doors to Mr. PHILLIPS.
lead_paragraph: The Athenaeum was crowded to its utmost capacity last evening, on the occasion of WENDELL PHILLIPS' lecture, by an attentive and enthusiastic audience, notwithstanding the fact that a mob had been threatened, and that apprehending an attack, two churches had closed their doors to Mr. PHILLIPS. No attempt was made to create a disturbance. Had there been a demonstration, however, it would have been promptly and effectually met by an efficient body of Police, under Deputy-Superintendent FOULKE, who had been detailed for the occasion, at the suggestion of the Superintendent of the Athenaeum, Mr. B.R. TAYLOR.
headline: {'main': 'WENDELL PHILLIPS IN BROOKLYN.; A Plea for the Dissolution of the Union. abstract: Two day's later news from Europe arrived with the Fulton at this port yesterday morning. The steamer left Havre on the 6th inst., and Southampton on the 7th. The Times has a comple list of the passengers and crew of the ill-fated Hungarian,--205 all told, not one of whom, so far as is yet ascertained, survived.
lead_paragraph: Two day's later news from Europe arrived with the Fulton at this port yesterday morning. The steamer left Havre on the 6th inst., and Southampton on the 7th. The Times has a comple list of the passengers and crew of the ill-fated Hungarian,--205 all told, not one of whom, so far as is yet ascertained, survived. There was another interesting debate in the English House of Commons on the 5th inst., with regard to the annexation of Savoy to France. The discussion was a warm one, and accusations and invectives against the Emperor of the French were indulged in freely. Lord J. RUSSELL deprecated such irritating remarks as had been offered, which were calculated to bring about a rupture with a neighboring friendly country. The Moniteur announces that the Minister of the United States at Paris had presented his lettres de credance. The Times' Paris correspondent gives wings to a rumor that the soldiers are to rejoin their regiments as soon as possible. The Cardinals and Prelates, who are members of the Senate, have presented to the House petitions asking for the maintenance of the temporal power of the Pope. That the people of Central Italy will confirm the vote of annexation to Piedmont is fully believed by the Government of that country. At Vienna, a programme of reforms, sanctioned by the Emperor, was about to be published; the Council of the Empire was to be increased. From Morocco comes the news of a forward movement by Gen. ECHAGNE, but it is not known in what direction. English troops in India were setting out to join the force for China.

abstract: Paymaster A.W. Gaines, U.S.A., died at Fort Smith, Arkansas, Feb. 19, 1860, from the effects of a severe injury caused by being thrown from his buggy on Christmas morning -- the horses having run away and dashed the same into pieces. abstract: Catharine Ryan alias Templeton, a servant employed by Mrs. Catharine Goodnow, of No. 673 Washington-street, absconded from her place a few days since with $73 worth of clothing belonging to her mistress. On Monday night she was found by Officer Horton, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, at a house half-way between Hoboken and Jersey City. He attempted to arrest the woman, but her husband interposed a knife and a club, with which the officer would doubtless have been injured had he not discharged his revolver at his opponent, and compelled him to retreat. The shot took effect, but whether in a vital part or not was not ascertained. Catharine was secured, and was yesterday arraigned before Justice QUACKENBUSH, to whom she admitted that she had taken the property, adding that she had been induced to steal it by her husband, who was present when the robbery was committed. She was held for trial.

abstract: We publish to-day a report, from the London Times, of a recent debate on the Italian question in the Parliament of Prussia, which will be read with great interest, as well for the prospective as for the retrospective light it sheds upon the part taken by Prussia in the great drama now enacting beyond the Alos.
lead_paragraph: We publish to-day a report, from the London Times, of a recent debate on the Italian question in the Parliament of Prussia, which will be read with great interest, as well for the prospective as for the retrospective light it sheds upon the part taken by Prussia in the great drama now enacting beyond the Alos. The debate arose upon a remonstrance sent in by the leading citizens of the active and flourishing city of Breslau in Silesia, against the somewhat dubious tone of the official reply which the Prussian Ministry had made to the circular of Lord JOHN RUSSELL on Italian affairs. The Cabinet of the Prince Regent, in that reply, it will be remembered, hesitated to put Prussia openly and frankly by the side of France and England, in the assertion of the policy of non-intervention and of the right of the Italian people to choose their own rulers.
headline: {'main': 'Prussia and the Italian Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Prussia and the Italian Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

WISE, of Virginia, on his visit to Harper's Ferry, took into his possession all the letters and papers found upon the persons of all the prisoners, and that he still holds them. Of course, he should know more of the designs of the conspirators, and of the complicity in them of ...
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that Gov. WISE, of Virginia, on his visit to Harper's Ferry, took into his possession all the letters and papers found upon the persons of all the prisoners, and that he still holds them. Of course, he should know more of the designs of the conspirators, and of the complicity in them of Northern men, as revealed in the correspondence thus obtained, than any other person. Indeed, the Governor, in a speech delivered a short time after at Richmond, publicly declared that he had in his possession documents which established beyond all doubt the complicity of prominent Northern politicians in JOHN BROWN's plot. He is reported also to have said, on another occasion, that nothing would tempt him to reveal the facts, of which he thus obtained the knowledge, lest a storm of excitement should be raised which would rend the Union into fragments.
headline: {'main': 'Gov. Wise as a Witness.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Gov. Wise as a Witness.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The announcement of NAPOLEON that he considers the reannexation of the little mountain province of Savoy to the French dominions, important for the security of his southern frontier, has apparently thrown England into as much consternation as if a French fleet had suddenly anchored off Spithead. We have given our views of the policy and motives of NAPOLEON in proposing this measure, and the absurdity of the objections raised against it by England.

abstract: A SMALL STRIKE AND ITS CONSEQUENCES.--A few days since the firemen and coal-passers on board the California steamer Northern Light--the former getting $25, and the latter $12 per month--organized a strike. The owners refused to comply with their demand and discharged the men.
lead_paragraph: A SMALL STRIKE AND ITS CONSEQUENCES.--A few days since the firemen and coal-passers on board the California steamer Northern Light--the former getting $25, and the latter $12 per month--organized a strike. The owners refused to comply with their demand and discharged the men. The next day an advertisement appeared in the daily papers, issued by a shipping-house in Dover-street, offering places to firemen and coal-passers, which was answered by hundreds in person. Of these, eighteen or twenty were selected who were willing to work at the wages refused by the strikers, and they signed the articles. But, meanwhile, the strikers had reached their "sober, second thought," and, through the intercession of one of the officers of the boat, were received again on board at the old wages. The newly-employed men were greatly incensed at this, and made a complaint at the Mayor's Office; but there they were informed that they could only obtain redress by a suit in the civil Courts.

abstract: At the last meeting of the Police Commissioners Mayor WOOD offered a resolution to submit to three persons, to be appointed by the Supreme Court, the decision of the issues still pending between the Board and sundry members of the Old Police Force. We trust the Board will give this proposol a favorable consideration. The decision of the Courts of law has already been given upon the only legal point involved in the case. It has been settled that the members of the old force were members of the new, when the new act came into effect, -- and that all of them who were not duly notified to appear for trial, upon specified charges, are members still, and are entitled to back pay. The worst effect of this decision is that it has restored to the Department two or three hundred persons who are not up to the standard which should be required for service on the Police. They are mainly the political parasites of the department, who had obtained their position in pay for party services, or else men unable, from illness, age or confirmed idle habits, to earn a living in any other way. They have been contending, in the Courts, for restoration to their old places, because they had nothing else to rely upon for support -- and now that they have been restored, they are not only inefficient themselves, but the cause, by their example, of serious inefficiency on the part of others.
lead_paragraph: At the last meeting of the Police Commissioners Mayor WOOD offered a resolution to submit to three persons, to be appointed by the Supreme Court, the decision of the issues still pending between the Board and sundry members of the Old Police Force. They have been contending, in the Courts, for restoration to their old places, because they had nothing else to rely upon for support -- and now that they have been restored, they are not only inefficient themselves, but the cause, by their example, of serious inefficiency on the part of others.

abstract: New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company vs. Robert Schuyler et al.--The proceedings in this case commenced again with the further examination of Mr. Bement, the present Treasurer of the NewHaven Railroad Company. He was asked to describe the offices occupied by the Company and those of the Schuylers; and to state how they were connected. In answer to questions on this subject tha witness drew a small diagram giving the relative positions of the rooms.
lead_paragraph: New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company vs. Robert Schuyler et al.--The proceedings in this case commenced again with the further examination of Mr. Bement, the present Treasurer of the NewHaven Railroad Company. He was asked to describe the offices occupied by the Company and those of the Schuylers; and to state how they were connected. In answer to questions on this subject tha witness drew a small diagram giving the relative positions of the rooms. It appeared that both suites of offices were connected. The entrance from the stairway was directly into the office of R. & G.L. Schuyler; and from their offices into those of the Company. It was incidentally stated that the transfers of stock were usually made in the outer office -- that of the Schuylers.

abstract: The purchase system in the English Army is in a fair way of being abolished. The Government have declared their willingness to exempt the Lieutenant-Colonelcies from its operation, and select officers to fill vacancies in the command of regiments from the whole number of Majors in the army. This is a very useful modification, as it subjects one of the most important posts to the influence of competition, or at least makes it a prize to which a few, having reached a certain point, talent and character, may reasonably look forward. Under this rule Lord CARDIGAN could never have obtained the command of the splendid cavalry corps in which most of his grossest misconduct has taken place; and as soon as such men as he find it impossible to "invest" in a whole regiment, the Army will not only cease to attract them, but be delivered from a very gross abuse.
lead_paragraph: The purchase system in the English Army is in a fair way of being abolished. The Government have declared their willingness to exempt the Lieutenant-Colonelcies from its operation, and select officers to fill vacancies in the command of regiments from the whole number of Majors in the army. abstract: MARY SMITH, at the New-York Hospital, yesterday, made a deposition that PETER RUDY knocked her down with his fist, and that she received no other violence. The woman, whose injuries (supposed to have been received in a Water-street saloon last Saturday night) may prove fatal, is a low character, given to intemperance. RUDY and SARAH LEE, who were suspected of having beaten her, have been discharged .... The skeleton of a man found on Tuesday, by workmen, at No. 49 Bowery, is supposed to be that of LOUIS FULLING. who lived there when the building was burned. The skeleton of a child, also found there, is not recognized.... WILLIAM O'BRIEN, a child, was badly burned, last Monday, at the corner of Broadway and Forty-eighth-street, and died on Tuesday .... EDWARD PENDER, a middle-aged Irishman, residing at No. 87 Cherry-street, disappeared last Saturday, and yesterday his body was recovered from the water at Pier No. 20, East River. Verdict, "Death from drowning."

abstract: POLITICAL. -- The regular Anti-Morris Democratic City Convention was held yesterday afternoon at Montague Hall, when the following nominations for City officers were made: Collector of Taxes, EDMUND DRIGGS; Street Commissioner, ROBERT FURY; Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies, BERNARD O'NEIL. There are now three sets of condidates in the field for these offices, two nominated by Conventions professing to be composed of Democrats and one by Republicans. The Democrats of the Eighteenth Ward have re-nominated MARTIN KALBFLEISCH for Alderman and JOHN GARRISON for Supervisor. In the Fifteenth Ward they have nominated for Supervisor PETER G. BRENSON; for Assessor, RALPH KIRKMAN.

abstract: In imitation of the old lady who insisted on over-sweetening her parson's tea, because "all molasses was none too good for her minister," the City authorities seem to have suddenly conceived an equal affection for their municipal sons, whose recent petitions for removal of mud from the streets have been answered ...
lead_paragraph: In imitation of the old lady who insisted on over-sweetening her parson's tea, because "all molasses was none too good for her minister," the City authorities seem to have suddenly conceived an equal affection for their municipal sons, whose recent petitions for removal of mud from the streets have been answered by a condition of things which, though throwing dust in their eyes, does not blind them to the fact that they are being shabbily treated. To be compelled to wallow in mud is certainly an evil, but it is equally unwholesome and inconvenient to have to move and breathe in an African sand-cloud like that which for the past few days has pervaded the atmosphere of the entire City.

abstract: Mr. WILSON has taken up the present condition of the Slave-trade by the introduction of a bill and two resolntions in the Senate, which, if carried into effect, will go far to remove the existing difficulties in the way of its suppression.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WILSON has taken up the present condition of the Slave-trade by the introduction of a bill and two resolntions in the Senate, which, if carried into effect, will go far to remove the existing difficulties in the way of its suppression. The bill provides for the construction of five steamships, adapted to the navigation on the African coast, and to be made a permanent squadron of preventive cruisers in that region.

abstract: BOARD OF EDUCATION.--At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a communication from the School Officers of the Tenth Ward, asking for an appropriation of $7,475 to repair school building No. 42 was referred.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF EDUCATION.--At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a communication from the School Officers of the Tenth Ward, asking for an appropriation of $7,475 to repair school building No. 42 was referred. The officers of the Sixteenth Ward School sent in a notice that the resignation of Commissioner DEWITT C. PETERS had been received, and that JOHN DELAMATER had been nominated to fill this vacency. It was referred. The Board decided to elect a City Superintendent and Assistants, at the next meeting. The term of the present incumbents will end on the 1st of June next. A resolution was offered directing that no principal of the Female Department of the Grammar School shall receive more than $750 per annum, and no principal in a Primary School more than $650 per annum. After a long debate the matter was referred and the Board adjourned.

lead_paragraph: Only three years ago JOHN STUART MILL, the ablest of living economists, described the United States as a country in which "all who can possibly be born can find employment, without overstocking the market; where every laboring man enjoys in abundance all the necessaries, many of the comforts, and some of the luxuries of life, and unless in case of individual misconduct, or individual inability to work, poverty does not, and dependence need not, exist."

abstract: New-York is emphatically a City of Monuments and Parks. But its monuments commemorate chiefly the sublime genius of the artists who model, and the admiring stupidity of those who adopt and pay for them; while the parks seem only waiting for the removal of rubbish and the commencement of the architects' work.
lead_paragraph: New-York is emphatically a City of Monuments and Parks. But its monuments commemorate chiefly the sublime genius of the artists who model, and the admiring stupidity of those who adopt and pay for them; while the parks seem only waiting for the removal of rubbish and the commencement of the architects' work. The inclosure about the City Hall seems in a condition of perplexed uncertainty whether it ought to don a green coat or give itself up with composure to the combined service of public thoroughfare and public dust-bin. The prospect at present is that the public will settle the question by adopting it for the latter use. The stone image in front of the Hall would doubtless be used as a hitching-post for teams, but for the legend handed down that it was erected in memory of the nation's founder. It this be leally its design, it should be made evident to the public, either by the use of a label or the vocal explanations of a showman appointed for the purpose.

abstract: The bark A.A. Drebert, Capt. HEWETT, arrived at Philadelphia on Tuesday, bringing the crew and passengers of the propeller Commerce, which had been abandoned at sea, 130 miles from Cape Hatteras, on the 14th inst. The Captain of the Drebert reports that on the evening of the 14th he saw the steamer to windward in distresss, the bark, at the time, being under close-reefed topsails, and the wind blowing a gale from the northwest, with heavy sea. The steamer's hull was seen coming stern on, and before the bark could fall off, she was struck on the weather fore-rigging, carrying away mainsail, bulwarks, staunchions, and doing other damage. The bark, as soon as she could be got clear, was hove to, and during the night the officers and crew, numbering twenty, and three passengers, were taken off. The steamer sunk before the bark got out of sight. The passengers taken from the steamer were M.L. ROUSE and T.W. MILLER, of New-York, and GEORGE KELLEY, of Brooklyn, New-York. Mr. ROUSE, one of the passengers brought to this port in the bark, states that the gale commenced from the northwest on Monday the 12th, at noon, when the steamer was about 130 miles from Cape Hatteras. About 3 o'clock of the same day, the steamer was put about, in consequence of the leaking of one of the boilers. The storm still continuing, the steamer sprung aleak, when the pumps were put in operation, and kept at work during Tuesday and Wednesday, but still the water gained upon them, and about five o'clock, on Wednesday, a gale of wind still blowing, the bark was seen, and a collision took place as described. There was nearly nine feet of water in the hold at the time, and the ship was entirely unmanageable. The passengers saved nearly all their baggage, and a lot of provisions was also transferred to the bark.
lead_paragraph: The bark A.A. Drebert, Capt. HEWETT, arrived at Philadelphia on Tuesday, bringing the crew and passengers of the propeller Commerce, which had been abandoned at sea, 130 miles from Cape Hatteras, on the 14th inst. The Captain of the Drebert reports that on the evening of the 14th he saw the steamer to windward in distresss, the bark, at the time, being under close-reefed topsails, and the wind blowing a gale from the northwest, with heavy sea. The steamer's hull was seen coming stern on, and before the bark could fall off, she was struck on the weather fore-rigging, carrying away mainsail, bulwarks, staunchions, and doing other damage. The bark, as soon as she could be got clear, was hove to, and during the night the officers and crew, numbering twenty, and three passengers, were taken off. The steamer sunk before the bark got out of sight. The passengers taken from the steamer were M.L. ROUSE and T.W. MILLER, of New-York, and GEORGE KELLEY, of Brooklyn, New-York. Mr. ROUSE, one of the passengers brought to this port in the bark, states that the gale commenced from the northwest on Monday the 12th, at noon, when the steamer was about 130 miles from Cape Hatteras. About 3 o'clock of the same day, the steamer was put about, in consequence of the leaking of one of the boilers. The storm still continuing, the steamer sprung aleak, when the pumps were put in operation, and kept at work during Tuesday and Wednesday, but still the water gained upon them, and about five o'clock, on Wednesday, a gale of wind still blowing, the bark was seen, and a collision took place as described. There was nearly nine feet of water in the hold at the time, and the ship was entirely unmanageable. The passengers saved nearly all their baggage, and a lot of provisions was also transferred to the bark.

abstract: Early yesterday morning the sloop E.A. Johnson, of Islip, Long Island, was discovered adrift in the Lower Bay, between the East Bank and Romer, Shoal, by Capt, SISTARY, of the schooner Telegraph, of New--London.
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning the sloop E.A. Johnson, of Islip, Long Island, was discovered adrift in the Lower Bay, between the East Bank and Romer, Shoal, by Capt, SISTARY, of the schooner Telegraph, of New--London. Her bowsprit was gone, her sails and rigging were dragging alongside, and there was no one on board. On boarding her, Capt. SISTAEE discovered that the decks, fore and aft, were bes[???] with blood, and found human hair, matted with gore, scattered here and there, indicating that a murderers affray had probably taken place. Large pools of blood were found on the floor of the cabin, and table, chairs and stove were spattered. Everything was in confusion and disorder. A large hammer was found on which were portions of human hair and blood, showing that the murderous work [???], in part, been accomplished with that instrument. From the cabin-door to the side of the vessel there were marks of blood, apparently indicating that the victims had been drawn from the canon and thrown into the ocean. A pool of blood was visible near the scuppers, and there were traces of it on the outside of the vessel, and prints of bloody hands on the rail. Pools of blood also surrounded the must near the windless, and the red traces of crime were found on the mast and sails. The vessel was taken in charge by the Captain of the schooner, and shortly afterwards the steam-tug Ceres coming along, took both vessels in tow, and brought them to Ful[???]on Market slip. Cor[???] ner SCHIMMER, with his assistant. Dr. BOUGHTON, instituted [???] investigation. The Captain of the sloop was GEORGE BURR [???] slip, L.I., aged about 34 years, and has a family at that place. The vessel had been chartered to go to Virginia for a load of oysters, and left Spring-street [???]ck on the 15th inst., with a crew consisting of three persons, two of whom were named SMITH WATTS and OLVIER WATTS; the name of the third is [???] (some say as much as $2,000) with him, to be used in purchasing his cargo. The sloop called at Keyport, N.J., and left there last Sunday. Nothing was seen of her afterwards with [???] morning [???] 2o'clock, when she ran into the [???] which was below the Narrows, on her way to w[???]mington, striking her amidships, [???] her down almost to the [???]edge, and [???] the schooner as to [???] Capt. NICKELSON (of the [???]) [???]was quite light at the time, and [???] saw [???]man at the helm, and the book [???] at the [???].

abstract: Edmund Lane, chief mate, and Gordon Hires, second mate of the bark Anna, who were arrested and examined before the Police Court of Southampton, upon a charge of causing the death of six colored seamen, while on a voyage from New-York to Laguna, S.A., and from thence to England, and who were remanded to the custody of the American Consul at that port to be sent home for trial, arrived by the steamer Fulton on Tuesday. Deputy-Marshal O'Keefe took charge of the prisoners, and brought them to the office of the United States District-Attorney, where complaints were formally laid, and they were committed to await examination. The testimony, which was lengthy, appeared in the London papers, and as recited presents a case of brutality and Inhumanity seldom equaled in the annals of sea-murders.

abstract: The equinoctial war has been fiercely waged in our streets for the last few days. The stormking has swept through the City on the wings of the wind and lighted the train of powder that our City authorities had permitted to be laid in every avenue and lane. The dust has curled up like smoke from a battle-field.
lead_paragraph: The equinoctial war has been fiercely waged in our streets for the last few days. The stormking has swept through the City on the wings of the wind and lighted the train of powder that our City authorities had permitted to be laid in every avenue and lane. The dust has curled up like smoke from a battle-field. Ash-carts laden -- the very calssons of the enemy -- rumbling through the streets these gusty mornings, have carried dismay to the hearts and debris to the eyes and nostrils of citizens. Every house has been a beleagured citadel, and servant-maids at the windows, armed with broom-stick and duster, like artillerymen at the port-holes of a fortress, have seemed to touch off pieces of mighty calibre, to the great discomfiture of all who happened to be within range. The washerwomen, our standard-bearers, whose banners had been given to the breeze from clothes-lines on house-tops and in back-yards, early struck their colors lest they should be seized and carried off as trophies by the foe when the sun crossed the line. Like the Prince in the fairy tale, who, with a single sneeze, could, transport himself, in the twinkling of an eye, to the remotest parts of the earth, men have, to all appearances, conveyed themselves from place to place by dint of a succession of sternutatory explosions. Dust has been swallowed by the mouthful. Husbands of well-known sobriety, in reply to the particular inquiries of over-anxious wives, on returning home from business at nightfall, have been unable consistently to say "I have not taken a particle, my dear." Crinoline has weathered it with difficulty, and many a craft with rent cordage and rigging disordered has put into port in distress. It is not wonderful that the elements, when the sun enters Aries, should, to use a rife Americanism, become rambunctious. Neither is it particularly pleasing for a weather-beaten wight, whom much out-door exposure at this season has transformed into a walking ashes and garbage box, with dust thrown in, to be pestered by a funny friend -- a man of leisure, a lover of in-door sports, a carpet knight, who seems to have just come out of a band-box -- by personal application of Hamlet's panegyric of his father:
headline: {'main': 'Equinoctial Winds and Omnipotent Dust.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Equinoctial Winds and Omnipotent Dust.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The liquor-store of Peter Connor, corner of Chrystie and Delancey streets, was broken into by unknown burglars, early yesterday morning, and the money drawer and the contents of a small desk were carried off .... A. Mrs. Chapman, of No. 325 West Twenty-sixth-street, on Tuesday evening, it is alleged, was struck on the head with the butt of a gun by Patrick Cunningham. The condition of the woman is critical, and her assailant is held for examination .... Detective Smith yesterday arrested Joseph Dryfus, a German, charged with receiving stolen goods, who forfeited his bail bonds a year ago.

War between Austria and Piedmont is deemed exceedingly probable. lead_paragraph: The steamship North Briton, which left Liverpool on the 7th inst., vid (Queenstown, reached Portland yesterday, with one day's later news. War between Austria and Piedmont is deemed exceedingly probable. The Emperor NAPOLEON is aaid to have commissioned Count ARESE to bring about a definite settlement between France and Piedmont of the Savoy question. In Florence a Government ordinance has been issued suppressing all former decrees against the liberty of the Press. Persons of distinction had been arrested in Naples, and noblemen exiled. The permanent occupation of Tertuan by the Spanish had been agreed upon. A letter from the Sultan of Morocco was read on the 25th of February in Tangiers, announcing his rejection of the conditions of peace proposed by Spain.

lead_paragraph: The topic announced above was the subject of a discourse delivered last evening in the Cooper Insti tute, by Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS. In anticipation of some physical demonstrations of poplar disfavor, Deputy-Superintendent CARPENTER and Capt. LEON- ARD were on hand with a considerable force of policemen. The audience, however, (which filled about two-thirds of the Hall,) was dispassionate and attentive. Mr. PHILLIPS was listened to with the utmost quietude, and was allowed to proceed without any interruption or the slightest expression of dissent. His appearance on the platform was greeted with loud applause, on the subsidence of which Mr. OLIVER P. JOHNSON advanced and said:

abstract: The Daily News' City Article, March 8, says the stock market remains depressed, attention being still almost exclusively directed to the complications on the Continent. The funds, however, have not experienced any decline. The share market continues to droop. The demand for money is slack, owing to the new check to business. About £44,000 in gold was taken from the Bank for export, a portion being for India. A sum of £70,000 in West Indies and Brazil was dispatched abroad.

abstract: Henry P. Barker vs. Henry P. Wilson. -- In this case, which was partly reported yesterday, and which has been on trial for two days, in the Marine Court, the defendant, Mr. Wilson, of the firm of Wilsons, Midgley & Jennings, was placed on the stand, and directly contradicted the testimony of plaintiff's witnesses as to his having made any representations whatever as to the credit of Whitney & McDonald. Other testimony was offered impeaching the credibility of the principal witness for the plaintiff. The jury rendered a verdict for the defendants.

abstract: Our attention has been called by responsible parties to a case of want which appeals to the sympathies of the charitable. A widow lady, who was once in comfortable circumstances, has been for some time entirely dependent upon her own exertions and the assistance of a few friends for support. She has labored cheerfully, early and late, with the needle, until her eyes have become affected, and she is unable longer to earn anything in that way. She is not strong enough for severe manual exertion, and in her seeming helplessness was about despairing, until a congenial employment was offered her at some distance from the City. But she is unable to provide herself with suitable clothing for her new position, or with money to reach it. Under these circumstances, which really entitle her case to the attention of the charitable, some of her friends, whose will to aid her is much better than their ability, make this appeal. Any sums which may be sent to this office for her will be duly acknowledged.

lead_paragraph: We publish below copies of telegraphic dispatches received yesterday morning by Secretary TOUCEY from Lieutenants MINOR and CHAPMAN, of the United States Navy, announcing that an engagement took place on the 6th inst., off Vera Cruz, between the United States sloop-of-war Saratoga, with detachments from the Savannah, and Prebie on board the steamers Indianola and Wave, under the command of Commander TURNER, and two war steamers -- the Gen. Miramon and the Marquis, of Havana -- belonging to the Miramon faction in Mexico, and proceeding to aid in the seige of Vera Cruz, which was commenced by MIRAMON on the 5th inst.

abstract: The New-York and New-Haven Railroad vs. Robert Schuyler et al -- The proceedings in this case were continued yesterday. The plaintiffs have offered in evidence the books of the Company, to wit: The construction books, certificate books, transfer books and stock ledgers, &c. Defendant's counsel objected to their admission, on the ground that these books are the private books of the Company, and that the defendants, by the theory of the plaintiffs, are not stockholders in the Company; that the construction book and transfer book are not books of original entries; that the stock ledgers are claimed by plaintiffs themselves, in their complaint, to be false, fran[???]ulent and [???]terfoited; that the books are offered in mass, and that plaintiffs should point out the portions they deem admissible; that the stock ledgers are not books of original entries; and that there is no testimony that has been given of their correctness.
