abstract: The English Press, which has had so much to say in denunciation of the ambition displayed by NAPOLEON III. in his demand for the annexation of Savoy to France, has passed over without a word the renewal in India of that systematic annexation which played so serious a part in bringing on the fearful revolt of 1857. The State of Hindur, known to British
lead_paragraph: The English Press, which has had so much to say in denunciation of the ambition displayed by NAPOLEON III. in his demand for the annexation of Savoy to France, has passed over without a word the renewal in India of that systematic annexation which played so serious a part in bringing on the fearful revolt of 1857. The State of Hindur, known to British diplomacy as "one of the independent hill States about Simla," has just been seized by the British Government, and annexed to the British dominions in the Punjaub. During the formidable war with the Ghoorkas, the Rajah of Hindur was a faithful ally to the British; and as he has died leaving only three "illegitimate" sons, the British authorities have felt compelled through respect for his memory to overlook these most improper representatives of his blood, and having declared the Rajah childless, they have constituted themselves his heirs. It does not appear that the people of Hindur have been consulted in the matter at all, as Napoleon proposes that the people of Savoy shall be; for although Lord BROUGHAM and other excellent persons in the British Parliament never weary of scarifying the Supreme Court of the United States for the doctrine imputed to it, that "negroes have no rights which white men are bound to respect," it is an acknowledged principle of British policy in India to allow the Hindoos no rights at all which may even seem to be inconsistent with the administration of British India.

abstract: Information was received last evening at the Police head-quarters, that an attempt to pass $2 counterfeit bills on the Warren Bank, Rhode Island, would be made. Mr. Polhamus, the telegraph operator, dispatched the news to every Station house in the City, and each patrolman was ordered to warn all the shopkeepers on his beat of the matter. In less than twenty minutes after the information was telegraphed from the central office a message was received from the Ninth Precinct, announcing the arrest of Bridget McDade, Mary Callahan and James Smith for attempting respectively to pass the counterfeit in question, at No. 734 Washington-street, corner of Greenwich and King, and corner of Clarkson and Hudson streets. In other Precincts arrests were also made.

abstract: The NEW-YORK TIMES is the youngest of the daily newspapers of the City of New-York. The first number was issued on the 18th of September, 1851,--so that it has only just completed the eighth year of its publication.
lead_paragraph: The NEW-YORK TIMES is the youngest of the daily newspapers of the City of New-York. The first number was issued on the 18th of September, 1851,--so that it has only just completed the eighth year of its publication. But it has already become one of the most widely known and most firmly established daily journals of the United States. Its circulation is quite as large as that of any other daily of its class in the City of New-York, -- and in reputation for enterprise, energy, and reliability, it may fairly challenge comparison with any other newspaper in the country.

lead_paragraph: The crack of JOHN BROWN's rifle at Harper's Ferry has found an echo in the gravest financial circles of Great Britain. At the mere suggestion of Disunion in America, with all its train of national and sectional calamities, the political economists of England have been suddenly roused to look fully in the face the actual condition of their commercial relations with this country; and all citizens of the Southern States who are not utterly incapable of looking before as well as after, and weighing the chances of the future in the light of the lessons of the past, will do well to consider betimes the bearings and tendencies of the great and organized movement which is now going on in England for the development of the production of cotton.

abstract: The English people are much engrossed in discussing the effect which the new French treaty and Mr. GLADSTONE'S budget will have on English manufactures and commerce. The former reduces the duties on a long list of British manufactured goods.
lead_paragraph: The English people are much engrossed in discussing the effect which the new French treaty and Mr. GLADSTONE'S budget will have on English manufactures and commerce. The former reduces the duties on a long list of British manufactured goods. These duties have hitherto been so high as to amount almost to prohibition, and this reduction will naturally stimulate powerfully commerce in the class of articles specified. As an offset to this, England reduces the duties on wine and brandy, &c, and various speculations are offered upon the effect that will be produced by allowing French light wines to invade the domains of port and sherry and good old English ale. These things, of course, are treated financially, for their value is estimated in pounds, shillings and pence.

abstract: John Brown was tried for an attempt at grand larceny, in January last, in the dry-goods store of Noble, Brown & Co., Church street. He was found in the basement of the building, where more than $3,000 worth of linen was stored up, with a bag in one hand and a parcel of goods in the other. As he was in no wise connected with the premises, he was arrested for an attempt to steal. The jury, on convicting him, recommended him to mercy, but Judge RUSSELL refused to take the recommendation into consideration, as he thought the Jury had been deceived. The prisoner, he said, was a notorious character, and had been previously convicted. The sentence of the Court was two years and six months in the State Prison.

abstract: It required an exceedingly vivid imagination to regard yesterday as the opening day for anything belonging to Spring. A snow-storm which would have done honor to mid-Winter howled through the streets and was endurable only from the contrast which it presented to the dust-simoom of the day before.
lead_paragraph: It required an exceedingly vivid imagination to regard yesterday as the opening day for anything belonging to Spring. A snow-storm which would have done honor to mid-Winter howled through the streets and was endurable only from the contrast which it presented to the dust-simoom of the day before. But rasmon delights to vindicate her supremacy over the elements, and selects for the display of her novelties precisely those seasons of the year which are most likely to subject her votaries to the severest test. Last year "Opening Day" was signalized by a drenching deluge -- which, however, scarcely damped the ardor of that large class of the lovelier portion of the community, who are as eager to catch the earliest glimpse of the coming fashions as ever an Eastern Parsee was to hail the beams of the rising sun.

abstract: Thomas Reilly vs. Charles G. Cornell and James McMann. -- This was an application before Justice PIERREPONT, at Chambers, of the Superior Court, for an order of injunction against the defendants to restrain them from interfering with the plaintiff in the occupancy and ownership of certain property situated on the corner of Allen and Houston streets, and known as Hermitage Hall. The premises were valued at about $25,000. The plaintiff states that in the year 1858 [???] mortgagees were foreclosed against said properly, amounting in all to the sum of $4,000; and that they were bid off by the attorney in the foreclosure suit, with the understanding that the plaintiff might pay the amount due thereon, and retain his property. That after said sale the plaintiff procured the defendants, Cornell and Johnson, to advance $5,600 to the attorney who bought in at the foreclosure sale, for the benefit of the plaintiff and towards the redemption of his estate so involved, they taking a deed from Judge ULSHOEFFER, the Referee appointed to sell, as their security. Said deed is conceded to have been absolute in form, but plaintiff avers that the defendants specifically agreed to hold it only as security for the advance stated. The plaintiff then set forth that since the date of said loan he has paid two installments of interest thereon to said Cornell and Johnson, besides a bonus of $250; that he has also tendered to them the entire amount due them, which they declined to accept, claiming that they are the owners of the property, setting up the Referee's deed as vesting the title thereto in them.

abstract: FUNERAL OF GEORGE WOOD. -- The funeral of this eminent lawyer took place yesterday afternoon, from the Reformed Dutch Church in Lafayette-place. A large number of members of the Bar and other prominent citizens were in attendance. Among the latter we noticed Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT. The services were conducted by Rev. Drs. DE WITT and VERMILYEA. Dr. VERMILYEA spoke at considerable length of the life of the deceased, and of his virtues as a man, a lawyer and a Christian. The funeral rites at the residence of the deceased were performed by Rev. Dr. VINTON and Rev. JOHN COTTON SMITH, according to the forms of the Episcopal Church. The following gentleman acted as pall-bearers: CHAS. O'CONOR, DANIEL LORD, HIRAM KETCHUM, Ex-Judge ROOSEVELT, EX-Judge PEABODY, JOSEPH BLUNT and R.H. MCCURDY. The remains were deposited in the family vault at Greenwood.

abstract: John B. Lemoine vs. James Hewelt and others. -- This is an action now on trial in the Supreme Court, before Justice MONCRI[???]F. It is brought to recover $1,343, alleged to be due on a consignment of a large amount of tobacco from one David M. Branch, residing in St. Louis, Mo., for sale by the defendants, who are commission merchants doing business both in this City and New-Orleans. Large advances were made to Branch by the defendants it the time of the shipment. After receiving these advances, he assigned the remainder of the amount which might be due to the plaintiff. The plaintiff alleges that the tobacco was sold by the defendants, and after deducting the advances made to Branch, and commission and expenses of the defendant, there remains due the sum of $343, which the plaintiff claims. The defendants assert that the tobacco did not sell for enough to cover the amount of the advances, and that Branch is entitled to them, and therefore deny that there is anything due to the plaintiff.

abstract: An interesting discussion occurred in the Senate yesterday on the Homestead bill. Mr. WADE moved to substitute that which originated in the House for the Senate bill, claiming that under the latter only little land which was worth anything could be taken up. Mr. CLINGMAN opposed that
lead_paragraph: An interesting discussion occurred in the Senate yesterday on the Homestead bill. Mr. WADE moved to substitute that which originated in the House for the Senate bill, claiming that under the latter only little land which was worth anything could be taken up. Mr. CLINGMAN opposed that provision of the bill which obliged each claimant to work five years before gaining a right to the land. In the course of an argument in favor of the measure Mr. HALE alluded to the strikes now in progress in Massachusetts, and expressed the hope that they would continue until the workmen engaged in them should obtain the highest wages compatible with the public good. Mr. WADE advocated the House bill; Mr. JOHNSON of Arkansas opposed it. Messrs. WIGFALL, PUGH, and JOHNSON of Tennessee, also took part in the debate, and finally the subject was postponed until Monday. In the House, Mr. NOELL spoke on the bill proposing to withdraw from the people of Utah the power of making their local laws through an elective assembly, which, he claimed, could never suppress polygamy. Some tribunal should be constituted which would protect not only the inhabitants of Utah, but the people of the Union. A resolution was adopted declaring it inexpedient to allow Mr. COOPER any further time to contest the seat of Mr. HOWARD of Michigan.

abstract: If any proof were wanted of that coalition with the machine branch of the Republican Party, by which FERNANDO WOOD was elected last December, it is abundantly supplied here to-day by the character of the legislation now in progress with reference to the City Charter, and the agencies at work in carrying this measure to success.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Wednesday, March 21, 1860.

abstract: Mr. E.Y. ROBBINS delivered the second of his course of lectures on "Sanitary Science," at Cooper Institute last evening. His subject was "Ventilation as Influencing Health and Longevity." He commenced by saying that air was the prime necessary of life; that we could live more days without food than we could minutes without air.
lead_paragraph: Mr. E.Y. ROBBINS delivered the second of his course of lectures on "Sanitary Science," at Cooper Institute last evening. His subject was "Ventilation as Influencing Health and Longevity." He commenced by saying that air was the prime necessary of life; that we could live more days without food than we could minutes without air. The purpose of our breathing was, first, to supply the blood with oxygen, which is the life-sustaining principle of the air, and second, to free the blood from carbonic acid and other impurities. The air which we breathe is found on expiration to have lost a large part of its oxygen, and to be impregnated with carbonic acid gas -- that substance which often proves fatal to persons who descend into wells, and which is the active agent of death in cases of suicide by burning charcoal. It produces death whether retained in the blood or inhaled into the lungs -- the poisoning process in both cases being precisely the same. To produce death by that agent, it was by no means necessary that it should be breathed in a pure state. Dr. CARPENTER had ascertained that air containing five or six per cent. of carbonic acid gas would produce immediate death, and that less than one-half that quantity would soon prove fatal; and Dr. T. HERBERT BARKER had ascertained by experiments with this substance, that an animal in an atmosphere containing only two per cent. of carbonic acid would die In about two hours. Now the air which we exhale from the lungs contains, according to standard authorities, about five per cent. of carbonic acid, and hence If exactly the same air were reinhaled it would quickly prove fatal. It is a substance that is constantly accumulating in the blood, and if it is not as constantly removed it will speedily produce death. The process of breathing is but the instinctive effort of nature to free herself from the presence of this poison. But air which has once been in the lungs will no longer perform this office, being already saturated with carbonic acid. Hence the necessity of inhaling fresh air at every breath. The importance of this was illustrated by Dr. SOUTHWOOD SMITH, who said: "Stop the respiration of an animal, or confine it to air which has already been respired, and carbon accumulates in the venous blood and mixes with the arterial blood. In half a minute the blood flowing in the arteries is evidently darker; in three-quarters of a minute it is of a dusky hue, and in a minute and a half it is quite black. Every particle of arterial blood now disappears and the whole mass becomes venous, sensibility is abolished, the animal falls down, and in three, or at most in four minutes, the heart entirely ceases its action, and can never again be excited." Now, if effects are proportioned to their causes, and if an atmosphere impregnated with five per cent. -- or one twentieth part of its volume -- of carbonic acid, will thus produce death in a few minutes, what must be the probable effect of breathing, for twenty or forty years, even the much minuter proportions which must be present in every inhabited room where there is not a. constant ingress end egress of air? It must lower the standard of health and shorten the duration of life. But not only is the air in a close room thus constantly being impregnated with carbonic acid gas to the amount of about 28 cubic inches per minute for each adult man occupying such room, but there is also, according to the best authorities, constantly being discharged by the lungs and pores of the skin, an equal amount, by weight -- that is, about 3 or 3 1/2 pounds in twenty-four hours -- of effete, decaying animal substance, in the form of insensible vapor, which, we often see condensed in drops upon the windows of crowded rooms and railroad-cars. Those drops, if collected and evaporated, leave a thick putrid mass of animal matter. The breathing of these exhalations is believed to be quite us efficient in producing disease as carbonic acid itself. Hut there is still a third deterioration produced in the air by respiration, and that is, the loss of its oxygen. Oxygen is the vital and life-supporting principle of the air, and it is found that, when the air enters the lungs, the blood absorbs about 40 per cent. of the oxygen which it contains. It is upon this we live; and the air that is exhaled being deficient by almost one-half in his vital element, of course can no longer support life. And as we inhale about 500 cubic inches of air every minute, we of course deprive that quantify of air of 40 per cent. of its oxygen each minute. The Creator has provided for the constant and complete removal of these poisonous exhalations by causing the expired air to rise, by its increased warmth and consequent levity, quickly above our heads and beyond the reach of a second inhalation, and by sweeping it away by the winds; but by our impervious ceilings and tight wails we obstruct the operation of this beneficent law, and prevent these poisonous exhalations from escaping. Hence the air of a close room, though occupied but by a single-person, becomes, from the very first moment of occupancy, impregnated with these impurities, which accumulate more and more, the longer it is occupied without ventilation, and the [???] it is crowded. It would certainly be difficult to over estimate the importance to life and health of the purity of the air we breathe, and it would also be difficult to determine to what period of duration human life might be prolonged, did we, and had our ancestors always breathed a perfectly pure atmosphere. A most remarkable, and convincing illustration of the effects of the quality of the air we breathe upon health, is to be found in the experience of the armies of England and France during the late Russian war. England, out of a total force of 93,959 men engaged in the campaign in the Crimea, lost 33,645, of which number only 2,658 were killed in action, and 1,761 died of wounds, while no less than 16,298 died of disease at the seat of war, and about 13,000 were sent home on account of sickness, many of whom, no doubt, afterwards died. To every one taken to the hospitals on account of wounds, twelve were taken there on account of disease. The chief destroyer was typhus fever. M. BOUDENS, Surgeon-in-Chief of the French army, in a letter written home during the war, says of this disease: "It is engendered by crowding and want, either in hospitals, prisons, or on board of vessels. The disease may indeed be called forth and removed at will." And he adds: "The first remedy is pure air and powerful ventilation." The great mortality in the English army was during the early period of the war. After the Sanitary Commissioners arrived and commenced their operations by securing greater ventilation, the sickness was stayed, and finally disappeared. The great panacea was fresh air. In the French army, where no sanitary reforms were introduced, the great mortality continued and increased, thus showing clearly that the changes made by the Sanitary Commissioners in the English army were the sole causes of the decrease of mortality where they labored. Recurring again to the condition of our buildings here, the lecturer said: In our school-rooms the matter is still worse; while in our railroad cars we have actually less breathing: room than the wretched prisoners in the black-hole of Calcutta -- they having had about forty cubic feet per man, while in our cars we have only an allowance of about thirty cubic feet. In addition to this, the lighting of our rooms in the evening is a source of great contamination to the air -- each gas burner being estimated to generate as much carbonic acid gas as the respiration of four persons, or more than 100 cubic inches per minute. Every gas burner should have a ventilating tube to carry off the products of combustion, and convey them entirely out of the room, as is the case in the Houses of Parliament, and many other public and private buildings in England. In conclusion, he stated his belief, that by due attention to sewerage and ventilation, the mortality of this City would be decreased ten thousand every year. The lecture, which occupied about an hour in reading, was listened to with great satisfaction by all present. When the lecture was concluded, Dr. HARRIS stated that the next lecture would be delivered on Monday evening.

abstract: Oakley Beach vs. The New-York and Erie Railroad Company. -- This suit, which is on trial in the Supreme Court, before Justice BONNEY, was brought by the plaintiff to recover compensation for the loss of three casks of liquors, viz., one cask of brandy, one cask of gin and one cask of wine, valued at $130, which were delivered to the defendants, to be carried to Port Jervis. The complaint alleges the goods to have been lost through the negligence of the defendants.

The complaint alleges the goods to have been lost through the negligence of the defendants.

abstract: Our City affairs seem to be making decided progress of some sort in the State Legislature. Gov. MORGAN has vetoed the bill regulating unlicensed places of amusement, on the ground that it will operate oppressively upon some of the weakest of them. He expresses a desire,
lead_paragraph: Our City affairs seem to be making decided progress of some sort in the State Legislature. Gov. MORGAN has vetoed the bill regulating unlicensed places of amusement, on the ground that it will operate oppressively upon some of the weakest of them. He expresses a desire, however, for some legislation which shall prevent their being opened on Sunday. Probably a law framed so as to meet his views will be introduced.

abstract: A regular meeting of this Club was held at Clinton Hall last evening--the President, SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., in the Chair. About one hundred members were in attendance. A resolution was adopted requiring the Executive Committee to report at the next meeting a plan of operations for the coming campaign, and inviting other campaign clubs throughout the country to correspond with, and send delegates to this Club.
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of this Club was held at Clinton Hall last evening--the President, SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., in the Chair. About one hundred members were in attendance. A resolution was adopted requiring the Executive Committee to report at the next meeting a plan of operations for the coming campaign, and inviting other campaign clubs throughout the country to correspond with, and send delegates to this Club. The President then introduced Hon. CHAS. CASE, Member of Congress from Indiana, who, he said, happening to be in the City, had been invited to attend the meeting of the Club, and who would now favor them with a speech.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the Charleston Mercury denounces the Homestead bill which has passed the House, on the ground that it will be availed of by emigrants from the North far more than from the South. A Southern planter has no motive to
lead_paragraph: The Washington correspondent of the Charleston Mercury denounces the Homestead bill which has passed the House, on the ground that it will be availed of by emigrants from the North far more than from the South. A Southern planter has no motive to leave his own country, and incur the expense, risk and trouble of taking his slaves with him into a new and remote region, while thousands and tens of thousands at the North are ready at all times to avail themselves of the chance. The influx of foreigners, he says, is the sole cause of the more rapid growth of the North over the South, and although attended with some advantages, he thinks it has beyond all question done much to demoralize the Democratic Party. When the next census is taken, the strength of representation will be westward to an extent that will astonish the other States. The South will deeply feel this, and so will New-England, for, says the correspondent, "in all those Northwestern States the tone of the Democracy is good for nothing. Their position on Squatter Sovereignty belies all their professions upon the constitutional rights of the South in the Territories concerning Slavery, and their advocacy of the Homestead bill shows their acquiescence in a principle that only makes the Abolition forces stronger, and the growth of any heresy sanctioned by American demogogues."

abstract: The House of Hapsburg, which already owes so much more to Venus than to Mars, seems to be invoking the Goddess of Beauty to provide it with a refuge in the New World, against the possible whims of Fate and the tides of revolution in the older hemisphere. The Archduke MAXIMILIAN, of Austria, now on a visit at the Court of the Emperor of Brazil, is reported to be negotiating a marriage between the eldest daughter of that sovereign and his own brother, the Archduke LOUIS VICTOR. The persons principally concerned in this momentous piece of matrimonial diplomacy are hardly old enough to interfere with any arrangements that may be made for their "settlement, in. life,", the Archduke LOUIS being barely eighteen, and his intended bride, the Princess ISABELLA, not quite fourteen years of age. As the Emperor, Don PEDRO has no sons, this young lady stands in the direct line of succession to the Brazilian throne; and should the projected match be carried out, it is quite within the range of probabilities that the family of the HAPSBURGS, like the family of BRAGANZA. before them, may be indebted to an American Emperor for the "comforts of a home." We cannot congratulate our friends of the Southern Empire on the chance of such a result.

abstract: The Decatur (Ala.) papers state that a lad about 16 years of age, son of Mrs. MORRIS, living at Decatur, Ala., was murdered by a negro servant belonging to the family. It seems the lad gave him some orders, and the servant not obeying, he threatened to have him punished, when the negro picked up a stone and hit his young master on the head, it is supposed, killing him instantly. After he had committed the deed, he took the body and threw it into an old well near by. The body was found after considerable search by tracking the blood which led from the place where the deed was committed, to the well.
lead_paragraph: The Decatur (Ala.) papers state that a lad about 16 years of age, son of Mrs. MORRIS, living at Decatur, Ala., was murdered by a negro servant belonging to the family. The body was found after considerable search by tracking the blood which led from the place where the deed was committed, to the well.

abstract: It is quite allowable to learn wisdom from an enemy. Thus far an old maxim warrants us in going. Experience shows that we may sometimes safely go further,--and that very frequently our enemies are the very best persons to whom we can go for instruction. Their plans and purposes may be so well defined and so abhorrent to our own, that, if we can only
lead_paragraph: It is quite allowable to learn wisdom from an enemy. Thus far an old maxim warrants us in going. Experience shows that we may sometimes safely go further,--and that very frequently our enemies are the very best persons to whom we can go for instruction. Their plans and purposes may be so well defined and so abhorrent to our own, that, if we can only ascertain their real views -- the direction of their efforts -- we shall be perfectly safe in going exactly the other way. WENDELL PHILLIPS is an "enemy" of precisely this stamp. The object he has nearest his heart is the destruction of the American Union. He is devoting all his energies to the accomplishment of this purpose. He is a man of great ability, -- accustomed to study the tendencies of public sentiment, and sagacious in his estimate of political and moral influences. He knows very well what condition of public affairs is best adapted to the advance of his object.

abstract: Telegraphic dispatches have already announced the disaster at the St. [???] Hotel, in New-Orleans; the explosion of the steamer Maning, on the Savannah River; and the burning of the steamer Judge Porter, on the Mississippi. Further particulars of these disasters have reached us. The total loss of life is thirty two; 18 on board the porter, 13 on board the Maning, and [???] at the St. Charles Hotel. The names of the persons killed on the Maning, in Georgia, are as follows: Jefferson Taylor, son of Capt Taylor; Joseph B. Williams, John Harrall, Jacob Parker, (the last three citizens of T[???]fair County,) and eight or nine negro hands. Among the negroes lost are Charles, the cook, jack and Edmond, belonging to William Willcox; Hal and --, belonging to James Y. Willcox; and Bill, belonging to John F. McRae. The victim of the St. Charles fire was John Ko[???]kelly; and there is no list of the sufferers of the Porter. The second engineer, steward, second cook and Mr. Farrar, the second clerk, are missing; it is supposed that they either perished in the flames or were drowned. Of the passengers, but one is known to have been saved -- be, together with the captain and crew, were picked up by boats from some vessel which was near by. The pilot, Mr. Henderson, was the last to leave the boat, which he did after heading [???] for shore.

abstract: Early yesterday morning, Capt. WEED, of the Second Precinct Police, received information that a sea-faring man, having in his possession a bag, containing a large amount of money, had come up to the City by a Staten Island ferry-boat on the previous day. In conversation with the hands on board, the man stated that he had been employed on the sloop Wm. Tell.
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning, Capt. WEED, of the Second Precinct Police, received information that a sea-faring man, having in his possession a bag, containing a large amount of money, had come up to the City by a Staten Island ferry-boat on the previous day. In conversation with the hands on board, the man stated that he had been employed on the sloop Wm. Tell, which had been sunk in a collision in the Lower Bay, and that the captain was crushed to death at the moment of the disaster, while he himself barely escaped by means of the boat, which he managed to cut away before the vessel sank. This not very plausible story appears to have been credited, and the man, assisted by his auditors, occupied himself with counting the contents of his money-bag while the boat proceeded to the City. This man is now believed to be the murderer of Capt. BURR and OLIVER and SMITH WATTS, the lads, who, with himself, composed the crew of the oyster-sloop E.A. Johnson, which was found abandoned on Wednesday morning, near Coney Island, with such undoubted evidences that a bloody tragedy had recently been exacted on board of her. With this clue, Capt. WEED started in pursuit of the individual in question, and soon succeeded in tracing him to his residence in the lower part of the City, whence he had departed on Wednesday evening, accompanied by his wife and child. Where he has gone to is not yet ascertained. The capture of the fugitive is not despaired of, however, as two experienced officers are on his track.

abstract: BROOKLYN IMPROVEMENTS.--By direction of the Mayor the Police have recently reported all of the next buildings erected in the city since the 1st of January 1859. The following is a synopsis of their report. The whole number of buildings erected is
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN IMPROVEMENTS.--By direction of the Mayor the Police have recently reported all of the next buildings erected in the city since the 1st of January 1859. The following is a synopsis of their report. The whole number of buildings erected is 1,5[???]1, of which 51 are in the First [???], 35 in the Second; 202 in the Third; 507 in the Fourth; 229 in the Fifth; 361 in the Sixth; 46 in the Seventh; 103 in the Eighth, and 217 in the Ninth. Of the new buildings, there are of brick or stone 466, two stories high; [???]94, three stories high, and 117, four stories and over. Of frame buildings there are 363 of two stories; 212 of three stories, and three of four stories and over. There are 22 public buildings of brick or stone, and six of wood. The number of buildings erected for manufacturing purposes is 67, of which 56 are brick or stone. The buildings for manufacturing purposes were for the following branches: Brass and copper, carriage, gas-fitting, gas-purifying, paint, whiting, kerosene oil, sulphur, Japan ware, percussion-caps, dyes, drugs, curled hair, cotton, gutta percha pipe, hats, paper, fringe, pottery, glass, agricultural implements, soap, tinware, block factory, porcelain, saw mill, hay-presses, blacksmith, planing mills -- one each; machinery, oil, boxes, drugs, white lead, chains -- two each; iron, three; cooper and carpenter shops -- four each; distillers, four.

abstract: The principal event of the past month has been the arrival at this port of His Royal Highness the Archduke MAXIMILIAN, of Austria. His Highness arrived about two weeks since, from Madeira, via Bahia and the Ambrolios, in the corvette Elizabeth. He is traveling strictly incognito, and avoids everything in the way of display or public honor.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRIO, Thursday, Feb. 9, 1860.

abstract: Ever since the reduction of postal rates from the former heavy impositions to the present reasonable scale, attempts have been constantly made to restore in some degree the former burden.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the reduction of postal rates from the former heavy impositions to the present reasonable scale, attempts have been constantly made to restore in some degree the former burden. None have been made with more unjust discrimination, however, than the plan recently reported in the Senate by Mr. YULEE, of Florid a, from the Post-office Committee, for increasing the rates in that direction which will most heavily oppress those who contribute most largely for the support of the national mail department. The proposition is to double the postage now paid on drop letters delivered by carriers in large cities.

abstract: The Assembly is eagerly engaged at present in discussing the propriety of abolishing capital punishment. There is probably no question in the whole range of criminal jurisprudence which has been so much and so thoroughly debated. Unfortunately for the purposes of early ...
lead_paragraph: The Assembly is eagerly engaged at present in discussing the propriety of abolishing capital punishment. There is probably no question in the whole range of criminal jurisprudence which has been so much and so thoroughly debated. Unfortunately for the purposes of early and satisfactory decision, however, the abstract right and wrong of the matter have been argued with just as much pertinacity and volubility as its expediency. As this has invariably led to citations from the Bible as controlling authority, the result has been that determined adherence to their own opinions on the part of the contending parties which seems to be the all-but invariable result of attempts to regulate the civil polity of modern nations by the precedents drawn from the Mosaic law. As soon as an attempt is made to support or condemn a legislative measure in modern times by the aid of Biblical criticism, all chance of compromise or agreement, or of any satisfactory solution of the problem, seems to vanish on the instant, and the conversion of either side to become impossible.

abstract: There is something intensely interesting and romantic in the fact that, while walking up Broadway any fine sunny day, viewing leisurely the many evidences of our high modern civilization which cluster in and around that much-frequented promenade, and pondering the great questions which now distract the world--first, will the ladies of Europe and ...
lead_paragraph: There is something intensely interesting and romantic in the fact that, while walking up Broadway any fine sunny day, viewing leisurely the many evidences of our high modern civilization which cluster in and around that much-frequented promenade, and pondering the great questions which now distract the world--first, will the ladies of Europe and America consent to wear the lately enlarged bonnets, or will they not? -- a question which now agitates and engrosses the entire female mind; next, who shall receive the nomination at the Charleston Convention? and last, but not least, who is to untie the hard knot of the "Italian question?" -- it is interesting, while thinking of these things, in the midst of a busy noonday crowd, made up of Bulls and Bears, rattling omnibuses, express wagons, Fifth-avenue carriages, railroad ticket offices, sewing-machine signs, play-bills, fashionable churches, telegraph wires, big hotels, with their big coaches hurrying passengers to steam on water or land; ragged boys handing through said coach windows the paper just warm from the great printing-press, telling what all the world is doing; -- it is interesting to find that in a few moments, and by passing through a rather slim and dusty hall -- which makes it all the more romantic -- you may shut yourself out from the present, and sit down among the ruins of a civilization and a people that formed a mighty race and a mighty kingdom, flourishing in power and splendor three thousand years ago. In this silent place you are surrounded with the tombs and the skeletons of once powerful kings and idolized gods -- kings who were not, as the petty monarchs of our day, the servants of the popular will, but sovereigns whose power was supreme, and who, not content with the homage of the world while they lived, built themselves splendid, and, as they thought, everlasting mausoleums, to contain the precious bones which may now be seen in Broadway, at the moderate charge of 25 cents.

abstract: In my last, I endeavored to sketch the condition of Protestantism in Tuscany under the Grand Duke, and the encouraging change which accompanied the Revolution. This change was not unexpected. Matters had long been so desperate that an improvement was inevitable; and the friends of the good cause, debarred from direct effort in its behalf, occupied themselves with preparation for the time when such effort would be possible.
lead_paragraph: ROME, Thursday, Feb. 16, 1850.

abstract: CENTRAL CLUB OF THE NATIONAL UNION PARTY. -- A meeting of this organization was held last night in one of the rooms in Clinton Hall. There were present about twenty-three members. Gen. LLOYD occupied the Chair, and Mr. GEO. A. HALSEY acted as Secretary. On motion of Mr. J. MANSFIELD DAVIES, of the fifteenth Ward, it was resolved that a delegate and alternate be elected by each Ward Club to represent the Union Party in the State Convention at Troy, and that the delegates be empowered, in case objection be made to their appointment by Wards instead of Assembly Districts, to order the election of District delegates as substitutes. Mr. E.J. BROWN read a letter from a friend commendatory of the objects of the Association, and announced that Hon. Messrs. MAYNARD and NELSON would appear at the National Union Meeting in the Cooper Institute on next Monday night. A Committee of five was appointed, consisting of Messrs. A.S. Jones, J.W. Savage, Peter J. Levius, Jr., George A. Kelsey, and W.T. Jennings, to take Messrs. MAYNARD and NELSON in charge, and "show them round." After addresses by Mr. MISER and Mr. ERASTUS BROOKS, the latter of which nominated Mr. BELL, of Tennessee, for the Presidency, and Mr. MCLEAN, of Ohio, for the Vice-Presidency, the meeting adjourned until Monday night next, when the big meeting is to be held in Cooper Institute. The Seventh Regiment band will constitute an important feature of the celebration.

abstract: Among all the forms of oppression which weigh heavily on the denizens of this badly-governed town, none is more widely extended and constant than the tyranny which stage drivers exercise over the public. They seem to be imbued with the idea that the long endurance of their power by the public has given them a prescriptive right to its continuance. They regard the street as their own personal domain, whereon no pedestrian may trespass, except at his own risk of being ground to powder beneath blindly-driven coaches. Only a day or two ago a man was run over and killed by one of these reckless Jehus, whose arrest to await the Coroner's verdict is probably a very poor consolation to the family that depended for support on the murdered man. It is a homely adage, but very applicable to the present case, that it is useless to lock the door after the horse is stolen. Preventive remedies are demanded as well as curative. Within a few days several instances have occurred of injuries, more or less severe, received by passengers on leaving coaches, which the drivers refused to stop a sufficient length of time for persons to alight. No one should leave a coach while in motion. For any injuries which they may sustain will be attributed to their own carelessness, and damages against the Company be refused. If everyone would insist on the stage stopping a sufficient length of time for a person to leave it, the drivers would soon learn better manners than they now display, and find that nothing is gained by their reckless haste.
lead_paragraph: Among all the forms of oppression which weigh heavily on the denizens of this badly-governed town, none is more widely extended and constant than the tyranny which stage drivers exercise over the public. They seem to be imbued with the idea that the long endurance of their power by the public has given them a prescriptive right to its continuance. They regard the street as their own personal domain, whereon no pedestrian may trespass, except at his own risk of being ground to powder beneath blindly-driven coaches. Only a day or two ago a man was run over and killed by one of these reckless Jehus, whose arrest to await the Coroner's verdict is probably a very poor consolation to the family that depended for support on the murdered man. It is a homely adage, but very applicable to the present case, that it is useless to lock the door after the horse is stolen. Preventive remedies are demanded as well as curative. Within a few days several instances have occurred of injuries, more or less severe, received by passengers on leaving coaches, which the drivers refused to stop a sufficient length of time for persons to alight. No one should leave a coach while in motion. For any injuries which they may sustain will be attributed to their own carelessness, and damages against the Company be refused. If everyone would insist on the stage stopping a sufficient length of time for a person to leave it, the drivers would soon learn better manners than they now display, and find that nothing is gained by their reckless haste.

abstract: The first case disposed of yesterday was that of Isidora Smith, a young colored girl, confederate of Malvina Francis, who was tried and convicted on Thursday of grand larceny. She had robbed her mistress, a Mrs. Henry, residing at No. 854 Broadway, of jewelry, wearing apparel and an opera glass, valued altogether at $200. Malvina was convicted, and yesterday Isidora, taking warning thereby, pleaded guilty. She was sentenced to imprisonment in the State Prison for two years.

abstract: Of all the uncomfortable places in the world, on a windy, chilly March day, Boston is the least desirable. For forty-eight hours an east wind has exerted itself, whether for the benefit of strangers or not, is more than I can say; but certainly a bluer-nosed, thinner-lipped, shrugged-shouldered set of men and women I never before met.

abstract: I intended to start on a trip into New-Hampshire this morning, and had directed the porter to call me in time for the 7 A.M. train. In obedience to his summons I got up, and what was my astonishment on looking from the window to see the snowflakes falling thick and fast, while the ground was already spread with the downy covering.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Thursday, March 22, 1860.

abstract: On Thursday, Thomas H. Purves was arrested, and held to bail in the sum of $6,000, charged by Messrs. Howland  Aspinwall with having obtained ten bales of raw silk, valued at $5,500, by false representations. It is alleged that Mr. Purves stated that he had made arrangements with Claflin, Mellen  Co., to furnish some thirty cases of manufactured ...
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Thomas H. Purves was arrested, and held to bail in the sum of $6,000, charged by Messrs. Howland Aspinwall with having obtained ten bales of raw silk, valued at $5,500, by false representations. It is alleged that Mr. Purves stated that he had made arrangements with Claflin, Mellen Co., to furnish some thirty cases of manufactured silk, and that he would give their notes for the amount of the raw silk, at the expiration of sixty days, which was assented to, and the silk delivered. At the expiration of the sixty days, when called on for the notes, he had made an assignment, and inquiries instituted by Messrs. Howland & Aspinwall resulted in the discovery, that not only had he no agreement with Claflin, Mellen & Co, but that on the very day on which he made the purchase of this raw silk, he had received from them $2,160 in cash, for twelve cases of manufactured silk, and that they had no arrangement with him as to any further purchases. There are three other similar charges pending against this man, involving $2,500, $5,000 and $2,000 respectively, in all of which, as in the present case, he procured the required bail.

abstract: Many of our citizens have been hoping, though, to my mind, almost against hope, that the Democratic National Convention would ultimately be held in Baltimore instead of Charleston. However much myself, in common with others, actuated, doubtless, by especially interested motives, might desire such a result, yet I have no idea Charleston will be forsaken.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Thursday, March 22, 1860 -- P.M.

abstract: The Milwaukee Democrat says: "The Investigating Committee, consisting of Councilors LOCKWOOD, NOYES, and TESCH, who for the last three weeks have been engaged in investigating the affairs of the city officers, came to a point, on Saturday afternoon, where they thought public justice required that two of our city officials--the Clerk, ROBERT B. LYNCH, and the Comptroller, E. L'HOMMEDIEU GARDINER--should ...
lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee Democrat says: "The Investigating Committee, consisting of Councilors LOCKWOOD, NOYES, and TESCH, who for the last three weeks have been engaged in investigating the affairs of the city officers, came to a point, on Saturday afternoon, where they thought public justice required that two of our city officials--the Clerk, ROBERT B. LYNCH, and the Comptroller, E. L'HOMMEDIEU GARDINER--should be arrested, and charges of a serious nature preferred against them. Accordingly, Mayor PAGE entered a complaint against R.B. LYNCH, and a warrant was issued for his arrest, on Saturday afternoon. Chief-of-Police BECK arrested him in the Mayor's office. Two charges were preferred against him, one for embezzlement of $2,000, and one for forging a treasury-note of $100, on or about the 19th day of July, 1869. Judge MALLORY fixed his bail at $1,500 on the charge of embezzlement, and $600 for forgery. Sufficient was also found to warrant the arrest of Comptroller GARDINER, and on complaint of Councilor TESCH, a warrant was issued for his arrest, charging him with forging a treasury-warrant for $50, on or about the 7th day of July, 1859. He was arrested at his house, on Sunday, and confined at the Station-house.

abstract: The United States vs. James S. Williams. -- Judge SMALLEY charged the Jury in this case yesterday morning. He said there was no variance between the evidence and the indictment, and that the objection of the prisoner's counsel to the indictment, that there could be no conviction on the charge of having taken from the Post-office a letter containing a promissory note, because the note was not sufficiently described in the indic[???]ment, was not a valid one in this case. It was necessary, in order to convict the respondent, to prove that, at some time previous to the [???]ling of the indictment, and within two years, he took a letter from the Post-office, not addressed to himself, and in violation of law. In the first place, it was necessary for Government to prove that such a letter was mailed and in the Post-office, and regularly under the charge of the officers of that Department. In the second place, it was necessary to prove that it was taken from the office in violation of law and without right. And, in the third place, it was necessary to satisfy the jury that this respondent was the person who thus took the letter. All the evidence introduced subsequent to that period was only important as tending to fix the offence on the respondent. It was proved that a note for $3,000 was made by F.A. Williams, indorsed by Charles Johnson, payable at three months, which was mailed to the bank of Norwalk on the 12th or 13th of December, or sent by Express. There was little doubt that it was received at the Bank. There was no conflicting evidence on that point It was proved that the note was remailed to F.A. Williams, with a letter [???]eiling him that the Bank could not discount the note at three months, but if it was changed to a two months note the Bank would; and that a letter with the words "From the Norwalk Bank" printed on it, was received in the Post office in this City, and laid out to be advertised, and that a letter directed to F.A. Williams was advertised on the 23d December, as charged. It was proved that some one brought a note, altered from a three to a two months' note, to Adams' Express Company, and wrote some lines on a sheet of paper, signed it "F.A. Williams," and sent it by the Express to the bank; that the letter and note were received; that the net proceeds of the note, after deducting discount and expenses -- $2,971 -- was, on the 27th of December, sent by the Express Company to the address of F.A. Williams, New-York; "that it was delivered to the same person who had called before, and his receipt taken; and that neither F.A. Williams nor Charles Johnson took a letter containing the note from the post-office, or saw it after it was inclosed to Norwalk. Therefore the conclusion would seem to be irresistible that some one tortuously took the letter containing the note from the Post-office, and probably there would be as little doubt but that the person who presented the note on the 24th December, at the Express Office, and received the money package on the 28th, was the same person who tortuously took the letter from the Post office. So that it probably came down to this point: Who was the person who presented that note to the Express Office on the 24th of December, and obtained the money on the 28th? The Judge recalled the evidence upon which the prosecution rested; the testimony that the respondent was in the habit of examining the list of advertised letters; that he frequently inquired at the Post-office for letters directed to men named Williams, with different christian names from his own; that he had received one letter there not Addressed to him; and that he was the man who took the note to the Express Office. He presented the evidence brought by the respondent to meet some of this testimony, and commented upon the absence of evidence for the defence in some cases. The Court then adverted to the proof of handwriting, going to identify that on the paper written by the person who called at the Express Office on the 24th of December with the handwriting of Britton and Simpson, [now acknowledged to be the same with the respondent,] and to the circumstance that Williams on the 5th of January deposited $1,000 in the Citizen's Bank, in the name of James Simpson, and $1,500 in the Bowery Bank, on the 30th of December, in the names of John Britton, Henry Britton and Mary Britton. The reason for using feigned names was stated by the respondent's counsel to be that he had received this money from lottery offices and for electioneering purposes, which being contrary to the law of the State, he feared he would lose the money if deposited in his own name. Of this reason the jury should judge, as also of the testimony of Lawson and Doyle, lottery dealers, that they had each paid him in the neighborhood of $500 about this time. These men kept no accounts, and had no means of fixing the time, except from recollection. The jury were to consider whether the defendant had explained in a satisfactory manner his possession of this large sum of money in December and January -- he being shown to have worked as a carver for from $6 to $9 a week. Lastly the Court received the testimony of Messrs. McMenomy and Hewlet, to prove an alibi; and the evidence of the Government in rebuttal. While the experience of Courts had led them to regard that species of defence with great suspicion, yet it was the duty of the jury to consider it and give it whatever weight they thought it deserved. They were to say, from all the evidence, whether they were satisfied, beyond reasonable doubt, that the respondent took the letter, as charged, from the post-office; and if they came to that conclusion it was their duty to find him guilty.

abstract: Our Democratic Primaries came off on Monday, with what here are deemed pretty lively accompaniments. There was some fighting, the Mint and the Custom-house being arrayed against each other in the persons of sundry stalwart employes on each side. Eleven men were arrested as the result of the day's work.

abstract: A permanent organization of the Maryland State Democratic Convention is in session here. Ex-Gov. LOWE is the Chairman, and the Vice-Presidents are chosen, one from each District. The Committee appointed on resolutions will report this morning, after which Delegates will be elected to Charleston. It is thought that Delegates favoring Mr. DOUGLAS will be chosen.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Friday, March 23.

abstract: The Brokers' Circular reports COTTON dull, at a decline of fully 1/3 on most descriptions, the heaviest  fall being on the middling and lower grades. The market closed with a general desire to realize on the part of holders. The sales of the week foot up 4,700 bales, of which speculators took 1,000 and exporters 6,000 bales.

abstract: A grave objection urged against the Homestead bill in the debate in the Senate, by Mr. WIGFALL and others, is that it is "eleemosynary" in its character. The Federal Government, it is urged, is the trustee of the public lands for the equal benefit of all the States, and therefore has no power under the Constitution to give them away.
lead_paragraph: A grave objection urged against the Homestead bill in the debate in the Senate, by Mr. WIGFALL and others, is that it is "eleemosynary" in its character. The Federal Government, it is urged, is the trustee of the public lands for the equal benefit of all the States, and therefore has no power under the Constitution to give them away. If, says the Senator from Texas, Congress "would give lands to the landless, why not niggers to the niggerless? why not give money?" We have a word or two to say in reply to this objection.

abstract: COMMON SENSE  IN THE ASCENDANT.--We have already announced the fact that Gov. STEWART, of Missouri, has vetoed the bill to reduce the free negroes of that State into slavery. We publish this morning his message upon the subject. It may properly enough be called a remarkable document--mainly because it treats ...
lead_paragraph: COMMON SENSE IN THE ASCENDANT.--We have already announced the fact that Gov. STEWART, of Missouri, has vetoed the bill to reduce the free negroes of that State into slavery. We publish this morning his message upon the subject. It may properly enough be called a remarkable document--mainly because it treats [???] negro question with a reasonable degree of fairness and common sense. This, of itself, is quite enough to distinguish it among the public documents of the day which reach us from the Slave States.

abstract: Application of Phoebe Ann Holmes. -- This was an application by a colored servant girl for an order of the Court, in pursuance of a writ of habeas corpus, that John T. Brown, the father of an illegitimate child of which she was the mother, deliver over to her the care and custody of her offspring. She complained that the child was a boy about five years of age, and that he was wrongfully detained from her by Brown, who had spirited the lad away to New-Jersey to get him beyond the jurisdiction of the Court. She claimed the lad as "Eugene Peterson Holmes." The respondent made his return to the writ, admitting that the boy was illegitimate, and that the relator was the mother thereof, but he averred that the relator resigned the boy to him, and that he only of the two was able to take care of the child. He also averred that the boy was sent to New-Jersey about four months ago, and placed in the care of a friend of his to be reared, and that he was not taken there to evade process of the Court. He also set forth that the relator was a servant in a house of prostitution in this City, and was unfit to have the care of the boy. He was a porter in the employ of an Express Company of this City, and perfectly able to take care of the child; but he was perfectly willing to produce the child in Court if the Justice thought it necessary, and would grant time for that purpose. He denied that the child's name was Eugene Peterson Holmes, but asserted with the pride of a progenitor that the name of the child was Eugene Peterson Brown.

abstract: We learn from our correspondent at Providence, R.I., that the detectives who went in pursuit of the suspected murderer of the captain and two lads belonging to the oyster sloop E.A. Johnson, had traced the object of their search to that city, and were confident of securing his apprehension during last night.
lead_paragraph: We learn from our correspondent at Providence, R.I., that the detectives who went in pursuit of the suspected murderer of the captain and two lads belonging to the oyster sloop E.A. Johnson, had traced the object of their search to that city, and were confident of securing his apprehension during last night. The man's name is WM. JOHNSON, and although his identity had been placed beyond conjecture on Thursday, yet it has thus far been suppressed in deference to the request of the Police authorities, who believed that publicity would frustrate their plans. As, however, he is probably by this time in custody concealment is no longer necesary. The profound sensation created by this triple murder has in no way abated. The vessel herself, with broken jib-boom, torn cut-water, and decks which, despite the recent snow, still bear stains of the blood of three of her crew, was yesterday an object of much interest. Visitors were even more numerous than on the preceding day, and from morning until dusk the piers adjacent to the slip in which she lies were crowded.

abstract: It is the object of these Lectures to furnish an argument against the modern school of ideal rationalists, or those who, while professing some kind of Christianity, deny its historical character.  It is maintained, on the other hand, that the religion of the Bible, instead of being mainly dogmatic, like other systems, is preeminently historical. It is the record of the divine dealings in the world.
lead_paragraph: It is the object of these Lectures to furnish an argument against the modern school of ideal rationalists, or those who, while professing some kind of Christianity, deny its historical character. It is maintained, on the other hand, that the religion of the Bible, instead of being mainly dogmatic, like other systems, is preeminently historical. It is the record of the divine dealings in the world. To a true faith, grounded on the higher plane of evidence, the Scriptures would thus become the key to all other history. The wonderful nation, and the wonderful church, explain all the other facts of the world. To such a faith questions of historical interest take the more rational, as well as the more reverent order. How does the Old Testament cast light upon the darkness of Egypt and Assyria? How does the New Testament make clear the problem of the Roman decline and the rise of the modern world?

abstract: FIRE IN A TENEMENT HOUSE. -- Yesterday about 11 A.M., a fire occurred in a house occupied by several families, at the foot of Bergen Hill, in Jersey City. The building was entirely consumed. It belonged to Mr. JACKSON, whose loss amounts to $1,500, upon which there was no insurance. An adjoining house was set on fire, but the flames were soon extinguished.

abstract: Rev. Dr. TYNG'S last letter on Sabbath-schools, in the Independent, dwells upon the importance of the office of instructor. He remarks: "I cannot speak or think of this agency as ever rivaling, or really separable from, the appointed ministry.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. TYNG'S last letter on Sabbath-schools, in the Independent, dwells upon the importance of the office of instructor. He remarks: "I cannot speak or think of this agency as ever rivaling, or really separable from, the appointed ministry. The teachers of my schools seem to me to be but parts of myself. Like the fingers of one of those beautiful power presses, they take up the very pages which I desire to impress, and smoothly and quietly spread them out before me, prepared to receive the blessed communications from on high which I long to stamp on their minds and hearts forever. When one surveys this tranquil but powerful operation, it is vain to compare the parts with each other in their relative importance. They must all be there, all proportionate, all adapted, all in order; and then the unseen, mysterious power applied, with its sure but imponderable energy, the result comes out, the happiness and the triumph of all. And who that stands to contemplate the glowing regularity and mysterious beauty of this work, would desire to go back to the single hand-press of the individual laborer, toiling, with far greater weariness, to accomplish but a small portion of the results."

abstract: The Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, with three days' later news from Europe. In the English House of Commons the consideration of the motion protesting against the annexation of Savoy to France had been postponed, on the ground that discussion at present would be prejudicial to the public service.
lead_paragraph: The Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, with three days' later news from Europe. In the English House of Commons the consideration of the motion protesting against the annexation of Savoy to France had been postponed, on the ground that discussion at present would be prejudicial to the public service. Lord JOHN RUSSELL stated that Austria and Prussia concurred in the views of England. Russia had not been heard from on the subject. The House of Commons voted an address to the Crown, approving the French treaty. It is rumored that since Sardinia rejected NAPOLEON's programme for Italy, the French troops have received orders to be ready to march at the first notice, and that the evacuation of Lombardy and the return of the army to France is threatened. The Bank of France had gained four and a half millions of francs during the month. The prominent topic with the newspapers was the Savoy question; but there is nothing new with regard to it. COUNT CAVOUR has written a long dispatch replying to the Italian programme, and pledging Sardinia to abide by the result of an appeal to universal suffrage. There were reports of an insurrection in Naples, but they lacked confirmation. Proposals had been made to the Porte by the Western Powers to assist in the maintenance of his rights in Servia and the Danubian Principalities, should any complications and an armed intervention occur there. It is said the Porte had requested a treaty of alliance with them for certain emergencies.

abstract: After all, journalism has its pleasures like other pursuits. If the unregenerate mind occasionally wearies of the work of recording commonplace events and criticizing commonplace characters; of analyzing the political prospects of insignificant dignitaries, and exposing the threadbare fallacies of incorrigible twaddlers, there still flash upon us, from time ...
lead_paragraph: After all, journalism has its pleasures like other pursuits. If the unregenerate mind occasionally wearies of the work of recording commonplace events and criticizing commonplace characters; of analyzing the political prospects of insignificant dignitaries, and exposing the threadbare fallacies of incorrigible twaddlers, there still flash upon us, from time to time, "glimpses that make us less forlorn of nonsense more sublime, gleams of an almost preternatural absurdity which it is at once a pleasure and a wonder to pursue. It is recorded of a certain celebrated naturalist, that he was so completely carried away by his zeal in the study of herpetology as to fill his wife's furred slippers with young snakes, for whom he could find no other abode so comfortable and so convenient. Nothing, of course, could be more un-conjugal, nothing more worthy of the severest reprobation, than such a proceeding as this. And yet we may as well confess at once to a lurking sympathy with this misguided devotee of science.

abstract: So long as the City Railroad bills before the Legislature ignore all those well-defined features which constitute the difference between a nuisance and a benefit--so long as the proposition is simply a railroad, it is to be hoped that they will be defeated. People talk about "a railroad," as if that were a specific term like a foot, or a degree of heat.
lead_paragraph: So long as the City Railroad bills before the Legislature ignore all those well-defined features which constitute the difference between a nuisance and a benefit--so long as the proposition is simply a railroad, it is to be hoped that they will be defeated. People talk about "a railroad," as if that were a specific term like a foot, or a degree of heat. Just so counting-room engineers talk about "a steam engine," as if that term defined the functions and value of the machine referred to, any more than does the simple phrase "a man" define at once the moral status of an alderman and a saint. If there is one proposition better defined and understood than other propositions, it is that a city railway, such, for instance, as the Fourth-avenue, as to track and all our City railways as to accommodations -- is a very great obstacle, and a source of enormous repair expenses to all common vehicles traversing the street; and that the system of furnishing the conditions of discomfort for the price of luxury, is both an unnecessary and an intolerable nuisance to the whole people. Let these schemes show their colors before we trust them. They may deal in palm-oil -- they are much more likely to be trading in ebony.

abstract: The American General Committee of this City has issued an address to the members of its party in this State, intended to rally them for the coming Presidential election. It rehearses the action of the party in 1856, and attributes its decline to the fact that it did not take an active and leading part in that contest, but avoided its issues and was content to hold a merely negative position.
lead_paragraph: The American General Committee of this City has issued an address to the members of its party in this State, intended to rally them for the coming Presidential election. It rehearses the action of the party in 1856, and attributes its decline to the fact that it did not take an active and leading part in that contest, but avoided its issues and was content to hold a merely negative position. It still thinks that the party is strong and influential, and calls upon its members everywhere to prepare for the coming election.

abstract: We have at last an intelligible, if not wholly satisfactory, explanation of the disgraceful condition in which the Worth Monument has been suffered to remain for so long a time. It seems that the contract for the erection of the Monument and railing was awarded by the Street Commissioner, after due advertisement, to J.B. & W.W. CORNELL. It was sent to the Common Council and remained unacted on for a period of nearly nine months. By the printed terms of every contract, if the award be not confirmed within 90 days the bidders are at liberty to withdraw their bids. The Messrs, CORNELL did not withdraw their bid, however, but consented to assume the contract, provided the Street Commissioner would grant a still further extension of time, to which he assented.
lead_paragraph: We have at last an intelligible, if not wholly satisfactory, explanation of the disgraceful condition in which the Worth Monument has been suffered to remain for so long a time. It seems that the contract for the erection of the Monument and railing was awarded by the Street Commissioner, after due advertisement, to J.B. & W.W. CORNELL. It was sent to the Common Council and remained unacted on for a period of nearly nine months. By the printed terms of every contract, if the award be not confirmed within 90 days the bidders are at liberty to withdraw their bids. The Messrs, CORNELL did not withdraw their bid, however, but consented to assume the contract, provided the Street Commissioner would grant a still further extension of time, to which he assented.

abstract: Prof. JOHN MCMULLEN, principal of the popular school for boys at No. 900 Broadway, delivered a public lecture last evening in the lecture-room of his Institute, upon the subject of "France and the French." The lecture was composed principally of reminiscences of travel in France, in which the geographical, historical and architectural features of the country, and the social manners and customs of the people, were sketched in a pleasant way, and to the evident delight and edification of a large audience of the pupils of the lecturer and their friends.

abstract: The admirers of MACAULAY will be edified by a letter, which we publish in another column, giving his opinions concerning our model Republic. It is a good deal more emphatic than complimentary. Mr. MACAULAY distrusts entirely the operation of universal suffrage, and predicts the most disastrous consequences from the attempt to carry on a Government upon that basis. His opinions are quite as decided, and quite as Anti-Democratic, as ALISON's, -- though he does not resort to the same perversions of fact to sustain them. We suspect this letter will abate considerably the enthusiasm which has pervaded the country for Mr. MACAULAY.

abstract: The theatres this week have been more remarkable for consistency than success. They have ad  hered to their programmes, and braved alike the weather and public indifference. At Wallack's Theatre, the "Romance of a Poor Young Man" has drawn the best houses. People who saw it on its production begin to take a fresh interest in its continued success, and desire to see it again.
lead_paragraph: The theatres this week have been more remarkable for consistency than success. They have ad hered to their programmes, and braved alike the weather and public indifference. At Wallack's Theatre, the "Romance of a Poor Young Man" has drawn the best houses. People who saw it on its production begin to take a fresh interest in its continued success, and desire to see it again. There are strangers, moreover, in the City, who cannot resist the [???]ascination of this modern instance of a lover's leap. At the Winter Garden Miss BAT[???]MAN still the attraction, and "Evangeline," the best produced play of the season, attracts a select class of admirers. Miss LAURA KEENE has remained true to Mr. BOURCICAULT's latest production, "Vanity Fair," notwithstanding the notable indifference of the public. An Irish drama from the prolific pen of the same writer is to be the next novelty. Something of the same sort will be produced on Monday by Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS at Niblo's Garden -- artists who enjoy the best patronage of the public, and defy the elements as successfully as they do criticism. The new play is called "Willie Riley, or Not Guilty," and is further described as a tale of Munster.

abstract: Europe is on the eve of another battle. The coming fight between SAYERS and HEENAM excites almost as much interest as did the war in Italy last Summer. Everybody here is on the tiptoe of anxiety. Arrangements are already made for steamers to land off Cape Race the earliest possible information of the result;--illustrated ...
lead_paragraph: Europe is on the eve of another battle. The coming fight between SAYERS and HEENAM excites almost as much interest as did the war in Italy last Summer. Everybody here is on the tiptoe of anxiety. Arrangements are already made for steamers to land off Cape Race the earliest possible information of the result;--illustrated newspapers publish pictorial representations of the drill and discipline by which the illustrious heroes of the affair put their forces upon a war footing; -- the topic is discussed in the British Parliament, -- grave journals canvass the subject as one of muscle rather than morality, -- and the whole matter is treated as if some grave point of national honor were involved in the issue.

abstract: I think it is no secret in England that Austria is arming upon an extensive scale, and that the preparations for war are unmistakable. Still the semiofficial papers are somewhat out of humor. Hearing that Sardinia increases her army, they actually attribute it to the madness or malice of Count CAVOUR; for if France should back Sardinia there will be no war, and if France does not, Sardinia will be crushed, whether she has 100,000 or 200,000 men under arms, whilst her armament ruins not only the Italians but forces Austria likewise to spend more money. All the court and military party reason in this way, and come to the conclusion that CAVOUR is the wickedest man on earth, who, seeing before him the complete downfall of his own country, maliciously puts Austria to great expense. Such are the men who rule this Empire.
lead_paragraph: I think it is no secret in England that Austria is arming upon an extensive scale, and that the preparations for war are unmistakable. All the court and military party reason in this way, and come to the conclusion that CAVOUR is the wickedest man on earth, who, seeing before him the complete downfall of his own country, maliciously puts Austria to great expense. Such are the men who rule this Empire.

abstract: Murders, like misfortunes, assuredly never come single. In addition to the particulars of the arrest and capture of the supposed murderer of the Captain and two of the crew of the oyster sloop E.A. Johnson, we publish below all that has thus far been ascertained of another mysterious affair on another similar vessel near this City, and of the singular conduct of a Chinaman, the sole survivor of the crew, who is suspected of having caused the death of the Captain and his brother. We have also an account of a terrible mutiny of a thousand Coolies on ship-board in mid-ocean; of their conflict with the crew, in which thirty of the former were killed and ninety wounded, and of their final submission.

abstract: We published on Saturday the conviction and sentence of JAMES S.WILLIAMS, for having taken from the Post-office a letter intended for another person, altered a check upon the Norwalk Bank which was inclosed in it, and received the money therefor. The testimony was purely circumstantial and presumptive except on one point,--that, namely, of the ...
lead_paragraph: We published on Saturday the conviction and sentence of JAMES S.WILLIAMS, for having taken from the Post-office a letter intended for another person, altered a check upon the Norwalk Bank which was inclosed in it, and received the money therefor. The testimony was purely circumstantial and presumptive except on one point,--that, namely, of the prisoner's identity with the person who called at the express office and received the money. Two witnesses swore positively that he was the man; -- but they had previously sworn, just as positively, that another man was the party who called, -- so that this point of the case cannot be considered entirely free from doubt. Nevertheless, WILLIAMS was convicted and sentenced to hard labor in the State Prison for eight years.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the North Atlantic Company's steamship Baltic, from Aspinwall on the 18th inst., we have interesting news from South America, Central America and California. The shipment of treasure by her was very small, on account, it is said, of the very large investments in the Washoe silver mines. It amounts to $895,000. The belligerents in Ecuador are resting on their arms, intending to renew the contest in May, when the rains have ceased. The Peruvian papers were jubilant over President BUCHANAN's expressed inability to redress the wrongs of American citizens in Peru. An attempted revolution in Arequipa had been speedily quelled. Politics, Indian massacres and mining news engrossed the Californian mind on the 5th inst., to which date we have advices from San Francisco.

The health of the ex-President of the United States being proposed, that gentleman made a very handsome and eloquent response, which is reported in full in the Nassau Guardian.

lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Board of Governors was held at 12 o'clock on Saturday. Present--Govs. B.F. Pinckney, Isaac J. Oliver, Chas. Brueninghausen, Anthony Dugro, Patrick G. Maloney, C. Godfrey Gunther and James Lynch. The President, B.F. PINCKNEY, said he had called a special meeting of the Board in reference to an article in the New-York Tribune of yesterday, reflecting severely upon all the members of the Board, and accusing them of malfeasance and gross immorality. If those charges were true, the Board ought to know it, and he thought it was their duty to adopt means to ferret out the matter and ascertain whether they were true or not. He was sorry that two members of the Board were unavoidably absent on account of sickness. In conclusion he offered the folio wing preamble and resolution:
