abstract: -- Mr. HOPE, well known as the gentleman who had so much difficulty with the New-York Bay Cemetery Company, in his investigations regarding the alleged violation of the grave of his own child, has recently become persuaded that the resting place of the child of Mr. OLIVER had also been disturbed. Accordingly, it was decided that Saturday morning all the parties interested should visit the cemeteries, and cause the bodies to be disinterred, in order, if possible, to set the matter right. Accompanying the party, was Dr. MORRIS, Mr. SPEER, undertaker in Jersey City; Mr. STEWARD, undertaker at No. 137 Grand-street, New-York; WM. H. GELLIFFE, counsel for Mr. YOST; Mr. WOOD, Superintendent of the New-York Bay Cemetery, and a number of others. On arriving at the Jersey City Cemetery, Mr. YOST declined to deliver the order for the exhuming of the coffin, without assigning any reason for so doing. Finally, the grave was opened, and upon removing the entire lid Mrs. OLIN and her husband at once exclaimed that that was their child, while Mr. and Mrs. YOST said the child was not theirs. Mrs. YOST, who is quite a large woman, thereupon became quite excited, and denounced Mr. HOPE in a vehement manner. The body was very much decomposed, and to all appearance had never been removed from the coffin from which it had first been placed. Dr. MORRIS and Mr. STEWARD were very positive that such was the case. The coffin was a white wood one, the same kind purchased by OLIN, and from which Mr. WOOD split a piece from the lid at the time Mr. YOST first caused the grave to be opened. The grave-digger says the grave has only been opened once since the interment, and that at the request of YOST, in order to procure a portion of the lid to be produced at the trial. The party then proceeded to New-York Bay Cemetery, and took from the vault another coffin, which was exhumed on Friday, and upon being opened YOST identified it beyond a doubt as that of his child.

abstract: -- Prof. CHARLIER delivers the third in his series of French lectures this evening at the Spingler Institute, -- upon Mad. RECARMIER et son salon. His second on Thursday evening, upon LAMARTINE, in spite of the extreme inclemency of the weather, drew a large and very intelligent audience. He gave a very spirited and interesting outline of LAMARTINE's life, and of his literary and political career. His picture of the princely style in which he traveled in the East, at an expense of two million francs, was very graphic and amusing. This series of lectures merits the attention of all who are at all interested in the language or literature of France.

lead_paragraph: EXPULSION OF A THEOLOGICAL STUDENT.--The friends of the Union Theological Seminary will regret to hear of the expulsion, on Saturday, of a member of the middle class, for the offence of forgery. Not forgery for the purpose of obtaining money, but for the purpose of gaining admission to the Seminary. The offender, while at the Princeton Theological Seminary some months since, conducted himself in such a manner as to merit the censure of the officers of the Institution, and when he applied for letters of recommendation to another institution, he was denied them. But he presented a letter, over the signature of Dr. MCGILL, of Princeton, to the Union Theological Seminary, and was admitted. Some dishonorable transactions alleged against him came to the ears of the Faculty, and they began to inquire into the young man's antecedents. They found that, so far from having sustained a good character where he had been well known, he was considered to be "bad at heart," and that his "letters" were forgeries. Consequently, Dr. ROBINSON, in the presence of Dr. SMITH and all the students of the Seminary, read the decision of the Faculty that Mr. JAMIESON be expelled. This announcement, as might have been expected, was the occasion of deep sorrow to all the listeners, but the deliberateness with which the sin was committed left no room for sympathy for the unfortunate man. All regard the punishment as deserved and timely.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 9th, Lord J. RUSSELL said -- Mhe noble lord the member for Durham (Lord A.V. TEMPEST) has put to me some questions on a subject of great public interest, and I feel bound to give him such information as I am able in reply to those questions. He asks me if I have taken any steps -- and if to, what the nature of those steps is -- to obtain the concurrence of Austria, Prussia and Russia in protesting against the rumored annexation of Savoy to France. Now, the course which we have adopted in that respect has been to communicate the correspondence which has taken place between her Majesty's Government and that of France on the subject to the Courts of Berlin, Vienna and St. Petersburg. I may add that we contented ourselves with simply communicating that correspondence, and desiring that a copy of it should be handed to the Governments of each of those countries respectively, without asking them to take any steps or to make any suggestion in the matter, but leaving them to adopt such a course as they might deem expedient on a question which is of importance to the interests of Europe. [Hear, hear.] With respect to the probable result of this proceeding I am quite unable to supply the noble lord with any information beyond this, that the Ministers for Foreign Affairs both at Vienna and Berlin say that they agree generally with the views of her Majesty's Government on this subject. Neither at Berlin nor Vienna, however, is it absolutely stated what steps their respective Governments propose to take in a matter which certainly requires careful consideration. From St. Petersburg I have received no account with regard to it, probably because the dispatch which we sent there was not forwarded so soon as those which were sent to Vienna and Berlin. I may at the same time observe that when any information in answer to the dispatch which we forwarded to St. Petersburg reaches us, we shall be prepared to lay it on the table the moment it is in a state to be thus communicated to the House. We shall, I may add, have some correspondence from Berlin and Vienna to lay on the table on Monday. The noble lord has asked me further whether we are acquainted with the final intentions of Sardinia in reference to the annexation of Savoy to France. Now, in answer to that question, I may state that I had placed in my hands, by a private friend of Count CAVOUR, a document which was said to be a copy of the Sardinian reply to the proposal of France, but I have been since informed that this document is not quite correct, and therefore I cannot, until I receive further information on the subject from Her Majesty's Minister in Turin, lay on the table any paper in reference to this particular point. I may, however, observe that the substance of the reply of Count CAVOUR is to the effect that, if the Parliament of Sardinia should deem it expedient to have re[???]ourse to a vote of the people of Savoy with respect to the question of its annexation to France, the Sardinian Government would take care that that vote should be taken with every form of liberty, so that the people of Savoy might exercise perfect freedom of choice in deciding whether they would continue under the Sardinian Government or prefer a separation from that country. The answer of Count CAVOUR then proceeds to state that, should the people of Savoy be in favor of separation, the Government of Sardinia trusts the question will be duly weighed by the other Powers of Europe, and that care will be taken not only of the interests of Switzerland, but due regard will be paid to the security of the frontiers of the Kingdom of Sardinia itself. So far as Switzerland is concerned, I believe the views of the Government of that country upon this subject remain quite unchanged, as the dispatches which I hope to be able to lay on the table on Monday will prove. [Hear, hear.]

abstract: -- The election in Connecticut excites an unusual degree of interest. Both parties attach a remarkable importance to the result -- not, of course, from any important issues pending there, but on account of its bearing upon the Presidential contest next Fall. Thus far the State elections have been very discouraging for the Democrats. They all indicate the total failure of the attempt that was made to alarm the country immediately after the affair at Harper's Ferry, and show that in spite of the excitement created by that invasion, the Republicans have actually gained strength. The New-Hampshire contest was especially significant, because the Democrats had confidently looked to that State for something like a reaction.

lead_paragraph: Information was received on Saturday of the probable murder of Capt. LEETE, of the sloop Spray, of Guilford, Conn., and his brother, by a Chinaman called JOHN LOWE, who was employed as cook on board the vessel. By a most singular series of coincidences, this last tragedy is believed to have occurred at about the same time, in very nearly the same latitude, and probably with the same object as prompted the murders on board the E.A. Johnson, and to make the analogy complete, the Spray came into collision with the sloop Lucinda, of Rockaway, L.I., as the E.A. Johnson did with the schooner John B. Mather.

abstract: -- The American public will be gratified with the announcement that JOHN LATHROP MOTLEY, author of the History of the Dutch Republic, has been elected Corresponding Member of the French Institute, in the place of the lamented PRESCOTT. In philosophical analysis, in clearness and vigor of style, and in learning and research, MOTLEY stands in the front rank of living historians, and perhaps no work which has issued from the press of this country has been received with more favor or elicited higher encomiums abroad than this history of our learned and accomplished countryman.

lead_paragraph: Just before midnight on Saturday, Wm. Cummings, a liquor-dealer in East Twenty-sixth-street, was arrested in Hamilton-avenue, near Columbia-street, for having discharged a pistol at one Peter Farrell. Cummings was apprehended, when he stated that he was just returning from Gowanus, where he had been to attend a raffle, and on passing down the avenue alone, on his way home, having been assailed by Farrell and a number of men who accompanied him, he had discharged the pistol in self-defence. This statement was not deemed satisfactory, so the prisoner was handed into the custody of an officer of the Third Precinct, who took him to the Station-house. Farrell and his party were allowed to depart.

abstract: PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY.--The fourth Concert of this Association for the promotion of agreeable gallantry took place on Saturday evening, and was talked through in a thoroughly satisfactory manner. The attendance was fuller than usual, which may be ascribed to the weather or the programme, according to the taste of the reader. BEETHOVEN'S second Symphony opened the Concert, and its quaint beauties ...
lead_paragraph: PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY.--The fourth Concert of this Association for the promotion of agreeable gallantry took place on Saturday evening, and was talked through in a thoroughly satisfactory manner. The attendance was fuller than usual, which may be ascribed to the weather or the programme, according to the taste of the reader. BEETHOVEN'S second Symphony opened the Concert, and its quaint beauties were very ably interpreted by the orchestra under Mr. BEEGMANN's direction. A composition by LISZT, called "Tasso," and further described as a Poeme Symphonique, was the attraction of the second part. Like everything else that LISZT has ever written, it is filled with startling effects, displaying rare knowledge of how to produce them. Beyond this technical recommendation and a borrowed theme, we could detect nothing worthy of remembrance. A well informed orchestra might improvise a similar composition, but how a well-informed orchestra can endure such deliberate non-sequences as a matter of choice, surpasses our comprehension. We can account for it only on the ground that any new combination of instrumental effects becomes pleasing after a certain amount of familiarity. The work, considering its excessive tediousness, was well performed. It fell flat, however, on the audience. WEBER's overture to "Der Freyschutz" concluded the concert.

abstract: The progress of events has gradually eliminated all other elements from the great problem of Italian nationality, and left the claims of Austria face to face with the positions of Sardinia. England has avowed herself the friend, if not the champion, of popular sovereignty in the Peninsula; and while she clamors, through ...
lead_paragraph: The progress of events has gradually eliminated all other elements from the great problem of Italian nationality, and left the claims of Austria face to face with the positions of Sardinia. England has avowed herself the friend, if not the champion, of popular sovereignty in the Peninsula; and while she clamors, through not the least considerable of her public organs, for the maintenance of the treaties of 1815 in Savoy, as indispensable to the peace of Europe, has resigned those treaties beyond the Alps to the tides of time and change. Russia and Prussia have given the clearest indications of their determination to acquiesce in, if not to adopt, the attitude of England. France has approved that attitude, but avails herself of her close connection with the leading power of Italy to suggest the programme which her Emperor thinks it desirable that Italy should carry out in establishing her liberty and her independence.

abstract: The intolerable wrong of charging the people of this City for sitting and elbow-room, for light and air, and then jamming them like cattle into dirty pens, for the purpose of enriching jobbers and speculators, is but half the story of our City locomotion. Any body but a Gothamite would think remedying this worth one ...
lead_paragraph: The intolerable wrong of charging the people of this City for sitting and elbow-room, for light and air, and then jamming them like cattle into dirty pens, for the purpose of enriching jobbers and speculators, is but half the story of our City locomotion. Any body but a Gothamite would think remedying this worth one earnest and general effort -- the sacrifice of a little precious business time. But the second nuisance is a sacrifice of precious business time; and as it is exaggerated by the yearly upward movement of residential quarters, the key note of our driving, hurrying, restless American character will be struck, and we may hope for reform. It will soon require double the time now occupied to reach the centre of dwellings from the centre of business. An hour's ride, wedged in a City rail-car, without room enough to open a newspaper, and the reeking air of side streets to breathe withal -- think of it! The New-Jersey monopoly will carry us twenty miles an hour, with defined and incompressible sitting space and under comparative circumstances of Oriental luxury, far into the quiet and wholesome country. If we are to travel by the hour, let us by all means seek green pastures, ample seats, heat, light, air and a show of decency. Could one even read or converse -- could one even exist without annoyance, uncompressed and in a normal posture, warmed in Winter and cooled in Summer, an hour's ride to the Central Park region would not be intolerable. But slow speed and long distances, superadded to present inconveniences, and all this without reduction of fares, or a diminution of taxes by the selling of these money-coining grants to the companies, is rather more than even the State Government can expect to saddle upon us. To render this semidiurnal penance of getting to business and back tolerable -- barely tolerable -- two new features are indispensable: more railroads and better accommodations. New-York groans for more and better railroads. Look at Broadway, with its tangled mesh of creeping omnibuses and its side-walks full of merchandise, garbage-boxes, stumbling-blocks and abominations; look at our few railroads, with their portable pens, more like the holds of slave-ships than the metropolitan conveyances of decent citizens -- and our business and our houses separated by this inevitable Styx. How long shall we enrich the remorseless Charon, and appease his many-mouthed Cerberus?

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. -- Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS -- who deservedly rank as the most agreeable artists now on the American stage -- regaled their patrons last night with a new piece. Being Irish, it involved, necessarily, a question of rent, and the entire train of dire consequences which result from not paying it. Beyond the usual conditions of extreme virtue in the non-paying tenant, and excessive brutality on the part of the unpaid landlord, we were unable to detect any striking point in the construction of the play, which, we may here place on record, is called "Willie O'Riley." The author has succeeded, however, in carrying the "agony" to an extreme point, and in obtaining thereby a succession of good situations. The dialogue, without any pretensions to literary excellence, is piquant from its strong and amusing Hibernicisms. Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS are of course supplied with excellent parts, and it is superfluous to add that they interpret them admirably. The remaining characters are sufficiently filled, and afford no opportunity for further notice. The piece was quite successful.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO'S GARDEN. -- Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS -- who deservedly rank as the most agreeable artists now on the American stage -- regaled their patrons last night with a new piece. abstract: G. -- It is delightful to notice the unanimity and fervor with which the Sunday papers applaud Gov. MORGAN's veto of the bill concerning Sunday amusements. They all concur in the opinion that he is the most upright, independent and excellent Chief Magistrate our State has had for a great many years. We trust they will be equally unanimous and emphatic in approving his signature of the bill now on its way through the Legislature, for the substantial attainment of the same end. They have not overlooked, we trust, the grounds on which his veto was based, as they are set forth in the Message.

abstract: ALBERT W. HICKS, alias WM. JOHNSON, the supposed murderer of the Captain and crew of the oyster-sloop E.A. Johnson, was taken from the Second Ward Station-house, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and conveyed in a carriage to the United States Marshal's office, preparatory to his being handed over to the United States authorities. Capt. WEED deceived the
lead_paragraph: ALBERT W. HICKS, alias WM. JOHNSON, the supposed murderer of the Captain and crew of the oyster-sloop E.A. Johnson, was taken from the Second Ward Station-house, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and conveyed in a carriage to the United States Marshal's office, preparatory to his being handed over to the United States authorities. Capt. WEED deceived the numbers who had gathered about the Station-house, and who, in the excitement of the moment, gave utterance to threats of violence against the prisoner, by removing him in a carriage from the rear of the building, while another vehicle, placed in front of the door, with a number of policemen keeping a passage-way in front of it, gave ground for the belief that the prisoner would leave that way. As soon as the ruse was discovered, which was not until half an hour after it had been carried into effect, the crowd added itself to that which had already gathered around the Marshal's office. All manifested the utmost eagerness to get a glimpse at the alleged culprit. He was conducted into the main office of the Marshal, where he remained for an hour and a half, during which time scores of persons were permitted to enter and gratify their curiosity by looking at the criminal, but no one held any conversation with him. He sat handcuffed in one corner of the room, and met the scrutinizing gaze of his multitude of visitors without betraying the slightest emotion of any kind. In fact he did not appear from his actions to be conscious that he was any more the object of curiosity than any one else in the crowd. He is not vicious-looking, and the universal expression of those who see him, for the first time, is that of disappointment in finding so "good-looking a man," when they expected to behold a monster.

lead_paragraph: We hay received a copy of the testimony taken by the Printing Committee in the House of Representatives, of which Hon. Mr. HASKIN is Chairman, concerning the manner in which the public money paid, out for Executive and Congressional printing is used. The testimony is very voluminous, and much of it, relating merely to matters of detail, is of very little general interest. We extract from the evidence given sundry portions which show how systematically the public money is used for party purposes, -- how the PRESIDENT himself, and the members of his Cabinet, have directed appropriations of the public funds to the support of party journals, and to electing members of Congress in doubtful districts:

abstract: Us? -- It is stated that as soon as the Spaniards captured Tetuan, they made the inhabitants clean the streets! The thing had not been done before for years. The Common Council, we presume, had pretended to do it, -- large sums of money had been levied annually on the population ostensibly for that purpose, and still the streets were full of filth -- muddy in wet weather, dusty in dry, and intolerably noisome, unhealthy and offensive at all times. The first result of their being conquered will be the luxury of clean streets. Will not the Spaniards, Mexicans, Moors, or some other barbarians, march an army into New-York? Clean streets would be cheaply purchased at the price of a conquest.
lead_paragraph: Us? -- It is stated that as soon as the Spaniards captured Tetuan, they made the inhabitants clean the streets! The thing had not been done before for years. The Common Council, we presume, had pretended to do it, -- large sums of money had been levied annually on the population ostensibly for that purpose, and still the streets were full of filth -- muddy in wet weather, dusty in dry, and intolerably noisome, unhealthy and offensive at all times. The first result of their being conquered will be the luxury of clean streets. Will not the Spaniards, Mexicans, Moors, or some other barbarians, march an army into New-York? Clean streets would be cheaply purchased at the price of a conquest.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to facilitate communication between the Atlantic and Pacific States was called up. It was so amended as to take from the Company which shall be organized under its provisions the power of interfering with the right to locate a railroad by preempting all the lands on the route of the proposed telegraph line, and by providing that no payment shall be made to the Company by Government...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to facilitate communication between the Atlantic and Pacific States was called up. It was so amended as to take from the Company which shall be organized under its provisions the power of interfering with the right to locate a railroad by preempting all the lands on the route of the proposed telegraph line, and by providing that no payment shall be made to the Company by Government until the line is in operation, and that it shall cease when the contractors fail in their contract. The Consular Appropriation bill was amended so as to provide that $175,600 of the appropriation for the relief and protection of American seamen shall be used in the present fiscal year; an amendment appropriating $15,000 for a Minister to Paraguay was rejected and the bill was passed. The bill to authorize the sale of public arms to the several States and Territories, and to regulate the appointment of Superintendents of the National Armories, was passed (28 to 18.) In the House, bills withdrawing the protection of Congress from non-resident landholders; appropriating $75,000 for improving Buffalo harbor; fixing and regulating the duty on imports; repealing the Fugitive Slave law of 1850; and enabling citizens of the United States to carry their property freely and without molestation into Kansas, were referred. The Committee on Commerce was instructed to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill making an appropriation for a steam revenue cutter for the Delaware River. Resolutions requesting the President to open negotiations with the leading Powers of Europe with the view of declaring the Slave-trade piracy, were introduced and referred. Mr. MCQUEEN, of South Carolina, offered a resotion instructing the Committee on Ways and Means to report a measure for relieving the Massachusetts shoemakers "from the tyranny of the capitalists of that State." To this Mr. BLAKE, of Ohio, responded with a preamble and resolution, declaring "the chatteling of mankind" notoriously a reproach to our country, and instructing the Committee on the Judiciary to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill interdicting Slavery wherever Congress has power to legislate upon it. Amid great confusion it was rejected.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. -- At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, the report in favor of giving the right of way over Flatbush and Fifth avenues to Thirty-ninth-street, with a branch through Third-street to the City line, to the Brooklyn and Jamaica Railroad Company, with permission to lay rails and run horse-cars thereon, under similar regulations as those under which the grant was given to the City Company, was adopted. The report in favor of giving the right of way to the same Company from Fourth-avenue, through Hanson-place, Green, Bedford and Gates avenues to Broadway, was laid over for one week. A report in favor of advertising for proposals for the South Fourth, Fourth and South Seventh-street road was adopted. The Water Committee presented a long report, with a list of water rates, which was made the special order for next Friday evening, to which time the Board adjourned. The Committee report in favor of rates in the main the same as those adopted by the Croton Board in New-York, for private houses and stores, but a much less rate for manufacturing establishments. At the conclusion of the regular business, the Board went into secret session on the Ferry question.

abstract: Owen Downs and Thomas Riley, little boys, were found in the street by an officer, late on Sunday evening, so drunk that they could not stand. Some scoundrels had induced them to enter the liquor-store of one Bigelow, in Fifteenth-street, near First-avenue, and forced them to drink. Bigelow was arrested, but denied that he participated in the outrage. The boys were sent to Bellevue Hospital, and the physician under whose charge they were placed pronounced Riley in great danger.

abstract: All day yesterday the excitement concerning the sloop Spray, of Guilford, Conn., and the mysterious fate of her captain and his brother, continued to increase. The vessel, which had been hauled into shoal water inside the Battery wall, was visited by crowds of persons, who were curious to learn everything which would tend to throw light upon the affair. A force of Harbor Policemen preserved order, and prevented the people from crowding on to the sloop's deck while the investigations were going on. Several personal acquaintances of Capt. LEETE, and of his brothers, from among the crews of the market vessels, came to look at the wreck. While the tide was falling the police examined the cabin of the sloop, which was still under water. With a boat-hook they fished out from the berths various articles, such as clothing, bedding, coils of rigging, &c. Among them was a white cotton shirt, which was much stained with something red, but there was a difference of opinion as to whether it was blood or iron-rust. A gray woolen under-shirt was found with thick red stains near the neck, which, when it was pressed, came off on to the hand, and might have been blood. Soon a bed-tick came up. It had been filled with feathers, but they had been washed out. On this tick, near one end, were conspicuous stains as of blood a foot or more in circumference. Shortly afterwards a white cotton under bed-tick was recovered, which had large bloody spots in various places. The discovery of these articles removed all doubts that a murder had been committed, and it seemed apparent that the bloody deed had been stealthily perpetrated while the victims were in their berths. A laborious search was made in every part of the vessel which could be reached for the dead bodies, which it was supposed might be below, but no traces of them were found. The bloody bed-clothing was taken to the office of the Harbor Police to be dried. The public curiosity having thus been satisfied, and the seeming evidences of crime brought to light, the eager crowd gradually dispersed, and left the Harbor Police in possession of the vessel. She is an old-fashioned sloop of about 40 tons burden, with a flush deck, and a cabin which is entered from abaft. The bowsprit, mast and boom are gone, and fragments of the mainsail, jib, and rigging, are scattered over the deck, with two or three barrels, and coils of rope, one of which is of new Manilla. Her port bow has been badly stove by the collision with the Lucinda.

abstract: Legal questions of interest, if not of difficulty will doubtess arise upon the trial of Johnson, alias HICKS, now in prison, on charge of having murdered Capt. BURR at sea. The idea is very common, that there can be no conviction for murder unless the body of the killed be found. It is true there is a rule that no person should be convicted in the absence of the body; and a...
lead_paragraph: Legal questions of interest, if not of difficulty will doubtess arise upon the trial of Johnson, alias HICKS, now in prison, on charge of having murdered Capt. BURR at sea. The idea is very common, that there can be no conviction for murder unless the body of the killed be found. It is true there is a rule that no person should be convicted in the absence of the body; and a very great English Judge once said: "I would never convict any person of murder or manslaughter, unless the fact was proved to be done, or the body be found dead." But this must be taken with qualification; and the circumstances may be sufficiently strong to show the fact of the murder, though the body has never been found. Thus, where a prisoner, a mariner named CLARK, was indicted in England for the murder of his captain at sea, and a witness stated that the prisoner had proposed to kill the captain; that the witness, being afterwards alarmed in the night by a violent noise, went upon deck, and there observed the prisoner take the captain up and throw him overboard into the sea, and that he was not seen or heard of afterwards; that near the place on the deck where the captain was seen, a billet of wood was found; and that the deck and part of the prisoner's dress were stained with blood, -- the Court, though admitting the general rule of law, left it to the jury to say, upon the evidence, whether the deceased was not killed before his body was cast into the sea; and the jury being of that opinion, the prisoner was convicted, and -- the conviction being approved of by all the judges -- was afterwards executed.

abstract: California may as well adopt at once for her escutcheon that famous shield in the good old story over which two gallant knights fought to the death, the one maintaining it to be a shield of gold, the other as stoutly asserting it to be a shield of silver. The name of EI Dorado will no longer answer as the sole synonym for...
lead_paragraph: California may as well adopt at once for her escutcheon that famous shield in the good old story over which two gallant knights fought to the death, the one maintaining it to be a shield of gold, the other as stoutly asserting it to be a shield of silver. The name of EI Dorado will no longer answer as the sole synonym for the first star of our Pacific empire; and San Francisco, according to present appearances, will soon be challenging the right of Buenos Ayres to be considered as the chief of Argentine cities. The news by the Baltic assures us that the wonders of Washoe have passed to the "order of the day," even with the prosperous gold miners of the Sacramento; and that the people of California have really fallen into the incipient stages of a silver fever, which threatens to throw them afresh off the balance upon which they had gradually settled down since speculation gave way to serious enterprise in the auriferous regions of the State.

abstract: WM. HICKEY, who was stabbed on Friday night, in an encounter at the porter-house of WM. DUNNIGAN, corner of Carlisle and West streets, died early yesterday morning. It appeared from the testimony given at the inquest held by Coroner SCHKIMER, that the death of the deceased was caused by DUNNIGAN, and a verdict was rendered accordingly. The accused, who said he had stabbed HICKEY in self defence, was locked up. JOHN KEVIN, who was stabbed in the same melec, probably will not survive.

abstract: The Young Men's National Union Club held a large meeting last night in the Cooper Institute. By way of preface to the proceedings within the hall, (those without consisting of a profuse display of sky-rockets and blazing tar-barrels,) a ...
lead_paragraph: The Young Men's National Union Club held a large meeting last night in the Cooper Institute. The building was quite full, though from certain occasional hisses it could hardly be inferred that those present were all of one mind on the questions discussed. By way of preface to the proceedings within the hall, (those without consisting of a profuse display of sky-rockets and blazing tar-barrels,) a gentleman on the platform called for three cheers for the Seventh Regiment Band, to which the assemblage gave an almost unanimous response. When the cheering had ceased, the band played Hail Columbia and a pot-pourri of well known airs, which were vehemently encored.

They submitted also the testimony they have taken on the subject, upon which their report is based. We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES sundry extracts from this testimony, which throw some light upon the manner in which this branch of the public service is managed.

abstract: Two nights of last week I spent in the heart of China. It cost but $1 a night to get there, and no worse penalties than the perpetual suspicion of fleas ever since, and a horrid din in the ears. A noted company of Chinese dramatists came to town,  and for their performances took the rickety, rathaunted, weather-stained old Union Theatre, on Commercial-street.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Monday, March. 5, 1860.

abstract: JOHN CRUMMINS, who is under sentence of death for the murder of DENIS McHENRY, is to be executed next Friday, unless Gov. MORGAN should again respite him. Of this, however, there is little hope as the Sheriff last week received a communication from the Executive, in which he declined to interfere with the sentence. CRUMMINS seems to realize keenly his unfortunate situation, and does not look composedly ...
lead_paragraph: JOHN CRUMMINS, who is under sentence of death for the murder of DENIS McHENRY, is to be executed next Friday, unless Gov. MORGAN should again respite him. Of this, however, there is little hope as the Sheriff last week received a communication from the Executive, in which he declined to interfere with the sentence. CRUMMINS seems to realize keenly his unfortunate situation, and does not look composedly upon his impending doom. He tells his visitors, who are very numerous, the same story with reference to the murder, that the related in Court, when his sentence was pronounced. The circumstances, as developed by the testimony, showed that MCHENRY, who bore a very bad reputation, came to CRUMMINS' house and insulted his wife. An altercation ensuing, CRUMMINS pursued his opponent into the street with a musket, and then returned to his house. MCHENRY soon came back and resumed his insulting language, which so exasperated CRUMMINS that he threw a weight at his head, the deceased resenting the attack by throwing stones at him, CRUMMINS finally rushed upon MCHENRY, and stabbed him three times with a sword, while he lay prostrate on the ground, having fallen in his attempt to elude his pursuer, and these wounds resulted in his death. CRUMMINS asserts that he committed the act in the heat of passion, without being conscious at the time of its performance. He is represented as having always borne a good character, being of a peaceable disposition, but easily excited. Earnest efforts are in progress to secure a commutation of his sentence by the Governor, or at least a further reprieve, and a petition for this object, bearing many influential names, was carried to Albany last evening by a deputation of citizens. Since the prisoner's incarceration in the Tombs he has won the good opinion of his keepers by his uniform good behavior. The wife of the unfortunate man, with her little boy, spends nearly all her time with him.

abstract: No further discoveries were made on board the sloop Spray yesterday, and nothing transpired that was calculated to throw any additional light upon the mystery. A crowd, not so large as on the previous day, remained on the Battery all day long viewing the wreck. The Harbor Police still have charge of it.
lead_paragraph: No further discoveries were made on board the sloop Spray yesterday, and nothing transpired that was calculated to throw any additional light upon the mystery. A crowd, not so large as on the previous day, remained on the Battery all day long viewing the wreck. The Harbor Police still have charge of it. It was understood that the United States Marshal would have the vessel hauled up and examined, but no order to that effect has yet been given. The tide ebbs and flows through the large hole in the bow of the sloop. It is not probable that any further traces of the crime will be discovered, and it is certain that there are no dead bodies on board of her.

BURR and of the brothers WATTS. The officers set out early in the morning in a small boat, but the water was so very rough that after skirting the ...
lead_paragraph: A search along the shores of the harbor and bay from Red Hook Point as far as two miles southeast of Coney Island, was yesterday prosecuted by Officers WHITNEY and McINTYRE, of the Harbor Police, with the hope of discovering the bodies of Capt. BURR and of the brothers WATTS. The officers set out early in the morning in a small boat, but the water was so very rough that after skirting the shore as far as Bay Ridge, they abandoned that mode of conveyance, and performed the remainder of their journey on foot. Calling at every house on their route, they explained the object of their visit, and obtained from the fishermen a promise that they would be vigilant in watching for the bodies. At Gravesend Bay they secured a black cloth cap, trimmed with fur, that had been washed ashore a day or two ago. Mr. SNEDICOR, who resides at Gravesend Bay, told them that the E.A. Johnson had anchored there on the Saturday previous to the commission of the murders and that he believed the cap was the same that Capt. BURR wore on that occasion. At the Point Comfort House, on the South side of Coney Island, the officers also obtained from FRANCIS ANTONI and EDWARD ROACH a low-crowned tarpaulin hat and another cloth cap, which had been picked up on the beach, last Saturday morning. A canvas money-bag, marked on one side "Mechanics and Farmers' Bank, Albany, $4,000, gold," and on the reverse "Mercantile Bank, New-York, $4,000," was likewise found near the articles mentioned. This bag is stained with finger-prints, which strongly resemble blood stains. Sergeant BREVOORT, in whose charge these articles were placed, proposes to renew the search to-day. Towards night-fall, the body of a man was seen floating through Buttermilk Channel, and three boats of the Harbor Police were sent to secure it, but darkness coming on they were not successful. It is thought that it may have been the body of either the Captain of the sloop Spray or his brother, who, it is supposed, were murdered up the Sound, and which it is quite likely by this time may have floated down to the harbor.

abstract: There appears to be a movement on foot to prepare a reception in this country for the Prince of WALES, whose visit to Canada seems now to be fully arranged. That he will leave America without entering the United States, seems very unlikely; and though his extreme youth renders it very improbable that any judgment he will form about the country or the...
lead_paragraph: There appears to be a movement on foot to prepare a reception in this country for the Prince of WALES, whose visit to Canada seems now to be fully arranged. That he will leave America without entering the United States, seems very unlikely; and though his extreme youth renders it very improbable that any judgment he will form about the country or the Government will be very correct, or of very great importance, still, in view of the position he is destined one day to occupy, it is desirable that any impressions he carries away with him, either of us or of our ways, should be at least pleasant. "Distinguished foreigners," "illustrious personages," and notorieties of all kinds, have always met with such a very fair share of public attention amongst us, that a recommendation that the Prince should not be allowed to steal through the country unobserved would be superfluous on its face. That there will be an immense host of volunteers for the arduous service of chaperoning him, and toadying him, and speechifying to him, and entertaining him, and taking him to church, there is no doubt whatever. And that he will leave us thoroughly convinced of the arrant stupidity of his great grandfather is also quite certain. If all that he needs is to be satisfied that we wish him well, and are free, prosperous and happy, he might therefore be safely left to the tender mercies of the great army of irregulars, whom we throw out en tirailleur, to harass the flank, and follow up the rear of all foreigners who cross our borders, with the slightest claims to celebrity.
headline: {'main': 'A True Prince Coming!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A True Prince Coming!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Hatters' Bank vs. Daniel Burnum.--This was an action by the plaintiff, a banking corporation, located in the village of Bethel, Danbury County, Conn., upon a draft made by the defendant on the 10th of January, 1854, for $1,200, payable at the Knickerbocker Bank, of this City, at sight. The plaintiff alleges that the check was not paid upon presentation, but was refused, and that it was drawn by the ...
lead_paragraph: The Hatters' Bank vs. Daniel Burnum.--This was an action by the plaintiff, a banking corporation, located in the village of Bethel, Danbury County, Conn., upon a draft made by the defendant on the 10th of January, 1854, for $1,200, payable at the Knickerbocker Bank, of this City, at sight. The plaintiff alleges that the check was not paid upon presentation, but was refused, and that it was drawn by the defendant fraudulently, he well knowing that he had no funds in the Knickerbocker Bank at the time. From this complaint the whole matter of controversy seemed to arise, merely from the non-payment of an ordinary check in the usual course of business; but when the defendant's answer came to be read, a new face was given to the transaction.

abstract: After much meditation, we have resolved to turn traitors to our country. We espouse the muscular cause and honor of England. We hope that the "American Champion," who has been beaten, will be handsomely thrashed by the "English Champion," who hasn't. We trust that JOHN C. HEENAN--without being very badly hurt--will be utterly routed and discomfited ...
lead_paragraph: After much meditation, we have resolved to turn traitors to our country. We espouse the muscular cause and honor of England. We hope that the "American Champion," who has been beaten, will be handsomely thrashed by the "English Champion," who hasn't. We trust that JOHN C. HEENAN--without being very badly hurt--will be utterly routed and discomfited by TOM SAYERS. Not that we have any animosity towards Mr. HEENAN -- whom, indeed, we have not the pleasure of knowing -- nor that we are hostile to the institutions, the honor and good name of our free and glorious Republic. On the contrary, like many men before us, we abandon our country only for our country's good. It is not that we love HEENAN less, but our country more, that we pray to have him flogged. For we are satisfied that, great as may be the self-denial, the substantial well-being of the Republic demands the sacrifice.

lead_paragraph: Judge BRONSON has furnished the Corporation with a long protest against the City Railroad bills now before the Legislature. It denounces them, in common with several other schemes now in progress at Albany, as the handiwork of hungry men who intend to live by their wits, and considers their adoption by the Legislature tantamount to a declaration that this City is incapable of self-government.

abstract: -- In a cave, near Penfield, Georgia, they have recently discovered the remains of three different species of bear, together with the bones and teeth of the hyena in abundance. The discovery is not alone of interest to naturalists, but furnishes also a hint of the probable support on which Congressional fillibusters from the South depend, when they speak with such confidence of their martial strength, in the event of a forcible collision between North and South. When CADMUS sewed dragon's teeth in classic soil, armed men sprang forth, and the sower reaped a warlike harvest. Our Southern neighbors seem inclined to imitate his husbandry.

lead_paragraph: The worst fears of the Marquis of NORMANBY, Mr. DISRAELI, Earl GREY, Mr. KINGLAKE, and other illustrious alarmists in the British Parliament, have been fully realized. Sardinia, we are assured, has deliberately consented to entertain the question of the cession of Nice and Savoy; and France, if the people of the French Alps have chosen so to will it, has doubtless ere this time taken decisive steps towards recovering her natural frontiers. The loudest organs of what is still facetiously called the Conservative Party in Great Britain will find it difficult, we imagine, to furnish forth a more tremendous note of woe over the accomplishment of this deed, than they have already lavished upon the mere suggestion that it had entered into the head of NAPOLEON III. to attempt it.

abstract: The Presidential cauldron is beginning to bubble in earnest. The heat and earnestness with which the State elections in Connecticut and Rhode Island are contested, indicate the profound interest felt in the approaching campaign. The Democratic Party is putting forth, every possible effort to secure these States,-- feeling satisfied, apparently, that unless they ...
lead_paragraph: The Presidential cauldron is beginning to bubble in earnest. The heat and earnestness with which the State elections in Connecticut and Rhode Island are contested, indicate the profound interest felt in the approaching campaign. The Democratic Party is putting forth, every possible effort to secure these States,-- feeling satisfied, apparently, that unless they can carry one of them at least, they may as well abandon all hope of succeeding in the great campaign of next Fall. Men and money are accordingly poured into those two little States without stint. The ablest orators of both parties are in the field, -- meetings are held every day and night in the principal towns and villages, -- a close canvass of the votes on both sides has been made, and each party seems sanguine of the result.

abstract: A 3  o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in ALLEN  MCDOUGALL'S ropewalk, on Waltonstreet, near Harrison-avenue, which, owing to the high wind prevailing at the time, was soon entirely enveloped in flames, and spread to adjoining property. The ropewalk was a frame building, two stories high, and about 900 feet long, extending the whole distance from Marcy to Harrison avenue.
lead_paragraph: A 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in ALLEN MCDOUGALL'S ropewalk, on Waltonstreet, near Harrison-avenue, which, owing to the high wind prevailing at the time, was soon entirely enveloped in flames, and spread to adjoining property. The ropewalk was a frame building, two stories high, and about 900 feet long, extending the whole distance from Marcy to Harrison avenue. The "jenny" house was made of brick, three stories high. The fire was first discovered breaking out at about the centre of the walk, and in the second story. How the fire originated no one seems to know. The whole walk, with nearly all of the contents, and jenny-house and contents, were destroyed. The fire spread to six two-story frame houses, owned by SAMUEL WISWALL, and occupied by different families employed in the ropewalk; then to the frame foundry, a one-story frame building, unoccupied, owned by CHARLES WOOSTER; then to the foundry of JONATHAN MOORE, then to a three story brick building, owned by CHAS. WOOSTER, occupied, on the lower floor by Messrs. ALLEN & MCDOUGALL, as a store-room, and the upper part by T.J. MOORE, as a brass clock factory. At this point the wind changed, and the Firemen succeeded in stopping the further progress of the fire.

abstract: It is just forty-five years since the imperative claims of one portion of the human race to the sympathies and protection of the remainder were first formally recognized in the great. Treaty of Nations concluded at Vienna. A century earlier, so different had been the opinions prevailing, that England had stipulated in special conventions with Spain for the ...
lead_paragraph: It is just forty-five years since the imperative claims of one portion of the human race to the sympathies and protection of the remainder were first formally recognized in the great. Treaty of Nations concluded at Vienna. A century earlier, so different had been the opinions prevailing, that England had stipulated in special conventions with Spain for the exclusive privilege of carrying slaves to the Spanish Colonies, and the actual abolition of Slavery in British dominions is still of very recent date indeed. If any one, however, is desirous of observing the respect with which these principles of philanthropy are now regarded he need do no more than peruse the discussion on Coolie Emigration which occurred in the House of Lords on Tuesday. Nothing could well exceed the jealousy and solicitude with which the natural rights of those helpless emigrants have been protected, and so rigorous, indeed, are the exactions advanced on their behalf that it may be a question whether the real interests of humanity are not sometimes jeopardized by its own sincerest advocates.

abstract: A verdict for $5,000 was recently obtained in Ohio, by a wife who had lost the use of her foot through the violence of her drunken husband, against the grog-shop-keeper who sold him the liquor. The proceedings were instituted under an act recently passed, and, so far as we can judge, it is not only sound in principle, but perfectly practicable in execution.
lead_paragraph: A verdict for $5,000 was recently obtained in Ohio, by a wife who had lost the use of her foot through the violence of her drunken husband, against the grog-shop-keeper who sold him the liquor. The proceedings were instituted under an act recently passed, and, so far as we can judge, it is not only sound in principle, but perfectly practicable in execution. There is no rule of law better settled than that a principal is responsible for the acts of his servants or agent, done by his instigation; and it certainly requires no straining to regard a drunken man as the agent or instrument, in. all damage which he commits, of the person who sells him the intoxicating drink. The dealer who deliberately sells enough rum to one man to deprive him of his senses, and then dismisses him to do his worst to those whom, he meets in the street or finds at home, is, in point of fact, quite as much to blame for any injury to person or property which follows, as a person knowingly keeping a vicious dog, or bull or horse.
headline: {'main': 'A Sound Liquor Law.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Sound Liquor Law.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: By the steamship Bohemian, which left Liverpool on the 14th inst., touched at Queenstown on the 15th, and reached Portland yesterday, we have important news. A dispatch from Turin states that Sardinia has consented to cede Savoy and Nice to France, by special treaty. Another irritating debate on the Savoy question had taken place in the English House of Commons. The Central States of Italy had voted almost unanimously for annexation to Piedmont, and the Municipalities of Milan had offered VICTOR EMANUEL 3,000,000 of francs as an expression of confidence in his national policy. M. THOUVENEL, in his reply to Count CAVOUR, says that if the King accepts the annexation of Tuscany, he cannot expect the support of France. The Pope has declined to create a Vicariate of the Romagna, as proposed by France. The campaign in Morocco had opened brilliantly. The Moors were repulsed with considerable loss in an attack on the encampments at Tetuan, and were pursued for half a league.

abstract: There have been many curious consequences predicted as likely to result from the abolition of Slavery in the Southern States of the Union; but Mayor WOOD has certainly discovered the most extraordinary of any. He informed his hearers in his speech recently, at Norwich, Conn., that if the negro slaves were emancipated, at least "two thousand of the ...
lead_paragraph: There have been many curious consequences predicted as likely to result from the abolition of Slavery in the Southern States of the Union; but Mayor WOOD has certainly discovered the most extraordinary of any. He informed his hearers in his speech recently, at Norwich, Conn., that if the negro slaves were emancipated, at least "two thousand of the mechanics" who abound amongst them would at once migrate to the town of Norwich, and there enter into competition with the white artisans of that locality; and as they "care nothing for the education of their children," says the worthy Mayor, "and are degraded, they would work for one-half the wages which the white mechanics receive." "Think of your condition, then," says the crator, to the white mechanics aforesaid.

abstract: Mr. MAURICE LESNER, whose arrest was mentioned in Saturday's TIMES, for having, as was alleged, defrauded a Philadelphia firm by false pretences, had a hearing on that day in Philadelphia, and upon satisfactorily explaining the matter concerning the checks alluded to, the complainant withdrew the charge. The complaint under which the arrest was made, originated simply from the circumstance that Mr. LENSER exchanged a check with SCHENKE, which was left unpaid by Mr. LESNER's bank. Upon explanation of the fact to Alderman K., the accused was instantly and honorably discharged.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MAURICE LESNER, whose arrest was mentioned in Saturday's TIMES, for having, as was alleged, defrauded a Philadelphia firm by false pretences, had a hearing on that day in Philadelphia, and upon satisfactorily explaining the matter concerning the checks alluded to, the complainant withdrew the charge. abstract: Among all the places of public amusement which the wise founders of our City Government provided at the people's expense, none is the source of more popular merriment than the Municipal ten-pin-alley. The "Ten Governors" do not complain of any reasonably moderate bowling. The ball that knocks down but two or three of their number is not regarded, for the keeper can easily set them up again. They can also easily tolerate domestic broils. Gov. A. may inform Gov. B. that he is a lying and thieving Governor, and Gov. B. may retort that Gov. A. has been so recently made Governor that he doesn't know how to behave like a Governor; and all hands may get into such a noisy and tempestuous wrangle as to make it evident that they are not Ten Governors of their own tempers, whatever maybe their ability in governing the paupers.
lead_paragraph: Among all the places of public amusement which the wise founders of our City Government provided at the people's expense, none is the source of more popular merriment than the Municipal ten-pin-alley. The "Ten Governors" do not complain of any reasonably moderate bowling. The ball that knocks down but two or three of their number is not regarded, for the keeper can easily set them up again. They can also easily tolerate domestic broils. Gov. A. may inform Gov. B. that he is a lying and thieving Governor, and Gov. B. may retort that Gov. A. has been so recently made Governor that he doesn't know how to behave like a Governor; and all hands may get into such a noisy and tempestuous wrangle as to make it evident that they are not Ten Governors of their own tempers, whatever maybe their ability in governing the paupers.

abstract: The announcement in the public prints that FERNANDO WOOD and HENRY WARD BEECHER would meet together on the same platform to address a mass meeting in aid of the Lynn strikers, drew together an audience of 600 persons at the Cooper Institute last evening. The announcement, however, as the event proved, was too startling to be true. Neither gentleman was present at the meeting, nor was any one of the long list of speakers announced in the public posters kind enough to respond to the call, and favor the audience with his presence, with the single exception of ALONZO G. DRAPER, of Lynn, and Hon. HORACE GREELEY.

abstract: -- A debate took place in the Senate, on Friday, on the bill for the relief of JOHN HASTINGS, late Collector of Pittsburgh, whose office was broken into, himself gagged, and some ten thousand dollars of the public moneys abstracted. Mr. CAMERON advocated the bill, and thought the principle of holding the sureties of a public officer responsible for his fidelity wrong -- he standing in the same relation as a private agent, who is alone responsible to his employer. Mr. DOOLITTLE opposed it, on the ground that such officer should be held to a strict account for the safe-keeping of the public funds intrusted to him. Finally the bill passed, with the amendment of Mr. BENJAMIN, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to inquire into the facts of the alleged robbery, and to credit Mr. HASTINGS with the amount thus stolen, if he was satisfied that the robbery was actually committed. The principle is an obvious one, that a public officer is responsible both for his fidelity and for the care and vigilance with which he executes his trust, and if any loss to the Government occurs by fire or flood, or by any casualty against which ordinary care and prudence could not provide, his responsibility is avoided.
lead_paragraph: -- A debate took place in the Senate, on Friday, on the bill for the relief of JOHN HASTINGS, late Collector of Pittsburgh, whose office was broken into, himself gagged, and some ten thousand dollars of the public moneys abstracted. Mr. CAMERON advocated the bill, and thought the principle of holding the sureties of a public officer responsible for his fidelity wrong -- he standing in the same relation as a private agent, who is alone responsible to his employer. Mr. DOOLITTLE opposed it, on the ground that such officer should be held to a strict account for the safe-keeping of the public funds intrusted to him. Finally the bill passed, with the amendment of Mr. BENJAMIN, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to inquire into the facts of the alleged robbery, and to credit Mr. HASTINGS with the amount thus stolen, if he was satisfied that the robbery was actually committed. The principle is an obvious one, that a public officer is responsible both for his fidelity and for the care and vigilance with which he executes his trust, and if any loss to the Government occurs by fire or flood, or by any casualty against which ordinary care and prudence could not provide, his responsibility is avoided.

abstract: If anything could be surprising in the history of human selfishness at this stage of the world's long and dark experience, it would be the intelligence that a certain number of NewYork landlords have dared to outrage the common instincts of mankind and the principles of Christianity, by proffering a petition
lead_paragraph: If anything could be surprising in the history of human selfishness at this stage of the world's long and dark experience, it would be the intelligence that a certain number of NewYork landlords have dared to outrage the common instincts of mankind and the principles of Christianity, by proffering a petition to the Legislature against the passage of any law regulating the construction of tenement-houses for the poor. Such a law has been introduced, as our readers know, at Albany. It was drawn up, not under the pressure of the tremendous facts revealed by the Legislative inquiry of 1856 into the moral and material condition of the tenement population of the metropolis; not for the purpose of diminishing the aggregate of human disease and human crime engendered by the inadequacies and the indecencies of the accommodation provided for thousands of American citizens in this richest of American cities; not with the determined intention on the part of our Republican law-makers to attack fever in its strongholds, and incest in its dens. True, the report of the Legislative Committee of 1856 had exposed the existence of these strongholds and the horrible influences of these dens. It had painted simply, clearly, without coloring too intense, or forms too exaggerated, a picture of life in New-York, from which we should have shrunk in horror and incredulity had it been offered to us as an image of the wynds of Glasgow or the slums of the He St. Louis. But the matter had slept, for no special catastrophe came to thrust it in all its hideous realities before the community at large.

abstract: Two mothers and their eight children--in all ten human beings--were burned to death yesterday morning, in one of a row of tenement-houses in  West Forty-fifth-street. The fire is believed to have been the work of an incendiary, because when first discovered it was confined entirely to the stairway of the house, No. 90, in which six families resided.
lead_paragraph: Two mothers and their eight children--in all ten human beings--were burned to death yesterday morning, in one of a row of tenement-houses in West Forty-fifth-street. The fire is believed to have been the work of an incendiary, because when first discovered it was confined entirely to the stairway of the house, No. 90, in which six families resided. There were four buildings in all, Nos. 84, 86, 88, and 90, and they were of the very worst description of tenement-houses. They were constructed about nine years ago, during the excitement among property owners in the vicinity of the site of the Crystal Palace, and were mere wooden shells, four stories in height, and partitioned so as to permit of their being occupied by the very largest number of families possible The building in which the fire originated was occupied -- the first floor by MARTIN REDMAN, as a grocery and liquor store; and the upper floors by five large families, as follows: On the second floor there were TIMOTHY NOLAN, his wife and four children, and Mr. KEARNEY, a widower, and his two children. The third floor front was occupied by Mr. WM. IRVING, wife and four children. On the rear of the third floor was THOMAS BENNETT, wife and four children. The fourth floor was occupied by ANDREW WHEELER, wife and four children. The only means of ingress and egress was a stairway three feet in width, so of course as soon as that was on fire there remained no places of exit except the windows. The fire was discovered soon after 1 o'clock in the morning, when all who were in the house were in bed. Before any of them were awakened to their danger, many of them were nearly stifled by the dense smoke that filled the various rooms. The alarm was given, and all who were able ran to the stairs, but only to be met and driven back by the ascending flames. The scene at this time is described by those who were present as appalling. The inmates could be seen running hither and thither, seeking a way of escape, but finding none. While the increasing flames rose higher and higher, and they were forced from one floor to another by the intense beat, the shriekings of the women and children were terrible to hear. Those outside looked on with feelings of horror, for, until the firemen arrived with their apparatus, they could do nothing to save them. With remarkable alacrity, even for New-York firemen, Hook and Ladder Company No. 8 came to the scene. There was immediately a hope expressed that those in the building might yet be saved, for the firemen lost no time in rearing a ladder against the building, and springing to the rescue, and the fire had not yet reached the upper story; but through their very eagerness to save those in peril, the time and the means were lost. All being anxious to rescue some one, too many climbed the ladder, and it gave way, bringing them all to the ground. Those inside who saw the ladder break, and who were not yet suffocated, gave one heart-rending cry, and it was the last. All who were able rushed to the windows and sprang out, preferring to die by the fall rather than by fire. In this way quite a number escaped without serious injury. The engines were now at work, but the fire had reached the roof, which was composed of canvass, covered with a layer of pitch, and over that a sprinkling of gravel and small stones. As soon as the flames touched the pitched canvas, the fire spread rapidly over all four of the buildings, and in a few minutes the upper stories were in a blaze. The inmates of all excepting No. 90 had, however, had sufficient warning, and they escaped; and with the assistance of Steam Fire Engine No. 46, the fire was soon extinguished. In a short time, all who were supposed to be alive of the former residents, were brought together, and it was ascertained that Mrs. WHEELER and her four children, and Mrs. BENNETT and her four children, had been [???] to death. abstract: The preliminary examination of the circumstances connected with the murder of Capt. Burr and his two seamen, the brothers Watts, on board the sloop E.A. Johnson, was commenced yesterday before United States Commissioner WHITE, in the United States Circuit Court room.
lead_paragraph: The preliminary examination of the circumstances connected with the murder of Capt. Burr and his two seamen, the brothers Watts, on board the sloop E.A. Johnson, was commenced yesterday before United States Commissioner WHITE, in the United States Circuit Court room. The prisoner was brought into the Court-room, which was crowded, from the Tombs, by some very roundabout way, by Marshal Rynders and his deputy, Mr. Duggan. He conversed freely with both, and with his counsel, Messrs. Graves and Sayers, seemed to regard the whole affair as a trifle, heard the testimony with an indifference that, if not stoical was stolid, and indulged in some expressions as to the character of the witnesses, which were much less polite than emphatic.

abstract: The weekly return of taxes and interest for the past week indicates a constant decrease in receipts. During the last week they amounted to $17,520 44, besides $1,046 82 interest, and for unpaid Croton water rents, $296 70. The decrease in business, however, in the office of Receiver of Taxes corresponds with the increase of work in the office of the Commissioners, to whom is entrusted the power of increasing or decreasing the amount of taxes. Some idea may be formed of the amount of business transacted in this office when we state that nearly 15,000 notices have been served on parties taxed for personal property, any one of whom has the right to appear before the Commissioners and correct under oath an erroneous assessment.

abstract: The voting on the question of annexation to Sardinia took place on 11th and 12th insts. in the various Italian States. abstract: As the session of our Legislature draws to a close, bills involving money are pushed rapidly forward. Yesterday the whole batch of our City Railroad bills were ordered to a third reading. This formality they will probably pass through to-day or to-morrow; they will then go to the Senate and be enacted with just as little discussion, and with just as complete
lead_paragraph: As the session of our Legislature draws to a close, bills involving money are pushed rapidly forward. Yesterday the whole batch of our City Railroad bills were ordered to a third reading. This formality they will probably pass through to-day or to-morrow; they will then go to the Senate and be enacted with just as little discussion, and with just as complete and contemptuous disregard of the interests of the City and the wishes of its inhabitants, as has hitherto been exhibited at every stage of these proceedings. The friends of these bills, -- which means simply the parties who have a money interest in their passage, -- would feel hurt if we were to intimate any doubt of their success. Such an intimation would reflect discredit upon their sagacity, -- upon the thoroughness with which they do their work; it would imply that they had not "secured" all the votes they need, in advance.

abstract: A day or two since, we commented upon the reply made by a convicted criminal in one of our Courts to that formal summons by which our Law, "the sum of human wisdom," after silencing a prisoner during the whole course of his trial, when his words might possibly serve the ends of justice, requests him to offer
lead_paragraph: A day or two since, we commented upon the reply made by a convicted criminal in one of our Courts to that formal summons by which our Law, "the sum of human wisdom," after silencing a prisoner during the whole course of his trial, when his words might possibly serve the ends of justice, requests him to offer any observations that may occur to his mind upon a sentence, which he could neither shake nor change were his tongue as the tongue of an angel. The case of this man, WILLIAMS, sentenced to eight years of imprisonment, with no power in all that time to provide for the sustenance, comfort and education of four motherless children, may well arrest the attention of the most amiable of optimists upon the fearful inadequacy -- to brand it with no sterner name -- of our existing criminal jurisprudence, to the work which society expects it to accomplish. Our laws are supposed to be aimed not only at the punishment of crime, but at its prevention; and we make it one of the loudest of our many loud boasts over the philanthropic progress of modern times, that we have gilded the social necessity of chastisement with the divine quality of reformation, in our systems of prison discipline. Yet here we find ourselves, not only sending the criminal to pass eight years of his life, as it were, in an exhausted receiver, under an absolute vacuum of all human motives, either to amendment or newness of life, empty alike of hope and fear; but actually condemning four innocent children to that utter destitution, both material and spiritual, which is the first stage, the primary school of habitual crime. In doing this, of course, we deliberately inflict upon the community the almost moral certainty of whatever suffering and loss four young lives surrendered up, by order of the Court to evil, and that continually can prepare for themselves and us!
headline: {'main': 'Childhood and Crime.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Childhood and Crime.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Opinion Nationale states that a new schism has broken out among the writers of the Journal des Debats, M. SAINT-MARC-GISAEDIN separating himself from MM. MICHAEL CHEVALIER and BAUDRILLART on the question of Customs Reform. "But less favored than M. DE SACY and JOHN LEMOINNE." says the Opinion, "M. SAINT MARC GIRARDIN has not been allowed to publish in the Debats his protest against the economic principles in the triumph of which his colleagues have had so great a part. M. SAINT MARC GIRARDIN has therefore brought out a pamphlet of 30 pages, in which be combats what he calls the pernicious doctrine of the Debats on the tariff questions."

abstract: An unknown man, apparently a laborer, was found by a policeman, lying in an open lot of the Nineteenth Ward, between two rocks, with his skull fractured and having other injuries on his person, from the combined effects of which he soon expired at Bellevue Hospital, whither he had been conveyed. Coroner JACKMAN has been summoned, and it is hoped the circumstances under which the deceased met his death will transpire.

abstract: The Physician of the State Lunatic Asylum of New-Jersey makes the following report: Whole number of cases received from opening of Asylum, May 15, 1840, to Jan. 1, 1860, 745 men, 818 women: total, 1,563. Of this number there have been discharged, recovered. 605; improved, 403; unimproved, 37; escaped. 5; not insane, 1; died, 206; total discharged and died, 1,257. The number of cases received and treated, during the past year, was 479 -- a larger number, by 53, than has before received the care of the institution in any single year.

abstract: The second trial of James Shepherd, whose name, on the allegation of his having committed two of the most heinous crimes known to the law, has been so frequently before the public, commenced yesterday in this Court. At the time of his first trial, which commenced Dec. 10, 1857, and occupied four days, Recorder SMITH presiding, he was convicted of arson in the first degree, that...
lead_paragraph: The second trial of James Shepherd, whose name, on the allegation of his having committed two of the most heinous crimes known to the law, has been so frequently before the public, commenced yesterday in this Court. At the time of his first trial, which commenced Dec. 10, 1857, and occupied four days, Recorder SMITH presiding, he was convicted of arson in the first degree, that crime involving the murder of his wife, whose half-charred body was subsequently found in the ruins of the building which was set on fire. The alleged crime was committed on the night of June 9, 1857. The issue of the trial before the Recorder was the conviction, as we have said, of Shepherd, and his sentence to be executed on Feb. 8, 1858. Before that day arrived a stay of proceedings was obtained by his counsel, and a motion for a new trial was made-before the Supreme Court and argued after considerable delay. The motion was denied, the judgment of the Court below affirmed, and on the 6th of June, 1859, Judge Roosevelt resentenced Shepherd to be hung on the 22d of the following July. Subsequently, in November of that year, the Court of Appeals, to which the case had been carried, granted a new trial, and yesterday, two years and seven months after his arrest, Shepherd was again placed before a jury.

abstract: Times has broached a new, and we must say, to Americans, an astonishing theory of parliamentary eloquence. In commenting upon the explosive demonstration with which the intelligence of the French Emperor's Savoyard policy had been received in Parliament, the Times ventures the assertion, that "every reasonable and deliberative assembly ought to have an object in its talk." Have the editors of the Times any acquaintance with the Pickwick Papers, or with the Congressional Globe? If they have not, how dare they pronounce in this decided way upon the proprieties of parliamentary palaver? If they have, how can they fly so directly in the face of facts? The least familiarity with the oratorical effusions of Alfred Jingle, or the Hon. Mr. WIGFALL, ought to have made an assertion of this hazardous and preposterous character impossible.
lead_paragraph: Times has broached a new, and we must say, to Americans, an astonishing theory of parliamentary eloquence. In commenting upon the explosive demonstration with which the intelligence of the French Emperor's Savoyard policy had been received in Parliament, the Times ventures the assertion, that "every reasonable and deliberative assembly ought to have an object in its talk." Have the editors of the Times any acquaintance with the Pickwick Papers, or with the Congressional Globe? If they have not, how dare they pronounce in this decided way upon the proprieties of parliamentary palaver? If they have, how can they fly so directly in the face of facts? The least familiarity with the oratorical effusions of Alfred Jingle, or the Hon. Mr. WIGFALL, ought to have made an assertion of this hazardous and preposterous character impossible.

abstract: CITY HOTEL, PROVIDENCE, R.I., Tuesday, March 27, 1860.  Little Rhody is in a flutter, and well she may be. In common with her sister Connecticut, she is attracting the attention of the whole confederacy. All eyes turn anxiously hitherward, waiting, fearing, hoping for the result of the election which is to be held on the 4th of April next.
lead_paragraph: CITY HOTEL, PROVIDENCE, R.I., Tuesday, March 27, 1860.

abstract: John Bancroft vs. Jacob Mitchell. -- The parties to this action were formerly partners in the manufacture and sale of mouldings, under the name of Jacob Mitchell & Co. This action was brought to compel an accounting, and for a dissolution of the copartnership, also, for the appointment of a receiver, an injunction having been heretofore granted, restraining Mitchell, the defendant, from interfering in any manner with the partnership business. The case was referred to H.P. Townsend, to hear and determine the issues between the parties. The Referee reported in favor of the plaintiff, which report was now confirmed, and a decree granted dissolving the copartnership, and appointing Andrew Stoeckel receiver, to take charge of, and dispose of, the partnership effects; and also for judgment in favor of the plaintiff, for the sum of $769 92 and costs.
