abstract: A correspondent of the Boston Traveller, writing from Jerusalem under date of Jan. 1, gives anaccount of the result of a demand for redress for outrages committed on citizens of the United States, which was made upon the Governor-General of Syria by Hon. JAMES WILLIAMS, United States Minister at Constantinople.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Boston Traveller, writing from Jerusalem under date of Jan. 1, gives anaccount of the result of a demand for redress for outrages committed on citizens of the United States, which was made upon the Governor-General of Syria by Hon. JAMES WILLIAMS, United States Minister at Constantinople. On arriving at Beirut, whither he was obliged to go without any display of naval force, as there was no American ship of war at hand, Mr. WILLIAMS stated his errand to the Governor-General, who replied that he had done and would continue to do every thing in his power to afford satisfaction and justice. Rev. Drs. THOMSON and VAN DYKE communicated the result of their interview to the American residents, who have addressed to Secretary CASS a letter expressing their appreciation of the services rendered by Mr. WILLIAMS.

abstract: SCIENCE. -- The third lecture of the course on Sanitary Science was delivered by Dr. E.Y. ROBBINS at Clinton Hall, on Monday evening, before a select audience. The subject was the "The Application of Sanitary Science, as a means of moral improvement, and for the prevention of pauperism and crime. The first point touched upon was the deaths of children, from 12,000 to 15,000 of whom, under five years of age, die yearly in this City, mostly from the impurity of the air they breathe. Marasmus, convulsions, cholera infantum, hydro-cephalus, pneumonia, are the monsters which feed on infants. The lecturer advocated the establishment of public nurseries, airy, commodious asylums, where the children of destitute parents might be nurtured. There was nothing Utopian in the suggestion. Paganism, in ancient Sparta, made all the children the care of the State, and should Christian charity do less? Even the children of rich parents might be benefited, for Fashion could not afford to let the child grow up healthily. Pneumonia destroyed as many children of the rich as it did of the poor. In view of the scant covering which Fashion allowed to their necks and arms, humanity might suggest that a "Fashionable Children's Protective Society" might be formed, to provide fitting clothing for the fashionably exposed children of the best circles. The moral effect of crowded and ill-ventilated rooms, where a whole family, and sometimes two families, live and sleep together, was next considered. The teachings of the Sabbath School were powerless against the daily teachings of an immoral home. For the ten thousand roving children, homeless, or worse than homeless, in this City, the doctor made an eloquent and powerful appeal. In reference to the various relations of his subject, he frequently quoted, and always with apt effect, from the writings of the Earl of SHAFTESBURY, and the Rev. CHARLES KINGSLEY and SYDNEY TURNER. The lecture was singularly effective, and it is to be regretted that it was listened to by so few persons. Surely, the subject of Sanitary Science, both in a moral and physical point of view, is one of the highest importance. The next lecture of the course will be delivered on Thursday evening next.

The lecturer advocated the establishment of public nurseries, airy, commodious asylums, where the children of destitute parents might be nurtured. There was nothing Utopian in the suggestion. Paganism, in ancient Sparta, made all the children the care of the State, and should Christian charity do less? Even the children of rich parents might be benefited, for Fashion could not afford to let the child grow up healthily. Pneumonia destroyed as many children of the rich as it did of the poor. In view of the scant covering which Fashion allowed to their necks and arms, humanity might suggest that a "Fashionable Children's Protective Society" might be formed, to provide fitting clothing for the fashionably exposed children of the best circles. The moral effect of crowded and ill-ventilated rooms, where a whole family, and sometimes two families, live and sleep together, was next considered. The teachings of the Sabbath School were powerless against the daily teachings of an immoral home. For the ten thousand roving children, homeless, or worse than homeless, in this City, the doctor made an eloquent and powerful appeal. In reference to the various relations of his subject, he frequently quoted, and always with apt effect, from the writings of the Earl of SHAFTESBURY, and the Rev. CHARLES KINGSLEY and SYDNEY TURNER. abstract: The Bangor (Me.) Whig verifies the report that Mr. R.D. Bartlett, machinest, recently engaged in raising sunken ships on the St. Lawrence, was among the lost on board the Hungarian. Neither letters nor tidings have since been received from him. The names of passengers forwarded two or three weeks ago to the American agents of the Grand Trunk, contained the name of "Bartlett, for Quebec," for which place he would be likely to take a ticket.

abstract: Several months ago, Sarah Schultz, a German woman, was apprehended by Officer Harold for an alleged theft, and subsequently the policeman went to the residence of Mrs. Adelaide Marks, daughter of the accused, at No. 675 Eighth-avenue, and, it is charged, without authority searched the premises for stolen property, carrying away with him, it is claimed, pawn-tickets representing $30 worth of goods.
lead_paragraph: Several months ago, Sarah Schultz, a German woman, was apprehended by Officer Harold for an alleged theft, and subsequently the policeman went to the residence of Mrs. Adelaide Marks, daughter of the accused, at No. 675 Eighth-avenue, and, it is charged, without authority searched the premises for stolen property, carrying away with him, it is claimed, pawn-tickets representing $30 worth of goods. Mrs. Marks says that she has repeatedly asked the officer to return the tickets, but he has invariably had an excuse for not complying, and finally, losing patience, she made the facts known to Justice CONNOLLY. The magistrate summoned the officer to explain the matter. The latter stated that he must have lost or mislaid the tickets, and in fact had but dim recollection of ever having had anything to do with them. In Order that the officer might refresh his memory, the further examination of the case was for the present postponed.

abstract: HARTFORD, Wednesday, March 28, 1860. The State Capital has hardly recovered from its  spree of last evening. So universal was the jubilee that the streets looked quite deserted this morning. VAN BRUNT has received the Republican nomination for Alderman in the Eighth Ward.

abstract: The Hartford Press says that the reasons for the "mysterious disappearance" of Mr. S.D. Northway, of Norwalk, Conn., are beginning to appear. The company of which he has been manager has made a statement, and claim that Mr. N. is a defaulter to the amount of $8,000. Including this claim to their assets, the company show a surplus of only $4,000. It is thought by his friends that a knowledge.
lead_paragraph: The Hartford Press says that the reasons for the "mysterious disappearance" of Mr. S.D. Northway, of Norwalk, Conn., are beginning to appear. The company of which he has been manager has made a statement, and claim that Mr. N. is a defaulter to the amount of $8,000. Including this claim to their assets, the company show a surplus of only $4,000. It is thought by his friends that a knowledge of the financial condition of the company and a fear of exposure of his own agency in producing it, may have occasioned partial insanity, or a feigned insanity. At the instance of family friends a gentleman has gone to Kansas to find Mr. Northway and bring him back.

abstract: Petitions in favor of the House Homestead bill and of a uniform bankrupt law were presented to the Senate yesterday. The Navy Pay bill was so amended that Captains at sea should receive a salary of $4,000; those who were waiting orders and are on leave, $3,000, and those discharging other duties $3,600. After some other unimportant amendments the bill was read a third time and passed.
lead_paragraph: Petitions in favor of the House Homestead bill and of a uniform bankrupt law were presented to the Senate yesterday. The Navy Pay bill was so amended that Captains at sea should receive a salary of $4,000; those who were waiting orders and are on leave, $3,000, and those discharging other duties $3,600. After some other unimportant amendments the bill was read a third time and passed. An interesting debate occurred in the House on the bill recently reported from the Committee on the Judiciary to suppress polygamy in the Territories of the United States. Mr. BRANCH suggested that if polygamy was declared criminal, there would be no reason why the same action might not be taken regarding Slavery. He could not vote for this provision of the bill, which made penal laws applicable to all the Territories of the United States. Neither could Mr. TAYLOR. Mr. CLARK stated that the Committee on Territories had it in contemplation to report a bill parceling out Utah among the neighboring territories, so that the people themselves might remove the evil of polygamy. A disposition decidedly favorable to the measure under discussion was shown by the vote on a motion to lay the subject on the table, 19 members recording their names in the affirmative, and 148 in the negative. Five thousand extra copies of the report on our commercial relations, and of the last volume of the survey for a Pacific Railroad by Gov. STEVENS, were ordered to be printed. Sitting in Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, the House rejected the amendment to the Army Appropriation bill, increasing the amount for the National Armories from $250,000 to $400,000.

abstract: The action in our legislature to restrain some of the grosser Sunday immoralities has awakened public attention to their nature and extent. From the tone of some of the Sunday papers, it might be thought that the rights of citizens were seriously imperiled by the bill which has passed the Senate, or that a religious observance of Sunday was to be enforced. The truth is, that the excesses of the caterers for Sunday sports have compelled some legislative intervention to preserve the public peace and order on Sunday. By degrees, a system of public exhibitions has grown up among us, more offensive to good morals than is tolerated in any European city. It is by no means restricted to the German quarter of the City, as some apologists for iniquity represent when they seek to involve a question of public order in political entanglements; on the contrary, the most shameful and disgusting of the places of Sunday dissipation and prostitution are to be found in Broadway and other thoroughfares, and are frequented by the apprentices and others of American and Irish parentage. The Sunday Herald parades the infamous advertisements of these establishments, column by column -- such advertisements as would bring down the Police of Paris or Vienna upon the paper and the proprietor the hour they were published.

abstract: the 20th March the family of COL LEMLEY, a lawyer, of New-Orleans, were poisoned at dinner by the house slaves. The number of persons poisoned was 15, of whom one, a little son of Mrs. YOUNG, died. Miss LEMLEY, daughter of the Colonel, aged 17, is very low, and her life is despaired of. The others are recovering. The poison was placed in the charlotte russe produced at dessert, of which the guests and the members of the family partook freely. The Delta explains the affair as follows: "The cook, ANN, has a son, a lad about 17 years old, who is an incorrigible runaway and is now in the police jail for safe keeping. Mr. LEMLEY had determined to sell him, believing that his mother had always instigated him to run away, and aided him in finding places of concealment. Mr. LEMLEY yesterday stated that since the poisoning his wife had said to him that she had some time been is fear of ANN, but her fears had not been serious enough to induce her to express them to any one some of the young ladies in Mr. LEMLEY's family stated that after the jelly had been prepared in the dish, and left standing before cooking, they found the negro boy HARRY stirring the mixture with a spoon. HARRY being questioned in prison, and warned to tell the truth if he expected mercy hereafter, declared, that he had not touched the dish or gone near it. Upon a second visit to Mr. LEMLEY's, the sick ladies repeated what they had said more positively than before,"
lead_paragraph: the 20th March the family of COL LEMLEY, a lawyer, of New-Orleans, were poisoned at dinner by the house slaves. abstract: are made to the Governor for the reprieve at least, of JOHN CRUMMINS, who is sentenced to be hung to-morrow for the murder of DENNIS MCHENRY. The circumstances of the case show very great provocation on the part of the latter to the assault which resulted in his death, and the jury which convicted the prisoner unanimously recommended him to mercy. His previous character was good, and his crime was perpetrated in a moment of excessive passion.

We must give the Republican Presidential ticket 6,000 majority, and upon
lead_paragraph: The Concord (N.H.) Statesman, is its "Thoughts on the Election," says that "the majority obtained for our State ticket is so large, that probably not much breath or money will be expended upon the Presidential campaign. We must give the Republican Presidential ticket 6,000 majority, and upon that substantial capital retire into Winter quarters. In the meantime, let Democratic journalists learn wisdom and improve their manners. Let them give up the application of vulgar terms to the Republican Party. Let them cease to abuse their betters."

abstract: The bill for the suppression of polygamy in Utah seems likely to be dropped before the close of the session. Our correspondent in Washington states that the opinion prevails amongst many people that the only remedy for the evil is to let it correct itself. We doubt very much whether it is one of those evils that will correct itself, and we confess we doubt very much also whether an act of Congress prohibiting it could be carried out, without the presence on the spot of a large Gentile and monogamist population.
lead_paragraph: The bill for the suppression of polygamy in Utah seems likely to be dropped before the close of the session. abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN is evidently aggrieved. The Message which he sent to Congress yesterday is one of the most lachrymose documents ever issued from the White House. What it lacks in dignity, it makes up in wounded pride. It is a vehement appeal to public compassion, too humiliating to inspire respect, and not sufficiently dignified to enlist any considerable degree of sympathy. It is in every respect a painful document -- one which will be read everywhere with surprise, and which is much more likely to excite contempt than any more amiable or respectful sentiment.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN is evidently aggrieved. The Message which he sent to Congress yesterday is one of the most lachrymose documents ever issued from the White House. abstract: THE STONECUTTERS' STRIKE ON THE ROMAN CATHOLIC CATHEDRAL. The men who were engaged in cutting stone for the new Roman Catholic Cathedral in Fifth-avenue, are still on a strike, no terms having yet been agreed upon between them and their employer. They held a meeting yesterday, and, in answer to the sympathisers who met in Millman's Hall, adopted the following:

During the interview at the tavern...
lead_paragraph: GEORGE ACKER was executed at Morristown, N.J., yesterday, for the murder of an old man named ISAAC H. GORDON on the 18th of October last. The circumstances of the case were briefly as follows: ACKER and GORDON, who had been friends and fellow- workmen, met at a tavern in Montville on the day of the murder, and after indulging freely in drink, had a slight quarrel. During the interview at the tavern GORDON displayed a sum of money amounting to about $30, and it is supposed that this, and not the quarrel, furnished the inducement to the commission of the crime. ACKER parted from GORDON at the hotel, and concealing himself by the roadside leading to the residence of GORDON, waited for his approach. After the latter had passed, ACKER came up behind him and struck him on the back of the head with a stone, knocking him senseless. He then dragged him into the field, cut his throut, and rifled his pockets. After going home to bed, being unable to sleep, the guilty man arose, returned to the scene of the murder, and buried the body in the sand, where it was found five days after. ACKER was arrested on suspicion, and his trial took place at Morristown last February, and resulted in a verdict of guilty. On being sentenced, he said, in answer to the usual question, that he was "innocent of the crime." Subsequently, however, he made a full confession of the murder, which, together with the report of the trial, has been published for the benefit of his family. In his confession, he attributes his ruin to indulgence in ardent spirits, and warns his associates against that fatal vice. Since his imprisonment he has manifested an apparent indifference and insensibility to his fate. Latterly he has charged visitors 25 cents a head for seeing him, devoting the proceeds to his wife, who has been constant in her attentions to him during his confinement.

abstract: There is a bill at this moment before the Legislature which is dignified with the name of "a bankrupt law," but which is in reality a measure for the abolition of all means of enforcing payment of just debts. It enables any man to wipe out all liabilities, no matter in what character he may have contracted them, whether as trustee or guardian or executor, if they are due more than one year, upon offering to assign all property actually in his possession for the benefit of his creditors. It does not contain a single provision throwing the slightest difficulty in the way of anybody's making a clean sweep once in every twelve months of all his pecuniary obligations. There is, we hope, not much chance of its passing, but the mere discussion of it reflects a good deal of disgrace on the body in which is was first introduced.

abstract: There could not be a better illustration of the way in which this City is sacrified to Federal politics than is afforded by the present pursuits of our worthy Mayor in Connecticut. He could not prove more clearly than he is now doing that he considers the municipal office which he adorns merely an instrument to enable him to look after the whole Union more effectually, that he values his position as Mayor simply for the additional weight which it lends to his utterances on the stump. FERNANDO WOOD, Esq., of New-York City, would, of course, not receive half so much respectful attention from admiring rustics as Mayor WOOD, the elect and beloved of some 30,000 of the more disreputable portion of the Metropolitan population. Accordingly, ever since his election, he has devoted an amount of time to the business of "the party," which any man of less "executive ability" could ill spare from the business of the Mayoralty, if its duties be even half as onerous as he describes them to be. He has paid a long visit to Washington, to concert a plan of action, we presume, with his confederates; and during the last fortnight he has been dispensing wisdom in Connecticut, of which this unhappy City is in only too great need, as everybody knows. It seems, in short, as if we kept a Mayor, not for our own benefit, but for that of the nation at large, and as if our suffrages qualified everybody upon whom they are bestowed for the office of instructor-general to the entire Republic.

abstract: Soon after dark last evening, a well-dressed young man, named Thomas Newell, attempted to pass a three-dollar counterfeit bill on the Exchange Bank of Hartford, Conn., at the store corner of Ninthavenue and Fiftieth-street, but the proprietor refused to accept it; and after Newell left, the circumstance was made known to Officer Tompkins, of the Twenty-second Ward, who immediately went in pursuit of the supposed forger.
lead_paragraph: Soon after dark last evening, a well-dressed young man, named Thomas Newell, attempted to pass a three-dollar counterfeit bill on the Exchange Bank of Hartford, Conn., at the store corner of Ninthavenue and Fiftieth-street, but the proprietor refused to accept it; and after Newell left, the circumstance was made known to Officer Tompkins, of the Twenty-second Ward, who immediately went in pursuit of the supposed forger. After Tompkins had traced the man a short distance he met Officer Cottrell, of the same Precinct, who was in citizen's dress, and directing him to follow the suspected party, so that suspicion on his part would not be excited, Officer Tompkins dropped behind. Soon Newell entered another store in the vicinity, where he sought to dispose of the same worthless bill, when his arrest was immediately effected. The prisoner was taken to the Stationhouse, where, having been searched, $5 in worthless money was found upon him, and he was identified as a resident in a house in Fifty-second-street, near Eleventh-avenue, that the Police had supposed was the resort of a gang of counterfeiters. The officers determined to go there and arrest its inmates. In answer to their summons for admission John M. Parker alias Garrett, came to the door, but on learning the nature of the officers' business, he drew a large self-cocking rifled barrelled pistol and threatened to shoot the first man that dared to touch him. The officers were unarmed, and as a young man, named Frederick Miller, besides two females, were also arrayed against them, Thompson left to obtain assistance, while Cottrell remained to guard the place. Capt. Coulter and a force of men soon arrived and arrested Parker, Miller and the two females, but it subsequently appeared that the interval between the departure of the officer for aid and his return with it, had been occupied by the prisoners in destroying the evidences of their guilt. One of the women, who claimed to be Parker's wife, was found in a bedroom on the second floor engaged in burning thick bundles of bank notes in the grate; fragments of the bills were lying around the fender. An attempt was made to secure some of the charred paper, upon which the letters and figures were still visible, but the woman snatched it from the officer, and afterwards thrust the remainder down into the fire with her bare hands, thus effectually concealing all trace of the greater part of it. The prisoners were all conveyed to the Station-house and locked up to await examination. Some $ 13, mostly in altered bank bills, on various banks, in different stages or preparation, were found upon them. A portion of the money was recovered from the stockings of one of the females. A partial search of the house resulted in finding a large quantity of chemicals, rolls of bank-note paper, metal for the manufacture of bogus coin, and a variety of other articles and implements, supposed to be used by counterfeiters. The house, which is one of a row of neat four-story brick buildings, will be thoroughly overhauled by the police, when doubtless other evidences of the guilt of the accused will be furnished. Several parties, who allege that they have been victimized by the prisoners, will appear against them to day.

abstract: The State Senate yesterday ordered to a third reading a bill locating our City Hall on Madison-square! The Legislature seems determined to exhaust the catalogue of outrages upon the City of New-York and its inhabitants. There is no conceivable....
lead_paragraph: The State Senate yesterday ordered to a third reading a bill locating our City Hall on Madison-square! To-day they will probably order the Post-office to be placed on the Central Park, and to-morrow the Battery will be legislated to Macomb's Dam. The Legislature seems determined to exhaust the catalogue of outrages upon the City of New-York and its inhabitants. There is no conceivable form of robbery, no practicable style of oppression, which they have not shown themselves ready and eager to perpetrate. Where all this will end nobody ventures to guess, -- and many, in absolute despair, have ceased to inquire. The only chance of relief seems to be in the adjournment, -- and everybody is looking forward now to that event with the eager agony of a besieged garrison expecting relief.

abstract: The Secretary of War to-day sent a communication to the Military Committee of the House, recommending the raising of a regiment of Texas mounted volunteers. He would have done so earlier, but was hesitating between that and a new regiment of cavalry. He now thinks the latter would cause too great delay, and recommends the former, which can be raised and put in the field in thirty days.

abstract: Yesterday the United States Circuit Court was thronged by a crowd curious to see the man who is charged with the murders on board the sloop E.A. Johnson. The prisoner was taken from the Tombs into the presence of Mr. WHITE, the Commissioner, by officers D'Angelis and Duggan, and on the way conversed with them quite coolly and freely.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the United States Circuit Court was thronged by a crowd curious to see the man who is charged with the murders on board the sloop E.A. Johnson. The prisoner was taken from the Tombs into the presence of Mr. WHITE, the Commissioner, by officers D'Angelis and Duggan, and on the way conversed with them quite coolly and freely. When being removed from his cell he asked them if they would not put on the "darbies" (cant for handcuffs) right away, and volunteered the intelligence that many a time in his life he had done the same thing for a men. In his progress to the Court-room he informed them that he had once been for three days on the Mobile, of Bath, when she was a total wreck, and gravely assured the officers that they might have no fear of his running off, as he was entirely satisfied with his position. The officers as gravely answered that if he attempted to escape they would shoot him instanter. He received the announcement with the utmost composure. At the Court the crowd was so excessive that not only the prisoner, but the officers of the Court, the counsel and the reporters, were obliged to seek admission by a private door.

abstract: Unless a telegraphic dispatch from Gov. MORGAN, respiting JOHN CRUMMINS, sentenced to death for the murder of DENNIS McHENRY, should reach Sheriff KELLY this morning, that unhappy man will undoubtedly be executed to-day, in the yard of the City prison, between the hours of 9 and 12 A.M. Twice, al-...
lead_paragraph: Unless a telegraphic dispatch from Gov. MORGAN, respiting JOHN CRUMMINS, sentenced to death for the murder of DENNIS McHENRY, should reach Sheriff KELLY this morning, that unhappy man will undoubtedly be executed to-day, in the yard of the City prison, between the hours of 9 and 12 A.M. Twice, already, the Governor has refused to interpose his official power between the sentence of the Court and its fulfillment, assigning as one reason, which will probably seem strange enough at first glance, that the jury having recommended the condemned man to mercy, it was his duty to disregard their recommendation, inasmuch as thereby they interfered with the prerogative of the Executives and virtually dictated to the Governor what culprit, he should pardon. Yesterday afternoon, however, Judge INGRAHAM, before whom CRUMMINS was tried in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, and by whom his sentence was pronounced, wrote to the Governor a strong indorsement of the jury's recommendation, accompanied with an earnest appeal for a respite. This letter was conveyed to Albany on the 4 1/2 o'clock P.M. train, by Mr. ASHMEAD, who had previously made arrangements with the Sheriff to await a telegraphic dispatch from him before the execution took place to day. In every direction public sympathy is in favor of a respite, the facts of the case, as the jury themselves considered, not warranting the execution of the death penalty.

abstract: We recently called attention to the fact that, as compared with Philadelphia, the mortality of New-York is 9,600 annually in excess of what it would be had we an equally efficient Health Department. This annual aggregate of deaths gave 200 as the weekly, and about 27 as the daily excess of deaths.
lead_paragraph: We recently called attention to the fact that, as compared with Philadelphia, the mortality of New-York is 9,600 annually in excess of what it would be had we an equally efficient Health Department. This annual aggregate of deaths gave 200 as the weekly, and about 27 as the daily excess of deaths. Every Saturday our City Inspector publishes to the world the humiliating statement that the undertakers of the City have recorded on his books the names, ages and residences of two hundred citizens who have fallen victims to causes which it was in our power to remove. Nothing is more clear than that we are accessories to these wholesale murders, for to have power to prevent death, and not to exercise it, is certainly homicidal.

abstract: But little business of interest was done in the Senate yesterday. A joint resolution, offered by Mr. GREEN, that Congress adjourn from the 20th of April to May 21, was taken up, and after a short debate was rejected by a vote or 12 to 29. The bill supplementary to the act to protect citizens who may discover deposits of guano, was amended and passed. So was the bill to prevent desertions and facilitate enlistments in the U.S. Army. Mr. GROW having lost all hope of the House taking any action on the Pacific Railroad bill, gave notice that he should call up that measure next Thursday. In the House a message was received from the President, protesting against the proposed investigation of his official acts. After an exciting debate it was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, with power to report at any time.

abstract: Prof. CHARLIER closed his series of four lectures in French, upon French literature, last evening at the Spingler Institute. His third lecture was devoted to Mad. RECAMIER and her salon, of which he gave a spirited and very interesting description, with notices of the principal personages who made those gatherings to famous. Last evening he opened his...
lead_paragraph: Prof. CHARLIER closed his series of four lectures in French, upon French literature, last evening at the Spingler Institute. His third lecture was devoted to Mad. RECAMIER and her salon, of which he gave a spirited and very interesting description, with notices of the principal personages who made those gatherings to famous. Last evening he opened his lecture by some spirited and exceedingly discriminating remarks in answer to the question whether such assemblages as have made French society famous -- gatherings in which conversation and social intercourse were the chief and sufficient attractions, -- were possible in this country, -- whether in a word the salon could be introduced here. A. writer in the last British Review has discussed the same question in regard to England, and answered in the negative, mainly on the ground, natural for an Englishman, that the English people are above such trifling. Prof. CHARLIER took a very different view of the subject, and found the only obstacles to the salon here in the incessant occupation of Americans, in the lack of a class of cultivated, scholarly, rich people, who have plenty of leisure, and in the fact that those who are not rich already, are resolutely and laboriously seeking to become so. He found plenty of social gatherings here -- but the people at them are either stiff and pre-occupied with their own thoughts, or else they break up into knots, and talk about business, politics, or other topics uppermost in their thoughts. Conversation seldom becomes general -- turning upon themes in which all are interested, and enlisting the participation, as well as the attention, of the whole company. Still he had found circles in New-York society where this was not the case -- and he was inclined to think, therefore, that the salon, in the French sense of the word, might and would be successfully introduced into America.
headline: {'main': "Prof. Charlier's French Lectures.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Prof. Charlier's French Lectures.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Brussels Nord publishes the chief portions of the reply of the Papal Government to the dispatch of M. DE THOUVENEL respecting the Romagna. The document (says the Nord) is too long to give in extenso, but we extract those passages which make known the resolutions of the Court of Rome and its secret hopes. Cardinal ANTONELLI commences by denying the motives attributed as the cause of the rising in the Romagna. What proves, he says, that the Romagnoles were not dissatisfied is that the other provinces of the Church did not revolt. Piedmont is at the bottom of it all. The Cardinal dwells at great length on this point. He also endeavors to throw blame on France for the campaign in Lombardy, but prudence gets the better of his resentment, and, suddenly coming to the real point in question, he declares that it ought to be well understood that if the Pope rejects the counsels of his protector, it is because he is compelled to do so by a higher principle, and that, moreover, that is not the exact point to be considered, but the promises of assistance given last year, in the month of March, by the Ambassadors of France and Austria.
lead_paragraph: The Brussels Nord publishes the chief portions of the reply of the Papal Government to the dispatch of M. DE THOUVENEL respecting the Romagna. The document (says the Nord) is too long to give in extenso, but we extract those passages which make known the resolutions of the Court of Rome and its secret hopes. Cardinal ANTONELLI commences by denying the motives attributed as the cause of the rising in the Romagna. What proves, he says, that the Romagnoles were not dissatisfied is that the other provinces of the Church did not revolt. Piedmont is at the bottom of it all. The Cardinal dwells at great length on this point. He also endeavors to throw blame on France for the campaign in Lombardy, but prudence gets the better of his resentment, and, suddenly coming to the real point in question, he declares that it ought to be well understood that if the Pope rejects the counsels of his protector, it is because he is compelled to do so by a higher principle, and that, moreover, that is not the exact point to be considered, but the promises of assistance given last year, in the month of March, by the Ambassadors of France and Austria.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN is so terribly hurt by the pro- posal to institute an inquiry into the general administration of the Government by means of a Committee of the House of Representatives, that he has indited the lamentable epistle which we published yesterday. All who have read that remarkable production will feel that this is the strongest language we could possibly use with regard to it.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN is so terribly hurt by the pro- posal to institute an inquiry into the general administration of the Government by means of a Committee of the House of Representatives, that he has indited the lamentable epistle which we published yesterday. All who have read that remarkable production will feel that this is the strongest language we could possibly use with regard to it. To publish the letter and accuse the President of writing it, is, we admit, a severe course to pursue, but upon "an old public functionary," milder measures would in all probability be thrown away.

abstract: After all the world does move, not perhaps quite so fast as enthusiastic optimists are apt to wish and to imagine; but positively and perpetually. No better illustration of its progress could be asked than is afforded by the contrast between certain words used by an English bishop in opposing the Commercial Treaty of 1786 with France, and the language of the French Emperor in announcing the Anglo-French Commercial Treaty of 1860 to the Corps Legislatif.
lead_paragraph: After all the world does move, not perhaps quite so fast as enthusiastic optimists are apt to wish and to imagine; but positively and perpetually. abstract: As far as depends on the vote of the population the fate of Central Italy is now decided. The result of the elections in all four provinces of Tuscany, Parma, Modena, and the Romagna, is now sufficiently known: By enormous majorities, by a vote almost amounting to unanimity, the people have decided for annexation to the Sardinian Kingdom, and have utterly rejected both the claims of their legitimate Sovereigns and the scheme which has been lately put forward by the Emperor of the French. So important a political act has not been performed since the Autumn of 1852, when the French nation, by a vote almost as decisive, overthrew the Republic, which had been founded less than five years before, and established the Imperial Monarchy which now rules their country. The present appeal to universal suffrage will, however, have the sympathies of Englishmen more than any former display of the kind. It can not be doubted that the act of the population is sincere. A nation which has suffered more than any other in Europe, the whole of whose modern history has been a long record of oppression, -- a nation which has not only never known public liberty and national independence, but whose private life has been embittered and degraded by all that the petty tyranny of Courts and the bad activity of a police can perpetrate, has at length been able to pronounce in favor of union and constitutional government. No one -- not even Lord NORMANBY, not even the organs of the Viennese Government -- will venture to say that this extraordinary vote does not express the real feeling of the Italian people. There is no question of force or fraud, of terrorized peasants and cheating ballot-boxes. The Pope, the Austrian Press, the Ultra-montane Clergy, and their few sympathizers in this country, will be able to say that the Italian people are mad, possessed, led away by the teachings of atheists and revolutionaries; but they will be obliged to confess that, right or wrong, whole mass of them utterly reject the Government under which they have hitherto lived, and desire to link their fate to that of the monarch against which Austria would willingly let slip the dogs of war, and at whose head the Pope is ready to hurl an excommunication. Where all are so completely in favor of annexation, it is impossible to say that any one province exceeds the other in enthusiasm. But, undoubtedly, the vote in Tuscany and in the Romagna has a greater importance than in the two minor provinces. The French Government had already assented to the union of Parma and Modena with VICTOR EMANUEL's kingdom, and consequently the voting there may be taken as merely formal. The addition of these small States to Piedmont seems to excite no jealousy on the part of the Power which desires the Alps as a protection against a too powerful Italy. Austria has made up her mind not to interfere, the population is known to be friendly to Piedmont, they have no traditions of provincial rivalry to keep them apart, and their addition to King VICTOR EMANUEL's domains may be taken as a matter of course. But we own that we have been much relieved by the approach to unanimity in Tuscany and the Romagna, for the destiny of these provinces still hangs in the balance. The French Emperor cannot be considered to have given up his plan of an independent kingdom in Tuscany and of a Piedmontese regency in the Papal province. If any considerable number of voters had pronounced in favor of these views the destinies of the two provinces might be very doubtful. A party favorable to Papal suzerainty and to a new Duchy of Tuscany would, when disclosed by the ballot-box, have given encouragement to all the enemies of Italian unity. The apparatus for working on continental populations has been carried to such perfection in certain quarters that we may be sure that a fourth, or even a fifth, of the Tuscans or Romagnoli, if supported by France or Austria, would have the power to counteract the wishes of the great majority. But happily, and we should think somewhat to the surprise of the French Government, the propositions emanating from Paris have found hardly a partisan in the two provinces. By the telegrams which we publish it will be seen that in Tuscany not one elector in 25 voted for the separate kingdom. The list is made up, with the exception of 108 communes, and stands thus: For annexation to Piedmont, 259,000; for the separate kingdom, 10,729. Now, we do think that this is a most remarkable and important result. Nothing can show the fixed resolution of the Italian people more than the Tuscan vote. The Duchy and its celebrated metropolis have a long and glorious history. Every Florentine has been accustomed to consider his city as a capital, as rivaling Rome in the presidency of Italian cities, as the pure fount of Italian literature, and the classic home of art. Nor has the Florentine jealousy of other cities wholly died out. Many very practical politicians have been in favor of preserving the present Italian sovereignties, and being content with uniting them in something like a federation, and this solely on the ground that neither Milan, Florence, nor Turin would ever recognize the claims of any city but itself to be the capital of the monarchy. This sentiment has been appealed to and encouraged by the manifesto of the French Emperor. Florence has been told that the greatest potentate of the Continent thinks she should still remain a capital city, and that the banks of the Arno should still be honored with the residence of a Court and the throng of visitors from all parts of the world. To give up, or, at least, to stand the chance of giving up all this, and at the same time to offend the master of half a million of men, has been the choice of the Tuscans. They have voted unconditional annexation to Piedmont, and the small minority which has listened to the counsels of M. THOUVENEL only serves to show the preponderance of the opposite opinion. Florence is content to take its rank with the other cities of VICTOR EMANUEL's kingdom in order that the darling object of Italian unity may be attained.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. An injunction, issued by Judge CULVER, of the City Court, at the instance of ALFRED CLOCK, was served, restraining the Board from using the money appropriated in secret session last Monday night, to be used by the Special Committee for ferry purposes. Alderman DAYTON stated that Judge CULVER, upon reading the resolution passed in the secret session, promptly issued an order to have the case heard to-day at 12 o'clock, when no doubt the order would be vacated. Considerable routine business was transacted, when Alderman DAYTON, who has just returned from Albany, presented the copy of a secret circular, which the Union Ferry Company had caused to be circulated at Albany, signed by the President and Secretary of the Company, in which they attempt to show that no person can afford to run the ferries at one cent fare for foot passengers. He said that was not the only means used to defeat the one cent ferriage bill. Members of the Legislature had been bought by the opposition, and they openly boasted of it, and at a proper time the men should be named. The same men in 1851 agreed to pay the New-York Aldermen $25,000 to get possession of the ferries, and $20,00 was actually paid, and this he could prove. The Committee had been approached by these men. He himself had been offered $10,000 by a member of the Company if he would let the Ferry matter drop, and he was offered $5,000 to let them slip in and sell the ferry leases on the 31st of January. He pledged the Committee would render a strict account of every dollar used by the Committee, and if the Board presented a united front the cheap ferriage would become a law. The Board adjourned to Monday evening.

abstract: The star of MIRAMON, the Mexican military chieftain, and the cherished son of the Pagan Church of Mexico, has set, and with it the red hand of a bigoted and bloody despotism has disappeared in that afflicted Republic, it is to be hoped forever. The expedition against Vera Cruz has proved a total failure, and the leader, with his shattered forces, is reported to have taken up his line of march towards the City of Mexico. The conspiracy in the city of Vera Cruz having been discovered and defeated, the Marin expedition, with supplies from Cuba, having been captured by United States forces; the City of Mexico surrounded by victorious liberals from the interior, and CARVAJAL, with his legions, being in the way to intercept the defeated and discouraged army of MIRAMON, it is scarcely to be expected that this General, without prestige or resource, will ever again be able to make head against the opposing current of events which has now so completely overwhelmed him. He will probably make good his stand at Jalapa or some point in the interior, until his arrangements to leave the country are consummated.

abstract: The Petersburg (Va.) Express, March 27, has the following:  "We learn from a friend residing in Burkeville, Nottoway County, that a most shocking and brutal murder was perpetrated within three-quarters of a mile of that place, on yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, the victim being HIRAM FOWLKES, Esq., and his murderers his own servants.
lead_paragraph: The Petersburg (Va.) Express, March 27, has the following: "We learn from a friend residing in Burkeville, Nottoway County, that a most shocking and brutal murder was perpetrated within three-quarters of a mile of that place, on yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, the victim being HIRAM FOWLKES, Esq., and his murderers his own servants. The deed was found out about 6 1/2 o'clock -- some five hours and a half after its commission -- traces of blood being discovered by the members of the family, and traced up until the mutilated body of Mr. FOWLKES was found about half a mile from the house, on the side of the Southside Railroad, covered with sand. The traces were also found to lead from one of the kitchens occupied by a portion of the servants of the deceased, and blood was found upon some of their clothing. The negroes were also seen at an early hour covering up the blood, as it since proves, along the road, which, had fallen as they conveyed the body away; and the horse which he generally rides was found tied to a limb near to where he lay, and had, apparently, trampled on his face. The authorities of the County, as soon as aware of the crime, commenced prompt measures towards the investigation of the affair, and fixed 11 o'clock for the time of the holding of the inquest. Previous to the leaving of the mail train for this city, our informant learned that the negroes were in custody, and had confessed the crime. It appears, also, that at about 1 o'clock, near which hour the murder occurred, the deceased, hearing a noise in the kitchen, left the house, and went to the kitchen to ascertain the cause of it. He did not return again. It is supposed that they then and there seized and dispatched him before he could recover from among them. Mr. FOWLKES was a highly-respectable gentleman, and was well known in this city as well as in the County in which he lived. He leaves several children."

abstract: We are, in this Chinese difficulty, in the multitude of counsellors, destitute of counsel. Mr. BRIGHT makes his stereotyped declaration that the Chinese are angels and the English are miscreants, and, with a pompous and rather pharisaical protest, washes his hands of the whole business. Lord JOHN RUSSELL and Mr. SIDNEY HERBERT say their official speeches, but for anything like practical information we are driven back upon our naval and military men, who tell us, of course, as Sir J. ELPHINSTONE in effect did last night, to trust it all to them, and let neither statesman or diplomatist meddle with it. We are warned by no means to go to Peking. All sorts of horrors are predicted from a march over a hundred miles of level, hedgeless country. The Chinese Court is depicted as so ancient and magnificent in its power and grandeur that we ought not to do anything to provoke it. Again, it is said to be so rickety, so insolvent, so powerless to protect its own subjects, or to gather its own taxes, that we ought to abstain from touching it, lest it crumble under our fingers. We are bid at the same time to tremble before a mighty monarchy, and to stand aside, lest we are covered by the dust of a falling ruin. If either of these were true, we might ask, "Why should we spare this strong Government?" or "Why should we fear this tottering pageant?" But, in fact, none of those who thus talk know anything about it. Whether Pekin is rich or poor, strong or weak, many will guess, but with our present opportunities none can know. In the Palace of Westminster, those who decide upon these questions most dogmatically know least, and if we would put their crotchets aside, and be guided by the rules of common sense -- if we would deal with the Chinese as with other mortals, believing that they are capable of being moved by hope and by fear, by kindness and by severity, as they may merit the one or deserve the other, we should probably save a large part of these threatened ten millions. There is a shortsightedness about our policy towards this empire which would cease if they of our statesmen who direct it would study it, or if the House of Commons would insist that they only who have studied the subject should direct the policy. It is a notorious fact that throughout our public offices the only men who have any ripe and useful knowledge of this matter are Lord PALMERSTON and one gentleman in the Foreign-office. The one knows it as a statesman, the other as a man of detail. The others only have their hands full of crotchets, which they shake together like bits of glass in a kaleidoscope. It is not their fault that it is so, but it is their fault that they will, by meddling, do harm in so great a matter. Some day it will come to this, that the country, in its weariness and disgust, will flatly refuse to send any more forces into those seas, happen what may. Nor is it certain that this will be in the end an unwise course in a national point of view. Russia, which stands at so many sick men's beds, has already made the will of the great Tartar Empire. It is her mission, and it is her present work, to absorb all the rich northern provinces. We English have no notion, nor need we care, how quickly this is proceeding. But every treaty right we now secure from the Emperor of China, will be of infinite value to us in no long time to come, when we shall have to claim its exercise under a strong Government, recognizing the laws and compelling the observance of the rights of civilized nations.

But, in fact, none of those who thus talk know anything about it. Whether Pekin is rich or poor, strong or weak, many will guess, but with our present opportunities none can know. In the Palace of Westminster, those who decide upon these questions most dogmatically know least, and if we would put their crotchets aside, and be guided by the rules of common sense -- if we would deal with the Chinese as with other mortals, believing that they are capable of being moved by hope and by fear, by kindness and by severity, as they may merit the one or deserve the other, we should probably save a large part of these threatened ten millions. There is a shortsightedness about our policy towards this empire which would cease if they of our statesmen who direct it would study it, or if the House of Commons would insist that they only who have studied the subject should direct the policy. It is a notorious fact that throughout our public offices the only men who have any ripe and useful knowledge of this matter are Lord PALMERSTON and one gentleman in the Foreign-office. The one knows it as a statesman, the other as a man of detail. The others only have their hands full of crotchets, which they shake together like bits of glass in a kaleidoscope. It is not their fault that it is so, but it is their fault that they will, by meddling, do harm in so great a matter. Some day it will come to this, that the country, in its weariness and disgust, will flatly refuse to send any more forces into those seas, happen what may. Nor is it certain that this will be in the end an unwise course in a national point of view. Russia, which stands at so many sick men's beds, has already made the will of the great Tartar Empire. It is her mission, and it is her present work, to absorb all the rich northern provinces. We English have no notion, nor need we care, how quickly this is proceeding. But every treaty right we now secure from the Emperor of China, will be of infinite value to us in no long time to come, when we shall have to claim its exercise under a strong Government, recognizing the laws and compelling the observance of the rights of civilized nations.

abstract: On Monday evening Mr. DUNCOMBE asked the Government a question relating to the kingdom of the Two Sicilies that is at the present moment equally grave and seasonable. He inquired whether, since the accession of FRANCIS II. to the throne, "any correspondence had passed between the Government and its representative at Naples relative to the constitution of reforms recommended by England and France in 1856?" Lord JOHN RUSSELL replied that there had been a great deal of correspondence on this subject, which he hoped to lay on the table in a few days. The production or the correspondence will probably have the effect of directing the attention of Parliament to the state of that unhappy country, as well as to the real designs of the Neapolitan Government; and in the present critical state of the southern portion of the Peninsula, this cannot happen too soon.

abstract: Dr. E.Y. ROBBINS delivered a lecture last week at Clinton Hall, before an appreciative audience, on the operations of air, light and costume upon the health of the female sex. He advocated the improvement of woman's health as a certain means of improving the race. He found a great deal of fault with the costume of the ladies.
lead_paragraph: Dr. E.Y. ROBBINS delivered a lecture last week at Clinton Hall, before an appreciative audience, on the operations of air, light and costume upon the health of the female sex. He advocated the improvement of woman's health as a certain means of improving the race. He found a great deal of fault with the costume of the ladies. He especially condemned the use of corsets, commenced as it was in the present age with infantile years, and quoted a celebrated English author to show that even a man, who, when not dressed could inhale 180 cubic inches of air in a given time, could, when dressed, inhale only 130 inches. And of course a greater proportionate difference was observable in women, by reason of their mode of dress. He contrasted the ravages of cholera with those of consumption, brought on by inattention to the laws of nature which he now sought to inculcate, and strengthened his argument by the statement that during the cholera season of 1849 there died in this City from that disease 31,506, while in the same year there died from consumption no less than 33,516. To show how much more than men women were, from there habits and mode of dress, liable to this disease, he asserted that in the same year (1849) 5,640 men died of consumption, while no less than 10,195 females were its victims. Of all the women who have died in the northeastern section of our country, more than one-half died of consumption, and those between the ages of fifteen and twenty years. The lecturer was particularly severe upon the subject of tight-lacing so especially prevalent among American ladies. He deprecated the practice of depriving girls of the air and exercise so necessary to health, which boys are permitted to partake of; and he was at a loss to know why such a difference should be made in the condition and habits of the sexes. Speaking of the higher classes, with special reference to our own City, he asserted that three-quarters of the young ladies of the upper and wealthier classes had some personal deformity, caused by this inattention to the most rational laws of health, or by an over-anxiety to reduce the circumference of the waist. The truth of his assertions was proved by a reference to the ancient Greeks, who, even now, after the lapse of centuries, were the models of form received by painters and sculptors; and he instanced also the Circassians and Georgians, who had never yet learned the mystery of corsets. Light, the lecturer contended, which was so much denied to women on account of their constant in-door confinement, was of the utmost importance in the development of health and strength. A plant or shrub grown in the shade never displayed the same amount of color or strength as those which enjoy the light of the Sun, and he claimed that if the ladies of this country would preserve health and retain their beauty, they must use more of air and sunlight. In England a woman was in the prime of her attractions at the age of 35, and gradually but beautifully faded away, while in this country at 25 a woman had reached her prime, and at 35 had begun to fade. He dwelt upon the responsibility of a mother. She must either be the giver of health, vitality, and strength or else the dispenser of disease and degeneration, and a knowledge of this fact should inculcate in woman a sense of her responsibility.

abstract: By the Arabia, at this port yesterday, we hear of the death of M. JULLIEN, the eminent chef d'orchestre. The information is conveyed to us in a brief paragraph from the English papers, and bears no evidence of authenticity beyond what it obtains as an item in the London Times. Glad as we should be to hear that, like other rumors of a similar character concerning M. JULLIEN, this, too, is but a device of a sensation penny-a-liner, we fear it may turn out to be sadly true. Not long since M. JULLIEN attempted suicide as an easy riddance of troubles which beset him, and it is not therefore remarkable to hear that a mind so disturbed has at last found repose in death. In a lunatic asylum seems to have ended the career of one of the most popular musicians of the present day. He died, says the report, on the 16th of the present month in a charitable institution of Paris.

abstract: Jacob Wichelhausen vs. James C. Willett, Sheriff. This case has been several times mentioned in our columns. It is an action against the defendant, as Sheriff, for an escape under the following circumstances: The plaintiff recovered a judgment against one John D. Williamson, and issued execution against his person to the present defendant. The defendant arrested Williamson and held him in custody in the jail limits, on the usual bond.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Wichelhausen vs. James C. Willett, Sheriff. This case has been several times mentioned in our columns. It is an action against the defendant, as Sheriff, for an escape under the following circumstances: The plaintiff recovered a judgment against one John D. Williamson, and issued execution against his person to the present defendant. The defendant arrested Williamson and held him in custody in the jail limits, on the usual bond. While he was thus in custody the House of Representatives at Washington issued a subpoena, requiring Williamson to appear and testify before an Investigating Committee. As he did not appear, the House adjudged him guilty of a contempt, and issued a warrant to the Sergeant-at-Arms for his arrest. That officer came on to New-York, arrested Williamson, and took him to Washington, to appear before the House. As soon, however, as he was released, Williamson returned to the jail liberties.

abstract: Among other Papal demonstrations in this country, Archbishop PURCELL, of Cincinnati, called his flock together on the receipt of the Pope's lamentable plea for his patrimony, and assured them that they ought to resolve Pro NONO back into his revolted Legations. The flock, more obedient than congregations of the sort which we habitually associate with the commercial metropolis of Ohio, ran together at the summons of their ecclesiastical reeve, and proceeded to do as they were commanded. They passed the usual resolutions of love and fidelity to the Head of their Church, for which, indeed, no fault can be found with them; the usual resolutions, also, of hatred and contempt for the wicked and rebellious Emperor of the French, whereupon nothing need be remarked save that which the big bargee said in behalf of his little wife when the police wished to arrest her for beating her husband: "O, let her alone -- I don't mind it; it amuses her, and it don't hurt me!"

abstract: The fact that two fine steamships (belonging to the same Company) have been lost within a few months at no great distance from each other, leads us to offer a few remarks on these deplorable shipwrecks, with the view of attracting attention to the advisability of laying down a set of courses for ships to traverse, both on the outward and homeward voyage. This is become the more necessary, since the steamers to and from New-York, Boston, Portland, and Halifax, touch at Cape Race to receive or communicate telegraphic messages. This emulation to bring or carry the latest news has led to what may be denominated a coasting trade from New-York to Cape Race of about 1,200 miles. When the New-York steamers struck straight away to the northeast on leaving the United States, or gave the coast a wide berth on their passage out, we never heard of these stranding on reefs or rocks. Steamers left our shores, and did not reach the New World; but the cause of their foundering in mid-ocean is a sealed book, which has not yet been unfolded to us. The Indian was lost on the Seal Ledge, near Cape Canseau, at the eastern extremity of Nova Scotia, and the Court acquitted the Master of all blame. Captain SMITH produced his chare to prove that the lighthouse on Whitehead Point was not marked there. Other beacons, erected within a few years, may cast their warning light to sea, whose whereabouts may not be laid down in any charts. Here, in England, lights, buoys and beacons are changed, or set up, without masters of ships being apprised thereof. The Scotch and Irish Boards advertise these alterations, and do their utmost to avert danger; but, beyond printing a few slips, and sending them round to the Custom-houses, our London Trinty Board do nothing to lessen the perils and dangers of the sea by timely warnings. It is left to survivors of wrecks to expose the shortcomings of the authorities. This is not as it should be. A tabulated yearly statement of every Beacon in and around the coast, with its bearings, should be published and advertised by the officials, and all changes as they occur should be at once made known in the Shipping and Mercantile Gazette. As doubts are even now expressed whether the charts of the British North American coasts are accurate, we would suggest their correction by a detailed letterpress report, such as we have here indicated. It is the duty of the Montreal Ocean Steamship Company to insist upon this perfect rec[???]fication.

abstract: The great question of the Court dress of American Ministers is about to be brought up again, by the presentation to Congress by the President of all correspondence in the possession of the Government touching this weighty matter, from the treaty of Ghent to the present time. It is produced in obedience to a call of the Senate, and will probably furnish materials for a debate to that not very much overtasked body.

abstract: The watch-word with which Italy undertook in 1848 to expel the foreign rulers, whose sway had paralyzed her energies and her progress throughout a whole generation, proves now to have been but a prophetic symbol of the great work which she is accomplishing to-day.
lead_paragraph: The watch-word with which Italy undertook in 1848 to expel the foreign rulers, whose sway had paralyzed her energies and her progress throughout a whole generation, proves now to have been but a prophetic symbol of the great work which she is accomplishing to-day. "L'Italia fara di se" -- "Italy will settle her own affairs" sounded like an empty boast in the ears of the incredulous world, when Austria, after a twelvemonth of desperate revolutionary warfare, found herself once more mistress from the Alps to the Adriatic. The heroic defence of Venice and of Rome; the splendid revolt of Milan; the victorious battles of Goito and Somma Campagna; the Spartan courage of the volunteers at Curtatone, had all by turns challenged the admiration and moved the sympathy of mankind; -- but all seemed at last to have been but the pathetic pageants of a glorious play, when the curtain fell upon Novara, and Sardinia alone was left, shattered, panting, but unsubdued, to attest the existence of a truly Italian nationality. That hackneyed old injustice of history, the doctrine that they alone are capable of freedom who can win it for themselves, came easily to the lips of happier nations, and the defeat of the Italian arms was acquiesced in by the selfishness of stronger and freer States, as a melancholy but irrefragable proof of the incapacity of the Italian character. Englishmen forgot Dutch WILLIAM and the strong hand which struck away the falling throne of Stuart bigotry and Continental despotism, before the Grand Monarque had time to stay its ruin. Americans forgot the gold of Spain and Holland, the armaments of France, which our fathers hailed in their extremist need as the visible interposition of Providence. Germans forgot the Lion of the North, with his blue and yellow battalions, his prayer-books and his pikes, beating back the imperialism of WALLENSTEIN and TILLY, and rescuing the liberties with the Protestantism of their Teutonic ancestors.

abstract: Rev. Dr. CURRY writes to the Independent on the "Past, Present and Future of the Methodist Church." He argues that although the Methodist Church is Episcopal in form and name, it is purely Presbyterian in character. Dr. CURRY says: "The fountain head of its episcopacy is in the Presbytery, and its highest functionary is a presbyter-bishop, receiving his office and jurisdiction at the hands of his fellow-presbyters, who may at will reclaim the power given to him, or modify or wholly abrogate the office itself. This element of Methodism pervades the whole system; and probably there is in this country no other body so simply Presbyterian in its organization and government as the Methodist Episcopal Church. Everywhere in its authoritative action the power of the Presbytery is recognized, on the one hand standing over the Episcopacy, of which it makes a convenience; and on the other, acting independently of the laity whom it serves, but declines to be subject to."

abstract: Mr. Chas. E. Turnbull, of Biddeford, Me., while waiting at Pier No. 2 to take the steamboat for home, was accosted by two genteel fellows, one of whom represented himself as the captain of the boat on which Turnbull was about to embark. They went on board together, and soon after one of the rogues presented the "Captain" with a bill, and asked him if it was convenient for him to cash it. The "Captain" said "Yes." but, on looking at his wallet, discovered that he had nothing less than a $100 [???]ill on the "City Trust and Banking Company." Turning to Mr. Turnbull he asked him if he could change it. The unsuspecting countryman gave him the amount, and took the $100 bill. Soon after, his new friends asked Mr. Turnbull to take a walk with them up Broadway, as they had some time to spare before the boat started. He consented, and they proceeded to the vicinity of the Exchange in Wall-street, where they requested him to wait outside a few minutes, while they went in to transact some business. They of course, did not return, and Mr. Turnbull soon found that his $100 bill was worthless. He gave information to the police before he left town, and yesterday a man named Ring alias Simmons, a well-known confidence operator, supposed to be one of the confederates in the swindle, was arrested by Detective Elder, and locked up. Mr. Turnbull has been telegraphed to come on and identify him.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Chas. E. Soon after, his new friends asked Mr. Turnbull to take a walk with them up Broadway, as they had some time to spare before the boat started. He gave information to the police before he left town, and yesterday a man named Ring alias Simmons, a well-known confidence operator, supposed to be one of the confederates in the swindle, was arrested by Detective Elder, and locked up. Mr. Turnbull has been telegraphed to come on and identify him.

abstract: By the arrival of the Arabia at this port we are in receipt of two days' later intelligence from Europe. The Commercial Treaty with France still occupied the attention of the British Parliament. On the 15th, it was debated at length, Earls GREY, MALMERSBURY and DERBY speaking in opposition to it, and denouncing it as a concession to conciliate the Manchester party. On a division there were 68 votes in favor of the address to the Crown in approbation of it, and 38 against it. The fortification, by the Emperor, of the Island of St. Pierre, near Newfoundland, formed the theme for an animated discussion -- Lord JOHN RUSSELL claiming that the French had not violated the stipulations of the treaty. The Sardinian Government is said to have consented to the demand of France for the cession of Savoy and Nice by a special treaty between France and Piedmont -- the treaty to be followed by the vote of the municipalities of the ceded territory. The total result of the voting in Tuscany on the question of annexation to Piedmont, was as follows: Total number inscribed, 386,446; for annexation, 366,571; for a separate kingdom, 14,925; canceled, 4,949. In the AEmilian Provinces, the numbers in favor of annexation to Piedmont are as follows: The Romagna, 202,659; Modena, 115,621; Parma, 88,511. The number of votes for a separate kingdom had not been yet announced in the Provinces.

abstract: The Yellow Springs Agricultural Works in Yellow Springs, Ohio, owned and occupied by Dane, Ewing & Co., were totally destroyed by fire March 20. The building was a substantial brick, and three stories in height, formed of two wings, each having a front of one hundred feet. The building had been erected but a few years, and was valued at $20,000; the machinery at $25,000, and the stock at $23,000. The insurance is $42,000, chiefly in the following New-York companies: North American, Commonwealth, Niagara, Security and Home.

abstract: In consequence of some dissatisfaction at the management of the Medical Department of Bowdoin College, Edward R. Peaslee, Professor of Surgery, and Charles A. Lee, Professor of Materia Medica, have resigned their Professorships, and it is stated, upon good authority, that Prof. William Sweeter will resign his office at the expiration of the present term. An effort is to be made, as matters now stand, to remove the school to Portland, which may be successful.

An effort is to be made, as matters now stand, to remove the school to Portland, which may be successful.

abstract: Early yesterday morning Sheriff KELLY received a telegram from Albany informing him of the positive refusal of Gov. MORGAN to interfere with the execution of the sentence of the law upon JOHN CRUMMINS, who murdered DENNIS MCHENRY in the month of October last, under circumstances that were generally believed not to have been devoid of mitigating features, with the details of which our readers are familiar, and which, until the last moment, it had been hoped, would have secured for the unfortunate man the clemency of the Executive. The intelligence was immediately communicated to CRUMMINS, who, although he had cherished a hope that the Governor would relent, received the decision with composure, and acknowledged his readiness to die. In anticipation of the result, all the necessary preparations for the execution had been made, and between 9 and 10 o'clock he was hanged.

abstract: A Madrid telegram states that on the 12th March a Moorish messenger delivered a letter to Marshal O'DONNELL from the Emperor of Morocco, professing his desire for peace, and requesting the Marshal to facilitate an arrangement advantageous to both nations. O'DONNELL consented to negotiate, but declared he would not suspend military operations.
lead_paragraph: A Madrid telegram states that on the 12th March a Moorish messenger delivered a letter to Marshal O'DONNELL from the Emperor of Morocco, professing his desire for peace, and requesting the Marshal to facilitate an arrangement advantageous to both nations. abstract: Dr. HIRAM COX, of Cincinnati, Inspector of liquors for Hamilton County, Ohio, lectured on Wednesday evening at Cooper Institute on the adulteration of liquors. Mr. WM. E. DODGE introduced the lecturer to his audience, which was discouragingly small. After giving a brief explanation of the modus operandi of analyzing liquors, Dr. Cox analyzed a few samples which had been handed in for that purpose. Pouring out some Otard brandy in a glass, he mixed with it a little chloride of barium, and in a few moments announced that it contained sulphuric acid and prussic acid. In Port wine, he found prussic acid and other substances not immediately distinguishable. He said however, that the specimen tested contained no alcohol whatever; whereas, if it were pure port, it should contain from 19 to 25 80 100 of alcohol. He next tried a bottle of pale Sherry, and found a large amount of sulphuric acid. All of the samples were labeled with the name of a prominent down-town liquor dealer, at whose store they were stated to have been purchased yesterday, without the seller knowing for what purpose they were to be used. A great many questions were put to the lecturer by individuals in the audience, some of which were impertinent, and evidently intended to annoy him. Of this class were the queries of one young gentleman who announced himself a liquor-dealer, and who was finally silenced by an aged gentleman, who arose in the audience and suggested to him that if he would allow the remainder of the audience to hear the Doctor through, he could then have an opportunity to take the stand and defend his trade at his leisure. Questions were asked about the Catawba wine, to which the lecturer replied that some of it was pure and some not -- generally not. He had analyzed samples of the Still Catawba, and found four per cent. of alcohol and a large amount of copper; and that the Sparkling Catawba was adulterated, he had been told by those who were engaged in its manufacture.
lead_paragraph: Dr. HIRAM COX, of Cincinnati, Inspector of liquors for Hamilton County, Ohio, lectured on Wednesday evening at Cooper Institute on the adulteration of liquors. Mr. WM. E. DODGE introduced the lecturer to his audience, which was discouragingly small. Pouring out some Otard brandy in a glass, he mixed with it a little chloride of barium, and in a few moments announced that it contained sulphuric acid and prussic acid. In Port wine, he found prussic acid and other substances not immediately distinguishable. He said however, that the specimen tested contained no alcohol whatever; whereas, if it were pure port, it should contain from 19 to 25 80 100 of alcohol. He next tried a bottle of pale Sherry, and found a large amount of sulphuric acid. All of the samples were labeled with the name of a prominent down-town liquor dealer, at whose store they were stated to have been purchased yesterday, without the seller knowing for what purpose they were to be used. A great many questions were put to the lecturer by individuals in the audience, some of which were impertinent, and evidently intended to annoy him. Of this class were the queries of one young gentleman who announced himself a liquor-dealer, and who was finally silenced by an aged gentleman, who arose in the audience and suggested to him that if he would allow the remainder of the audience to hear the Doctor through, he could then have an opportunity to take the stand and defend his trade at his leisure. Questions were asked about the Catawba wine, to which the lecturer replied that some of it was pure and some not -- generally not. He had analyzed samples of the Still Catawba, and found four per cent. of alcohol and a large amount of copper; and that the Sparkling Catawba was adulterated, he had been told by those who were engaged in its manufacture.

abstract: The execution of CRUMMINS yesterday will strengthen the growing disposition of the community to tolerate the abolition of capital pun- ishment. Almost everybody concedes that the deliberate murderer, one who kills in cold blood, from a distinct, well-defined motive, whether it be avarice or revenge, ought to be hung.
lead_paragraph: The execution of CRUMMINS yesterday will strengthen the growing disposition of the community to tolerate the abolition of capital pun- ishment. Almost everybody concedes that the deliberate murderer, one who kills in cold blood, from a distinct, well-defined motive, whether it be avarice or revenge, ought to be hung. But nobody believes that such a crime should be put upon a level with an act of homicide, perpetrated in the heat of momentary passion, under a degree of provocation which human nature, even in the best of us, is very weak to resist, surrounded by circumstances which palliate the offence, and followed by instant and sincere repentance on the part of the offender. If the law confounds these acts, the just instinct of the public heart does not, and if a false interpretation of the law, -- a reckless or over-rigid enforcement of its letter, leads to the disregard of this distinction, the public will demand a remedy -- even at the hazard of error on the other side.

abstract: THE RECIPROCITY TREATY.  Petitions from all parts of New-York are pouring in, praying that the Reciprocity Treaty with Canada may be amended or rescinded. Hostility to it is daily growing more bitter, so ruinous is it to the interests of Western New-York. Mr. HATCH'S report will not only be strongly condemnatory of the Treaty, but will urge that it be abrogated at the earliest possible day.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.
